content.articleContent:
Understanding Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)
Your aorta is your body’s main blood vessel that runs from your heart through the center of your chest and stomach (abdomen). It’s your body’s main supplier of blood, and a rupture to it can cause life-threatening bleeding.
This rupture commonly happens when the aorta’s thick wall is weakened or damaged. It forms a bulge or a balloon, called an aneurysm. Though an aneurysm can occur in any blood vessel, they occur most often in the abdominal (stomach) portion of the aorta. This is called an abdominal aortic aneurysm.
Call us today at 1-800-39-JOBST (56278) to schedule an appointment.
What are the symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm?
Though three out of four people show no symptoms, some people feel stomach or low back pain.
Who’s at risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm?
Men over the age of 60 have the highest occurrence.
Family history increases your risk.
Chances increase if you have high blood pressure.
Risk gets higher if you smoke.
Chances increase with age.
What are my options if I have an abdominal aortic aneurysm?
Your vascular surgeon will recommend specific tests and treatment based on the size of the aneurysm and how fast it’s growing. Treatment may include monitoring, surgical repair, or endovascular stent graft repair.

Allergy Testing and Treatment
Allergies are more than just a nuisance; in extreme cases, they can actually be life-threatening. Whether it's a specific food or an environmental factor, identifying the source of your allergies is an important step toward managing your symptoms and feeling your best. After thorough allergy testing, our experts can help you understand what's triggering your symptoms and develop a treatment plan designed to help prevent allergic reactions and reduce your discomfort.
View our Allergy and Immunology Specialists.
Other Conditions We Treat
Our allergy and immunology expertise encompasses a number of other conditions. Together, we can identify common sensitivities and help you get your symptoms under control.
Asthma
Whether you're living with ongoing asthma or your symptoms develop only when you get sick or encounter certain allergens, seeking treatment is recommended. We will create a treatment plan to provide short term relief and long-term control of your asthma symptoms.
Children's Asthma
Asthma is a common and growing condition among school-aged children. For a child suffering from asthma, every day brings new challenges and the fear that breathing could become difficult at any time.
Our goal is to help families overcome the limitations and debilitating symptoms associated with childhood asthma. With comprehensive treatment we provide, the frequency and severity of asthma symptoms may be reduced, allowing your child to a more active life.
Sinus Issues
Are you plagued by chronic sinus infections, sinus headaches, blockages or other unbearable sinus issues? Sinus conditions can be caused by many things, from allergies to anatomical factors. And the symptoms of sinus problems can include snoring, congestion, debilitating headaches and obstructed breathing, among others. Our providers can diagnose and treat sinus issues.
Skin Conditions
Contact Dermatitis
Contact dermatitis is a type of rash that causes your skin to get red, itch, and in some cases, feel like it’s burning. There are two main classifications for contact dermatitis - allergic and irritant. While the triggers for each are different, the reactions and treatment recommendations are very similar.
Most of the time, contact dermatitis can be treated at home, but in some cases you may need to see a specialist. After a few days, if the rash has not responded to treatment and is painful, you should contact our office to be seen.
Hives
Hives can be caused by a number of factors, from bug bites to food reactions to environmental triggers. And unfortunately, hives can be itchy and irritating, causing undue amounts of discomfort. We will analyze your condition and recommend solutions to alleviate the symptoms associated with hives outbreaks.
Ezcema
Eczema (also called atopic dermatitis) affects between 15 and 20 percent of school-age children and as many as 10 percent of adults. This chronic condition causes itchy, inflamed skin that is sometimes accompanied by asthma or allergy symptoms. Although some over-the-counter treatments can be helpful in treating and preventing eczema flare-ups, professional dermatologic care often offers the best results. Our skincare team can help you gain control of your eczema and experience increased confidence and improved quality of life.

Patient-centered Care That Enhances Quality of Life
Learning that a loved one has Alzheimer’s disease or dementia can turn your world upside-down. There are countless questions around care options and finding the right care for your loved one’s changing needs.
We understand the uncertainty that can come with this kind of diagnosis, which is why our neurologists work closely with families and caregivers to develop a treatment and care plan.
You’re not alone in this journey. Whether you have questions about providing in-home care or joining a support group, our specialists will be here for you every step of the way.
content.about:
Understanding Alzheimer’s Disease and Dementia
Recognizing the Symptoms
Dementia is a term that describes different diseases and symptoms related to brain functions, such as memory loss or problem-solving skills.
Alzheimer’s disease is a progressive type of dementia, which means the person’s memory gets worse over time. No one knows exactly what causes Alzheimer’s disease. Genes, lifestyle habits and overall health may all play a role.
Alzheimer’s disease symptoms develop differently in each person. Most people live for an average of eight years after symptoms appear, but some people can live as long as 20 years with the disease.
Alzheimer’s disease typically affects people over age 65. In rare cases, it appears in people under age 60. This condition is called early onset Alzheimer’s disease.
Common Alzheimer’s disease symptoms can include:
Decision making problems.
Difficulty with judgement.
Language difficulties.
Memory problems.
Personality changes.
Diagnosis
If it’s suspected you or a loved one may have Alzheimer’s disease, your doctor will start with a physical exam. During this exam, he or she will ask about your or your loved one’s medical history, medications and any family history of dementia or Alzheimer’s disease.
You or your loved one may also undergo several tests, including:
Imaging tests, such as an MRI or PET scan.
Lab testing, such as blood tests.
Mental status testing.
Neuropsychological tests.
Stages of Alzheimer’s Disease
There are four stages of Alzheimer’s disease, with three of the stages having symptoms. These stages help doctors and caregivers make decisions on how to care for someone with Alzheimer’s disease.
It’s important to remember that not every case of Alzheimer’s disease is the same. Each person moves through symptoms and stages differently.
Preclinical stage
This is the earliest stage of Alzheimer’s disease. During this stage, the brain is undergoing changes that will later lead to cognitive symptoms, such as memory loss. The preclinical stage can last for many years before symptoms appear.
Mild, early stage
Forgetfulness is the most common symptom in the early stage of Alzheimer’s disease, but it’s often misunderstood as a common sign of aging. A person at this stage can still live independently, but may have problems with:
Concentration.
Making plans.
Managing money.
Recalling recent events.
Remembering a name.
Remembering where a valuable object is stored.
Staying organized.
Moderate, middle stage
The middle stage of Alzheimer’s disease is usually the longest stage and can last for many years. At this stage, symptoms can include:
Becoming moody or withdrawn, or having personality changes, such as hallucinations, paranoia or delusions.
Feeling restless, agitated, anxious or tearful, especially in the late afternoon or at night.
Having trouble remembering events.
Having trouble remembering names of familiar people, such as a spouse or a child.
Losing track of time and place.
Needing help with daily activities, such as getting dressed or brushing teeth.
Problems learning new things.
Problems with reading, writing and working with numbers.
Sleep problems.
Trouble remembering one’s name, but not details about one’s life, such as address and phone number.
Trouble with planning complicated events, like a dinner.
Severe, late stage
Most people at this stage need around-the-clock caregiving. During this stage of the disease a person may:
Be more likely to get infections, especially pneumonia.
Be unaware of his or her surroundings.
Lose bowel and bladder control.
Lose the ability to walk, sit or eat.
Need help with activities all of the time.
Say some words or phrases but cannot have a conversation.
Stages of Dementia
There are seven stages of dementia used to describe a person’s progression through the disease that help doctors and caregivers make decisions about treatment.
Stage 1
When a person is in stage 1 dementia, they have no signs of cognitive decline and don’t show any problems with memory.
Stage 2
Although there often aren’t any signs evident during the doctor interview, people in the second stage of dementia may complain about forgetfulness and very mild cognitive decline. Many people with stage 2 dementia are still able to complete tasks and function socially.
Stage 3
A person at this stage has started to show early signs of confusion and family members may start to notice symptoms, including:
Memory loss during doctor testing.
Some denial about their condition.
Trouble remembering names of new people.
Stage 4
At this stage, a person will continue to show early signs of confusion and problems with cognitive function will become more noticeable. However, most people at this stage are still aware of time and location. Symptoms can include:
Being unaware of current and recent events.
Problems concentrating.
Trouble remembering events from his or her personal history.
Using denial as a main defense mechanism when asked about symptoms or problems.
Stage 5
This stage indicates early dementia. While those with stage 5 dementia may be able to eat and use the bathroom on their own, they start to show signs of moderate to severe cognitive problems, including:
Being unable to recall major events in his or her life.
Feeling disoriented in time or place.
Feeling tearful.
Having trouble sleeping.
Needing help with choosing what to wear.
Occasionally dressing improperly.
Resisting the need for caregiving.
Wandering around and looking for a way out of the room or building.
Stage 6
At this stage, a person shows severe cognitive problems and isn’t able to live independently. He or she may:
Be unable to recall most recent events.
Have problems bathing.
Have sleeping problems.
Not be able to complete two-step commands.
Only eat with assistance.
Remove or not wear clothing properly.
Repeat conversations.
Show great resistance to caregiving.
Wander on purpose.
Stage 7
In the final and most severe stage of dementia, people aren’t able to easily communicate or function on their own, and may:
Not be able to complete simple tasks.
Not be able to eat on his or her own.
Not be able to hold his or her head up.
Not be able to sit up or walk independently.
Not smile.
Speak very little; sometimes as little as one word a day.
content.treatment:
Treatment
While there is no cure for Alzheimer’s disease or dementia, there are medicines and therapies that can help slow and manage symptoms. However, many people eventually require in-home caregiving, memory care or assisted living to stay safe and healthy.
If a residential center is the answer, our calm, secured environments provide regular routines that help engage our residents, promote their independence and individuality and improve quality of life.
With ProMedica by your side, you can rest easy knowing that your loved one is in safe and compassionate hands. Our residential memory care centers include assistance with daily living needs in a comfortable, home-like setting. Our services include:
24-hour supervision by staff specially trained in Alzheimer’s and dementia care, including hourly safety checks.
A community room with daily engaging social and fitness activities.
Daily medication management and administration.
Programming tailored for various forms of dementia, including individual pursuits, Engagement Therapy Treatment and Lifestyle programming.
Personal Care Services, such as bathing, dressing, laundry and housekeeping services.
Three meals made fresh daily, with special preparation and presentation to meet the needs of our residents.
Assistance in arranging medical care.
Learn more about our memory care communities

content.articleContent:
About Angiography
Angiography is an x-ray study of the arteries. This procedure involves injecting a contrast material (x-ray dye) into a blood vessel to make it visible on an x-ray. The dye is placed directly in the artery through a very small flexible tube called a catheter, which is inserted in to the artery through a small nick in the skin.
The procedure is often used to detect abnormalities of the blood vessels, such as narrowing and blockage caused by fatty deposits or blood clots, and aneurysms (defined as weakening or ballooning of the wall of the artery). Angiography can also detect abnormal patterns of blood vessels caused by tumors and can show sites of internal bleeding. Demonstrating these blood vessel abnormalities can help the physician determine the extent of the disease and determine the best treatment option.

Manage Your Anticoagulant Medications
ProMedica’s Jobst Medication Therapy Management (Jobst MTM) through Jobst Vascular Institute offers many clinical services including an anticoagulation service. Our anticoagulation service helps people who take an anticoagulant (blood thinner to prevent blood clots) safely and effectively manage their medication. It has been shown that patients who are monitored by an anticoagulation service receive the most effective treatment to reduce their risk of new blood clots or bleeding.
Warfarin is dosed based on your international normalized ratio (INR) which is the number of seconds it takes for your blood to clot.
Other anticoagulants such as Lovenox, Eliquis, and Xarelto can be measured by Anti-Xa levels to determine the amount of drug in the body that blocks the clotting factor Xa.
All of these medications are monitored based on your kidney function, liver function, and other lab results. Overall lifestyle and other medications you take can also affect your anticoagulant medication so we will work closely with you to make sure that you are taking the safest and most effective dose for you.
Why do people take an anticoagulant?
An anticoagulant is prescribed to prevent harmful blood clots from forming or to treat an existing blood clot. Physicians commonly recommend taking an anticoagulant medication for conditions including:
Atrial fibrillation
Blood clotting disorders
Deep vein thrombosis
Following a heart attack
Presence of a heart valve
Leg bypass
Pulmonary embolism
Valvular heart disease
What help will I get managing my blood thinners?
Our anticoagulation service will:
Provide careful outpatient monitoring of labs and adjust your anticoagulant medication as needed to make sure you are taking the most safe and effective dose
Answer your questions about your anticoagulant medication and provide ongoing education for you and your family
Review all of your medications and help as medications are added, adjusted, or stopped to make sure adjustments are made with any identified interactions
Explain how diet, over-the-counter medications, and supplements can affect your anticoagulant medication
Help when you need to stop and restart an anticoagulant medication for a procedure or surgery
Refill your anticoagulant medication prescription and help with affordability options
Help resolve any side effects you may be experiencing
What other services does Jobst Medication Therapy Management (Jobst MTM) offer?
Diabetes medication management
Full medication review
How do I get started with anticoagulation services?
If you are interested in having our anticoagulation service manage your anticoagulant medication, please have your doctor send our service a referral or call us at 419-291-2010 for more information.

content.articleContent:
Helping Your Child Grow and Thrive
Most children face some form of anxiety as they grow up. Changes in school, social life and physical development can all play a part in typical childhood stress. But if anxiety keeps your child from leading a full and happy life, it may be time to find help.
ProMedica’s pediatric behavioral health specialists know how to work with children at every age and stage. As a parent or guardian, you can count on our expertise and lean on our support. We’ll walk every step of this journey together. Our work isn’t finished until your child is facing a brighter tomorrow.
content.overview:
Understanding Anxiety Disorders
Types of Childhood Anxiety Disorders
While children show anxiety in many different ways, an anxiety disorder will usually fall into one of these two categories:
Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD): Constant worry and stress about any aspects of life, including school, friends and family.
Separation anxiety disorder (SAD): Fear or anxiety caused by being separated from someone the child is attached to, such as a parent or sibling.
Signs of Anxiety Disorders
Whether a child has a generalized or separation anxiety disorder, the signs are often the same. Common signs include:
Distress when leaving home or family.
Fear about personal safety or the safety of others.
Frequent physical complaints, such as headaches or stomach aches.
Being unable to relax.
Being irritable.
Lack of focus or concentration.
Refusing to go to school.
Refusing to sleep alone.
Trouble sleeping.
Uncommon fatigue.
Very clingy behavior with family.
Worry about friends and school activities.
Worry about getting lost.
Worry about things before they happen.
Causes of Anxiety Disorders
When a child’s anxiety moves from a common uneasiness to something that disrupts normal life, it’s important to learn why. The most common causes of childhood anxiety disorders are:
Chemical imbalance in the brain.
Learned behavior from a family member.
Traumatic experiences.
By diving deeper into the cause, our experts can learn which treatments will work best for your child. From medicines to therapies and counseling, we’re ready to help your child develop healthy coping skills.
content.treatment:
Treating Anxiety Disorders
If your child is showing signs of anxiety disorder, reach out to your primary care provider. Your child’s provider can refer you to a behavioral health professional who is specially trained to help your child achieve total health.
Find your ProMedica provider.

content.articleContent:
We're Here to Protect Your Heart
As your largest vessel, your aorta performs the vital job of delivering oxygenated blood from your heart to the rest of your body. But over time, it can balloon, separate or tear. These problems put you at risk for an aortic rupture that needs medical attention right away.
At ProMedica, our cardiothoracic team stands ready to care for you — day-to-day and in emergencies. They can diagnose and monitor your aortic heart disease and can recommend when you may need aortic surgery.
content.overview:
Overview
There are two conditions that lead to most aortic procedures: aortic dissections and thoracic aortic aneurysms.
Aortic dissection surgery is considered an emergency medical procedure. This method allows your surgeon to repair a tear in the wall of your aorta, which is your body’s main artery.
Thoracic aortic aneurysm surgery repairs, removes or stents an aortic aneurysm. But not all aortic aneurysms need surgery. It depends on the aneurysm’s size, location and growth rate.
Common types of aortic aneurysms include:
Aortic root.
Diagnosis of and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases.
Ascending aortic arch.
Transverse aortic arch.
Descending aortic arch.
Marfan Syndrome
This is an inherited disorder that impacts the connective tissue, which supports and anchors your organs and other parts of your body. Marfan syndrome can lead to aortic valve problems. If you have a family history of Marfan syndrome, ask your doctor to recommend the best way to monitor your aortic health.
content.before:
Prepare for Optimal Aortic Surgery Results
Before aortic surgery, you’ll consult with your cardiothoracic surgeon. At this visit you’ll be examined, find out what pre-admission tests you need to take and have a chance to ask questions.
Your pre-admission tests will most likely include blood work, a chest X-ray, an EKG and an exam of the arteries in your neck. You may also need pre-surgery dental work.
Remember, the success of your surgical experience is based on more than just the procedure itself. Being ready to manage your health during recovery is key. Come to your consultation ready to ask questions like:
How quickly will I recover?
What are the pros and cons of aortic surgery?
What kind of lifestyle changes will I have to make after surgery?
Will I need care or rehab after my surgery?
Once your testing is complete, you’ll set a surgery date.
Before your procedure, you may be asked to start a new medicine or stop taking some current ones.
content.after:
Post-Surgical Care That Puts You on the Path to Recovery
Aortic surgery is an in-depth procedure. Knowing what to expect while you’re with us, as well as when you’re recovering at home, will help you feel comfortable during the process.
Be prepared for at least a three- to four-day hospital stay. You should also be aware that:
You’ll be connected to several tubes and monitoring equipment during and after your surgery.
Your family will receive updates from your care team during your surgery, and as you move into recovery.
You’ll be moved to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for recovery.
You’ll eat your meals sitting up in a chair. You’ll start with a clear, liquid diet and then move on to solid food as you’re able to tolerate it.
You may be moved to the step-down floor on your first postoperative day.
You’ll be encouraged to take short walks in your hallway and begin cardiac rehab therapy exercises.

content.articleContent:
Aquatic Therapy Rehab
If you are recovering from an injury, surgery or illness and experiencing pain or weakness that makes it difficult to exercise then aquatic therapy may be right for you. Various conditions that may benefit from aquatic therapy include:
Total joint replacements
Low back pain
Pediatric neurological conditions
Multiple injuries following a car accident
Fracture healing
Generalized weakness following prolonged illness
Which ProMedica locations offer aquatic therapy?
At ProMedica Total Rehab, our experts are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. We provide aquatic therapy in a number of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.
Please consult with your physician to determine if aquatic therapy is right for you.
A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.
Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

What Is Arrhythmia?
Arrhythmia is an irregular heart rate or rhythm that causes poor blood flow to your body. Some arrhythmias increase your risk for having a stroke. If you or for a loved one is diagnosed with arrhythmia, it’s natural to have questions. A ProMedica electrophysiologist in the Toledo area can help you determine whether you or a loved one are experiencing arrhythmia.
Understanding Arrhythmia
What are the most common kinds of arrhythmia?
Atrial fibrillation (AFib): Fast, irregular heartbeat.
Tachycardia: Fast, but regular heartbeat.
Bradycardia: A slow heartbeat.
How does arrhythmia work?
The heart is an electrical pump. Normally, electrical impulses start every beat of your heart and keep your heart beating with a nice, regular rhythm.
But sometimes those rhythms become chaotic, irregular or rapid. The upper parts of your heart get out of sync with the lower parts of your heart.
How does arrhythmia feel?
Some people have no symptoms at all, while some have different sensations. You may notice these feelings occasionally, often, or all of the time. You may describe the feeling in your chest like this:
A fish flopping
A drum pounding
Butterflies fluttering
Your heart leaping out of your chest
Your heart skipping a beat, and then your heart racing
You may also feel:
Lightheaded
Nervous
Out of breath
Weak
Dizzy
Tired
What causes arrhythmia?
Electrical flaws or damage to the heart are the most common causes. However some people with arrhythmia have none of these.
Why should you be concerned?
Arrhythmia, especially AFib, increases your risk for stroke by five times that of a person without arrhythmia. Your atypical heartbeat allows blood to pool in your heart, where a blood clot can form. Eventually the clot may dislodge and travel to your brain. This causes a stroke.
ProMedica’s cardiac electrophysiologists have the expertise to help you determine the best diagnosis and treatment for your arrhythmia.
What is a cardiac electrophysiologist?
This specially trained cardiologist treats patients who have rhythm problems with their hearts.
Learn more about cardiac electrophysiology

Help Your Child Regain Control
When your child has a hard time breathing, it can be hard to catch your breath, too. That’s why our team of pediatric pulmonologists, pediatric sleep specialists, registered nurses and respiratory therapists are here to help.
content.ourProgram:
A Program Dedicated to Supporting Your Child’s Every Breath
ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Hospital’s asthma program is the first to be dual-certified for inpatient and outpatient care by The Joint Commission. This recognition puts us in the company of fewer than a dozen organizations in the United States to achieve this certification. We meet the highest national standards for quality and safety in asthma diagnosis, treatment and education.
Childhood asthma in Lucas County is widespread. It affects 5% of children under the age of five, 15% of children under the age of 11, and 21% of children in grades 6 through 12. Of children diagnosed with asthma, 32% are African American.
At ProMedica Ebeid Children’s Hospital, the goal of our asthma program is to help minimize the frequency and severity of a child’s symptoms. Working directly with affected children and their families, we help them understand and manage their condition. This reduces their risk for emergency room and hospital visits, and improves quality of life. Our patient care program offers a wide spectrum of services and support, including:
Controller medicines to decrease symptoms and prevent asthma attacks.
Education on personal asthma triggers, such as allergies, smoke, exercise and cold air.
How to understand the differences among medicines and how to take the right one at the right time.
Personalized Asthma Action Plans to help monitor and manage symptoms and document key healthcare contacts. The plans can be shared with schools, athletic coaches and day care providers.
Rescue medicines for sudden attacks.
content.ourExpertise:
Experts in Pediatric Pulmonary Conditions
The board-certified specialists in our pediatric pulmonary clinic are committed to excellent care for your child. We follow nationally recognized guidelines and advise on the most up-to-date medicines.
Most importantly, we make sure families understand how to help their children with the right treatments and symptom management for asthma and other respiratory disorders, including chronic cough, apnea of infancy, cystic fibrosis, sleep disturbances, and more.
content.resources:
Asthma Resources
We work with patients and their families to empower them to better understand asthma and how they can manage their condition. If your child has asthma, you can help by:
Understanding signs and symptoms. Download our booklet .
Becoming tobacco free. Download our flyer .
Attending a free asthma class. Learn more by calling 419-291-5474.
Download our free pediatric asthma activity book .

content.articleContent:
Expert treatment that helps you live a full and healthy life
If you’ve been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, you’re not alone. AFib is the most common heart rhythm problem in the United States, and it affects at least three million Americans today.
At ProMedica, you’ll benefit from cutting-edge technology and cardiac expertise. Our goal is to make sure you get the treatment you need to live a full and healthy life.
A Center Dedicated to Irregular Heartbeats
ProMedica’s Heart Rhythm Center is a new, state-of-the-art facility on the second floor of ProMedica Toledo Hospital. Providing the highest quality of heart rhythm care in Toledo, the center treats simple to complex heart arrhythmias, such as AFib.
Learn more about the Heart Rhythm Center
content.overview:
Understanding AFib
What is AFib?
AFib is a type of abnormal heart rhythm. While an irregular heartbeat isn’t always dangerous, the side effects can raise your risk for a stroke.
During AFib, the electrical signal that starts the heartbeat gets jumbled. This causes the upper chambers of the heart (atria) to contract and relax irregularly. The heart’s upper chambers get out of sync with the lower chambers (ventricles) and the heart can’t pump blood efficiently.
When the heart can’t pump blood properly, the blood pools in the upper chambers. At some point, this pooled blood may form a blood clot. If the blood clot escapes the heart and gets stuck in an artery leading to the brain, it can cause a stroke.
Get the facts on AFib with our fact sheet.
Risk Factors
AFib is more common in women and people over age 65. Certain foods and substances, such as caffeine and alcohol, can also cause attacks.
Other risk factors include:
Congenital heart defects.
Diabetes.
Heart failure.
Heart surgery.
High blood pressure.
Obesity (overweight).
Obstructive sleep apnea.
Thyroid disease and thyroid medicines.
Are you at risk for atrial fibrillation? Download our checklist.
content.diagnosis:
Diagnosis & Treatment
Symptoms
Atrial fibrillation symptoms can vary from person to person, range from mild to severe and, in some cases, may not cause any symptoms at all.
Common symptoms can include:
Chest pain.
Confusion.
Dizziness.
Fatigue.
Pounding or fluttering in the chest (palpitations).
Shortness of breath.
Trouble exercising.
Weakness.
Diagnosis
If your doctor believes you may have atrial fibrillation, you’ll have a physical exam. During this exam, your doctor will ask you about your health history and your family’s health history, as well as any medicines you may be taking.
Your doctor may also refer you to a cardiac electrophysiologist. These doctors specialize in treating the heart’s electrical system and heart rhythm problems like atrial fibrillation.
After a physical exam, your doctor may also ask you to have several tests, including:
Blood tests: These tests can help your doctor figure out whether another condition is causing the atrial fibrillation.
Echocardiogram: This is an ultrasound of the heart. Your doctor may use an echocardiogram to check your heart’s structure and how it’s pumping blood.
Electrocardiogram (EKG or ECG): This test checks your heart’s rhythm and whether it’s sending and receiving electrical signals properly. If your atrial fibrillation comes and goes, your doctor may ask you to wear a portable electrocardiogram (Holter monitor) for a few days at home.
Stress test: During this test, you will walk or run on a treadmill while your doctor monitors your heart and blood pressure. It can help show how blood flows to and from your heart.
Treatment
If you’ve been diagnosed with AFib, your doctor may decide to treat the condition with medicines, minimally invasive procedures or surgery. The treatment your doctor chooses will be based on how severe your atrial fibrillation is and other health conditions you may already have.
Medicines
Medicines that may be used to treat atrial fibrillation include:
Blood-thinning medicines to prevent blood clots and stroke.
Rate control medicines to slow a rapid heartbeat.
Rhythm control medicines to help your heart beat with a normal pattern.
Ablation and Cryoablation
Ablation is a treatment that burns or freezes small parts of the heart to create scar tissue. This scar tissue stops the abnormal electrical signals that cause atrial fibrillation.
The ablation procedure may use heat or cold to create the scar tissue. When cold temperatures are used, the procedure is called cryoablation.
During ablation, you will be mildly sedated. Your doctor will make a small incision (cut) in your groin and insert thin, flexible tubes (catheters) into a blood vessel and feed the tube up to your heart. The tube will have small electrodes on the tip.
Your doctor will place the catheters on different areas of the heart and send electrical pulses through the catheter. The catheter then records the heart’s signals to find out where the abnormal electrical signals are coming from.
Once your doctor finds where the abnormal signals are coming from, he or she will send heat or cold through the catheter tips. This forms scars on that area of the heart and stops the abnormal signals.
AV node ablation
AV node ablation helps control your heart rate by using heat to form scar tissue on the part of the heart that connects the upper and lower chambers (AV node). This process stops the upper chambers of the heart from sending irregular electrical signals to the bottom chambers.
Electrical cardioversion
During electrical cardioversion, your doctor will send a low-energy shock to your heart to reset it to a normal rhythm. This treatment is usually only temporary.
Implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD)
An ICD is similar to a pacemaker. It’s a device that’s attached to the heart and sends low-energy shocks to your heart to reset it to a normal rhythm.
Open-heart maze procedure
During an open-heart maze procedure, a surgeon makes several small cuts in the upper part of your heart and stitches the cuts together. This process creates scar tissue, which helps prevent the heart from sending electrical signals that cause atrial fibrillation. Your doctor may recommend this treatment if medicines and other less-invasive treatments do not work.
Pacemaker
A pacemaker is a small device that your doctor inserts under the skin and attaches to the heart. It sends electrical signals to the heart to prevent slow heartbeats.
Subcutaneous implantable cardioverter defibrillator (S-ICD)
An S-ICD is a small device that’s placed under the skin but isn’t attached directly to the heart. It sends low-energy shocks to your heart to reset it to a normal rhythm.
Schedule a visit with your primary care doctor to begin taking steps to lower your risk for AFib.

content.articleContent:
Understanding ADHD
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is one of the most common childhood developmental disorders.
Typically symptoms start developing before age 7. Children with ADHD may appear overly hyper, compulsive, active or unable to focus. These symptoms create significant challenges in at least two areas of their day-to-day life – home, social settings, school, activities or work (for adults).
Remember that everyone matures differently. Behaviors shouldn’t cause concern unless they are more severe or frequent than in other children the same age. Additional factors – personality, temperament, energy or other health conditions – are sometimes mistaken for ADHD. Because of this, careful diagnosis is crucial. The evaluation process typically includes several tests performed by a behavioral health professional.
What are the common ADHD symptoms? Signs are grouped into three areas:
Inattention
Easily distracted
Does not appear to listen
Avoids or dislikes tasks requiring sustained mental effort
Struggles to follow through on instructions – especially multiple steps
Frequently forgets or misplaces belongings
Hyperactivity
Has difficulty doing quiet activities
Excessively fidgets or talks; squirmy
Has difficulty remaining seated
Acts as if driven by a motor
Impulsivity
Blurts out answers before questions have been completed
Frequently makes unnecessary mistakes or take risks
Interrupts others
Has difficulty waiting or taking turns
What should you do if your think your child has ADHD? Contact your pediatrician to discuss. If further assessment is needed, your pediatrician may recommend evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional.

content.articleContent:
Treating Hearing Issues for Your Best Health
No matter the type, degree or configuration of hearing loss or whether you have a more serious otologic disorder, the audiologists at ProMedica can help you manage and treat hearing loss and vestibular disorders. This team of licensed hearing healthcare professional wants to improve your quality of life by helping you hear your best.
content.approach:
Our Approach to Audiology Care
With a large network of audiology specialists in northwest Ohio, ProMedica takes a comprehensive approach to managing hearing and vestibular disorders.
Audiologists at ProMedica work collaboratively with ENT doctors to make sure you receive complete, high-quality care. Our priority is to provide patient-centered care that is entirely focused on improving your health and well-being. We provide evaluation and treatment to adults and children.
content.conditions:
Audiology Conditions
From hearing tests and evaluations to hearing devices and accessories, the audiologists at ProMedica have the in-depth knowledge and expertise needed to treat a range of conditions. You can trust that they’ll put you at the center of your care when diagnosing and treating your hearing loss or vestibular disorder. Common audiology problems include:
Hearing loss.
Vestibular disorders (dizziness or balance).
Tinnitus (high pitch ringing or buzzing).
Hearing conservation.
Auditory processing disorders (ability to understand speech).
content.treatment:
Audiology Treatments for Better Health
Our licensed audiologists are dedicated to providing the best care in treating and managing your hearing and balance concerns. Whether you need a hearing evaluation, assistive listening devices, or vestibular evaluations, you can be sure you’re receiving the region’s best in expert care.
Our services include:
Hearing tests for children and adults.
Newborn hearing evaluations and screenings.
Hearing aid evaluations and programming.
Cochlear implant evaluations and programming
Evaluations and programming of bone anchored hearing devices.
Auditory processing evaluations.
Assistive listening devices.
Ear molds, swim plugs, hearing aid accessories and hearing protection devices.
Counseling patients about hearing health and the possible need for treatment/management of their hearing loss.
Vestibular evaluations including: Videonystagmography (VNG), rotary chair, Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potential (VEMP), and Electrocochleography (ECoG), and Computerized Dynamic Posturography (CDP).

content.articleContent:
Compassionate, Specialized Care for Your Child’s Needs
Facing an autism diagnosis can send a family into a whirlwind of uncertainty. It’s normal to feel overwhelmed with questions and concerns about your child’s future.
At ProMedica, our goal is to ease your fears, answer your questions and provide critical support services for the whole family.
Wherever you are in your child’s autism journey, know that our doctors and specialists are available to provide the resources your child needs to live a happy and healthy life.
content.overview:
Understanding Autism
Having answers always helps. We’re here with answers to your questions about what your child is experiencing. Autism, also known as autism spectrum disorder (ASD), is a developmental disability that causes major social, behavioral and communication problems. It’s a lifelong condition that affects one in 59 children in the United States.
ASD describes several different conditions that used to be diagnosed separately, including:
Autistic disorder.
Pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS).
Asperger’s syndrome.
Signs of Autism
You may first notice signs of autism before your child turns three. But they most often appear within the first 12 to 18 months.
Remember, autism spectrum disorder affects everyone differently. Symptoms vary from child to child. The most important thing is to talk with your pediatrician about your concerns.
Communication problems are often the first signs of autism. A child with autism may not:
Babble or respond to his or her name by 10 months.
Be soothed by mom’s voice by three months.
Follow simple spoken directions.
Give big smiles by six months.
Imitate simple words or sounds by 15 months.
Locate objects when asked by 15 months.
Make eye contact.
Seem startled by loud sounds by three months.
Understand common words such as “no” or “bye-bye.”
Want to be with other people.
Along with having communication problems, a child with autism may:
Arch his or her back or make other unusual body movements.
Be extremely irritable.
Frequently choke or gag.
Have a floppy or limp body.
Have stiff arms or legs.
Make minimal gestures — such as pointing, reaching and waving — by 12 months.
Only use one side of the body.
Risk Factors
Autism can affect children of all races, ethnic groups, education levels and incomes. It’s almost four times more likely to affect boys than girls.
There’s no known single cause of autism. Researchers are still looking into why some children develop autism and others don’t.
Risk factors for autism may include:
A sibling with autism.
Genetic conditions, such as Rett, fragile X or Down syndromes.
Low birth weight.
Older parents.
There’s no proven link between vaccines and autism.
Diagnosis
Your child’s pediatrician will perform developmental tests during the first two years of check-ups. A doctor who thinks your child may have an autism spectrum disorder will suggest a diagnostic evaluation, which looks at your child’s behavior and development. This may include:
Genetic tests.
Hearing tests.
Neurological (nervous system) tests.
Medical tests, such as blood tests.
Vision tests.
In some cases, your child’s pediatrician may want you to go to a specialist who does the diagnostic evaluation. These specialists can include:
Child psychiatrist or psychologists.
Developmental pediatricians.
Occupational therapists.
Pediatric neurologists.
Speech and language therapists.
Treatment
While there’s no single treatment or medicine that can cure autism, there’s hope and help. Behavioral and communication therapies have been shown to help improve the way a child functions in life, especially if therapy is used early.
At ProMedica, you’ll find in-depth applied behavioral analysis (ABA) services at the Finnegan Family Autism Center at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital. That’s where our board-certified behavior analysts, special educators, speech and language pathologists and behavior therapists will focus on helping your child with:
Behavior.
Communication.
Life skills that fit your child’s developmental level.
Play and social skills.
Your child will also have a personalized treatment plan that includes:
Behavioral and educational consultation.
Behavioral therapy.
Functional behavior assessment.
Intensive applied behavior analysis intervention.
Ongoing evaluations.
Speech and language services.
Your child will start treatment with one-on-one sessions and then move into small group settings. Our specialists also encourage parents and family members to be involved with the treatment.
Your child’s pediatrician or specialist may also prescribe some medicines to help manage your child’s autism-related symptoms. These symptoms may include high energy levels, depression, seizures or inability to focus.
content.support:
Lifelong Support for Children and Families
Every child with autism spectrum disorder is on a different journey. Many children with autism go on to lead normal, independent lives, while others may need lifelong care and supervision.
No matter what level of care your child needs, you can trust ProMedica’s team of compassionate pediatricians and specialists to be by your side. We’re here to help you and your child every step of the way.
Learn about ProMedica’s Autism Early Learning Program.

content.articleContent:
Look and Feel Your Best
Achieving your weight loss goals isn’t just about looking good — it’s about lifelong health.
Perhaps you’ve tried dieting and exercise, but still aren’t seeing the results you want. Or you may be concerned about high blood pressure, diabetes or another weight-related condition. Whatever your reasons are, it may be time to think about having weight loss surgery.
ProMedica is here to help you decide if a bariatric procedure is right for you. Our expert team can guide you through every step of the process. We’ll explain all your treatment choices and make sure you understand what to expect before, during and after surgery. We’re your partners on the journey to a lasting weight loss solution.
content.getStarted:
Getting Started on Your Bariatric Journey
Fill out our patient information form, then watch our seminar. There’s no pressure to commit – this is just the start of an important conversation.
We’ll make sure you meet the requirements for being a candidate for surgery and that you understand all the risks and benefits before you take the next step.

Find the Form and Seminar Here
content.journey:
Understanding Your Bariatric Journey
Weight loss surgery isn’t a quick fix. It’s a lifelong journey of embracing a healthier lifestyle. At ProMedica, we support your desire for a full, healthy life by equipping you with the knowledge and tools for long-term success. From seminars that explain your surgery options to support groups following your surgery, we’re here to help you every step of the way.
Benefits of Weight Loss Surgery
Some benefits of weight loss surgery are clear. As in, people see a major improvement in their overall health and well-being. But weight loss surgery offers many other health benefits that can help you lead a longer, happier life.
Benefits of weight loss surgery include:
Better mood and self-esteem.
Enhanced fertility in younger women.
Less pain related to osteoarthritis.
Lowered risk of heart disease.
Much lower blood pressure and cholesterol levels.
Reduced risk of breast and colon cancer.
Relief from acid reflux and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
Resolved sleep apnea and respiratory issues.
Diabetes Management
Weight loss surgery can have major, life-changing effects, especially for those with type 2 diabetes. Weight loss can not only help prevent the onset of diabetes, but it can even reverse the condition. About 84% of patients report remission of their diabetes after surgery. Other people typically need less medicine to control their condition.
So how does bariatric surgery help diabetes? Weight loss surgery limits your food intake. The small intestine is rerouted slightly, which redirects the digestive process. The result is that your body absorbs fewer calories. This can balance the insulin-regulating hormones in the intestines and stomach that cause diabetes.
For some people, diabetes goes away within days of surgery. For others, blood sugar levels begin to fall soon after surgery and become completely normal within a year. Long-term benefits include a lower risk of stroke, kidney disease, blindness and peripheral nerve damage.
Risks of Weight Loss Surgery
All surgeries come with risks. If you’re thinking about having weight loss surgery, be sure to talk with your doctor about these risks:
Blood clots.
Gallstones or gallbladder disease.
Hernias.
Infection.
Intestinal disorders.
Vitamin deficiencies.
Types of Weight Loss Surgery
Single Anastomosis Duodenal-Ileal bypass with Sleeve (SADI-S)
The SADI-S procedure consists of a sleeve gastrectomy and a bypass of some of the small intestine with one connection between the duodenum and the small intestine. Endorsed by the American Society of Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery in 2019, the surgery works in three ways.
The sleeve gastrectomy portion of this surgery creates a 2-3 oz small stomach and as a result, a person cannot eat much.
Food will move from the new small stomach directly into the lower 10 feet of the small intestine and bypass the first part of the small intestine, which is about half of the small intestine. Normally, the small intestine that is available to absorb calories and nutrients is around 15 to 25 feet long. The result is that less of the calories are absorbed.
Additional Facts about the SADI-S:
The sleeve gastrectomy portion of this surgery creates a 2-3 oz small stomach and as a result, a person cannot eat much.
Food will move from the new small stomach directly into the lower 10 feet of the small intestine and bypass the first part of the small intestine, which is about half of the small intestine. Normally, the small intestine that is available to absorb calories and nutrients is around 15 to 25 feet long. The result is that less of the calories are absorbed.
Revision Surgery
Bariatric Revision Surgery is a procedure that corrects or improves prior weight loss surgery. Most of the time, bariatric surgery is successful. However, it may be recommended for you if you’ve experienced:
Inadequate Weight Loss
Weight re-gain
Ruptured or displaced gastric bands
Displaced gastric band ports
Disrupted staples
Enlarged gastric pouch
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
Problems swallowing
Bariatric Revision Surgery Options
At ProMedica Weight Loss Surgery, we use the latest minimally invasive technology, including robotic assisted surgery, to perform bariatric revision surgery. We offer several revision procedures, including:
Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass Revision
The original gastric pouch created during surgery may become larger over time. This procedure involves the following:
Increase intestinal bypass
Decrease pouch and stomach size
Gastric Sleeve Resection
We can correct gastric sleeve surgery by:
Converting the gastric sleeve to a gastric bypass
Recreating the gastric sleeve
Changing the gastric sleeve to duodenal switch
When a patient undergoes a revision to his or her gastric bypass, we usually see a 65-75% excess body weight loss, which is 65-70 lbs. weight loss for every 100 pounds. If a patient has a small stomach pouch which cannot be revised, weight loss is usually 50-55 lbs. for every 100 lbs. of excess body weight.
Insurers all have different requirements, but they generally cover revisions to the sleeve or bypass to address weight regain, if you meet these criteria: If your BMI is greater than 40, or if you have a BMI of 35 along with a medical problem related to obesity
What to Expect Before Surgery
The first step in our program is to see if weight loss surgery is the right choice for you. We want all of our patients to achieve lifelong health, which is why we’ll only recommend surgery if we believe you’re a good candidate.
We look at a variety of factors, including your:
Age: You must be between the ages of 18 and 67.
Lifestyle and health: You must stop smoking at least three months before your weight loss surgery and agree not to smoke after surgery. You should also commit to exercising and eating a healthy diet after surgery. These are essential to help keep the weight off for good.
Personality: You must be motivated to make a real change in your health. The ideal candidate for weight loss surgery is willing to face the physical, emotional and social changes that come with weight loss.
Weight: You must have a body mass index (BMI) of 40 or more (about 100 pounds or more over ideal body weight). Or have a BMI of 35 to 39.9 with serious medical conditions related to obesity that would improve with weight loss.
What to Expect After Surgery
Part of the bariatric surgery journey is for you to commit to healthier lifestyle changes. These include your diet and eating habits. This will be one of the biggest changes you’ll need to make after surgery.
Our bariatric dietitians will help you understand the dietary and nutritional changes to expect in the days and weeks after your weight loss surgery. We’ll support you through every step and guide you through meal options, food choices and more.
Right after surgery, your digestive system will need to rest and heal for a couple of days. You’ll begin a liquid diet of light broths and beverages while you’re still in the hospital.
After a few days of the liquid diet, you’ll move to pureed foods like lean meats, beans, yogurt and egg whites. You’ll eat pureed foods for a few weeks when you go home.
Once your body is comfortable with pureed foods, you’ll begin eating soft, solid foods like ground meats, soft fruits and cooked vegetables. You’ll continue to get support and menu ideas from your dietitian and bariatric care team for two to three months.
Eventually, your doctor will transition you back to enjoying solid, healthy foods.
After surgery, your body doesn’t absorb nutrients the way it used to. That’s why it’s important to take nutritional supplements. Supplements help make sure you’re getting all the nutrients you need. You can get supplements specially made for weight-loss surgery patients at our pharmacy partner, Pharmacy Counter.
Ideas for Cooking at Home
Once you return to eating solid food, there are many well-balanced meal choices. These videos and our free downloadable cookbook introduce some of the easy, healthy meals you can include in your post-bariatric diet.
Download our free weight loss surgery cookbook.
Bariatric Breakfast

Make a well-balanced, perfectly portioned breakfast that’s high in protein and fiber.
Bariatric Lunch

Check out how to use leftovers to create a healthy, pre-portioned lunch when you’re on the go.
Balanced Dinner

Discover this easy to make, high-protein recipe that everyone will love!
Bariatric Support Group
On-going post-surgical support helps patients adjust to their new lifestyle and reach the greatest level of success. Being with people who share your situation can help you maintain the long-term life-style changes required after surgery. ProMedica Weight Loss Surgery offers multiple days and times for their support groups.
View Support Group Dates

content.articleContent:
Understanding Balance Disorders
Balance related falls account for more than half of all accidental deaths among the elderly; however, balance disorders can occur at any age.
Do you continuously feel dizzy when trying to perform day to day activities such as walking?
Do you often fall or feel as though you are going to fall?
Our experts at ProMedica Total Rehab can help you manage your balance disorder through our educational resources and treatment.
What is a balance disorder?
A balance disorder is a condition that makes you feel unsteady or dizzy. Often, if you are lying down, sitting or being still, it may feel as though you or the area around you is moving. If you are walking, it may feel as though you will tip over.
How is a balance disorder diagnosed and treated?
A qualified, licensed physical therapist can perform a thorough evaluation of your balance disorder by observing your posture and movement. By comparing the results of your evaluation testing with established norms, your therapist will determine the strengths and weaknesses of your individual balance system. Your therapist will work with you to develop a treatment plan and exercises for you to perform at home.
How can ProMedica Total Rehab help you?
At ProMedica Total Rehab, we are committed to helping you regain control over your balance disorder.
Talk to your physician to determine if this treatment is right for you.
A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.
Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

About Balloon Sinuplasty
Balloon sinuplasty is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis and sinus-related pain. Unlike traditional sinus surgery, it does not require cutting or removing any bone or tissue from the nose. Instead, it uses a small, flexible balloon catheter, which is inserted through the nose to open up blocked sinuses and decrease pressure.
 
Balloon sinuplasty is performed at our Adrian location.

content.articleContent:
Find Hope for a Brighter Tomorrow
Most of us don’t think twice about getting help for our physical concerns. But we often hesitate when it comes to our mental well-being. Yet nearly half of us will have a mental or emotional issue at some point in our lives, so it’s important to know that help is near.
Early intervention to help prevent health problems is just as vital for the mind and emotions as it is for the body. Get the right diagnosis and find the best possible treatment, so you can feel like yourself again.
Download Mental Health Resource Guides
Northwest Ohio Mental Health Resource Guide
Lenawee Resource Guide
Download the Monroe Resource Guide
Download Hospital Resource Guides
ProMedica Flower Hospital Patient Rights and the Grievance Procedure booklet
content.approach:
Our Approach
When you or a loved one face a mental health issue, you want caring and proven treatment. With a wide range of counseling and psychiatric services, ProMedica is ready to help you and those you love most. Every service is delivered by a compassionate team that specializes in behavioral health for children, teens and adults.
A Compassionate Network of Providers
ProMedica’s mental health professional network works across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. It provides specialized skill, compassionate support and secure and private care.
Our multidisciplinary approach makes sure you get treatment that’s tailored to your specific mental health needs. When you turn to us for help, you’ll have access to:
Counselors who assess and diagnose mental health conditions and provide individual or group therapy.
Nurses to help assess, treat and manage cases, and assist with psychotherapy.
Physicians to guide your treatment plan.
Psychiatrists to evaluate medical and psychiatric issues, treat psychiatric disorders, provide psychotherapy, and prescribe and monitor medicines.
Psychologists to provide psychological testing and evaluations, treat mental disorders, emotional and behavioral problems and offer a range of psychotherapeutic methods.
Social workers to provide case management, inpatient discharge planning, placement services and other daily-living services.
Therapists to support your rehabilitation needs.
Mental Health Care Close to Home
Our goal is to support your commitment to better mental health. To make it easier to get treatment, we have multiple locations that provide services to the entire Toledo metro area, as well as southeast Michigan. This includes specialized programs for children, teens and adults at these ProMedica facilities:
The Coping Center at ProMedica Defiance Regional Hospital: Adult inpatient psychiatric services. Added inpatient services include an intensive care unit, a general psychiatric unit and emergency evaluation.
ProMedica Flower Hospital, a division of ProMedica Toledo Hospital: The largest adult inpatient psychiatric provider in the northwest Ohio area.
ProMedica Coldwater Hospital: Inpatient psychiatric care in a stable environment.
ProMedica Monroe Regional Hospital: Inpatient services for adults.
ProMedica Toledo Hospital: Complete mental health services, including emergency service and crisis intervention for psychiatric needs and substance abuse. There’s also a psychiatric intensive care unit for people who need observation and supervision. Call 419-291-4000.
The Child and Adolescent Behavioral Medicine Program at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital: Inpatient care and for kids and teens; home to Children’s Safe Harbor and The Cullen Center for children and families who have gone through emotional trauma.
content.services:
Our Services
We believe early intervention and treatment are the keys to helping people who are challenged with emotional problems, mental illness or chemical dependence. But the onset of behavioral health issues can be different for everyone. Our expert staff is ready to guide you through diagnosis, treatment and recovery, no matter where you are in your mental health journey.
We can help you get on the path to emotional wellness with outpatient and inpatient services that include community education programs, crisis intervention, counseling and therapy. Treatment can be arranged at your request, or at the request of family members and by referral from a doctor, clergy member, school representative, employer or another agency.
Outpatient Mental Health Systems
Our multidisciplinary team of psychiatric specialists provides a full range of outpatient community counseling services for children, teens, adults and families including:
Diagnostic evaluations and consultations.
Educational programs.
Family therapy.
Individual and group treatment.
Medicine assessment and management.
Stress reduction programs.
Substance abuse services.
Inpatient Mental Health Systems
ProMedica’s adult inpatient behavioral health services are there when you need the extra support of a safe and caring environment, 24/7. They offer complete, secure adult psychiatric treatment.
ProMedica Flower Hospital (a division of ProMedica Toledo Hospital) is home to the largest provider of inpatient psychiatric care in northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. We’re recognized for our inpatient psychiatric care program. Across our network, we provide patients with the tools and support they need to restore their mental and emotional health, including:
Coping strategies.
Crisis management.
Diagnostic evaluation.
Medicine assessment and management.
Structured individual and group treatment.
Special Services for Children and Adolescents
Childhood is a time of rapid changes in the body, mind and emotions. So when your child’s behavior suddenly changes, how do you know if it’s just a phase or something more serious?
There’s a wide range of “normal” behavior among children. But when certain behaviors stray from what is normal for your child, or they become constant or severe, it’s worth taking a deeper look at what’s going on. Getting an early, accurate diagnosis is vital — so your child gets the right help and support.
Our pediatric psychological services for children and adolescents include both inpatient and outpatient treatments. They’re designed to address the mental health concerns and conditions that impact young people, including:
Anxiety disorders: Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), separation anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder, panic disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
Behavioral conditions: ADHD, oppositional defiant disorder (ODD), drug use, criminal activity and anger management.
Developmental disabilities: Autism, language disorders and intellectual disabilities.
Eating disorders: Anorexia nervosa, binge eating and bulimia.
Mood disorders: Depression, bipolar disorder and self-harm.
Substance disorders.
Suicidal behavior.
Substance Abuse Treatment
Coming to terms with a substance abuse problem can take time. That’s why our outpatient treatment program is designed for patients to enter at any stage of dependency. It provides a complete approach to treatment that recognizes the biological, social, mental and spiritual elements of each person’s addiction.
All care is private and secure and is supervised by a medical director who works along with certified addiction counselors, social workers and psychologists. The wide range of treatment services include:
Cooperation with self-help and 12-step programs such as Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous.
Educational programs.
Evaluations and consultations.
Individual, group and family counseling.
Treatment for children and adults who have parents who are chemically dependent.
Employee Mental Health Services
When your employees or their dependents need help overcoming personal problems, guide them toward the right care through ProMedica’s employee mental health services.
Administered by the ProMedica Employee Assistance Program (EAP), we offer employers expert mental health services to help minimize the impact of mental health issues on employees’ well-being, families and job performance.
We can contribute to your company’s overall health with services that include:
24-hour phone availability.
Formal referrals and case management.
Critical incident stress management.
Financial problems.
Marital and family counseling.
Short-term counseling.
Substance abuse assessment, education and referral.
Workplace conflict management.
Call ProMedica EAP at 833-798-5975.

title: Bipolar Disorder Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System

content.articleContent:
Understanding Bipolar Disorder
Bipolar disorder is a mental disorder that causes identifiable and sometimes intense changes in mood and energy level. Someone with bipolar disorder may experience periods of high energy (manic periods) followed by periods of depression or lethargy (depressive periods). The exact cause is unknown, but research suggests that it is hereditary, as it often runs in families. Studies are still underway to try and identify which gene (or genes) may be responsible.
Signs of Bipolar Disorder
Someone with bipolar disorder will experience both types of the following symptoms to a varying degree:
Manic symptoms:
Has an overly inflated sense of self-esteem
Seems to not need sleep or rest as much
Is very distracted and irritable
Excessively gets involved in high-risk and/or pleasurable activities, for example: sexual promiscuity, reckless driving, reckless spending, substance abuse
Enhanced talkativeness
Appears to have excessive “high” or euphoric feelings, grandiose at times
Unpredictably changes mood from happy or silly, anger or agitation
Increased sex drive
Increased energy level
Uses uncharacteristic poor judgment
Depressive symptoms:
Difficulty with relationships
Expresses excessive guilt
Expresses hopelessness
Is extremely sensitive to failure or rejection
Is unable to concentrate
Lacks energy
Lacks interest in activities once enjoyed
Persistently suffers sadness
Seems irritable, hostile or aggressive
Shares feelings of wanting to die
Shows changes in appetite or weight
Shows signs of low self-esteem
Sleeps too much or very little
Thinks about suicide or attempts suicide
If you think you may have bipolar disorder, talk to your primary care doctor. After ruling out other conditions through a physical exam, they can help you find a psychiatrist, psychologist or other behavioral health specialist with experience in treating bipolar disorder.
Bipolar Disorder in Children and Adolescents
Bipolar disorder is a condition with alternating sets of symptoms. During certain periods of time, your child or adolescent may act extremely happy, elated, or very irritable (manic symptoms). During the alternate periods of time they will exhibit symptoms of major depression.
When symptoms are present before age 12, they are sometimes confused with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). However, advances continue to be made in recognizing bipolar disorder in younger children.
If you believe your child has bipolar disorder, contact your pediatrician or family doctor to set up an appointment for evaluation. If further assessment is needed, your doctor may recommend evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional. Bipolar disorder can be effectively treated, usually with a combination of therapy and medication.
