content.articleContent:
Help Us Advance Medical Research, Locally
You're having a surgery or medical procedure. You want to take it a step further and make a difference in the lives of others affected by cancer and disease. What about contributing to medical research advancement at the ProMedica BioRepository?
It’s so simple to donate your blood and body tissue samples.
Biorepository FAQs
What is the ProMedica BioRepository?
It’s a “bank” that stores tissue or blood samples, called biospecimens, that can be used to help researchers discover new treatments for cancer and other medical conditions. The ProMedica BioRepository is located on the ProMedica Toledo Hospital campus and it’s your local answer to helping others and furthering medicine.
What do the researchers do with tissue and blood samples?
An ultra low-temperature laboratory freezer preserves your samples for long term storage. The research on these samples can be used to discover what causes cancer, how to prevent it, and how to treat it. It can also help us learn the causes of and find treatments for other diseases such as:
Diabetes
Alzheimer's Disease
Heart disease
Crohn's Disease
Where do tissue and blood samples come from?
You have the ability to easily donate your tissues and blood samples if you’re undergoing a procedure. At your scheduled pre-op appointment, you may request the blood samples taken during your procedure be donated to our ProMedica BioRepository. As for tissue donation, your doctor removes a certain amount of tissue needed for your diagnosis or treatment during your procedure. But sometimes, there’s extra tissue. In most situations, this tissue is destroyed. Instead of destroying what’s left over, you may choose to have it donated to the ProMedica BioRepository.
Will donating affect diagnostic results?
No, your leftover tissue donation will not affect your diagnostic results.
How much blood do you need to donate?
For blood samples, you’ll be asked for permission for an additional four to six teaspoons to store in the BioRepository. It’s done at the same time as your scheduled blood workup, so no separate appointment is needed.
Can you be identified from your donation?
No. Identification of all donated samples is replaced with a code, which allows for de-identified tissue donation.
Is it safe?
Yes. You don’t need to go through any extra procedures or tests. The remaining tissue leftover from your procedure is all that’s needed.
How do you do it?
If you’re interested, please speak with your doctor. When you come in for pre-admission testing or for a procedure, a ProMedica BioRepository member may speak with you and give you the choice to participate. For further information, please call 419-291-4584.
Learn more about the Biorepository.

ProMedica's Blood Management Program
Bloodless care is for patients who decline a blood transfusion under any circumstance, whether it be for cultural, religious or personal reasons. Blood management is our broader program for patients who prefer to avoid a blood transfusion, if possible.
For both bloodless care and blood management patients, we utilize the same best practices to prevent anemia and minimize bleeding caused by surgery or illness. Together, you and our physician-lead team will develop a plan based on your individual needs.
The goal of ProMedica’s progressive blood management program is helping you avoid an unneccessary blood transfusion.
Reasons to avoid a blood transfusion when possible include:
Decrease risk of infections
Reduce exposure to viruses and other blood-borne diseases
Shorten the length of your hospital stay
Conserve our precious community resource
Why trust ProMedica’s blood management program?
One of the few programs in the country, ProMedica began its blood management program with a bloodless care program in 1993. For the past twenty years we have established ourselves as a leader of blood management and bloodless care in our region, our knowledgeable doctors are able to perform procedures such as open-heart, orthopaedic and gastrointestinal surgeries without the need for blood transfusions.
Our team includes an expert physician medical director and dedicated registered nurses. We offer a wide range of strategies to minimize blood loss and improve red blood cell production. Many treatments can take place at a ProMedica infusion center.
As an active member in the the Society for the Advancement of Blood Management (SABM), we have access to the latest industry resources and techniques available to provide the best recommendations for you. 
Treatment Strategies
Often there are proactive steps that lessen or eliminate your need for a blood transfusion. These may include:
Before Surgery
Iron (oral or intravenous)
B12, folic acid, vitamin C
Medications
Nutritional education planning
Synthetic erythropoietin
During Surgery
Electrocautery
Hemodilution
Hemostatic drug therapy
Intraoperative blood cell recovery and reinfusion
 
Meticulous surgical technologies
Minimally invasive surgery
Thrombin and adhesives
Volume expanders
After Surgery
Erythropoietin and iron
Minimal blood draws
How do you know if you need a blood management evaluation?
Don’t hesitate to talk with your doctor if you:
Develop anemia
Have a surgery or procedure scheduled that could result in blood loss
What happens during a blood management evaluation?
You’ll have an in-person or phone call consultation with one of our knowledgeable nurses. Most likely, blood tests will be ordered. After your consultation and review of your blood test results, a treatment plan meeting your specific needs will be developed and shared with you and your physician.
In most cases, any pre- and post-surgery treatments can take place in one of ProMedica’s convenient infusion centers. After your care, our blood management team will follow up with you and your physician.
Talk with your physician to discuss if you are a candidate for the blood management program. Call ProMedica’s blood management program at 419-824-1222.

Your Brain Health Is in Expert Hands
If you’ve been diagnosed with a brain tumor, you’ll need to make some major decisions about your care. We understand this can feel overwhelming. But you’re not alone.
At ProMedica, our whole team — which includes highly specialized neurosurgeons, medical oncologists, radiation oncologists, pathologists, radiologists and nurses — joins together to support every step of your care. And we want you to feel secure in the combined expertise of ProMedica Neurosciences Institute and ProMedica Cancer Institute.
You’ll benefit from a complete spectrum of services. They include diagnosis, evaluation, treatment and follow-up care.
content.overview:
What Is a Brain Tumor?
A brain tumor is a growth or mass of abnormal cells in the brain that may be cancerous (malignant) or noncancerous (benign). Some are formed inside the brain (glioma). Other tumors start as cancer somewhere else in the body and then land in the brain (metastatic). There are also tumors that grow on the outside surface of the brain and create pressure (meningioma). Every type of brain tumor has many levels of severity and there are different treatments for each type.
It’s important to know the risks for developing a brain tumor, especially if you have a family history. Many times, these symptoms may appear: new or changing headaches, seizures, hearing or vision loss, fatigue and cognitive issues. But the type, size and location of a tumor can also dictate the kinds of symptoms you have. If you have any concerns, please talk about them with your family doctor.
content.diagnosis:
Diagnosis
Your family doctor may perform a standard neurological exam to measure your nervous system function. If your doctor has concerns after your exam, a CT scan of your brain may also be ordered.
If a brain tumor is detected from your CT scan, you’ll likely be referred to a neurosurgeon or oncologist. They will evaluate you further, which often includes a biopsy.
During a biopsy, a piece of the tumor is removed and sent to a pathologist for testing. A biopsy can help your doctor decide if the tumor is cancerous, understand how severe it is and detect any growth patterns.
content.treatment:
Treatment Options

Chemotherapy
Radiation
Tumor Removal
Chemotherapy
A medical oncologist may want you to have chemotherapy to stop the tumor from growing.
After surgery, sometimes a systemic or local chemotherapy is also used to keep your tumor from growing back.
Learn more about chemotherapy.
Radiation
Radiation therapy may be recommended after a biopsy or tumor is removed. This is to destroy the tumor or stop its growth. Some brain tumors cannot be removed with surgery. That’s when radiation therapy may be given before, during or after chemotherapy treatment.
Your specialist may recommend Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS), which is a type of radiation therapy. With SRS, one extremely high and targeted dose of radiation is sent to a small tumor. The precise targeting means there’s less chance of damaging healthy cells around the tumor. SRS does not require surgical incisions (cuts) or openings.
Learn more about radiation therapy.
Tumor Removal
For most noncancerous and many cancerous brain tumors, the first treatment step is to perform surgery to remove the tumor. Our highly experienced neurosurgeons use the most advanced tools, such as BrightMatter™ visualization and surgical navigation technology.
Some common types of brain tumor surgery include:
Complete removal: The whole tumor is removed.
Craniectomy: Part of the skull is removed and not replaced.
Craniotomy: Part of the skull is removed and replaced.
Debulking: The size of the tumor is reduced.
Partial removal: Only part of the tumor is removed.
Shunt: Extra fluid in the brain is drained to another part of the body.
Learn more about neurosurgery at ProMedica Toledo Hospital.
Chemotherapy
Chemotherapy
A medical oncologist may want you to have chemotherapy to stop the tumor from growing.
After surgery, sometimes a systemic or local chemotherapy is also used to keep your tumor from growing back.
Learn more about chemotherapy.Radiation
Radiation
Radiation therapy may be recommended after a biopsy or tumor is removed. This is to destroy the tumor or stop its growth. Some brain tumors cannot be removed with surgery. That’s when radiation therapy may be given before, during or after chemotherapy treatment.
Your specialist may recommend Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS), which is a type of radiation therapy. With SRS, one extremely high and targeted dose of radiation is sent to a small tumor. The precise targeting means there’s less chance of damaging healthy cells around the tumor. SRS does not require surgical incisions (cuts) or openings.
Learn more about radiation therapy.Tumor Removal
Tumor Removal
For most noncancerous and many cancerous brain tumors, the first treatment step is to perform surgery to remove the tumor. Our highly experienced neurosurgeons use the most advanced tools, such as BrightMatter™ visualization and surgical navigation technology.
Some common types of brain tumor surgery include:
Complete removal: The whole tumor is removed.
Craniectomy: Part of the skull is removed and not replaced.
Craniotomy: Part of the skull is removed and replaced.
Debulking: The size of the tumor is reduced.
Partial removal: Only part of the tumor is removed.
Shunt: Extra fluid in the brain is drained to another part of the body.
Learn more about neurosurgery at ProMedica Toledo Hospital.
BrightMatter: Innovative Technology to Remove Brain Tumors

ProMedica Toledo Hospital is the first hospital in Ohio to offer patients some of the most important, leading-edge brain surgery technology made available today. It’s called Bright Matter®, and comes with, among other advantages, the benefit of a built-in GPS system, giving neurosurgeons the ability to safely remove previously inoperable tumors.

content.articleContent:
Empowering You with Hope and Healing
A diagnosis of brain cancer can be challenging to accept. It may be a scary time for you and your loved ones as you face the days ahead.
You aren’t alone. The cancer care experts at ProMedica are here to help provide the strength you and your family need for the challenges ahead. We use the latest technology to diagnose and treat a wide variety of brain cancers.
At ProMedica, you’ll find expertise that gives you the energy and courage for the best possible outcomes.
content.approach:
Our Approach
At ProMedica, we work together to provide a personalized treatment plan for each brain tumor patient. Our cancer care team includes highly specialized neurosurgeons, medical oncologists, radiation oncologists, pathologists, radiologists and nurses.
From diagnosis to treatment and follow-up care, you get complete care through every step of your healing journey. You’ll feel secure in the combined, expert care of ProMedica Neurosciences Institute and ProMedica Cancer Institute. They connect you to the latest neurosurgery technologies, treatments, resources and experts.
Access to BrightMatter™ Technology
ProMedica Toledo Hospital is home to Ohio’s first BrightMatter™ technology. This innovative solution combines advanced imaging, planning, navigation and robotics to assist us with complex brain and spine surgeries.
BrightMatter provides our team with the latest advancements in visualization tools. We can perform minimally invasive brain procedures for shorter surgery times and with better results.
Using advanced MRI brain-imaging called diffusion tensor imaging (DTI), we create a highly detailed map of your brain’s white matter pathways. This allows your surgeon to see details of your brain that can't be seen by the naked eye. It also allows access to locations of your brain that couldn’t have been operated on in the past.
Care Coordination and Nurse Navigators
We know cancer treatment can feel overwhelming. We want you to focus on getting better, not trying to keep tests, treatment and doctors straight. A member of your care team or a personal nurse navigator will guide you through every step of treatment, including:
Working side-by-side with you to ensure compassionate, supportive and individualized care.
Scheduling/coordinating appointments, and helping to reduce the amount of time from diagnosis to treatment.
Providing education and support to you and your family.
Facilitating/coordinating care provided by an interdisciplinary team of physicians, including medical, surgical and radiation oncology consults.
Working on behalf of you and your family to remove possible obstacles to care, including insurance issues, medication assistance or lack of transportation.
Communicating with your physician and helping to communicate the physician’s plan of care.
content.diagnosis:
Risks, Symptoms and Diagnosis
Know Your Brain Cancer Risk
Brain tumors are abnormal growths of cells in the brain. They can grow aggressively and take away healthy cell space, blood and nutrients.
Tumors can start in the brain, or be caused when cancer in another part of the body spreads to the brain.
While we still aren’t certain what causes brain tumors, we do know that these factors play a role:
Exposure to toxins or radiation.
Tobacco use.
Weakened immune system.
Your genetics, including inherited syndromes.
Recognize Brain Cancer Signs and Symptoms
Not all brain tumors cause symptoms. And, your symptoms can vary widely based on the size and location of the tumor. Still, being able to recognize these symptoms can help you start a conversation with your doctor:
Clumsiness.
Trouble with walking.
Trouble with speech.
Abnormalities in vision.
Frequent headaches.
Memory loss.
Nausea.
Seizures.
Vomiting.
Unexplained changes in behavior.
Weakness.
Get a Fast and Accurate Diagnosis
If you have symptoms that concern you, it’s best to start with your trusted doctor. During your visit, your family doctor may perform a standard neurological exam to test your nervous system.
If your doctor has a concern, a CT scan or MRI of your brain will likely be the next step.
If a brain tumor is found during diagnostic testing, you will then be referred to a neurosurgeon or oncologist for more specific testing.
A neurosurgeon can perform a biopsy to analyze the tumor. During the biopsy, a sample of the tumor tissue is removed and then sent to a pathologist. When the pathologist studies the tissue, we can:
Learn if your tumor is cancerous.
Evaluate how severe your cancer is.
Measure tumor growth and pinpoint growth patterns.
content.treatment:
Find Effective, Comprehensive Treatment
If you’re diagnosed with a brain tumor, our expert neurology team is here with a variety of treatment choices to heal your cancer.
Chemotherapy
A medical oncologist may suggest chemotherapy after surgery to keep the tumor from growing back. Chemotherapy can also be used to stop tumor growth.
Radiation
Radiation therapy may be needed after a biopsy to destroy your tumor or stop its growth. This is especially useful in cases where a brain tumor can’t be removed with surgery.
Radiation is often used along with other therapies and can be given before, during or after chemotherapy treatment.
Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS)
SRS is a specific type of radiation therapy that allows your surgeon to very precisely target your tumor. This helps lessen the damage to healthy cells that surround it.
Surgery
For most brain tumors, the first step of treatment is to remove the tumor with surgery. Our highly experienced neurosurgeons use the most advanced technology, like BrightMatter, to provide complex surgeries close to home.
Some common surgical procedures we use include:
Shunt: Excess fluid is drained to another part of the body.
Complete removal: All of the tumor is removed.
Partial removal: Only part of the tumor is removed.
Debulking: The size of the tumor is reduced.
Craniotomy: Part of the skull is removed and replaced.
Craniectomy: Part of the skull is removed and not replaced.

content.articleContent:
Care that Delivers Lifesaving Results
Most brain aneurysms don’t cause any health problems. But pressure placed on nerves and nearby brain tissue can sometimes cause aneurysms to rupture and bleed within the brain (hemorrhagic stroke).
When the worst happens, you can count on ProMedica for expert and compassionate care. Using the latest technology and therapies, our neurologists, neurosurgeons, interventional vascular neurologists, and neuroradiologists work together with one goal: to safely place you on the path to recovery.
If you think you may be having an aneurysm rupture, call 911 right away.
content.treatment:
Treatment
Many factors are considered when deciding on treatment for a brain aneurysm. These include your age, the size and location of the aneurysm and your overall health and medical history.
Our brain aneurysm clinic at ProMedica Toledo Hospital uses a patient-centered and multi-disciplinary approach. The clinic provides patients with access to both a cerebrovascular neurosurgeon and an interventional vascular neurologist during the same clinic encounter. That means patients and their families can talk with both doctors about the jointly developed plan to manage the patient’s brain aneurysm. We offer a wide-range of treatment options including surgical clipping, endovascular coiling, flow diversion and observation with follow-up imaging.
Surgical Treatments
It’s our goal to treat you with minimally invasive methods whenever we can. They include medicines and minimally invasive therapies. But sometimes surgery is needed. Your specialist may advise surgery if the aneurysm is in danger of rupturing. There are three primary surgical treatments for a brain aneurysm:
Endovascular coiling: Also called coil embolization, endovascular coiling is a minimally invasive method. This means an incision (cut) in the skull is not needed to treat the cerebral aneurysm.
Open craniotomy (surgical clipping): This procedure uses surgery to remove part of the skull.
Woven Endobridge (WEB) Aneurysm Embolization System: Called The Web, this device is used for treating complex brain aneurysms. In 2019, ProMedica became the first regional center in northern Ohio and Michigan to offer a this new, cutting-edge treatment for brain aneurysms. The device offers patients with complex brain aneurysms a treatment that is less risky and less difficult than previous endovascular therapy.

content.articleContent:
Meet the Challenges of Breast Cancer with Confidence
Breast cancer is the second most common cancer diagnosed in women in the United States. Fortunately, more women than ever are seeking diagnosis and treatment.
Still, it's never easy to be diagnosed with breast cancer. If you or your doctor find something suspicious in your breast, you may feel overwhelmed. And the journey ahead can seem uncertain. With ProMedica Cancer Institute, you’ll find encouragement and assurance every step of the way.
Our teams are recognized as the region’s leading experts in breast cancer care. They also have access to the most current research and technology in the field. We understand this common cancer can feel like it’s upending your life, but you can be confident you’re moving forward to the best possible outcome.
content.approach:
Our Approach
The ProMedica Cancer Institute is home to state-of-the-art diagnostics, technology, treatments and services for breast cancer care. As a patient with us, you’ll have access to leading-edge care.
Accredited, Exceptional Care
Our breast cancer center is accredited by The American College of Surgeons’ National Accreditation Program for Breast Centers (NAPBC). This makes us part of a group of national, professional organizations that are focused on breast health.
We received this accreditation because we’re dedicated to improving quality outcomes for patients with breast disease. To do that, we use evidence-based standards and patient and professional education.
Personalized Treatment Plans
Research suggests that personal attention may improve patient outcomes in cancer care. At ProMedica, we try to make sure you have the same patient navigator coordinate your care from start to finish. We're by your side from diagnosis through treatment with patient education and compassionate support. You can expect personal care every step of the way.
content.diagnosis:
Breast Cancer Signs & Screenings
Risk Factors
Understanding why you may be at risk for breast cancer can help you spot any early warning signs you should discuss with your doctor.
All women should see themselves as having some level of risk for breast cancer. However, if any of the following risk factors also apply to you, your doctor may recommend that you have mammograms earlier or more often:
Increased age.
Obesity.
Personal or a family history of breast cancer.
Prior radiation treatment to the chest.
Tobacco or alcohol use, or both.
Breast Cancer Signs
Often, the first sign of breast cancer is a lump or a change in the feel of the breast. But there are other symptoms that may alert your doctor to possible breast cancer and the need for a mammogram. These include:
Changes in the nipple.
Itchy or irritated breast.
Nipple discharge.
Pain in the breast.
Redness or color changes in the breast.
Swelling of the breast.
Detecting cancer early can increase your chances for recovery and may even save your life. Speak with your doctor right away if you notice any unusual changes in your breasts.
Breast Exams
There are three levels of breast cancer detection. These include breast self-exams, clinical breast exams and mammograms. Your doctor will recommend the exams that are right for you, based on your age and risk factors.
Breast Self-Exams
A breast self-exam is a check-up you can do at home to look for changes or problems in the breast tissue. Your doctor may recommend that you include a monthly self-exam as part of your wellness routine. If so, your doctor will give you instructions on how to do a breast self-exam.
Clinical Breast Exams
Starting in your 20s and 30s, your doctor will include a clinical breast exam as part of your regular well-woman visit. The exam will be done at least every three years.
Mammograms
Mammograms can find a change in your breasts before you can feel it. That’s why ProMedica recommends that you receive a baseline mammogram at 35 years old (25 years old if your mother had breast cancer before the age of 35), then annually beginning at 40 years old.
How to Schedule Your Mammogram
We believe it shouldn’t be hard for you to schedule preventive and diagnostic testing. That’s why we offer just one number to call to schedule a mammogram at any of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. Our schedulers can help you find a convenient time and location. All you have to do is:
Receive an order from your doctor. If your doctor is a ProMedica Physician, you can find this order in your MyChart account.
Call ProMedica Central Scheduling at 419-291-3000 or 1-800-479-8805 to schedule. Or, login to your MyChart account to schedule your mammogram.
Find a mammogram location near you.
Diagnosis
If a mammogram finds something suspicious in your breast, the next step is diagnostic testing. At ProMedica Breast Care and our locations across the ProMedica system, we offer specialized diagnostic tests. They’re given by caring experts in breast cancer and women’s health.
Based on your unique condition and screening results, the needed diagnostic tests may include:
Breast tomosynthesis.
Breast ultrasound.
Dedicated breast MRI scanning.
Digital mammograms.
Image-guided breast biopsies (ultrasound, MRI or stereotactic).
Magnetic seed localization.
Molecular breast imaging scanning.
Breasts have many layers of glandular and fatty tissue. Because of that, sometimes we need to combine several tests to get a complete picture of your breast health.
The screening process can seem confusing and cause anxiety for many women. We strive to guide you through the screening process as quickly and easily as possible. If your exam is diagnostic, we may offer an ultrasound or biopsy that same day if needed to speed up the process of getting a diagnosis. MRIs and MBIs will likely be scheduled out as they must coincide with your menstrual cycle. Here are the screening steps you might expect when you come to ProMedica for breast care:
Clinical breast exam.
Mammogram to detect abnormalities in breast tissue.
Ultrasound to learn if the mass is a cyst or tumor.
Biopsy for lab evaluation.
Another mammogram to confirm the biopsy was in the right place.
MRI or MBI if the biopsy is positive for cancer.
Breast cancer treatment begins.
content.treatment:
Breast Cancer Treatment
Breast cancer treatment is different for every person. Accredited and nationally recognized, the ProMedica Cancer Institute is the largest cancer registry in the region. This means our highly trained and credentialed providers can make sure your care plan includes personalized and exceptional care at a location that’s close to home.
Multidisciplinary Teams, Individualized Plans
ProMedica’s breast cancer team is made up of multidisciplinary cancer professionals including medical, radiation and surgical oncologists. They deliver state-of-the-art care including:
Clinical trials.
Genetic testing and counseling.
Healing care.
Nurse navigator services.
Medicine management counseling.
Precision radiation therapy.
Rehabilitation services.
Survivorship program.
Your breast cancer care plan may include more than one type of treatment. Your ProMedica providers take into account the stage and type of your breast cancer, its location in your breast, your risk factors and whether it has spread to other parts of the body. Then they will recommend a course of treatments that may be used separately or together in your care plan.
Chemotherapy
Chemotherapy for breast cancer treatment may be given before or after surgery, and also when breast cancer has spread to other areas of the body. It is given through an IV.
Biotherapy (or Immunology)
Biotherapy, also referred to as immunotherapy, uses your own body’s immune system to help fight the cancer.
Hormone Therapy
Hormone therapy blocks hormones that are causing the breast cancer to grow. It’s used for hormone receptor positive breast cancers.
Radiation
Radiation therapy for breast cancer uses high energy X-rays to shrink and kill cancer cells. It’s usually given after surgery or chemotherapy to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back.
Surgery
Surgical treatment is used to remove the cancer and possibly the lymph nodes and healthy tissue around the cancer. Types of surgical treatments for breast cancer include lumpectomy and mastectomy.
A Surgeon Dedicated to Breast Oncology
Jessica Burns, MD, is the region’s only fellowship-trained surgeon in breast oncology. She provides patients with high-quality care and the latest breast surgery techniques. This includes breast conservation surgery and oncoplastic techniques, as well as nipple-sparing mastectomy.
View Dr. Burns' profile.
Care Coordination and Nurse Navigators
Working side-by-side with you to ensure compassionate, supportive and individualized care.
Scheduling/coordinating appointments, and helping to reduce the amount of time from diagnosis to treatment.
Providing education and support to you and your family.
Facilitating/coordinating care provided by an interdisciplinary team of physicians, including medical, surgical and radiation oncology consults.
Working on behalf of you and your family to remove possible obstacles to care, including insurance issues, medication assistance or lack of transportation.
Communicating with your physician and helping to communicate the physician’s plan of care.

content.articleContent:
Image Guided Breast Biopsy
Early detection is key to breast health. You and your doctor have decided a breast biopsy is the best choice. One such biopsy type is an image guided breast biopsy. Be assured in our prompt, efficient service so you can know; the sooner the better.
What is an image guided breast biopsy?
It’s an office procedure that’s minimally invasive, which means it doesn’t involve surgery, requires very little time to perform, and results in minimal discomfort for you.
It gives your radiologist greater visibility and greater accuracy to reach the part of your breast that may be in question. It requires a local anesthetic, a nick in your skin, and a small, ultrasound-guided tool to navigate the area.
What are the benefits of image guided breast biopsy over conventional biopsies?
The common benefits to you are:
Less discomfort
Fewer after-effects
A smaller incision
Is image guided breast biopsy the best choice for you?
This is a decision for you and your doctor. Openly discuss the options, benefits and effectiveness.
Want to know more? Easily access this test and further information from the Breast Care Center at ProMedica Toledo Hospital.

Understanding Breast MRI
You want a thorough understanding of your breast health. A breast MRI is an advanced technique that, when paired with conventional mammography, gives you and your doctor even more information to grasp your condition and act with targeted accuracy.
What is breast MRI?
Breast MRI is sophisticated MRI technology that uses a computer, magnetic field, and radio waves – instead of X-rays – to produce images of your breast tissue.
Remember that breast MRI doesn’t replace mammography, but is a powerful tool used to provide additional information about your breast health.
For which conditions is a breast MRI used?
It can be used for various conditions and situations, including:
Determine cancer’s extent
Evaluate patients with positive surgical margins for residual cancer
Monitor cancer therapy
Exclude cancer’s existence in high-risk women
Detect occult cancer
Characterize lesions
Evaluate implant integrity and detect cancer in women with breast augmentation
Is breast MRI offered near you?
In early 2019, our Breast MRI department underwent a renovation and installed a Siemens 1.5T Aera MRI machine right here in northwest Ohio at the Breast Care Center at ProMedica Toledo Hospital.

Surviving Cancer with Rehabilitation
You’re ready to move past living with your cancer treatment side effects and want to be stronger, more vibrant, and feel better. You’re a survivor. We’re right here with you.
Cancer treatment can be very toxic and often causes significant pain, fatigue and disability for survivors. Through our cancer rehab program, we help survivors minimize these side effects to have the best quality of life possible.
As a patient, you'll receive comprehensive cancer rehabilitation treatment to improve the symptoms affecting your daily functioning and quality of life. You’re ready to work through side effects such as fatigue, weakness, insomnia, memory loss, fear, anxiety, and depression. You’re ready to enjoy life.
Frequently Asked Questions About Cancer Rehab
Is cancer rehabilitation covered by my health insurance?
Yes. Cancer rehabilitation services are reimbursable by health most insurance providers. You get access to world-class follow up cancer care, without added medical costs.
When should I start cancer rehab treatment?
Any time you and your doctor feel you’re ready. Whether you’ve just begun or are finished with your treatment, or if you experience late effects or unresolved issues from long-ago treatment, we’re here. No matter your prognosis, cancer stage, or recovery phase. You just need your doctor’s referral.
What kind of health care professional provides cancer rehabilitation treatment?
Our rehabilitation care is specially trained to treat survivors of all forms of cancer. They’re medical experts at the top of their fields and comprise a variety of disciplines:
Doctors
Physical therapists
Occupational therapists
Speech and swallowing therapists
Registered dietitians and nutritionists
Mental health professionals
How will you know what services I need?
After a thorough doctor’s evaluation, you’re assigned to a team of medical specialists according to your individual needs. You’ll get a personalized rehabilitation plan, with goals like increased strength and energy, pain alleviation, improved physical function, emotional balance, and an immune system boost.
We take into consideration these factors that impact physical healing:
Diet
Sleep issues
Existing pain, endurance
Strength
Exercise habits
Emotional outlook
What should I bring to my first visit?
Please wear comfortable clothing and walking shoes suitable to physical activity. To your first visit, bring your
Insurance card.
Medical history information.
Current medications and dosage list.
Physician referral if your doctor office did not send it directly to your rehab site.

content.articleContent:
You're Never Alone During Your Fight Against Cancer
Cancer affects more than your physical health: It can also take a huge toll on your emotional and mental well-being. During treatment, and even well beyond, you may not feel like yourself. That’s why it’s essential to have support as you face the challenges of cancer treatment.
This support can and should come from many places, including your family, friends and care team here at ProMedica. Having a network of people walking beside you on this journey will help you face the future with hope and optimism.
Remember, you’re never alone during your fight against cancer. Along with your personal network, we can connect you to support groups and community resources. We also have a whole team of counselors, social workers and other providers ready to meet your unique needs.
You listened and offered encouragement.Lorraine M.
content.expect:
What to Expect During Cancer Treatment
Cancer treatment can change how you look, feel and go about your daily tasks. While these changes usually don’t last, it’s possible some will be long-term. It may be helpful to know that, as difficult as they are, some changes are common in people going through cancer treatment and recovery. If you need support as you deal with these changes, never be afraid to ask for help.
Physical Changes
Cognitive and Emotional Changes
Dietary Changes
Physical Changes
It’s common to go through some physical changes during cancer treatment. But it’s important to keep in mind that every person’s body responds to treatment in its own way. It’s common for cancer patients to go through these changes:
Bowel and bladder problems.
Burning, numbness or tingling in your hands and feet.
Having less strength and endurance.
Trouble swallowing.
Fatigue.
Hair loss.
Menopause symptoms.
Mouth sores and teeth problems.
Pain.
Surgery scars.
Swelling.


Some changes in your body may mean there are other health problems. Your treatment plan may need to be adjusted. Always talk with your doctor if you have any of these changes:
Confusion, dizziness or loss of balance.
Trouble breathing.
Extreme tiredness that gets worse.
Persistent constipation.
Trouble waking up.
Nausea, vomiting or diarrhea that can’t be controlled.
Cognitive and Emotional Changes
Cancer treatment can affect the way you feel and think. As your body changes, the way you see and think about yourself can also change. This is normal and you shouldn’t feel afraid or ashamed to share what you’re dealing with.
Mental and emotional changes may include:
Anger.
Anxiety.
Trouble concentrating.
Depression.
Fear.
Memory loss.
Dietary Changes
Many people have changes in their appetite as they go through cancer treatment. Because of certain medicines, you may not feel hungry. However, it’s very important to eat nutritious, balanced meals. A healthy diet can help you stay strong. Certain foods can even help you manage some side effects of cancer treatment such as nausea and fatigue.
Talk to your doctor if you’re concerned about your diet or appetite. Your doctor can make meal suggestions or connect you with a dietitian who can address specific concerns.
You may want to keep a daily record of what you eat and drink. Note the type of food you eat, how much you eat and what time you eat. This can help your doctor learn if you’re getting the right nutrients and enough calories.
Other tips for your diet include:
Eating frequently: Even if you have less appetite, it’s important to eat regularly. If you’re losing weight, eat a small meal or snack every few hours. This will help you keep your weight up and get the nutrition you need.
Eating protein and healthy fats: These nutrients give you long-lasting energy. Protein also helps your body repair and heal itself. Protein and healthy fats can be found in seeds, salmon, chicken breast, hamburger, tofu, tempeh, lentils, milk, nuts, nut butters and eggs.
Staying hydrated: Drink plenty of fluids. Dehydration adds to fatigue, so drink water, unsweetened tea, 100% fruit juice or sports drinks. Avoid soda and sugary drinks.
Physical Changes
Physical Changes
It’s common to go through some physical changes during cancer treatment. But it’s important to keep in mind that every person’s body responds to treatment in its own way. It’s common for cancer patients to go through these changes:
Bowel and bladder problems.
Burning, numbness or tingling in your hands and feet.
Having less strength and endurance.
Trouble swallowing.
Fatigue.
Hair loss.
Menopause symptoms.
Mouth sores and teeth problems.
Pain.
Surgery scars.
Swelling.


Some changes in your body may mean there are other health problems. Your treatment plan may need to be adjusted. Always talk with your doctor if you have any of these changes:
Confusion, dizziness or loss of balance.
Trouble breathing.
Extreme tiredness that gets worse.
Persistent constipation.
Trouble waking up.
Nausea, vomiting or diarrhea that can’t be controlled.

Mental and emotional changes may include:

Dietary Changes
Many people have changes in their appetite as they go through cancer treatment. Because of certain medicines, you may not feel hungry. However, it’s very important to eat nutritious, balanced meals. A healthy diet can help you stay strong. Certain foods can even help you manage some side effects of cancer treatment such as nausea and fatigue.
Talk to your doctor if you’re concerned about your diet or appetite. Your doctor can make meal suggestions or connect you with a dietitian who can address specific concerns.
You may want to keep a daily record of what you eat and drink. Note the type of food you eat, how much you eat and what time you eat. This can help your doctor learn if you’re getting the right nutrients and enough calories.
Other tips for your diet include:
Eating frequently: Even if you have less appetite, it’s important to eat regularly. If you’re losing weight, eat a small meal or snack every few hours. This will help you keep your weight up and get the nutrition you need.
Eating protein and healthy fats: These nutrients give you long-lasting energy. Protein also helps your body repair and heal itself. Protein and healthy fats can be found in seeds, salmon, chicken breast, hamburger, tofu, tempeh, lentils, milk, nuts, nut butters and eggs.
Staying hydrated: Drink plenty of fluids. Dehydration adds to fatigue, so drink water, unsweetened tea, 100% fruit juice or sports drinks. Avoid soda and sugary drinks.
content.care:
Care Coordination and Nurse Navigators
We know cancer treatment can feel overwhelming. We want you to focus on getting better, not trying to keep tests, treatment and doctors straight. A member of your care team or a personal nurse navigator will guide you through every step of treatment, including:
Working side-by-side with you to ensure compassionate, supportive and individualized care.
Scheduling/coordinating appointments, and helping to reduce the amount of time from diagnosis to treatment.
Providing education and support to you and your family.
Facilitating/coordinating care provided by an interdisciplinary team of physicians, including medical, surgical and radiation oncology consults.
Working on behalf of you and your family to remove possible obstacles to care, including insurance issues, medication assistance or lack of transportation.
Communicating with your physician and helping to communicate the physician’s plan of care.
content.survivorship:
Our Services
Support After Treatment and the Cancer Survivorship Program
The end of cancer treatment is a time to celebrate, but it’s also a time of change. You’ve entered into a new phase called “survivorship.” We want to help you grow and thrive in your life after cancer treatment. The ProMedica Cancer Institute Survivor Center is here to guide you every step of the way.
You can take part in our Cancer Survivorship Program even if you didn’t receive your cancer treatment at a ProMedica facility. It’s open to anyone with a cancer diagnosis who has completed active treatment (which may include chemotherapy, radiation or surgery). We want everyone to benefit from the support and resources of our unique program.
Our team will coordinate all aspects of your physical, mental and emotional recovery after cancer treatment. We want you to embrace this time of change with the follow-up care and support you need.
To make an appointment with the Cancer Survivorship Program, call 419-824-1952.
Meet our cancer survivorship specialist
Webinars
To learn more, watch our ProMedica Cancer Institute Survivorship Webinars:
ProMedica Cancer Institute Webinar Talking Nutrition and Cancer Survivorship
Life After Cancer: Introduction to ProMedica Women’s Sexual Health program
Finding Purpose After Cancer Diagnoses or other Health or Life Crisis
Addressing Psychosocial Issues after Cancer — Coping, Finances, Insurance
Cancer Survivorship: Life After Cancer Treatment
Girl Talk: Menopause
Girl Talk: Pelvic Pain
Girl Talk: Prolapse and Incontinence
Follow-Up Care
The first step after your cancer treatment ends is to make an appointment at the ProMedica Cancer Institute Survivor Center. This can be done through a self-referral or through a doctor’s referral. A nurse practitioner and an oncologist will review your health and treatment history.
Make sure to let your nurse and doctor know if you’re having any new symptoms or having trouble doing your daily activities. You can also use this time to ask questions about the long-term effects of treatment, such as sleep problems or intimacy issues.
During this first visit, we may do a physical exam or order tests to check if the cancer may be coming back. We can perform risk assessments to learn if you’re at risk for other cancers. We’ll also suggest healthy lifestyle changes.
From here, we’ll come up with your follow-up medical plan and share it with your primary doctor. You will also receive a Cancer Treatment Summary and Survivorship Care Plan. This document reviews details of your cancer treatment and a plan for checking your health going forward.
The plan may recommend medical and support services such as:
Cancer rehabilitation.
Dietary education.
Educational seminars.
Financial counseling.
Genetic testing and counseling.
Medicine management help.
Psychological services.
Social work support.
Speech therapy.
Healing Care Program
Our Healing Care Program helps you on your journey to health during and after cancer treatment. Classes and one-on-one sessions are free to you and your family for two years after your last treatment date.
Healing Care sessions can be scheduled in medical oncology, before or after radiation, or at another time you choose, depending on the site. Video visits are also available on the first Thursday from 8 a.m. to 12 p.m. and the third Tuesday from 12:30 p.m. to 4:30 p.m.
The program includes:
Relaxation and meditation: Focus on breathing along with visualization to calm the mind and body.
Guided imagery: Voice guided meditation provides positive, healing images to help you cope with and decrease stress.
Aromatherapy: Essential oils are provided for inhalation to help you relax and improve your mood.
Ear seeds: use of non-invasive ear seeds applied with mild pressure to specific areas on both outer ears. May help calm, provide comfort, and/or enhance relaxation.
Healing touch: A practitioner provides gentle touch to help balance and align your energy. This may also be done without touching the body, if you prefer.
Psi Bands: apply pressure to your wrist to help reduce nausea.
Relaxing music: Calming music helps to soothe and relax your mind and body.
Sleep tips: Learn helpful solutions for getting better sleep at night.
Other helpful resources: Meditation, movement, education, classes, and more may be available in your area.
For further information or to schedule an appointment call 419-824-5538.
ProMedica Cancer Institute Women’s Sexual Health
Living with cancer is not only physically, emotionally and spiritually taxing, but also sexually challenging. The experts at ProMedica Cancer Institute Women’s Sexual Health are specially trained in understanding the unique physical and emotional effects that cancer treatment can have on a woman’s sexuality. Some physiological examples include:
Decreased sexual drive (libido).
Orgasmic disorders.
Sexual pain.
Narrowing of the vagina from radiation treatment.
Vulvar and vaginal skin disorders, including burning, itching and lesions on the skin.
Vulvar pain (vulvodynia).
Your First Appointment
Your initial appointment at ProMedica Cancer Institute Women’s Sexual Health will last about 30 minutes. You’ll meet with one of our highly specialized sexual health providers to discuss your concerns and goals. They will also perform a physical exam.
We will work with you to design a plan that meets your individual needs. This plan may include:
Medical management techniques and treatments.
Referrals to counseling or educational services.
Referrals to members of our multi-disciplinary team, including menopausal, pelvic pain and urogynecology specialists.
Follow-up appointment requests.
Making an Appointment
Your doctor may refer you to the ProMedica Cancer Institute Women’s Sexual Health program, or you may contact us directly. To make an appointment or to learn more, please call 567-585-0393 and ask for a member of the ProMedica Cancer Institute Women’s Sexual Health team.
Bridge to Fitness Program
It’s important to stay active after cancer treatment. Getting back to the strength and mobility you may have lost can help you on your road to recovery. ProMedica’s Bridge to Fitness program offers an exercise plan that’s guided by professionals. Each exercise plan is tailored to your unique needs and fitness level.
If you’re interested in our Bridge to Fitness program, talk to your doctor or call 419-824-1733 to learn more.
There is a small cost to take part in the program (often less than $6 per session) and qualified participants pay nothing. These exercise classes are open to patients of ProMedica Cancer Institute, ProMedica Toledo Hospital Weight Loss Surgery Center and ProMedica Flower Hospital Cardiac and Pulmonary Rehab programs.
Giving Back
As a cancer survivor, you may want to support other patients and their families who have been touched by cancer. Whether you donate goods or services, take part in a fundraising event or make a tax-deductible monetary gift, your help makes a major, positive impact.
As a not-for-profit organization, our cancer services can always use charitable gifts. Donations are used to improve treatment technology, enhance community awareness and provide support programs for people and families who are dealing with the overwhelming effects of cancer.
Learn more about making a donation.
I feel lucky to have this level of care. ~ Lucy D.
To make an appointment with the Cancer Survivorship Program, call 419-824-1952

content.articleContent:
About Cardiac Arrest
You may have heard the heart term cardiac arrest. But, do you know what cardiac arrest is and what to do if you see someone suddenly collapse?
Cardiac arrest occurs when electrical impulses in your heart become abnormal and your heart suddenly stops beating.
Call 911 at the first sign of any heart attack symptoms. Don't hesitate. Every second counts.

content.articleContent:
Strengthen Your Heart with Cardiac Rehab
Live longer, live stronger, and lessen your chance for another cardiac event. Our cardiac rehab program is designed to reduce your risk of other complications so you can live an active and normal life within the limits of your disease.
With cardiac rehab you can:
Increase your energy level and spirits
Learn how to exercise safely
Resume normal activities safely
Understand how to recognize symptoms of heart problems
Manage stress to improve your heart health
Adjust your lifestyle to decrease risks for future heart problems
Boost you and your loved ones’ confidence
Decrease anxiety about managing heart problems
Quit smoking to decrease risks of heart problems
Learn how to eat heart healthy
More About Cardiac Rehabilitation
If you have a heart condition, your healthcare provider may recommend a cardiac rehab program to help you recover.
Where do cardiac rehab sessions take place?
Promedica offers in-person cardiac rehabilition at all of our hospitals as well as virtual at-home sessions through our partner, Recora. Visit our page to see if our virtual program is right for you.
Who should participate in a cardiac rehab program?
Talk to your doctor if you have or have had:
Stable angina
Heart attack
Open heart surgery such as coronary bypass or heart valve surgery
Angioplasty
Stent replacement
Heart transplant
Heart failure
What is included in a cardiac rehab plan?
A team of experienced professionals will help you develop an individualized care plan. Your plan will include:
Initial health assessment by an experienced cardiac rehab staff member
Pre- and post-functional exercise evaluation
Personalized exercise program
Continuous EKG heart-monitored exercise sessions
Individualized risk factor modification
Ongoing contact with physicians involved in your care
Individual and group education and support
Discharge evaluation and recommendations

content.articleContent:
Understanding Cardio-Oncology
As part of your cancer care, you may be given drugs or radiation treatment to kill cancer cells. Sometimes the normal cells in and around your heart may also be harmed, causing lasting damage. This is called cardio toxicity. Your risk increases if you already have heart disease.
The cardio-oncology program at ProMedica Cancer Institute balances these risks. Our team of cardiologists and hematologists/oncologists work with you and your primary care provider to lessen the cardio toxicity that may be caused by your cancer treatment.
Cardio-oncology is appropriate at any stage of your cancer treatment or survivorship journey. Sometimes heart issues may surface long after cancer treatment is complete.
Do you need a cardio-oncology evaluation?
Your doctor bases your need for a cardio-oncology evaluation on:
The type of cancer you have
The cancer treatment plan developed for your cancer
Your current and past heart health
Any changes in your heart health during or any time after treatment – even years after your treatment completion
For more information, call ProMedica Cancer Institute at 877-291-1441. Ask for the cardio-oncology clinic.
What happens at a cardio-oncology clinic appointment?
You’ll see a cardiologist in our clinic, located in ProMedica Hickman Cancer Center, a department of ProMedica Toledo Hospital, on the campus of ProMedica Flower Hospital in Sylvania, Ohio. The cardiologist will review your heart function and health history (such as age, gender, BMI, and history of heart conditions).
The doctor may order special tests including cardiac-specific blood tests and an echocardiogram with strain imaging. The echocardiogram, a special cardiac ultrasound, evaluates the function of your heart muscle.
After the evaluation, the cardiologist, if needed, may:
Prescribe drugs or treatments to help protect your heart during your cancer treatment.
Develop a plan to monitor and improve your heart health following cancer treatment – which may include additional visits to the cardio-oncology clinic.
Work with your oncologist to adjust your cancer treatment to lessen harmful effects to your heart.
Please know: We will not delay your cancer treatment. As always, your treatment will begin as soon as possible.
How to make an appointment
Talk with your oncologist or primary care provider to decide if you are a candidate for the cardio-oncology clinic.
Call ProMedica Cancer Institute at 877-291-1441. Ask for the cardio-oncology clinic.

content.articleContent:
Nationally Recognized Heart Surgery Close to Home
When you or a loved one needs heart surgery, you want expert care and the comforts of home. We believe you should have both, because home is where your heart should be. Experience nationally-recognized heart surgery close to home.
Our highly distinguished heart surgeons provide nationally recognized care right here in northwest Ohio. Our team performs more cardiothoracic surgeries than any other group in the region – more than 900 surgeries every year. We use state-of-the-art technology and surgical techniques for improved patient outcomes and we work hard to keep you close to home for diagnosis, treatment, recovery and follow-up.
Our team of cardiothoracic surgeons has earned national recognition from organizations like U.S. News & World Report, The Society of Thoracic Surgeons and other hospital rating and ranking organizations.
content.approach:
Our Approach
Commitment to Quality
Because we’re committed to quality and safety, we work tirelessly to improve the care we provide to our heart surgery patients, and our clinical outcomes. You can count on us to never stop searching for answers or working to get you back to the life you love.
The Most Experienced in the Region
Heart surgery is what we do. All day. Every day. Our board-certified, experienced and specially trained surgeons are some of the most skilled in their field, performing more cardiothoracic surgeries than anyone else in the region — that’s more than 900 cardiothoracic surgeries every year.
Learn about other types of heart surgery at ProMedica.
Long History of Success
Our heart surgery program has a long history of success, caring for patients requiring heart surgery in the Toledo area for more than 25 years. At your side every step of the way — from your first consultation through recovery — we’ll be there to help ease your mind, decide on the best surgical treatment for you and support your path to healing.
Nationally Recognized Surgeons
Our program is nationally recognized by The Society of Thoracic Surgeons and U.S. News & World Report.
The Society of Thoracic Surgeons
Our heart surgery team has earned a distinguished three-star rating from The Society of Thoracic Surgeons. This honor recognizes our team for the highest level of patient care and some of the nation’s best surgical outcomes. This rating, which marks the highest category of quality, places our team among the elite.
U.S. News & World Report

content.surgery:
Before & After Surgery
What to Expect Before Heart Surgery
Before your surgery, you’ll need several tests including blood work, chest X-ray, electrocardiogram (ECG) and a test of the arteries in your neck. Your surgeon may also make changes to your current prescriptions or recommend new medications to begin taking before your surgery.
You’ll hear from your surgeon’s office regarding day-of surgery instructions, such as what to do about eating, drinking and bathing. Call your surgeon’s office if you have any concerns about day-of instructions.
If you begin to experience chest pain, shortness of breath, flu-like symptoms, rash or fever, call your surgeon’s office immediately.
What to Expect After Heart Surgery
Cardiothoracic surgery is complex, so your procedure could take anywhere from three to five hours. Your care team will provide updates to your family throughout your surgery and into recovery.
After surgery, your family members and loved ones will be able to visit you in the intensive care unit (ICU). Once recovery milestones have been met, you will be transferred from the ICU to a step-down unit.
As you continue to recover in the hospital, your care team will help you:
Eat more.
Manage pain.
Move more.
You should be ready to go home from the hospital three to five days after surgery. A discharge planner from the hospital will meet with you to discuss your needs for home health care and details on your cardiac rehab program.

content.articleContent:
About Carotid Artery Disease
Carotid artery disease, also called carotid artery stenosis, is a common cause for stroke. You want to understand more about this vascular disease and the risks for yourself, or for someone you care for.
The carotid arteries are the main blood vessels, one on each side of your neck, that carry blood up to your brain. If you’re diagnosed with this disease, it means a fatty deposit (plaque) has built up in one or both of the carotid arteries and this plaque is restricting blood flow to your brain. Pieces of this plaque can break off and briefly block the artery, causing a transient ischemic attack (TIA) or “mini stroke,” or break off and completely block the artery, causing a stroke.

Here to Help You Prevent, Treat and Heal
Every year, more than 12,000 women in the United States are diagnosed with cervical cancer. The disease impacts a woman’s reproductive and overall health.
But the good news is that it can be prevented. It’s highly treatable when caught in its earliest stages.
You can have confidence in the women’s health and cervical cancer experts at the ProMedica Cancer Institute. They’re committed to personal, compassionate care for you.
You’ll have access to the most current research and technology in cervical cancer screening and treatment. With convenient locations across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan, it’s our mission to help you achieve your best possible outcome — close to home.
content.approach:
Our Approach
Highest Standards for Care
The ProMedica Cancer Institute is accredited by multiple national organizations for cancer care. These credentials recognize our expertise and achievements in meeting the highest standards in our fields. We are accredited by:
The American College of Radiology
The Commission on Cancer (CoC)
The National Cancer Institute’s Quality Assurance Review Center
The Radiation Therapy Oncology Group
Leading Cancer Research and Technology
As a cancer patient at ProMedica, you’ll have access to the most current methods and treatments in cancer care. This includes extreme precision radiation therapy, cancer genetic testing and counseling, clinical trials, pharmacy counseling, rehabilitation services, healing care and the survivorship program.
Sexual Health Clinic for Female Cancer Survivors
We are specially trained in understanding the unique physical and emotional effects that cancer treatment can have on a woman’s sexuality. Through the ProMedica Cancer Institute Women’s Sexual Health program, we work with you to design a plan that meets your individual needs.
Care Coordination and Nurse Navigators
We know cancer treatment can feel overwhelming. We want you to focus on getting better, not trying to keep tests, treatment and doctors straight. A member of your care team or a personal nurse navigator will guide you through every step of treatment, including:
Working side-by-side with you to ensure compassionate, supportive and individualized care.
Scheduling/coordinating appointments, and helping to reduce the amount of time from diagnosis to treatment.
Providing education and support to you and your family.
Facilitating/coordinating care provided by an interdisciplinary team of physicians, including medical, surgical and radiation oncology consults.
Working on behalf of you and your family to remove possible obstacles to care, including insurance issues, medication assistance or lack of transportation.
Communicating with your physician and helping to communicate the physician’s plan of care.
content.risks:
Understanding the Risks and Symptoms of Cervical Cancer
When cervical cancer is found early, the chances for recovery are high. That’s why early detection is so important.
Determine Your Risk Factors
When it comes to detecting cancer, knowledge is power. You’ll want to understand your family health history, your own health conditions and how your lifestyle can contribute to cervical cancer. This will help you spot any warning signs and guide the conversations you need to have with your doctor.
If any of the following risk factors apply to you, speak with your doctor about which screenings are recommended and how often you should have them.
Age.
Excess weight.
History of herpes.
Immune system deficiency.
Personal or family history of cervical cancer.
Smoking.
Use of oral contraceptives.
Your mother took the medicine DES (diethylstilbestrol) while pregnant with you.
Recognize the Symptoms
If you notice any symptoms of cervical cancer, time is of the essence. Talk with your doctor right away, especially if you’re at higher risk.
Cervical cancer symptoms can include:
Abnormal vaginal bleeding (after intercourse, after menopause or between periods).
Pain during sex.
Pelvic pain.
Periods that are longer or heavier than usual.
Unusual discharge (may contain some blood).
Understand the Relationship Between HPV and Cervical Cancer
Almost 93% of all cervical cancer cases are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), a very common virus among sexually active people.
HPV alone doesn’t cause cervical cancer, but it may when it’s combined with other risk factors.
Most people who are exposed to HPV won’t develop symptoms — and their immune systems will likely clear the virus from their bodies in about two years. Still, certain strains of HPV cause cells of the cervix to change and become cancerous in some women.
HPV can be prevented by getting the HPV vaccine and by using a condom during sex.
Know How Smoking Impacts the Development of Cervical Cancer
Medical studies suggest that tobacco and its by-products can cause damage to the DNA of cervical cells and cause them to become cancerous. That’s why it’s important to quit smoking as a way to help prevent cervical cancer, especially if you’re already at higher risk.
Find a ProMedica tobacco cessation program.
content.diagnosis:
Diagnosis and Treating Cervical Cancer
Get an Accurate Cervical Cancer Diagnosis
At ProMedica, we recommend regular pelvic exams, Pap tests and HPV tests to help prevent cervical cancer. General screening recommendations from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists are as follows:
Under 21 years: no screening.
21 – 29 years old: Pap test every 3 years.
30 – 65 years old: combined Pap test and HPV test every 5 years OR Pap test every 3 years OR HPV test every 5 years.
Screening recommendations depend on your age and health history. Your healthcare provider can help you choose the best exam schedule for you. The doctor can also recommend any added testing or screening for you, based on your unique history and needs. Talk with your doctor about scheduling a screening.
Your recommended screenings may include:
Pelvic exams: Typically, a pelvic exam is the first step in diagnosing gynecologic cancers. During a pelvic exam, your doctor will be able to note changes in the size or shape of your cervix.
Pap tests: Cell changes on the cervix called precancers can become cervical cancer if they aren’t treated. A Pap test, also sometimes called a Pap smear, can help your doctor test for these cell changes.
Colposcopy: If the results of your Pap test are abnormal, your doctor will recommend a procedure called a colposcopy. This lets your doctor examine the surface of your cervix to find any abnormal areas.
Biopsy: If an abnormal area is seen during a colposcopy, a biopsy will be done to learn if it’s cancer.
HPV tests: These tests let you know whether or not you have HPV, which can produce cancerous cells. It’s a good first step if you’re having symptoms.
Learn more about cervical cancer screening.
Find Expert Cervical Cancer Treatment
It can feel overwhelming to be diagnosed with cervical cancer and have to navigate your treatment choices. Especially since cervical cancer treatment differs based on your cancer type and stage.
But you can count on the ProMedica Cancer Institute to help you understand your condition and guide your treatment decisions. We’re accredited and recognized as the largest cancer program in the region. That means our highly trained and credentialed medical, radiation and surgical oncologists will offer you access to:
Clinical trials.
Genetic testing and counseling.
Healing care.
Nurse navigator services.
Medicine management counseling.
Precision radiation therapy.
Rehabilitation services.
Survivorship program.
Once your doctors determine the stage and location of your cervical cancer, they will recommend a treatment plan. The plan may include one therapy or a combination of several therapies.
Chemotherapy
Chemotherapy for cervical cancer treatment, which is administered through an IV, may be given before or after surgery. It may also be provided in cases where the cancer has spread to other areas of the body.
Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy (HIPEC)
HIPEC treats metastatic (stage IV) cervical cancer during the surgery to remove your tumor. It kills the remaining microscopic tumor cells by filling your abdominal cavity with heated chemotherapy.
Immunotherapy (or Biotherapy)
Immunotherapy is also referred to as biotherapy. It uses your body’s own immune system to fight cervical cancer.
Radiation Therapy
Radiation therapy uses high energy X-rays to shrink and kill cancer cells. It’s usually given after surgery or chemotherapy to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back.
Surgery
Surgery is used to remove the cancer, and possibly the lymph nodes and healthy tissue around the cancer. Types of surgical treatments for cervical cancer include Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP), conization and hysterectomies.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Chemotherapy
Your doctor has recommended chemotherapy and you want to know what this means for you. What is chemotherapy? It’s the use of medications to treat cancer. Depending on the cancer type and its stage, chemotherapy is used to treat cancer, keep it from spreading, slow its cell growth, or to relieve its symptoms.
Chemotherapy, commonly referred to as chemo, destroys cancer cells and stops them from growing or multiplying. Chemotherapy can be used along with radiation therapy, surgery, or both.
How is chemotherapy given?
You may be treated in your doctor’s office, a clinic in the hospital, or at home. Some common methods include:
Intravenous (through your veins)
Oral (by mouth)
Intramuscular (injected deep into the muscle)
Intrathecal (injected into the spinal canal)
Sometimes, a more permanent catheter type is recommended to avoid repeated painful needle sticks into your vein. These permanent catheters are called “central venous catheters” and are placed under your skin’s surface. Chemotherapy, blood, and IV fluids can be given through this catheter, and blood for lab tests can be drawn from this site.
An implantable port can also be used to deliver chemotherapy. It’s round in shape and is usually surgically inserted under your skin surface on the chest wall between your neck and shoulder. To use the port, the nurse will insert a needle through your skin surface to access it.
How long does chemotherapy treatment last?
Your dosage schedule is individualized to your treatment plan. This may last a few weeks, up to a year, or longer with varying cycle frequency. Treatments can be once a week, once a month, or other intervals. Treatments are followed by rest cycles to give your body time to build healthy new cells and regain strength.
What are the side effects of chemotherapy?
Common side effects may include:
Fatigue
Infections
Nausea and vomiting
Hair loss
Anxiety, fear, anger, and depression due to life stress and chemotherapy’s effects on your mood
Mouth and throat sores
Anemia
Your potential side effects will depend on your drugs and dosages used to treat your cancer. Your doctor will prepare you for these side effects and recommend ways to cope and manage them including:
Nutrition for managing fatigue and nausea
Emotional support
Opportunities to discuss your unique experience and explore complimentary therapies
Resources for and information about hair loss
Infection control and education

content.articleContent:
About the Child Life Program
The Child Life program at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital seeks to support children and families coping with the emotional impact of childhood illness. We help your child understand and cope with his or her illness, and adjust to our hospital environment.
Our team consists of certified Child Life Specialists, a music therapist, a certified teacher, and technology support staff focused on reducing stress for you and your child.

Comprehensive Care and Support for Your Child
A cancer diagnosis can turn a family’s world upside down. You have questions and need answers fast. You need doctors with compassion and expertise.
At ProMedica, our goal is to find the best treatment for your child. Our Debbie Brass Children’s Cancer Center is part of the ProMedica Cancer Institute. This means you’ll have access to skilled specialists, the latest technology and the newest therapy choices.
Your ProMedica team will be with your family for every part of the cancer journey. From diagnosis to treatment to recovery — we’ll be here to support you when you need it most.
content.approach:
Our Approach
With ProMedica by your side, you can rest easy knowing your child will be getting the best possible care close to home. As part of the ProMedica Cancer Institute, we can access a large network of specialists and the latest treatments.
The Institute has also received several accreditations from national cancer organizations. These recognitions show our dedication to providing the highest quality care.
Wherever the cancer journey takes your child, our team is here to help. Together, we’ll create a plan that fits your family’s unique needs.
Access to the Latest Technology and Treatments
The ProMedica Debbie Brass Children’s Cancer Center is the only member in the region of the National Children’s Oncology Group. This group is the world’s largest organization dedicated to pediatric cancer research. With this resource, your child will have access to the latest treatments and clinical trials.
We can offer the most advanced cancer technology available today. This includes the latest diagnostic tools, radiation therapy and genetic testing.
Comprehensive Services
We believe in providing complete cancer care close to home. Our cancer services include more than just diagnosis and treatment. We also offer:
Genetic testing and counseling.
Healing care.
Medicine management counseling.
Rehabilitation services.
Survivorship program.
Highly Skilled Specialists
Your child’s cancer care team features a diverse group of experts. It includes highly skilled medical, surgical and radiation oncologists. Each expert has received special training and is dedicated to helping your child have the best outcome.
All of our nurses have also received pediatric chemotherapy and biotherapy certifications from the Association of Pediatric Hematology/Oncology Nurses (APHON).
content.understanding:
Understanding Childhood Cancer
Childhood cancers are very rare. There are also major differences between the causes, diagnoses and treatments for childhood cancers and those for adult cancers.
One of the biggest differences between childhood cancer and adult cancer is the survival rate. Childhood cancers usually have better outcomes. Doctors believe this is because childhood cancers respond better to treatment. Children can also tolerate more aggressive therapy.
Survival rates for childhood cancer depend on the child’s age, diagnosis and cancer type.
Types of Childhood Cancer
Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors
There are many different kinds of brain and spinal cord tumors. Brain tumors tend to be more common than spine tumors.
Childhood brain tumors usually start in the lower part of the brain.
Brain and spine tumor symptoms may include:
Blurred or double vision.
Clumsiness.
Dizziness.
Nausea and vomiting.
Stumbling or falling.
Leukemia
Leukemia is a blood and bone marrow cancer. It’s the most common type of childhood cancer.
Leukemia symptoms may include:
Bleeding or bruising.
Bone and joint pain.
Fatigue.
Fever.
Pale skin.
Weakness.
Weight loss.
Lymphoma
Lymphoma starts in immune system cells. These cells are called lymphocytes. Lymphomas usually grow in the lymph nodes or parts of the lymph system, such as the tonsils or thymus gland.
Lymphoma can sometimes travel to the bone marrow or other organs. This is because the lymph system carries fluid all through the body.
There are two types of childhood lymphoma. The type depends on which kind of lymphocyte is affected by the cancer. Each type of lymphoma has a different treatment.
Hodgkin lymphoma. This type of lymphoma is usually found in teenagers. Sometimes it can be found in children under five.
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma. This type of lymphoma grows quickly. However, it responds well to treatment. It’s usually diagnosed in young children, but rarely before age three.
Common lymphoma symptoms may include:
Fatigue.
Fever.
Sweating.
Swollen glands or lumps in the armpits, neck or groin.
Weight loss.
Neuroblastoma
Neuroblastoma is cancer that affects the nerve cells. It usually affects infants and young children because it starts forming before birth in the fetus’ or embryo’s nerve cells.
Symptoms of neuroblastoma may include:
Bone pain.
Fever.
Swelling or a lump around the stomach.
Wilms Tumor
A Wilms tumor starts in one of the kidneys. This cancer usually affects children between ages three and four.
Common Wilms tumor symptoms may include:
Fever.
Loss of appetite.
Nausea.
Pain.
Swelling or a lump around the stomach.
Risk Factors for Childhood Cancer
While doctors don’t know exactly what causes childhood cancer, risk factors may include:
Environmental factors, such as exposure to radiation.
Genetic changes.
Personal or family history of cancer.
Diagnosing Childhood Cancers
At ProMedica, we have access to advanced testing that can diagnose childhood cancer. These tools help us determine a precise diagnosis, which means we can find the most effective treatment for your child.
Diagnostic tests may include:
Computed tomography (CT scan).
Laboratory tests and pathology.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
Positron emission tomography (PET).
Ultrasound.
Treating Cancer in Children
At ProMedica, your child will receive personalized cancer treatment at the Debbie Brass Children’s Cancer Center. The Cancer Center is located at the ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital.
Our specialists understand that every child is unique and every diagnosis is different. That’s why we tailor treatment to fit your child’s specific needs.
Treatment for childhood cancer may include:
Chemotherapy. This treatment is given in the veins (intravenously). It prevents cancer cells from growing by killing the cells or stopping the cells from dividing. Chemotherapy may be given before or after surgery. This treatment is also used if cancer has spread to other parts of the body.
Radiation therapy [Link to ‘Understanding Radiation Therapy’ page]. This treatment uses high-energy X-rays to shrink and kill cancer cells. It’s usually given after surgery to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Chromosomal Abnormalities
Chromosomal abnormalities onset as soon as a baby starts developing in the mother’s womb. Chromosomes (small “groups” of genes) in the body determine how a baby grows and functions after birth. Minor changes in these genes can greatly affect body and brain development.
Down Syndrome
Down syndrome affects about 1 out of every 700 babies born. The condition occurs when a baby develops in the womb with one extra copy of chromosome 21.
Down syndrome is normally tested for during pregnancy, or right after birth, to allow parents time to prepare for a baby requiring special needs.
While people with Down syndrome share similar physical traits, each individual has different abilities. They typically experience intellectual and physical challenges, but can reach full and productive lives with the support of speech, occupational and physical therapy.
Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS)
FAS can occur when a pregnant mother drinks alcohol, passing it through the umbilical cord to their baby.
Alcohol exposure can prevent a baby from developing properly in the womb. There is no measure for a “safe” amount of alcohol to drink during pregnancy. Zero consumption is recommended.
Children born with FAS may have abnormal facial features, experience stunted growth and central nervous system problems. In addition, many people experience trouble with learning, speech, sight, and hearing throughout their lives.
There is no cure for FAS, but early treatment and ongoing support can help a child reach their full potential.
Treatment factors:
Early diagnosis (before age 6)
Stable home environment
Absence of violence
Special education and social services
Our multidisciplinary team of physicians and behavioral health specialists can help your child reach their individual potential.
