content.articleContent:
About Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or COPD, is a group of lung diseases that worsen over time and cause increasing breathlessness. COPD is the third leading cause of death for men and women in the United States. And, although 90% of people who have COPD have smoked, it can also occur from long-term contact with harmful pollutants or genetic factors.
Symptoms
If you suffer from COPD, you may experience the following symptoms:
Shortness of breath
Coughing and mucus production
Limited ability to complete normal activities
Diagnosing COPD
COPD is diagnosed by a doctor. Your doctor will perform a health history and physical exam. They may order additional tests including: blood work; chest X-ray; and pulmonary function test.
Treating COPD
Your treatment depends on how serious your disease. Common treatments include:
Knowing your symptoms and when to take action
Medicine (inhalers, nebulizers and oxygen therapy)
Stopping smoking
Monitoring your symptoms and taking action
Exercise and regular activity
Healthy eating
ProMedica Pulmonary Clinic
If you have trouble controlling your COPD flare ups, you may benefit from the ProMedica Pulmonary Clinic for additional education. Our team of respiratory therapists will work with you and your physician to help you better manage your disease and enjoy a better quality of life.
What services are provided at the ProMedica Pulmonary Clinic?
Your respiratory therapist will:
Teach you how your medications work.
Show you how to use your inhaler. Teach you proper breathing techniques.
Work with your primary care physician to carefully adjust medications, when needed.
Make recommendations to improve your treatment plan, if needed.

Helping You Live Your Best Life
If you’ve been diagnosed with colon or rectal cancer or think you’re at higher risk for the disease, you want to know you’re in expert hands. At ProMedica, we offer screenings, diagnoses and state-of-the-art treatments for total colorectal health.
Our specialists are highly experienced in finding colorectal cancer early, which gives you the best chance for a successful outcome. We take the time to learn about you and your lifestyle before we recommend treatments. This helps us choose the therapies that will be least disruptive to your quality of life.
content.approach:
Our Approach
Any kind of cancer can be scary, and colorectal cancer can be very intimidating. You may wonder what effects treatment will have on your daily life, or if you’ll ever be able to return to normal activities. You can rest assured that ProMedica is here to answer all your questions and guide you through your entire treatment journey.
Patients all around Ohio and Michigan choose us for their colorectal cancer care because we’re the region’s leader in early detection and innovative treatment.
Easy-to-schedule Colon Cancer Screenings
Our open access colonoscopy program makes it easier to get colon cancer screenings. The program allows healthy people, age 50 and older and with an average risk for colon cancer, to schedule a colonoscopy without having an office visit first. You’ll save both time and the cost of an office co-payment.
Learn more about our open access colonoscopy program
Multispecialty Team
At ProMedica, we’re committed to excellence. By providing the highest quality care, we’re helping people live longer, healthier lives. And while our services have earned national recognition our greatest reward is watching our patients return home, free of cancer.
Exceptional care starts with exceptional doctors. We’ve put together a highly experienced team of colon and rectal cancer specialists, including:
Colorectal surgeons.
Gastroenterologists.
Oncologists.
Radiation oncologists.
Radiologists.
Ongoing Support
You need support at each stage of your cancer journey. We’ll help you deal with everything from getting your initial diagnosis to getting back to your life after treatment. When you choose ProMedica, you’re never alone.
Our support services include:
Genetic counseling.
Healing Care.
Medicine management counseling.
Patient navigation.
Rehabilitation services.
Survivorship program and support groups.
Care Coordination and Nurse Navigators
We know cancer treatment can feel overwhelming. We want you to focus on getting better, not trying to keep tests, treatment and doctors straight. A member of your care team or a personal nurse navigator will guide you through every step of treatment, including:
Working side-by-side with you to ensure compassionate, supportive and individualized care.
Scheduling/coordinating appointments, and helping to reduce the amount of time from diagnosis to treatment.
Providing education and support to you and your family.
Facilitating/coordinating care provided by an interdisciplinary team of physicians, including medical, surgical and radiation oncology consults.
Working on behalf of you and your family to remove possible obstacles to care, including insurance issues, medication assistance or lack of transportation.
Communicating with your physician and helping to communicate the physician’s plan of care.
content.risks:
Understand the Risks, Symptoms and Screening Guidelines
Colon cancer, often called colorectal cancer, is a cancer of your lower digestive tract (colon and rectum). Most colorectal cancers start as small bumps, called polyps, in the lining of your colon or rectum.
Some polyps can turn into cancer. Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer diagnosed in both men and women in the United States. There are about 100,000 new cases of colon cancer and 40,000 new cases of rectal cancer each year.
Like other cancers, colorectal cancer can spread (metastasize) to other parts of the body. The liver and lungs are the most common places for colorectal cancer to spread.
Know Your Risk
Since colorectal cancer often doesn’t show itself until its later stages, it’s crucial to understand your risks. When you’re aware of your risk factors, your doctor can help you plan a screening schedule that makes sense to you.
Colon cancer risk factors include:
Age: Colorectal cancer is more likely in men and women over the age of 50.
Genetics: A family history of colorectal cancer or adenomatous polyps (non-cancerous growths) raises your risk of colorectal cancer. Your risk also goes up if you have inherited syndromes such as Lynch syndrome (hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, or HNPCC).
Health history: Colorectal cancer is more likely if you have colorectal polyps, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease or type 2 diabetes.
Race and ethnicity: African Americans have the highest colorectal cancer rates of all racial groups in the U.S. Jews of Eastern European descent (Ashkenazi Jews) have one of the highest colorectal cancer risks of any ethnic group in the world.
While there are some risk factors you can’t control, there are others you can manage by choosing to make changes. These include:
Body weight: Being overweight or obese raises your risk of developing colon or rectal cancer.
Diet: Eating a diet high in red meats and processed meats (like hot dogs and some luncheon meats) can raise your risk of colorectal cancer. Cooking meats at very high temperatures (frying, broiling, grilling) may raise your risk of cancer overall.
Lifestyle: Smoking, using tobacco and consuming large amounts of alcohol can raise your risk of colorectal cancer — and many other cancers, too.
Recognize the Symptoms
For many, the symptoms of colon cancer can be very hard to detect, until it’s progressed to a later stage. That’s why it’s important to stay aware and talk with your doctor if you have:
Blood in your stool.
Changes in your bowel habits.
Cramping or abdominal (belly) pain.
Diarrhea or constipation lasting more than a few days.
Low red blood cell count.
Rectal bleeding.
Weakness and fatigue.
Unexplained weight loss.
Protect Your Colon Health with Regular Screenings
Men and women age 45 and older should have a colonoscopy every 10 years. However, if you’re at greater risk for colorectal cancer, talk to your doctor about screening earlier and more often.
A colonoscopy is the most common way to diagnose colon cancer. It involves a visual exam of your colon, using a tiny, lighted camera. If polyps are found during your screening, your doctor can remove them right away.
ProMedica's open access colonoscopy program allows healthy people, age 50 and older and with an average risk for colon cancer, to schedule a colonoscopy without having an office visit first. Colonoscopies also offer an important advantage.
Learn more about our open access colonoscopy program.
Other screenings are also available. These tests let you take a stool sample at home to send to the lab. Along with being more private, they are also less invasive. While they serve a purpose and can be helpful, especially between colonoscopies, these tests aren’t as accurate as colonoscopies.
If a colonoscopy shows that you have colon cancer, your doctor may recommend more tests to learn the extent or stage of your cancer. Imaging exams can show the size of the tumor(s), how far into the lining of the colon and rectum the cancer has spread and if the cancer has spread to other parts of the body.
content.treatment:
Find Expert and Compassionate Treatment
Just as we’re all different, there’s no one-size-fits-all treatment plan. That’s why we’ll design a customized colorectal cancer treatment plan with your unique condition and needs in mind. Your doctor may even suggest combining treatments to help make sure you have the best possible outcome.
Chemotherapy
Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment given intravenously (through a vein) to stop cancer cells from growing.
Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy (HIPEC)
ProMedica offers a unique form of chemotherapy for colorectal cancer called hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC). Also called “hot chemotherapy,” we give this treatment during the surgery, immediately following the removal of the visible tumor(s) in the colon or rectum. The abdominal cavity is filled with a heated chemotherapy drug to kill any remaining microscopic cancer cells.
ProMedica Toledo Hospital, part of ProMedica Cancer Institute, is the only local hospital that offers this innovative therapy from the area’s only fellow-ship trained surgical oncologist, Jeffrey Sutton, MD.
The benefits of HIPEC include:
Drug is contained to your abdominal cavity.
Given in a single treatment, not multiple visits.
More targeted, intense dose of chemotherapy.
Fewer side effects than traditional chemotherapy.
May be effective in killing the small, undetectable cancer cells that cannot be seen, which prevents them from forming into new tumors.
Learn more about HIPEC cancer treatment
Radiation Therapy
Radiation therapy uses high-energy X-rays to shrink and kill cancer cells. It's usually given after surgery or chemotherapy to lower the risk of the cancer coming back.
Surgery
Surgery for colorectal cancer will depend on many factors, including how advanced the cancer is. If the cancer is in a very early stage, small or medium-sized polyps can even be removed during a colonoscopy (polypectomy).
Your doctor may perform an endoscopic mucosal resection during your colonoscopy, which removes the polyps as well as a layer of the colon’s lining.
Laparoscopic Colorectal Surgery
Polyps that can't be removed during a colonoscopy may be removed using laparoscopic surgery. In this minimally invasive procedure, your surgeon makes several small incisions (cuts) in your abdominal wall. The surgeon inserts a laparoscope (small, lighted video camera) through an incision to display your colon on a video monitor. Using this method, tumors can be removed without large incisions or too much soft tissue damage.
In some cases, your doctor may recommend a laparoscopic partial colectomy (partial removal of the colon). The cancerous sections of the colon are removed and the healthy portions are reattached.
Colostomy
If colorectal cancer is advanced, the surgeon may not be able to reattach sections of the colon after a colectomy. A colostomy may be needed, which is a procedure that makes an opening in the abdominal wall. Waste (stool) that would normally move through the colon is rerouted to exit the body into a bag on the outside of the body. A colostomy may be temporary or permanent.
At ProMedica, we know that having a colostomy has a huge impact on your daily life. That’s why we make every effort to treat your colorectal cancer conservatively or minimally invasively before recommending a colostomy.

content.articleContent:
Understand CT, commonly known as a CAT Scan
You want to know what to expect, what it is, and why it may benefit your healt; we’ll help with that.
What is a CT? Short for computed tomography, a CT is a series of X-rays taken from different angles of targeted body parts. Compiling these X-rays into images gives your radiologist essential information about your bones or your body’s soft tissues.
Why is a CT performed? CT is requested for many reasons. Your doctor may want further information to:
Locate an infection, a blood clot, or a tumor.
Diagnose muscle or bone issues.
Detect internal injuries.
Diagnose and monitor heart, lung, or liver disease.
Guide surgical, biopsy, or radiology procedures.
Detect lung cancer
How does CT work? During your CT, you’ll lie down and pass slowly through a large, doughnut-shaped machine. You’ll be able to communicate with your technician the entire time, but will need to remain still during the test. During this time, the CT machine takes various X-rays that your radiologist will interpret. At a later appointment, your doctor will discuss with you your results.
Why is a CT important to my health? CT gives your doctor valuable insight into your body, how it’s functioning, and what treatments may result. The more accurate your diagnosis, the more effective your treatment.

content.articleContent:
Advanced Care for Cystic Fibrosis
Cystic fibrosis is a disease that primarily affects the lungs and pancreas, but impacts the entire body. While no cure currently exists, tremendous treatment developments now allow you or your loved one to live well into adulthood. Here you’ll find the care you need, at any age, from diagnosis to ongoing treatment and research.
Frequently Asked Questions
What is cystic fibrosis?
Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disease where the body creates an unusually thick, sticky mucus. The abnormal mucus clogs the lungs, causing infections and making it difficult to breathe. This mucous also prevents the pancreas from secreting the digestive enzymes produced. Without these enzymes, it’s hard for the body to absorb enough nutrients. Physical growth can be affected.
Symptoms include:
Salty tasting skin
Persistent cough, sometimes with phlegm
Frequent lung infections
Shortness of breath or wheezing
Slow growth and weight gain, in spite of eating well
Frequent bowel movements that may be greasy and bulky
Talk to your primary care physician right away if you or your child has any of these symptoms. Early treatment can help reduce the impact of this disease.
How is cystic fibrosis diagnosed?
Children are typically diagnosed before two years of age. Diagnosis occurs in several ways:
Newborn infant screening at birth (all children born in the U.S. are screened)
Sweat chloride test
Genetic testing
Chest X-rays and lung function testing
Stool sample analysis
Learn about sweat chloride testing
How is cystic fibrosis treated?
Cystic fibrosis treatment eases your, or your child’s, symptoms and improves quality of life. This disease affects individuals differently, so the treatment plan is tailored to you or your child.
Common treatments include:
Airway Clearing Techniques help you clear the thick mucus from your lungs.
Inhaled medicines (bronchodilators or antibiotics) are turned into a mist and inhaled.
Pancreatic enzymes capsules are taken before meals and snacks to aid with digestion.
Treating Cystic Fibrosis in Adults
Cystic Fibrosis is potentially life-threatening. But recent progress in treatments has more than doubled the life expectancy for those living with cystic fibrosis. Our treatments are state-of-the-art and based on the latest research and standards. You’ll get the expert care you need to keep going strong.
The Cystic Fibrosis Center of Northwest Ohio
Receive the latest, most advanced care at our nationally accredited Cystic Fibrosis Center of Northwest Ohio. Our accreditation with the National Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (CFF) ensures that you or your loved one is receiving comprehensive state-of-the-art care, as strict evidence-based guidelines are followed. Our care center is also a part of the Therapeutic Drug Network through the CFF, which permits cutting edge research in cystic fibrosis to occur right here in northwest Ohio. You’ll get everything you need to treat this disease.
Learn More

content.articleContent:
Understanding DEXA Scans
You’ve discussed a DEXA or bone density scan with your doctor and want to know more. Feel confident understanding what to expect and how it works.
What is a bone scan?
It’s an important way to see if a disease has developed in your bones. It functions much like a standard X-ray, but differs in that a radioactive material is injected into your body. This material settles into your bones for a short time and allows your doctor to detect bone disease much earlier than when using typical X-ray.
It’s a comfortable procedure that takes about three to four hours, which includes time for the injected material to settle and for the actual scan (X-ray).
Why is a bone scan important to your health?
A bone scan is an important tool to quickly detect the source of various symptoms you may have experienced like bone pain or swelling. Early detection is essential to prevent fractures or the spread of disease or infection through your bones. You and your doctor can discuss the most effective treatments based on your bone scan results.

content.articleContent:
Take Charge of Your Diabetes
A diabetes diagnosis can change the way you approach your day-to-day life. You may be an adult who’s been diagnosed. Or perhaps you’re caring for a child with diabetes. In every case it’s important to understand how the disease works, how to manage it and where you can get diabetes support.
The number of Americans living with diabetes grows every year. That’s why at ProMedica, we believe it’s important to do our part to help people take charge of their own health after a diabetes diagnosis.
If you suspect you or your child might have diabetes, contact your ProMedica doctor right away. We’ll review your symptoms and risk factors, and run diagnostic tests to pinpoint the reason for your symptoms.
Together, we’ll take charge.
content.overview:
Overview
About Diabetes

Learn more about diabetes, how it develops, and the way it affects your body from ProMedica diabetes specialists.
Helpful Tips

Living with diabetes doesn’t have to be hard. Learn some helpful tips for managing the disease from ProMedica specialists.
Types and Testing

Learn about the different types of diabetes and the blood sugar levels you should expect with or without diabetes.
content.understanding:
Understanding Diabetes
What is diabetes?
What most people refer to as “diabetes” is actually a group of diseases called diabetes mellitus. These diseases affect your body’s ability to turn the sugar (or glucose) in your blood into energy.
Your body uses insulin to change glucose so it can be used by cells for energy. Based on what diabetes type you have, your body either doesn’t produce enough insulin or doesn’t use it properly.
If it’s not treated, any form of diabetes can lead to death or serious complications such as:
Amputation.
Blindness.
Diabetic retinopathy.
Heart and vascular disease.
Kidney failure.
Stroke.
Wounds and infections.
Download this free Diabetes 101 booklet
What are the symptoms?
The signs, symptoms and severity of diabetes depends on the type. It’s also based on how high your blood sugar is. Some people don’t have symptoms right away, but some common signs include:
Blurred vision.
Constant thirst.
Extreme hunger.
Fatigue.
Frequent infections.
Frequent urination.
Irritability.
Rapid weight loss.
Slow-healing sores.
What are the types of diabetes?
Type 1 diabetes
Type 1 diabetes, often called “insulin-dependent diabetes,” happens when your body stops making insulin. It’s most common in children but can be diagnosed at any age. Symptoms include dry mouth, fatigue and a fruit flavor in your mouth.
While type 1 diabetes is a long-term condition that can’t be reversed, you can control it by making healthy lifestyle changes and by using prescribed insulin effectively.
Types 2 diabetes
Type 2 diabetes, often called “non-insulin dependent diabetes,” happens when your blood sugar level is too high. It’s most common in adults but can be diagnosed at any age. Though sometimes no symptoms are noticed, signs can include extreme hunger, blurry vision and frequent urination.
While type 2 diabetes is a chronic condition that can’t be reversed, you can manage it with healthy lifestyle changes, medicine and insulin therapy.
Gestational diabetes
Gestational diabetes happens during pregnancy when changes in your body cause high blood sugar. It’s possible this short-term condition can be reversed. Since most women don’t notice any symptoms, your obstetrician will monitor your glucose levels often as a part of your prenatal care.
You can manage gestational diabetes during your pregnancy, and it often goes away after your baby is born.
Prediabetes
As a regular part of your primary care, your doctor will test your blood sugar levels periodically (usually yearly). Since it’s possible that prediabetes can be reversed, catching it early is key.
You’ll be considered prediabetic if your blood sugar levels are higher than normal, but not high enough to be diagnosed as diabetes. Your doctor will talk with you about important steps you can take to control or reverse your prediabetes.
content.diabetes:
Managing Your Diabetes
Start Your Journey
With a little mindfulness, you can manage your diabetes and lead a healthy, active life. The first important step is to learn the signs that your blood sugar isn’t within a normal range. Then you can make adjustments and get the support you need.
Next, we advise you to create a support network of dietitians, educators, programs, doctors and others who can help you navigate a healthy diabetic lifestyle. Seeing your support team often is crucial to achieving your best health. During your journey, you may be asked to think about:
Creating a healthy diet plan with a dietitian’s help.
Discussing common treatments for diabetic complications, such as hyperbaric medicine for wound care.
Taking prescribed medicines, including insulin injections.
Trying nonmedical and medical weight loss treatments and programs.
Wearing an emergency ID bracelet that lets people know you have diabetes.
Please see a doctor right away if you have symptoms that last more than a few hours or are more serious. These include cuts, wounds and blisters that aren’t healing or are infected, or chest pain, shortness of breath, and pain or numbness in your arms and legs.
Seek Education Services
At ProMedica, we know that patients who understand diabetes enjoy a better quality of life than those who aren’t clear about how to handle the disease. We want to empower you to get the knowledge you need. That’s why we offer education about diabetes and how to take control of your health.
Our education services are recognized by the American Diabetes Association (ADA). These services help you plan for your treatment and understand your medicines. They also show you how to monitor your blood glucose levels. You’ll learn how to plan meals and exercise in a way that keeps your diabetes under control. After all, you should be able to enjoy your life without worrying about your health.
Call us at 419-291-6767 to learn more or to schedule an appointment.
Know When Your Blood Sugar Isn’t Within Range
High Blood Sugar
A good first step in managing your diabetes is learning to recognize the signs of high blood sugar, which include:
Blurred vision.
Drowsiness.
Dry skin.
Extreme thirst.
Frequent urination.
Passing out.
Low Blood Sugar
Low Blood Sugar
A good first step in managing your diabetes is learning to recognize the signs of low blood sugar, which include:
Dizziness.
Fatigue.
Hunger.
Impaired vision.
Irritability.
Passing out.
Shaking.
Sweating.
Weakness.
Understand Wound Care
Diabetes can lead to wounds and infections, including potentially dangerous foot ulcers. ProMedica Wound Care is here to help you with hard-to-treat wounds. Learn more about ProMedica Wound Care.
Diabetes and Wound Care

Learn why it’s vital to manage your blood sugar to prevent wounds or keep them from getting worse. Advice from clinical pharmacist Chuck Riepenhoff, RPH, CDE.
Understand Good Nutrition
Good nutrition is key to your good health. It’s one of the most important ways to manage diabetes. The right diet — one rich in nutrients and good fats, but low in calories — will help you control your glucose levels.
At ProMedica, our dietitians will work with you to create a diabetes medical nutrition therapy (MNT) diet. It takes into account your health as well as your likes, dislikes and lifestyle. MNT plans are designed just for you and your condition. Focused on fruits, vegetables and whole grains, your MNT plan will be built around a variety of healthy foods. It includes balanced portions and regular meals all through the day, along with wholesome snacks.
Medical Nutrition Therapy
A meal plan that’s chosen by you and your dietitian helps you maintain a healthy glucose level in your blood. When you eat too many calories and bad fats, your glucose rises in an unhealthy way. Staying on top of what you eat helps keep your glucose in check and avoids problems that come with having high blood sugar.
A medical nutrition therapy plan also works well as a safe way to lose weight. Many people with diabetes find that weight loss helps them manage their glucose. Losing weight also improves your health in many other noticeable ways.
Best Foods
Your ProMedica dietitian will help you select foods that are best for you to manage diabetes. Some of the delicious, nutritious choices for you are:
Fiber. Among its many health benefits, fiber helps control blood sugar levels. You’ll want to try these high-fiber foods: whole-grain pasta; garbanzo, black, and white beans; brown rice; apples; guava; strawberries; broccoli; peas; and brussels sprouts.
Fish. ProMedica dietitians advise eating fish twice a week. Generally, fish is lower in overall fat, saturated fat and cholesterol. Broil, bake, or poach. Avoid fried. Try tuna, salmon, mackerel and other fish high in Omega-3 fatty acid.
Healthy carbs. Carbohydrates are broken into three types: fiber, starches and sugars. Carbs raise your blood glucose. But eating healthy carbs in line with your meal plan helps you keep your blood sugar within a healthy range. Try whole-grain breads, sweet potatoes, quinoa, steel-cut oatmeal, kale and bananas.
Healthy fats. As long as you don’t eat too many of them, monounsaturated fats and polyunsaturated fats can lower cholesterol, though they tend to be higher in calories. Try avocados, walnuts, salmon, pumpkin and sesame seeds, olives and olive oil, and navy beans.
Foods to Avoid
When working toward your health goals you should avoid foods that contain:
High sugar. Can be found in candy, desserts and sugar-sweetened beverages such as soda and sweet tea.
High salt. Can be found in chips, cured meats, sauces and dressings, and packaged food.
High cholesterol. Can be found in butter, bacon, ice cream, lobster and fried foods.
Trans fats. Can be found in deep-fried foods, non-dairy creamer, cake mixes and margarine.
Saturated fats. Can be found in cheese, butter, fatty beef, chicken with skin and whole milk.
content.faq:
Frequently Asked Questions
There’s a lot to learn when you or a loved one is diagnosed with diabetes. You’re not alone — many people likely have the same questions you do. That’s why you’ll find answers to the questions we’re asked most often, right here in one place.
What does insulin do?
Insulin is the hormone that allows sugar (also called glucose) to enter your cells and be used as energy.
What is blood glucose?
Glucose is the fuel our bodies need for energy. If it’s going to be used by our bodies, it needs to get into our cells. When someone has diabetes, the glucose stays in the bloodstream instead of entering the cells. This starves our cells of energy.
Why do I have to measure my blood sugar (glucose)?
Blood sugar tests give you vital information about how to manage your condition. Knowing your glucose level helps you:
Reach your treatment goals.
Understand how your daily choices in diet, exercise or stress levels affect your condition.
Understand how your medicine works for you.
How do I measure my blood sugar (glucose) levels?
Your blood glucose can be measured by placing a blood drop on a strip that a glucose monitor can read. Your doctor will work closely with you to decide how often you should be testing your blood sugar. It’s common to test it several times each day.
What could happen if I don’t know my blood sugar (glucose) levels?
Most of the time people don’t know if their blood sugar is under control since it’s constantly changing throughout the day. That’s why it’s a good idea to check your blood sugar levels at various times of the day to be sure your blood sugar is under control.
What is the A1C test?
The A1C test is a blood test that shows your average blood sugar level over the past three months.
What do food choices have to do with diabetes?
Carbohydrates are our major energy source and have the greatest effect on blood sugar. High-fiber carbohydrate foods like whole-grain bread, whole fruits, legumes, nuts and oats digest slower. That helps keep blood sugar from getting too high.
What does exercise have to do with diabetes?
Exercise helps insulin work more efficiently and can help keep blood sugar in a normal range. Talk with your doctor about which exercise program is right for you.
Is there a medicine I can take for diabetes?
If you have Type 1 diabetes, insulin must be taken every day because your body doesn’t make its own. A wide range of oral and injectable medicines can also be used to help control your Type 2 diabetes.
Should I be concerned about a cut, wound or blister that won’t heal?
Any time you notice a break in your skin that heals slowly, talk to your doctor. Wound care and diabetic vascular disease specialists provide treatment and also teach you how to care for your wounds at home.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Depression
Major depression is a chronic condition and different than just experiencing the occasional “blues”. If you have depression, it consistently affects your mood, thoughts and body.
Symptoms of Depression
You may notice several of the following signs during the same two-week period:
Difficulty with relationships
Excessive guilt
Hopelessness
Extremely sensitive to failure or rejection
Unable to concentrate
Lack energy
Lack interest in activities once enjoyed
Persistent sadness
Irritability, hostility, or aggression
Feeling of wanting to die
Changes in appetite or weight
Low self-esteem
Sleeping too much or very little
Thinking about suicide or attempting suicide
In most cases, treatment is necessary for recovery. Begin a conversation about your depression with your primary care physician, or look for a behavioral health specialist such as a counselor or psychiatrist.
Depression in Children and Adolescents
According to the National Institute of Mental Health, the onset of major depression is occurring much earlier in life than it used to. And the earlier the condition onsets, the higher the probability that it will continue into adulthood.
If your adolescent has major depression, they are unable to merely “snap out of it” and feel better on their own.
What should you do if your think your child has major depression? Contact your pediatrician or family doctor immediately to discuss. Early diagnosis of depression is important because it often coexists with another psychiatric disorder, such as substance abuse or anxiety disorder. If your doctor feels your child needs further assessment, they may recommend evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional. Major depression can be effectively treated.

content.articleContent:
About Diabetic Retinopathy
Diabetic eye disease refers to a group of eye problems that people with diabetes could face. These conditions may include diabetic retinopathy, cataracts and glaucoma. Although eye diseases can cause severe vision loss or even blindness, they can often be treated before vision loss occurs. Prevention is the key.
Frequently Asked Questions
What is diabetic retinopathy?
Diabetic retinopathy is the most common eye disease in people with diabetes and is a leading cause of blindness in American adults. Changes in the blood vessels of the retina, the light sensitive layer of tissue at the back of the inner eye, can lead to this condition. In some people, retinal blood vessels may swell and leak fluid. In others, abnormal new blood vessels grow on the surface of the retina. These changes may result in vision loss or blindness.
Who is at risk for diabetic retinopathy?
Anyone with diabetes is at risk for diabetic retinopathy. The longer you have diabetes, the more likely you are to develop diabetic retinopathy. Your risk rises if you have diabetes and you smoke, have high blood pressure, or are pregnant.
What are the symptoms of diabetic retinopathy?
In the early stages of diabetic retinopathy, you may have no symptoms. Vision may not change until the disease gets worse. Then you may have blurry or double vision; dark or floating spots; pain or pressure in one or both eyes; or rings, flashing lights, or blank spots in your vision.
A decrease in your central vision could be caused by macular edema which may occur from diabetic retinopathy. It happens when the macula, a part of the retina, swells from the leaking fluid and causes blurred vision. When new vessels grow on the surface of the retina, they can bleed into the eye. This may decrease vision.
How is diabetic retinopathy diagnosed?
Along with a complete health history and eye exam, your eye care professional may do these tests to diagnose diabetic retinopathy:
Visual acuity test. This is the common eye chart test that measures vision ability at various distances.
Tonometry. This standard test is done to check the pressure (intraocular pressure, or IOP) inside the eye.
Pupil dilation. For a close up exam of the eye’s lens and retina, your pupil is widened with eye drops.
Ophthalmoscopy. This is a test where a doctor looks very closely at the retina using a special magnifying glass.
Fluorescein angiography. In this test, a dye is injected into the bloodstream. The dye helps the blood vessels in the eye show up while pictures are taken with a special camera. This test lets the doctor see if the blood vessels are leaking.
Optical coherence tomography. In this test, light waves are used to make detailed images of the retina.
How is diabetic retinopathy treated?
If you have diabetic retinopathy, your treatment will depend on your age, general health, symptoms and the severity of the condition.
Even people with advanced retinopathy have a good chance of keeping their vision if they are treated before the retina becomes severely damaged. Treatment for diabetic retinopathy may include:
Laser surgery. This involves shrinking the abnormal blood vessels, or sealing the leaking ones.
Vitrectomy. Vitrectomy is a procedure that involves removing the cloudy, jelly-like substance (vitreous) that fills the center of the eye. The vitreous is replaced with a saline solution.
Injections. Certain medications can be injected into the eye to slow the growth of the abnormal vessels of the retina.
Can diabetic retinopathy be prevented?
While you can’t completely prevent diabetic retinopathy, you can reduce your risk of getting it. Controlling your blood sugar slows the start of retinopathy and keeps it from getting worse. It also lessens the need for laser surgery for severe retinopathy.
You can reduce the risk of developing the condition by:
Having a dilated eye exam once a year. An eye exam does not prevent retinopathy but it can help diagnose eye problems that can then be treated. An eye exam can also alert you and your healthcare provider if the diabetes needs to be better controlled.
Having an eye exam before pregnancy or in the first trimester of your pregnancy. If you’re pregnant and take insulin to manage your diabetes, that can raise the odds that the condition will become worse. Continue to be monitored every trimester and for 1 year after birth depending on how severe the retinopathy is.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Deep Vein Thrombosis
Veins carry blood back up through your body. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) happened when a clot (thrombus) forms in a deep vein, usually in your leg.
DVT is a dangerous condition. If the clot breaks free from the wall of your vein and is released into your bloodstream, it’s called an embolus. This embolus can travel through your bloodstream and up to your lungs. There, it can block your blood vessel and the lung’s blood supply.
The resulting condition is called a pulmonary embolism and can be fatal.
content.dvtSymptoms:
What are the symptoms of a DVT?
Swelling in the leg
Pain in the leg
Redness and warmth of the skin
If you experience DVT symptoms, see your ProMedica doctor right away to discuss diagnosis and treatment options.
content.dvtRisks:
What are your risks for forming a DVT?
Medical conditions that affect your body's ability to form blood clots such as cancer, blood disorders, trauma or surgery
Long period of time when your movement is restricted, like bed rest
Injury to a vein
Previous history of DVT or pulmonary embolism
Oral contraceptives
Hormone therapy
Family history
Pregnancy

content.articleContent:
Treating ENT Problems for Your Best Health
We’ve all experienced ear, nose and throat (ENT) problems at one time or another. Whether you have common or chronic ENT conditions, ProMedica ENT physicians can help you manage and overcome them. This team of board-certified otolaryngologists wants to see you get back to living the life you love.
content.approach:
Our Approach to Complete ENT Care
With the provider in southeast Michigan and largest network of ENT specialists in northwest Ohio, ProMedica takes a comprehensive approach to managing disorders that involve the ears, nose and throat, as well as other related structures of the head and neck region.
ProMedica’s ENT doctors work closely with audiologists to make sure you receive complete, high-quality care. Our priority is to provide patient-centered care that is entirely focused on improving your health and well-being. We provide medical care and surgical treatment for adults and children.
content.conditions:
ENT Conditions
From common ear infections to throat and oral cancers, ProMedica Physicians ENT specialists have the deep expertise needed to treat a range of conditions. They diagnose and manage diseases of the sinuses, larynx (voice box), oral cavity, mouth and throat, as well as structures of the face and neck. They have special expertise in the management of cancers that involve the thyroid and salivary glands, the mouth, throat and voice box, and other cancers of the head and neck region. Trust them to help manage your conditions so you can live your best life.
Common ear, nose and throat problems include:
Hearing loss.
Nasal congestion, sinus problems and breathing problems.
Deviated septum, snoring and sleep apnea.
Issues associated with Down syndrome.
Ear issues, such as ear infections, tinnitus, swimmer’s ear, balance problems, dizziness and hearing impairments.
Growths or tumors in your ears, nose or throat.
Hoarseness, sore throats, recurrent tonsillitis, salivary gland disorders, and voice and swallowing problems.
Nerve problems and pain in your ears, nose or throat.
Problems with smell.
Thyroid and parathyroid disorders.
Unwanted appearance of the nose or face including drooping eyelids and hair loss.
content.treatment:
ENT Treatments for Better Health
ProMedica Physicians ENT is home to the largest number of ENT specialists in the Toledo area. Our board-certified physicians and experienced staff are dedicated to giving you leading-edge ENT care. Whether your condition needs state-of-the-art surgery or can be handled in-office, you can be sure you’re receiving the region’s best in responsive, expert care.
Focused on Patient-centered Care
Creating an experience that’s focused on our patients is important to us. For your convenience and satisfaction, we offer these enhanced services:
Hearing aids: When purchased through ProMedica, hearing aids are serviced for the lifetime of the hearing aid, even years after the company service warranty has expired. This is not a service provided by most hearing aid vendors.
Speech-language pathologists: Our two speech-language pathologists evaluate and treat patients with voice and swallowing disorders. This improves access to the services offered by a speech therapist and allows for improved communication between the speech therapist and your otolaryngologist. ProMedica ENT is the only otolaryngology practice in the Toledo metro region that employs speech pathologists.
In-Office ENT Procedures
We provide in-office care across a range of specialties. You’ll have access to care for the full spectrum of ENT conditions and diseases, including:
Ear, audiology and neurotology procedures: This includes audiograms, ear wax removal, ear tube placement, trauma care, ear infection treatment, vertigo care, hearing care and the treatment of benign tumors and nerve pathway disorders.
Nose and sinus procedures: We can diagnose and treat smell disorders, polyps, nose bleeds, stuffy nose and nasal obstruction due to a deviated septum, balloon sinuplasty and tonsil abscesses. We also treat chronic nasal and sinus conditions and earaches.
Head and neck procedures: You can receive cosmetic and reconstructive surgery, biopsies, skin cancer removals, cyst and polyp removals and tonsillectomies.
ENT Surgical Procedures
Using advanced technology and a broad range of surgical methods, ProMedica physicians can perform the full range of surgeries to treat ENT conditions. This includes pediatric ENT surgery and skin cancer removal, as well as:
Cosmetic, functional and reconstructive surgical treatment of abnormalities of the face, neck and ear.
Ear surgery, ear tube placement and stapedectomy (replacing a stuck bone in the ear to fix hearing loss).
Endocrine, thyroid and parathyroid surgery.
Removal of saliva glands.
Head and neck cancer surgery.
Lymph node biopsy or removal, lipoma (fatty tumor) or sebaceous cyst removal.
Nasal surgery including ablation (tissue removal) and removal of nasal turbinates (tissue that obstructs nasal breathing); endoscopic sinus surgery; septoplasty (straightening a crooked nasal septum); and adenoidectomy.
Otology, neurotology and skull base surgery.
Sleep apnea surgery.
Tonsillectomy.

content.articleContent:
Live the Life You Love Without Missing a Beat
An irregular heartbeat, known as arrhythmia, can happen suddenly and take you by surprise. It can be scary, too. That’s why it’s important to act quickly and work with a team you trust to understand your condition. ProMedica’s electrophysiologists offer specialized arrhythmia care in Toledo. They assess, diagnose and treat irregular heart rhythm problems, including atrial fibrillation (AFib). ProMedica cares about your peace of mind. That’s why we offer you high-quality, best-in-class care close to home.
content.approach:
Our Approach
Electrophysiology (EP) is the study of heart rhythms. Your heart makes electrical impulses that coordinate the contractions of its different parts. These contractions create movement — your heartbeat or heart rhythm — which keeps blood flowing through your heart the way it should.
Cardiac electrophysiologists are specially trained cardiologists. These heart specialists diagnose irregular heartbeats and treat patients who are dealing with heart rhythm disorders.
A Center Dedicated to Heart Arrhythmias
The Heart Rhythm Center is a brand new, state-of-the-art facility on the second floor of ProMedica Toledo Hospital. Providing the highest quality of heart rhythm care in Toledo, the center treats simple to complex heart arrhythmias.
Learn more about the Heart Rhythm Center.
content.devices:
Heart Devices for Abnormal Heart Rhythms
Your heartbeat is started and controlled by a natural electrical system. It coordinates the contractions that pump blood through your heart and out to the rest of your body.
Based on your age and overall health, your heart contracts and dilates 60 to 100 times a minute. But when your heart has trouble starting a heartbeat or naturally pacing your heart rhythm, your body may not get enough blood.
Pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD) are the two types of heart devices that treat irregular heartbeats. A surgeon implants one of these devices to send electrical pulses to your heart. This should reset your heart to its normal rhythm.
ProMedica’s experienced team of cardiac electrophysiologists will help you decide if a pacemaker or an ICD is the best way to treat your abnormal heart rhythm. They’re highly skilled at implanting these devices and the procedures can be done close to home in the Heart Rhythm Center at ProMedica Toledo Hospital.
Pacemakers
You may first notice signs of autism before your child turns three. But they most often appear within the first 12 to 18 months.
Pacemakers are small devices that generate pulses to prompt the heart to beat normally. There are two types of pacemakers — biventricular and leadless pacemakers.
Biventricular pacemakers are used for ventricles (heart chambers) that don’t contract at the same time. They work to pace both ventricles to contract in unison.
Leadless pacemakers are a newer type of pacemaker technology that removes the need for a surgical pocket and insulated wires (known as “leads”) to pace the heart. Instead, the leadless pacemaker is a self-contained generator and electrode system that’s implanted directly into the right ventricle. Since it is only placed in one ventricle, it is also called a ventricular pacemaker.
Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (ICD)
An implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) is similar to a pacemaker. Some ICDs even have pacemakers built into them. An ICD device can send the same type of low-energy pulses to your heart that pacemakers do, but it can also detect more life-threatening arrhythmias. Then it will send a high-energy pulse if an arrhythmia becomes dangerous or your heart stops beating. For this reason, ICDs are advised for patients who are at high risk for a life-threatening ventricular arrhythmia.
Subcutaneous Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (S-ICD)
A subcutaneous implantable cardioverter defibrillator (S-ICD) has all of the benefits of an ICD with less risk because it’s not attached to the heart. S-ICDs are placed under the skin and are safer to implant because there’s no risk of injuring a blood vessel.
Carla's Story

Find out how an S-ICD helped Carla Phillips regain the confidence to live on her own after a cardiomyopathy diagnosis.

content.articleContent:
A Closer Look with Your Comfort in Mind
Sometimes your doctor needs to take a closer look to make an accurate diagnosis. With endoscopy services at ProMedica locations all around the Toledo metro area, you won’t have to go far for your procedure. Whether you choose one of our area hospitals or an outpatient location, you can feel safe and at ease knowing you’ll be in the capable, gentle care of the ProMedica team.
content.overview:
Overview
An endoscopy is an outpatient procedure that looks at your internal organs using a thin instrument and a tiny camera. It lets your doctor analyze the health of your colon, esophagus, lungs, stomach, portions of the small intestine and pancreas. Using advanced technology, ProMedica gastroenterologists take a closer look at these areas of the body to diagnose infections, ulcers, cancers and other possible causes of pain or discomfort.
Most endoscopic procedures include mild sedation. They take anywhere from 15 to 90 minutes, based on the type. Our doctors will talk with you about your symptoms and concerns. Then they’ll form a plan to examine and treat you that works best for your health needs.
content.procedures:
Common Endoscopic Procedures
The most common endoscopic procedures include colonoscopy, upper GI endoscopy, flexible sigmoidoscopy, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and liver biopsy.
We want you to feel comfortable and informed about your procedure. Talk with your doctor about the risks and possible side effects. Our goal is to have you home in no time, with the peace of mind that your diagnosis is accurate.
Colonoscopy
A colonoscopy is a visual exam of your colon using a lighted, flexible fiberoptic or video endoscope. An endoscope is inserted through your anus and moved gently around the bends of your colon. Viewing the colon like this helps your doctor check for conditions like colon cancer, noncancerous tumors (which can be painlessly removed during the colonoscopy), inflammation, infection and bleeding. A colonoscopy can be performed by a general surgeon, a gastroenterologist, or a colorectal surgeon.
Easy-to-schedule Colon Cancer Screenings
Our open access colonoscopy program makes it easier to get colon cancer screenings. The program allows healthy people, age 50 and older and with an average risk for colon cancer, to schedule a colonoscopy without having an office visit first. You’ll save both time and the cost of an office co-payment.
Learn more about our open access colonoscopy program.
Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography
Also known as ERCP, this procedure is used to diagnose problems in the pancreas, bile duct, liver and gallbladder. ERCP may help treat gallstones or other blockages, where stenting or sphincterotomy to open the bile duct is needed.
A local anesthetic is sprayed to numb your throat and an endoscope is gently inserted through your mouth and down your throat. Your doctor then inspects your stomach and duodenum (the first section of the small intestine). A dye is injected into your duodenum and detailed X-rays are taken of the bile ducts and pancreas.
Endoscopic Ultrasound
Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is a minimally invasive procedure to evaluate digestive (gastrointestinal) and lung diseases. It uses high-frequency sound waves to produce detailed images of the lining and walls of your digestive tract and chest, nearby organs such as the pancreas and liver, and the lymph nodes.
Flexible Sigmoidoscopy
A flexible sigmoidoscopy is used to diagnose and treat rectal bleeding, persistent diarrhea, pain, colon cancer and abnormalities that may appear on X-rays. An endoscope looks at the inside of your rectum and sigmoid colon (the last one to two feet of your colon).
During the exam, you'll lie on your left side with your legs drawn up and a sheet placed over your lower body. A finger exam of your anus and rectum is performed, and then an endoscope is gently inserted into the rectum. The bowel is inflated with air to expand it and allow careful examination. The endoscope is then carefully moved around the various bends in the lower bowel.
Liver Biopsy
A liver biopsy lets the doctor take a small sample of liver tissue to view under a microscope and diagnose a condition. A local anesthetic is used to numb the skin and tissue and a thin needle is inserted through the skin, usually through the lower-right chest between the ribs. The needle is quickly moved into and out of the liver (in about one to two seconds) to take a piece of tissue.
Upper GI Endoscopy
An upper GI endoscopy is a visual exam of your upper intestinal tract using a lighted, flexible fiberoptic or video endoscope. A spray or liquid is used to numb your throat so you don’t feel the endoscope as it’s gently inserted into your upper esophagus. This exam is used to diagnose and treat ulcers, tumors, trouble with swallowing, upper abdominal pain, indigestion, chronic inflammation and intestinal bleeding.
content.beforeAfter:
Before and After Your Endoscopy
How do I prepare for an endoscopy?
Before your endoscopy, you will have a first-time visit and consultation with your gastroenterologist. This is a chance for you to discuss your condition and symptoms so we can learn about your health. Usually, no procedures are done on your first visit.
Our physicians ask that you have a doctor’s order for the endoscopy. Please arrive 30 minutes before your scheduled appointment time if you’re a new patient and fifteen minutes ahead if you’re a follow-up. If you arrive fifteen minutes after your scheduled appointment time, your appointment will need to be rescheduled. Please bring your informed consent form.
As endoscopy procedures vary, please talk with your physician for instructions regarding preparations for your endoscopy.
After Your Endoscopic Procedure
After your endoscopy, your physician will share your test results with you and your visitor (with your permission). You'll be monitored for at least 30 minutes before you’re sent home. Your doctor will also give you a discharge instruction sheet.
Because you’ll be sedated during your endoscopy, it’s important to limit your activity afterward.
No drinking alcoholic beverages.
No driving or operating any equipment.
No important decision-making.
No working.
You may resume all of your usual activities the next day.

content.articleContent:
A Clear View for Healthy Eyesight
Eyesight is one of our most valuable senses. That’s why ProMedica offers complete, full-service ophthalmology services for patients of every age all around northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. From routine vision testing, glasses and contact lenses to eye disorder treatment and even vision correction, we’re all about meeting your every eye-care need.
content.eyeHealth:
Protect and Maintain Your Eye Health
Keeping your eyes healthy is just as important as keeping the rest of your body healthy. And taking steps every day, as recommended by your eye care provider, will go a long way. Whether that means using eye drops when your eyes are dry, itchy or irritated or properly cleaning and using needed eyewear, treat your eyes like the important organ they are.
And, since some eye diseases don’t show early warning signs, it’s important you remember to get your eyes checked as often as your healthcare provider tells you to, or if you have any new vision problems.
Get Routine Vision Screenings
Regular eye exams are the best way to understand and protect your eye health. Early diagnosis will make sure you get proper treatment that could help save your eyesight. This is especially vital for eye conditions that don’t have clear, early signs or symptoms.
At ProMedica’s eye care centers, we use leading-edge technology to perform exams, adjust eyeglass prescriptions and treat eye problems. Our methods include:
Fluorescein angiography (retinal imaging).
HRT (three-dimensional imaging).
OCT cross-sectional imaging.
Pentacam®.
VISX™ Star S4 IR™.
Our ProMedica eye care specialists recommend regular checkups for eye health at every stage of life. Keep these guidelines in mind:
Children who have no family history of eye disease or symptoms should have their eyes examined by their pediatrician as part of their regular well-child check-ups. Children should have a complete eye exam by an eye care professional before they start school, and then every two years after. Learn more.
A complete eye exam is recommended for adults who have good vision and healthy eyes with no family history of eye disease or symptoms. This should be done at least one time between ages 20 and 29 and at least two times between ages 30 and 39.
If you’re an adult with no symptoms or eye disease risk factors, the American Academy of Ophthalmology now recommends a baseline complete eye exam at age 40 to screen for eye diseases. Between the ages of 40 and 60, adults should follow up at the times that are recommended by their eye doctor. This will depend on factors that are evaluated at the baseline exam.
Older adults ages 60 and over should have a complete eye exam every one or two years. The exam should check for eye diseases such as diabetic retinopathy, glaucoma, age-related macular degeneration and cataracts. People with a family history of eye disease or other risk factors should see their eye care doctor more often.
Follow Eye Safety Tips
Protect your eyes during your daily routine and planned activities. Be sure to wear:
One-piece plastic sports frames with polycarbonate lenses when playing sports or recreational activities.
Plastic safety goggles when working with household cleaning products, weed-killers, fertilizers and other chemicals, or with power tools and yard equipment.
Sunglasses that block 100% of both UVA and UVB radiation whenever you spend time outdoors. Gray, green and brown lenses provide the most protection.
Wraparound frames when you spend a lot of time outdoors in bright sunlight.
Take Care of Your Eyewear
If you wear contact lenses, keep these guidelines in mind:
Clean and disinfect your lenses' carrying case often. Use a new case every six months.
Don't put contact lenses in your mouth or dampen them with saliva.
Don't go to sleep with your contact lenses in. The only time to do this is when the lenses are made to be worn day and night. Sleeping with them in can raise your chances of getting an infection by about 10 times.
Don't use homemade saline solutions.
Carefully follow lens care and wearing instructions.
See your eye care provider if you have pain wearing lenses or you have any change in your vision.
Wash your hands thoroughly before handling your lenses.
Avoid Eye Strain
There’s no doubt that using a computer strains your eyes. It's important to think about your eyes when you’re working on the computer. It’s part of doing all you can to protect your valuable sight.
Adjust the angle of the computer screen to cut down on reflections from overhead lights and desk lamps.
Adjust the screen 20 to 25 inches away from your eyes and slightly below eye level.
Follow the 20-20-20 rule. Every 20 minutes take a 20-second break and focus your eyes on an object 20 feet away.
Keep the screen’s brightness as bright or brighter than other bright objects in the room.
Place the screen at right angles to any windows to cut down on glare. Use a filter that reduces glare or, if glare is an ongoing problem, use a computer hood with three sides.
Use an adjustable holder for papers. Adjust the holder so your reference materials are at the same height and distance from you as the computer screen.
Use artificial tears to refresh your eyes when they feel dry.
Wipe the screen often with an anti-static cloth.
Learn about the importance of your annual eye exam.
content.eyewear:
Eyewear and Treatment Options
Eyewear
You have a lot of options when it comes to correcting your vision. A basic pair of glasses, disposable contact lenses, designer frames, tinted or progressive eyeglass lenses — the choices may seem endless. Your ProMedica eye care provider can help you decide which option meets your exact needs. We’ll help you choose the right lenses for you and also talk with you about add-ons such as anti-glare coatings and transitional lenses.
At ProMedica’s eye care center in Toledo, you can choose from a wide range of glasses, contact lenses or both. Our eyewear options include:
Basic and designer frames.
Children’s eyewear.
Contact lenses.
Crystalens®.
Glasses, sunglasses and lenses.
Lightweight progressive, bifocal lenses.
Protective sports eyewear.
Reading glasses.
Refractive lens implants.
Specialty lenses.
Visit our retail shop to see your eyewear options.
Common Eye Treatments
If you’re tired of depending on glasses or contact lenses, laser vision correction may be a good choice.
At ProMedica Eye Care, our experienced physicians and clinical staff offer highly effective and advanced procedures to treat eye conditions and diseases. This includes refractive surgery.
You might be able to have refractive surgery if you’re nearsighted, farsighted, have astigmatism or just can’t see as well as you did when you were younger. ProMedica offers refractive surgery as an outpatient procedure. It’s performed in the office at ProMedica Health and Wellness Center.
Your comfort and care are most important to us. That’s why we perform the full spectrum of vision procedures in a healing, supportive outpatient environment. These procedures include:
Cataract extraction.
Corneal surgery.
Cosmetic plastic surgery, blepharoplasty, Botox, and dermal fillers.
Glaucoma corrective surgery.
Various laser procedures.
Oculoplastic surgery.
Refractive lens implants.
Retinal surgery.
content.faq:
Frequently Asked Questions
We need our sight to see and make sense of the world. The health of your eyes is vital to your quality of life. But if it’s been a while since your last vision exam, you may feel overwhelmed by all the information that’s covered. Here are some of the questions you’re likely to discuss with your eye doctor.
What is “20/20” vision?
When you hear that someone has “20/20” vision it usually means they have good eyesight and don’t need eyeglasses. The phrase “20/20 vision” refers to normal vision and a person’s ability to read a certain row of letters on a standard vision chart from 20 feet away.
Why is it important to have a dilated eye exam?
Dilation lets your eye doctor view the inside of your eyes and check their health. During a dilated eye exam, the doctor can see signs and symptoms of vision problems, eye diseases and even other health conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol.
What does it mean if you are nearsighted, farsighted or have an astigmatism?
Nearsightedness, farsightedness and astigmatism are all refractive disorders and are the most common eye problems in the United States. If you’re nearsighted, it means you’re able to see objects clearly up-close, while objects in the distance are blurry. If you’re farsighted, you’re able to see objects clearly in the distance and up-close objects are blurry. Having an astigmatism means your cornea is shaped like a football, which causes objects both near and far to be distorted and out of focus.
Sometimes I see spots or things that seem to float. Is that a sign of something serious?
In most cases, spots or “floaters” are very common and are a part of the natural aging process. As we get older, the vitreous (the clear, gel-like substance that fills the inside of the eye) tends to shrink slightly, detach from the retina and form clumps within the eye. What you see are the shadows these clumps cast on the retina, the light-sensitive nerve layer that lines the back of the eye.
Floaters can get in the way of clear vision, often when reading. Try looking up and then down to move the floaters out of the way. While some floaters may remain, many of them will fade over time.
If you have a sudden “flash” of light or rush of floaters, you may have a tear in your retina, or your retina may be detaching from the back of the eye. This is a serious problem that must be treated by a healthcare provider as soon as possible to avoid losing vision permanently.
Is glaucoma curable?
Currently, there is no cure for glaucoma. Vision that’s lost because of glaucoma can’t be restored. That’s why complete dilated eye exams are critical to diagnose glaucoma. Then treatment can begin before permanent damage occurs.
What is a cataract and am I going blind?
Cataracts are cloudy areas that form on the natural lens of the eye. Cataracts keep light from passing to the retina. This makes it hard to see at night and causes objects to look blurry, hazy and dull. Cataracts are one of the most common eye conditions in the United States and are treated with surgery. If left untreated, cataracts cause ongoing vision loss and can lead to legal blindness or even total blindness.
Why do I need to return for a contact lens check?
You need a contact lens check if you’re new to wearing contact lenses or your contact lens brand or prescription has changed. A contact lens check makes sure that both lenses fit on the eye properly and it also shows the quality of your vision with the new lenses.
content.conditions:
Common Eye Conditions and Diseases
At ProMedica Eye Care, our expert physicians and clinical staff have experience with the most effective, advanced procedures to treat eye conditions and diseases.
Cataracts
Cataracts are cloudy areas in a person’s normally clear eye lens that blocks the passage of light to the retina. Cataracts can cause a person to be more sensitive to light glare and can make it hard to see, especially at night. Cataract patients often have dull visual sharpness, color and form, and a halo effect around lights.
Chronic Dry Eye
Chronic dry eye develops when the eye does not produce enough tears or the eyelid’s structure keeps tear film from forming evenly over the surface of the eye. The eye’s naturally produced tear film dries up too quickly, and the composition of tears is not normal.
Diabetic Retinopathy
Diabetic retinopathy be caused by long-term diabetes and it usually affects both eyes. It’s often symptom-free until the last stage, which can cause rapid, permanent eye damage and vision loss. The symptoms of diabetic retinopathy may include:
Blank or dark areas in your field of vision.
Blurred vision.
Colors appear washed out or different.
Floaters (spots, dots or cobweb-like dark strings floating in your vision).
Poor night vision.
Vision that sometimes changes from blurry to clear.
Learn more about diabetic retinopathy care with ProMedica.
Flashes and Floaters
Flashes and floaters appear as small specks or clouds moving in your field of vision. They’re more common as we approach middle-age.
Floaters are actually tiny clumps of cells or material inside the vitreous, which is the clear, gel-like fluid that fills the inside of your eye. Once that vitreous gel begins to shrink, the posterior vitreous detaches itself from the back wall of the eye. This results in floaters and flashes.
Glaucoma
Glaucoma is created when fluid builds up because it’s not able to naturally drain out of the eye. This fluid build-up raises the pressure in the eye. It can lead to permanent optic nerve damage with partial or even total vision loss. If caught early, glaucoma can usually be controlled.
There are several types of glaucoma:
Angle-closure.
Congenital or “childhood.”
Irido corneal endothelial syndrome (ICE).
Neovascular.
Normal tension.
Pigmentary.
Primary open-angle (POAG).
Macular Degeneration
Macular degeneration affects the part of our eyes that lets us see fine details. It’s part of the body's natural aging process and is more common in those over age 75.
There are two classifications of macular degeneration: dry macular degeneration and wet macular degeneration.
Dry macular degeneration affects one or both eyes and can make distance vision or reading vision blurry. If you have this condition, you may need more bright light to see up close and colors appear less vivid or bright. You may have hazy vision or trouble seeing when you enter a dimly lit room from the bright outdoors. You may not be able to easily recognize people's faces, and there’s a blank or blurry spot in your central vision.
Wet macular degeneration symptoms usually appear and get worse quickly. Colors lose their brightness and don’t look the same for each eye. The size of objects may also look different for each eye. You may have distorted vision (straight lines will appear bent, crooked or irregular), dark gray spots or blank spots in your vision. You may also lose your central vision.
Retinal Detachment
Retinal detachment happens when the light-sensitive membrane in the eye separates from the layers that support it. Some signs that your retina has detached are:
A sudden appearance of flashes, which could be the first stage of a retinal tear or detachment.
A sudden decrease in your vision.
A sudden increase in size and number of floaters.
Having a shadow appear in the periphery (side) of your field of vision.
Seeing a gray curtain move across your field of vision.
Eye Styes and Blepharitis

Eye styes are painful and can lead to bigger problems. Pediatric Ophthalmologist Dr. Michelle Ariss explains how we treat and prevent styes.

content.articleContent:
Helping Children See the World Clearly
Children’s bodies grow and change fast — and that includes their eyes. That’s why it’s important for children to get regular eye care. ProMedica’ eye care team can make sure their eyes are healthy and detect and correct eye problems in their early stages.
We recommend that infants be closely checked by their pediatrician and have their first eye exam when they’re six months old. Children should have more eye exams when they enter preschool at age three and before they start kindergarten at age five or six. School age children should visit an eye doctor for a complete vision screening every one to two years.
Common pediatric eye conditions include:
Amblyopia (lazy eye).
Blocked tear duct.
Cataract (cloudy eyes).
Cellulitis (an infection of the eyelid that’s related to trauma or an upper respiratory problem).
Chalazion (small lump on the eyelid).
Conjunctivitis (pink eye).
Juvenile macular degeneration.
Pediatric glaucoma.
Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid).
Sty (a red, sore lump near the edge of the eyelid).
content.development:
What to Look for at Every Age
Children with a family history of childhood vision problems are more likely to have eye problems themselves. But all parents should know the warning signs of vision problems. Use these guidelines to help you know how to properly care for the eyes at every stage of childhood.
Birth to Four Months Old
Most babies’ eyes occasionally look misaligned (this is called strabismus). After four months of age, inward crossing or outward drifting that happens often is considered abnormal. If you notice crossing or drifting, let your child's doctor know.
Babies Older Than Three Months
Infants older than three months should be able to follow or track an object, like a toy or ball, with their eyes as it moves across their field of vision. If your baby can't make steady eye contact by this age or doesn’t seem able to see, report this to your doctor.
Toddlers and Preschoolers
Many vision problems have no warning signs. So, children often don’t notice it and most likely won’t complain about vision problems. That's why it's important to have your child's eyes checked. Even if your child can’t read yet, your doctor can do special vision tests.
All Children
If you notice any of the following, have your child's eyes checked by an eye care professional:
Eyes that flutter from side to side or up and down.
White or grayish-white color in the pupil.
Bulging eye(s) or drooping eyelid(s).
Pus or crust in either eye; or eye pain, itchiness or discomfort.
Redness in either eye that doesn't go away in a few days.
Eyes that are always watery, sensitive to light or both.
Other signs that your child may have a vision problem that and needs a complete eye exam:
Avoiding up-close tasks.
Complaining of headaches or tired eyes.
Blinking or rubbing their eyes too much.
Having a short attention span.
Holding reading materials too close or sitting too close to the television.
Poor hand-eye coordination.
Tilting their head, squinting, or closing one eye to see better.
Using a finger to follow along or losing their place while reading.
content.safety:
Keep Your Child's Eyes Safe
The best safeguard against childhood eye injuries is taking steps to prevent them — and, when children are old enough to understand, teaching them safety practices when enjoying certain activities. Some tips include:
Give your children safety glasses when they're playing with chemistry sets, workshop tools or toys that fire objects.
Have your children wear the correct goggles when skiing, snowboarding, and riding on snowmobiles. They should wear helmets with face guards when playing football, ice hockey, roller hockey and other high-impact sports.
Keep children away from activities like snow blowing, mowing, working with power tools or hand tools, using cleaning agents, applying fertilizer or weed-killer, or doing other work that can be harm eyes.
Keep children away from fireworks, firecrackers and other flammable materials.
Treatment for Misaligned Eyes in Children

Pediatric Ophthalmologist Dr. Michelle Ariss explains treatment options for misaligned eyes, a condition where children’s eyes don’t look in the same direction.
Eye Styes and Blepharitis

Eye styes are painful and can lead to bigger problems. Pediatric Ophthalmologist Dr. Michelle Ariss explains how we treat and prevent styes.
content.eyewear:
Eyewear for Children’s Unique Needs
Children need eyewear that’s appropriate for their age and activities. At ProMedica your pediatric eye care provider will help your child understand what options are right for them. We also work closely with children to teach them how to take care of their eyewear, from young children getting their first pair of glasses, to preteens and teens that are learning how to put in contact lenses.
Our eyewear options for children include:
Basic and designer frames.
Contact lenses for preteens and teens.
Glasses, sunglasses and lenses.
Protective sports eyewear.
Visit our retail shop.
content.faq:
Frequently Asked Questions
Sight is critical to childhood development. Kids use their vision to make sense of the world and acquire the information they need to learn. If your child has been referred to us for vision care, they probably want to know more about what comes next. Here are some of the most frequent eyesight questions we get asked.
What is “20/20” vision?
If you hear that someone has “20/20” vision it usually means they have good eyesight and don’t need eyeglasses. The phrase “20/20 vision” refers to normal vision and a person’s ability to read a certain row of letters on a standard vision chart from 20 feet away.
Why do I have to have a dilated eye exam?
Dilating your pupils allows your eye doctor to see the inside of your eyes and check for symptoms of vision problems, eye diseases and other health conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol.
What does it mean if you are nearsighted, farsighted or have an astigmatism?
Nearsightedness, farsightedness and astigmatism are the most common eye problems in the United States. If you’re nearsighted, it means you can see objects clearly up-close, but objects in the distance are blurry. If you’re farsighted, you can see objects clearly in the distance and up-close objects are blurry. Having an astigmatism means your cornea is shaped like a football and causes objects both near and far to be distorted and out of focus.
