content.articleContent:
Exercise Your Way to Lifelong Health
Whether you want to get back in shape after baby, need to regain strength after an orthopaedic injury or are managing a health condition like heart disease or diabetes, an exercise plan can help you reach your fitness goals.
From better sleep to a more confident you, exercise offers you many benefits including:
Improved heart, lung, bone and joint health.
Reduced risk for future injury, heart disease, high blood pressure and some cancers.
Lower stress levels.
Weight management and weight loss.
ProMedica offers a variety of exercise programs designed to meet a variety of health goals. And, our trainers, medical exercise specialists and nutritionists are on hand to guide every step of your journey.
content.programs:
Our Fitness Programs
Whatever your age, current health or fitness level, we have options for you at ProMedica. From access to facilities where you can work independently to medically supervised programs, we’ve made sure there’s something for everyone.
Remember to speak with your healthcare provider before participating in an exercise program. You’ll need a referral to register for our medically supervised exercise programs. For assistance obtaining a referral, to register, or for more information, please call ProMedica ForeverFit at 419-539-0235.
Some of our specialized fitness programs include:
Expand All
Bridge to Fitness
Bridge to Fitness is a fitness education program designed to encourage a commitment to physical activity to enhance your wellbeing as you live with certain medical conditions.
Offering a mix of cardiovascular, strength and flexibility activities that match your endurance level, you will take these group classes with people who are at similar points in their health.
Through Bridge to Fitness, you’ll improve your cardiovascular endurance and muscular strength, reduce fatigue and improve your ability to perform day-to-day activities. And, by focusing your energy on wellness, you will improve your mood and decrease anxiety.
Bridge to Fitness is specifically offered for:
Cancer survivors.
Cardiac and pulmonary rehab patients.
People living with diabetes.
People who’ve had or are planning to have bariatric surgery.
To register, speak to your doctor or call 419-539-0235. There is a minimal cost to participate (typically less than $6 per session), but some qualified participants pay nothing. Contact us to learn more.
Fitness Is Ageless
Your age doesn’t matter when it comes to fitness. Exercise reduces your risk of heart disease, diabetes, stroke, memory issues, sleep disorders and injuries. It also enhances independence at home. That’s why ProMedica designed a safe, effective exercise program for seniors to stay healthy and active.
Fitness is Ageless is a one-hour class that includes low-impact exercises to help improve your:
Balance.
Energy.
Flexibility.
Overall well-being.
Strength.
Classes are held throughout the week at ProMedica ForeverFit.
ProMedica ForeverFit
ProMedica offers a variety of programs to help you get and stay fit. If you’re looking to start a fitness regimen on your own, check out ProMedica ForeverFit, an athletic club that focuses on healthy aging. With cardio and strength training areas, group fitness classes, and small group training available free to members, ForeverFit has the tools you need to be fit at any age.
Learn more about ProMedica ForeverFit
Script4Fitness
Script4Fitness is a medically-based supervised exercise program. Participants will have the opportunity to work one-on-one with an exercise physiologist who will help tailor an exercise program to fit participant’s specific needs.
Script4Fitness is a great choice if you:
Are dealing with chronic health issues (heart disease, diabetes, obesity, arthritis, etc.).
Have recently finished physical therapy and would like to continue improving orthopaedic limitations.
Are working to prepare for bariatric or orthopaedic surgery.
Would benefit from a general exercise program in order to improve activities of daily living or quality of life.
Participants have the option to participate in two different program tracks:
Fully-supervised: The fully supervised track allows participants to meet with an exercise physiologist for eight sessions. Sessions can be completed as either eight one-hour sessions or sixteen half-hour sessions.
Partially-supervised: The partially-supervised track allows participant to work one-on-one with an exercise physiologist to develop an exercise program that they can then perform independently at the facility for 60 days. Participants receive four total one-on-one sessions.
Speak to your doctor before participating in an exercise program. You’ll need a referral to register for our medically supervised exercise programs. For assistance obtaining a referral, to register, or for more information, please call ProMedica ForeverFit at 419-539-0235.

content.articleContent:
General Surgery at ProMedica
Our team strives to provide innovative surgical care for our patients in state-of-the-art facilities. Our continued focus is outstanding surgical outcomes, patient safety and technological advancements.
We treat and care for a range of conditions related, but not limited to, the following:
Gallbladder
Hernia
Endocrine
Appendectomy
Colectomy
Cholecystectomy

Gastrointestinal surgery

Choosing the right surgeon and type of surgery can make a world of difference. In addition to traditional general surgery, we also offer general surgery procedures performed by our surgeons using the da Vinci surgical system. Often times, robotic surgery can reduce the pain and risk associated with traditional surgery.
Learn more about robotic surgery at ProMedica.
General Robotic Surgery
Choosing the right surgeon and type of surgery can make a world of difference.
Robotic surgery can reduce the pain and risk associated with traditional surgery.
You’ll likely get improved outcomes and quicker recovery.

content.articleContent:
Helping You Understand and Manage Your Cancer Risk
When there’s a family history of cancer, the idea of a possible cancer diagnosis can bring a lot of anxiety about the future. But what if we could help limit the unknowns and ease some of your fears?
When you need answers, you can count on the ProMedica genetic counseling team. We’ll help you determine if genetic testing is right for you and your family — and if testing is needed, we’ll be there every step of the way. Together, we’ll help you manage your cancer risk and take charge of your health.
content.whatIs:
What Is Genetic Counseling?
Our genes act like instructions for our body’s cells. They help decide what we look like and how our body is built.
Sometimes our genes change, or they look different from normal genes. This is called a mutation. Mutations can affect how cells in your body behave. In some cases, a mutation can raise your risk for cancer.
Scientists have found certain gene mutations can raise the risk for certain cancers. For example, mutated BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes can raise the risk for ovarian and breast cancers.
When parents pass one of these gene mutations to their children, it’s called a hereditary cancer syndrome. Families with this syndrome are more likely to have cancer.
Genetic counseling and testing can help show if you or family members have a hereditary cancer syndrome. If you have the syndrome, you can work with your doctor to come up with a prevention plan. This plan can include regular cancer screenings, lifestyle changes and preventive surgery.
Know When to Test
Some cancers are linked to certain genetic mutations. You may want to think about having genetic testing if you or a family member have been diagnosed with:
Breast cancer before age 50.
Breast cancer in both breasts (bilateral breast cancer).
Colorectal cancer before age 50.
Endometrial cancer before age 50.
Male breast cancer.
Metastatic prostate cancer.
Ovarian cancer.
Pancreatic cancer.
You may also consider genetic testing if you have:
A relative with a BRCA gene mutation.
Family members of Ashkenazi Jewish descent who have had breast cancer at any age.
More than one family member with the same kind of cancer.
Several family members who had cancer at a young age.
What to Expect During Counseling and Testing
If you believe you could benefit from a hereditary risk assessment, discuss with your physician. If the two of you decide you are an appropriate candidate, your physician will refer you to our genetic services. Our program is run by board-certified, licensed genetic counselors, and is the largest in the region.
During this appointment, you’ll talk about your personal and family health history so it’s helpful to prepare this ahead of time. The licensed genetic counselor will discuss options for you and your family. These may include further genetic testing, possible changes to medical screening procedures and frequencies, and other risk reducing options.
If genetic testing is deemed appropriate, we’ll refer you to one of the ProMedica hospitals that has genetic testing services. We have nine genetic testing locations in northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. Once your test results are ready, we’ll go over the results together and come up with a plan for screening and prevention. The genetic counselor will send this plan to your doctor.
Prevention plans are different for everyone. They may include starting cancer screenings early, such as mammograms or colonoscopies. Some people also consider preventive surgery. Your genetic counselor will go over all your choices and will answer any questions you have along the way.
content.faq:
Frequently Asked Questions
Are genetic tests covered by insurance?
Many health insurance plans pay for genetic tests. But you should still check with your own health plan company. Our preauthorization team can help you figure out whether your health plan covers the tests.
Can genetic tests make a difference if I already know I have a family history of cancer?
Yes. Genetic tests can help you and your doctor understand your true risk for a hereditary cancer syndrome. These tests can help you make the best choices to screen and prevent cancer.
Does law prohibit genetic discrimination?
Yes. Federal law prevents discrimination against people based on their genetic information. Most states also have similar discrimination laws.
Who can access my genetic test results?
Genetic test results are completely confidential. Even when health plans pay for tests, the health plan company won’t get the results. We won’t give the test results to anyone unless we have your written permission.
Which family member should be tested first?
The person who has been diagnosed with cancer should be the first person to have genetic testing. But, if this person can’t be tested, we can test another family member.
I had genetic testing a few years ago and my results were negative. Are new tests available?
Yes. Scientists have found more genes that cause hereditary cancer syndromes. Based on your health history, you may want to have more testing.
Can men be affected by hereditary cancer syndromes?
Yes. Both mothers and fathers can pass a hereditary cancer syndrome to their children. Men can also take steps to lower their cancer risk or find cancer early.
content.contact:
Contact Us
If you’d like more information about genetic tests for cancer or want to request an appointment, we’re ready to help. Submit this form and a member of our team will be in touch.

content.articleContent:
About Gynecologic Surgery
Treatment for a number of female reproductive conditions may require surgery. We help you get back on your feet and back to your normal activities faster with robotic surgery.
Robotic Surgery
Gynecologic robotic surgery is performed through several tiny incisions, making robotic surgery the least invasive type of gynecologic surgery available.
Gynecologic surgeries we perform with the da Vinci® Surgical System include:
Cervical cancer
Endometrial cancer
Benign hysterectomy
Hysterectomy
Laparoscopy diagnostic
Myomectomy
Oophorectomy
Pelvic reconstruction
Pelvic pain procedures
Resection of endometriosis
Sacrocolpopexy
If your physician recommends surgery for any of these conditions, ask if robotic surgery is right for you. Robotic surgery is available at ProMedica Bay Park Hospital, ProMedica Flower Hospital, and ProMedica Toledo Hospital.
Call 419-291-4575 to learn more about gynecologic robotic surgery.

Personalized care for you and your daughter
A woman’s health care needs can be very personal. You need a provider you can trust to ask the right questions, provide the best treatments and offer you choices that fit your life and your health.
At ProMedica, our gynecologists focus on your specific needs. From puberty on, we’re here for you with the full range of gynecologic care, individualized for your age, your health and your personal choices.
We’re also here for your daughter, with advice on how to talk with her about safe sex and also with immunizations to protect her from sexually transmitted diseases. We want you and your daughter to stay as healthy as you can be.
content.approach:
Our Approach
All women need gynecologic care, and they need it to be right for them. Your board-certified gynecologist at ProMedica will establish a relationship with you in order to understand your healthcare needs, especially your reproductive health. To help you stay healthy throughout your life, we offer:
Consultation on gynecologic surgeries and on alternatives to hysterectomy.
Diagnosis of and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases.
Fertility evaluations and family planning.
Help with menstrual difficulties and menopause.
Hormone replacement therapies.
Pap tests to check for cervical cancer.
Regular wellness exams.
content.services:
Our Services
Annual Gynecology Visits
Our top priority is to keep you well, and that starts with your yearly gynecology checkup. These checkups are important for any girl or woman who is sexually active. If not, these exams should start at age 13 to 15.
During this visit, your gynecologist will listen carefully to any symptoms or problem you may have. You may also have some of the following tests and procedures:
Breast exam: Your gynecologist is an expert at checking for any lumps or other abnormalities in your breasts, and will do it quickly and efficiently.
General health check: Your personal and family health history can offer clues to your health today. That’s why we’ll ask about any conditions you or someone in your family have had. Your nurse will also weigh you, take your blood pressure and may also ask you to take blood and urine tests.
Internal bimanual exam: This test is done to check for problems in your cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes and ovaries. To complete the bimanual exam, your provider inserts two gloved, lubricated fingers into your vagina while lightly pressing on your abdomen with the other hand. This is done to feel around for any growths or abnormalities.
Pap test: This test is done during your pelvic exam to check for cervical cancer and other problems. Your gynecologist uses a small brush to collect cell samples from your cervix, which are sent to a lab for testing.
Pelvic exam: It’s normal to feel uneasy about this exam, but it’s important to your health. Your gynecologist will examine your vagina and cervix. You may feel some pressure during this exam, but it shouldn’t be painful.
STD tests: If you’re sexually active, you may have a sexually transmitted disease (STD) even if you don’t have symptoms. Your gynecologist may take a swab of cells during your pelvic exam, or order blood or urine tests, to check for STDs such as gonorrhea, chlamydia, syphilis or HIV.
Your gynecologist will also help you know how to listen to your body, so you can tell what’s normal and recognize when there may be a problem. For example, many women have chronic pelvic pain yet they suffer in silence. If this includes you, please make an appointment. We’re here to help.
Birth Control Guidance
When you choose a method of birth control, you’ll be considering many issues — most of them personal. Your ProMedica gynecologist can give you the information you need to choose which of these options is best for you:
Barrier methods: This includes condoms, diaphragms, cervical caps and contraceptive sponges. All of these block the sperm from fertilizing the egg.
Birth Control Pills: With about 12 million women in the United States using birth control pills, they’re by far the most common method of birth control and are proven to prevent pregnancy when you take them correctly.
Hormonal methods: Birth control pills, a contraceptive implant (Implanon), a contraceptive injection (Depo-Provera), the vaginal ring (NuvaRing) and the contraceptive patch (Ortho Evra) are all examples of hormonal birth control. They keep you from ovulating, so there is no egg for sperm cells to fertilize.
Intrauterine devices (IUDs): These include the copper IUD (ParaGard) and hormonal IUD (Mirena). Both work by changing the way sperm cells move so they can’t fertilize the egg.
Sterilization: Tubal ligation, or having your tubes tied, keeps your eggs away from sperm cells. Essure® is a permanent, non-surgical way to keep eggs away from sperm.
Natural family planning, or the rhythm method: With this type of birth control, you avoid intercourse based on your basal body temperature and your cervical mucus, which can tell you when you will ovulate.
Gynecology Care for Adolescents
If you have a young daughter, you’ve probably thought about “the talk.” This can mean talking to her about the body changes she’ll experience with puberty, along with everything that follows as she gets older.
We can help with this. Your gynecologist can give you ideas about how to talk with your daughter about sex, sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), and the health care she will need as she grows up.
Your Daughter's First Gynecologic Exam
This is an important doctor visit, since it can set the tone for your daughter’s future healthcare experiences. The gynecologists at ProMedica understand how to talk with girls and how to put them at ease.
Schedule your daughter’s first gynecologic exam when she’s 13 to 15 years old or when she becomes sexually active, whichever comes first. If you don’t know how to talk about sex with your daughter, your gynecologist can give you some ideas for how to proceed.
Important Immunizations
There are vaccinations that can protect your daughter from several diseases and may be given before her first gynecologic exam, including:
Cervical cancer vaccine: Most cervical cancers are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Gardasil and Cervarix are FDA-approved vaccines that prevent most cervical cancers if they are given before your daughter is exposed to the HPV virus.
Both should be given between the ages of 11 and 12 years, in a series of three injections over a six month period. They can prevent vaginal and vulvar cancer, and Gardasil can also prevent genital warts and anal cancer.
HPV vaccine: The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine protects against four major types of HPV. This can help your daughter avoid most genital warts and most cervical cancers.
This vaccine is given in three doses, with the first recommended between the ages of 11 and 12 years. The second dose is given one or two months after that, and the third dose is given six months after the first injection.
Menopause Counseling
Your sexual health and needs may change around your menopause years. We can recommend a course of action that will help you adjust to your body’s changes. Depending on your symptoms and their causes, we may recommend counseling, education or medication.
Learn more about menopause.
Screening and Prevention
Screenings can point out your risk factors for conditions such as cancer, cardiovascular disease and osteoporosis, which tend to happen later in life. Once you know your risks, you can work with your doctor to determine the best combination of diet, lifestyle changes and medications to help you avoid these conditions. If you are diagnosed with a condition, your doctor will recommend an effective treatment plan.
Surgical Treatment
A number of conditions of your reproductive system may require surgery. Surgeons at ProMedica use a state-of-the-art method called da Vinci® Surgical System, which is the least invasive type of gynecologic surgery so you can get back quickly to the activities you enjoy.
We use the da Vinci® Surgical System for these surgical procedures:
Cervical cancer treatment.
Diagnostic laparoscopy.
Endometrial cancer and endometriosis treatment.
Hysterectomy.
Pelvic pain procedures.
Pelvic reconstruction.
To learn more about gynecologic robotic surgery, call 419-291-4575
Lifestyle Assessment
Your gynecologist plays an important role in your overall health. We can look at all aspects of your lifestyle and help you identify changes you can make to be healthier.
We can provide dietary education and counseling to help you reduce menopausal symptoms and your risks for cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis and breast cancer. We can also make recommendations for being active to help your heart, your lungs, your mood and manage your weight.
Sometimes we may connect you with other services, such as a weight reduction program that uses prescription weight-loss medications, a physician-monitored weight-loss program or a consultation with a dietitian. And if you smoke, we can help you quit. We’re here to be a partner in your health.

content.articleContent:
Boost Your Healing
If you’re dealing with slow-healing wounds, diabetic foot ulcers or serious burns, it can be hard to focus on the rest of your health. When you need help, you can count on ProMedica for state-of-the-art hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBO) and healing.
For medical emergency referrals, call 919-684-4326. Ask to speak to the HBO physician on call. Diving emergency referrals should contact Divers Alert Network at 800-446-2671.
content.expect:
What to Expect with HBO Therapy
When body tissue is injured, it needs more oxygen to survive. To raise the amount of oxygen in your blood, HBO delivers 100% pure oxygen under a specialized pressure chamber. This higher pressure lets your lungs gather up to three times more oxygen than with normal air pressure. The oxygen-rich blood is carried to your damaged body tissue to help heal wounds more quickly and fight infection.
Effective Treatment for a Wide Range of Health Conditions
Although some disorders are mainly treated with hyperbaric oxygen therapy, it's most often combined with other types of medical treatments. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is an approved treatment for many types of conditions, including:
Anemia.
Bone infections.
Carbon monoxide and cyanide poisoning.
Chronic wounds, including non-healing skin grafts and flaps.
Decompression sickness.
Diabetic wounds in the feet and legs.
Embolism.
Necrotic soft tissue infections.
Smoke inhalation.
Thermal burns.
Tissue damage from radiation treatment.
Traumatic injuries that prevent blood from reaching tissues or organs.
What to Expect Before Treatment
Before your hyperbaric oxygen treatment, we’ll make sure you’re comfortable and at ease. We can answer any questions you may have about the treatment and what to expect. To help make sure you have the safest, most effective session, please be sure to:
Give us a complete list of your prescription and over-the-counter medicines. We need the list to see if you’re taking any medicines that may change your body’s response to oxygen.
Report an illness, like a cold or the flu, to your HBO care team. You may need to be treated after your illness is over.
Remove watches, jewelry, hearing aids and other prosthetic devices before you begin your treatment.
Wash all oil and alcohol-based products out of your hair and off your skin.
You may have to take vitamin E about 30 minutes before each treatment.
What to Expect During Treatment
During hyperbaric oxygen therapy treatments, you’ll lie comfortably inside the HBO chamber. Because the HBO chamber is clear acrylic, you can see the therapist or nurse during the whole treatment. You can also speak to the staff through the chamber’s intercom. During therapy, you can relax, nap or watch television.
After the door to the chamber is closed, the oxygen begins to circulate. The chamber’s pressure, which is prescribed by an HBO physician, is slowly raised over a short time. During this compression period, you may feel fullness in your ears, similar to when you fly in an airplane. The hyperbaric medicine staff offers ways to ease this feeling, but it often goes away once the right amount of pressure is reached.
Treatment lasts 120 to 154 minutes, based on your condition. However, some developing conditions may need longer treatment sessions.
The number of sessions also varies based on how your body responds to the treatment. You may need HBO therapy over a few days or over several months. Your hyperbaric provider will check on your progress regularly and adjust your therapy plan as needed.
What to Expect After Treatment
You shouldn’t notice any side effects from your treatments and should be able to resume your normal daily activities right away. However, in some cases, patients have reported feeling light-headed or tired for a short period of time.
Your doctor will monitor your progress throughout your course of treatment and will let you know when HBO sessions are no longer needed.
content.faq:
Frequently Asked Questions
We want to make sure you have answers to all your questions before you have HBO therapy. If you don’t see the information you need below, please feel free to ask a member of your care team.
Who will administer my oxygen therapy?
You'll be evaluated by a doctor who specializes in hyperbaric oxygen therapy. The doctor will oversee your treatment, which is most often given by respiratory therapists and registered nurses. They’re specially trained in hyperbaric medicine.
Our team also works closely with other specialists to make sure you get care that’s tailored to your unique needs. We work together with:
Anesthesiologists.
Emergency medicine physicians.
Infectious disease doctors.
Internal medicine doctors.
Orthopaedists.
Podiatrists.
Pulmonologists.
Trauma specialists.
Vascular specialists.
Where can I find hyperbaric oxygen therapy near me?
Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is available at ProMedica Toledo Hospital. You'll need to have a referral from your doctor.
Doctors can make referrals seven days a week, 8 a.m. - 6:30 p.m. Please call ProMedica Toledo Hospital at 419-291-2072.
Will my insurance cover hyperbaric oxygen treatment?
Medicare, Medicaid and most major health plans cover the cost of medically necessary hyperbaric oxygen treatment. Talk to your health plan about coverage details. If you have concerns about paying for this therapy, you may be able to get financial assistance.

content.articleContent:
Advanced Cardiac Care from a Compassionate Team
Your heart works hard for you. And when it’s healthy, it gives you the strength you need for activities that bring you joy.
At the ProMedica Heart Institute, it’s our mission to help you live your very best life. You can count on our heart team for compassion, expertise and the most advanced technologies available — all so you can benefit from the very best in cardiac care.
Learn more about heart services.
View our 2021 annual report
If you think you or someone you’re with is having a heart attack, call 911.
content.approach:
Our Approach
A healthy heart helps you live the life you want. It starts with feeling confident that you’re getting the best in heart care. When you choose ProMedica, you choose a proven leader.
Expand All
Comprehensive Heart Care Throughout Our Region
Our collaborative network of experts ensures you’ll get high-quality, standardized care at any one of our hospitals, physician offices and outpatient facilities. ProMedica has physician offices conveniently located throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. Wherever you live, we’re working to take your health to heart in your neighborhood.
Convenient, Round-the-Clock Access
ProMedica Toledo Hospital is the only hospital in the Toledo region staffed by a cardiologist 24 hours a day, seven days a week. This helps us make sure we’re always prepared to treat patients who are having a heart attack.
Coordinated Care
All heart disease patients need precisely coordinated care. ProMedica’s team of heart experts are committed to making sure you have the most advanced, state-of-the-art technology and methods of cardiac care. With locations across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan, you can stay close to home for diagnosis, treatment and follow-up.
We’ve been serving Toledo and nearby communities for more than 25 years. Our team of specialists includes:
Cardiac electrophysiologists: Doctors who provide cutting-edge treatments and diagnostic procedures for issues related to the rhythm of your heart.
Cardiologists: Specialists in nonsurgical heart care, who can guide you toward lifestyle changes, medicines and potential ways to treat and prevent heart conditions.
Cardiothoracic surgeons: Highly trained specialists who perform open heart surgery and thoracic surgeries.
Pediatric cardiologists: Doctors who specialize in nonsurgical heart care for infants, children and adolescents.
Interventional Cardiologist: Experts who treat structural heart conditions through catheter-based minimally invasive procedures.
content.services:
Custom Treatments for Heart Disease
ProMedica has a collaborative network of heart-health experts in northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. As a cardiac patient, you can rest assured you’re getting high-quality heart care at any one of our hospitals, physician offices or outpatient facilities. We use a personalized approach that puts you at the center of your care.
Cardiac Rehab
Lower your risk of complications after your heart treatment or surgery: Work with the skilled professionals in our cardiac rehab program. They can help you with your diagnosis, treat your heart and educate you about how to live an active life within the limits of your disease.
Heart Failure Clinic
Maybe you’ve been discharged from our hospital with heart failure. Or perhaps you’re working with your cardiologist to diagnose your condition. Wherever you are in the process, the staff at our heart failure clinic will be with you. They’ll review your medicines, provide resources and address your concerns. You’ll have strong support to make lifestyle changes, navigate your care and address your emotional needs.
Arrhythmia and Devices
ProMedica provides heart rhythm care that includes pacemaker and device insertion. They also offer treatment for many other heart rhythm issues.
Cardiothoracic Surgery
Our heart surgery team performs more cardiothoracic surgeries than any other group in the Toledo region – more than 900 surgeries every year. We use state-of-the-art technology and surgical techniques for improved patient outcomes and work to keep you close to home for diagnosis, treatment, recovery and follow-up.
Learn more about cardiothoracic surgery.
Structural Heart Clinic
Our Structural Heart Clinic at ProMedica Toledo Hospital is dedicated to diagnosing and treating patients with structural heart disease. We use advanced tests and treatments to treat conditions that involve damage to or flaws in the make-up of your heart.
Learn more about the Structural Heart Clinic.
Access to Leading Edge Clinical Trials
If you’re being treated for heart disease, you may be able to take part in ProMedica’s clinical trials. The benefits? You’ll get access to the newest heart treatments, all while you’re under the watchful eyes of your cardiologist. To find out if you’re eligible for a clinical trial, email: phsirb@promedica.org or research@promedica.org.
Clinical Study: New Aortic Heart Valve

Get an in-depth look at this breakthrough ProMedica clinical trial.
content.heartHealth:
Keeping Your Heart Healthy
Know Your Risk Factors
It’s true that you can’t control your age, family history, gender or ethnicity. But there are factors you can control to lower your risk of heart disease and heart attack. It’s important to understand that a single risk factor makes it more likely you’ll develop heart-related problems. The more of these risk factors you have, the more concerned you need to be about seeking prevention and treatment.
High Blood Pressure
High blood pressure places extra stress on the walls of your arteries. That’s why you’ll want to keep your blood pressure within a normal range.
High Cholesterol
High cholesterol raises your risk of heart disease. That means it’s important to check your cholesterol levels regularly.
Lack of Physical Activity
Exercising makes your heart able to do a better job of pumping blood. It also raises your heart rate, which helps build a healthier heart. Aim for 150 minutes of moderate physical activity each week.
Obesity
Excess weight makes your heart work harder and raises your risk for high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes.
Smoking
Nicotine has been shown to narrow arteries and destroy the cells that line your arteries. If you smoke, look for tools that can help you quit.
Find a ProMedica smoking cessation program.
Stress
High stress can lead to high blood pressure and then heart disease. Try activities such as yoga, breathing exercises and walking, which have all been shown to help lower stress levels.
Schedule a Cardiovascular Exam
Your healthcare provider is your top ally in protecting your heart health. Take ten minutes to schedule your yearly checkup. It’s the first step toward learning about your health status and your risk for cardiovascular diseases. During your appointment, here’s how your doctor will assess your cardiac health:
Order or review blood work so you know your total cholesterol and blood sugar numbers.
Record your weight and height.
Review your personal risk factors for heart disease.
Take your blood pressure.
Talk to you about your family health history.
Track any changes in your health.
Act Fast During a Heart Attack
If you think you or someone you’re with is having a heart attack, do not drive to a hospital. Call 911 right away.
Emergency medical personnel will arrive by ambulance and can provide on-the-scene, life-saving treatment. They can also tell others what they’re seeing and deliver test results to the emergency room.
At ProMedica Toledo Hospital, a cardiologist is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week to make sure we’re ready when you need us most.
Learn more about heart attack symptoms.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Heart Disease
Heart disease, also called cardiovascular disease, is a phrase used to describe a number of different diseases of the heart like:
Irregular heartbeat
Congenital (birth) heart defects
Weak heart muscles
Heart valve problems
Heart infections
Coronary artery disease
Heart attack
Heart failure
Stroke
Heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States. It commonly leads to heart failure and heart attack. But what causes it, and how do you know your risks?
Are You at Risk for Heart Disease?
Do you have diabetes?
Is your blood pressure high?
Have you been tested for high cholesterol?
Do you smoke?
Are you overweight?
Are you inactive?
Is there a family history of heart disease?
Are your stress levels high?
ProMedica Physicians cardiologist A. Vincent Songco MD, FACC says, “If you have diabetes, high blood pressure or high cholesterol, your main goal is to keep your number(s) within normal limits. If you're having trouble, your doctor may prescribe medications.” Ask your doctor what numbers are healthy for you.
Lower Your Risk of Heart Disease
Fortunately, many heart diseases are within your control. With the help of your doctor, you can make changes in your lifestyle to improve your heart health and minimize the risk of heart disease.
To lower your risk for heart disease:
Maintain a healthy weight. Discuss with your doctor what is healthy for you.
Increase your physical activity. Your doctor can guide you on beginning an exercise program.
Kick the habit. Find a stop smoking program to support you.
Limit your alcohol consumption.
Eat heart smart foods. Foods rich in good fats: peanuts, olive oil, oatmeal, flaxseed. And foods rich in nutrients: egg whites, berries, kale, and whole grain bread. Avoid foods high in sodium.
Reduce your stress. Find calming activities and spend time with supportive people.
Talk with your doctor about your lifestyle choices and how they affect your heart health. If you have concerns, explore diagnostic tests and treatments for heart disease.

When You Want the Very Best for Your Heart
If your heart is damaged from a heart attack or other heart condition, you want skilled and compassionate care. You can count on the expert team at ProMedica. Our heart surgeons use state-of-the-art technology and the most advanced surgical methods to care for one of your most vital organs.
content.procedures:
Surgical Heart Procedures
From minimally invasive to traditional open procedures, we offer a full range of surgical services for your heart condition, including these common procedures:
Atrial Fibrillation Surgery
Atrial fibrillation (AFib) is an abnormal heart rhythm (arrhythmia) and is the most common kind of heart rhythm problem. With atrial fibrillation surgery (sometimes called the maze procedure), scar tissue is created through a number of small incisions. This scar tissue stops the abnormal signals that caused the atrial fibrillation. This allows your heart rhythm to return to normal.
Learn more about AFib
Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery
Coronary artery bypass graft surgery, or CABG, is a procedure used to treat coronary artery disease. If your arteries become blocked because plaque builds up, you may need bypass surgery. This helps restore oxygen and blood flow from your heart to the rest of your body.
Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm Repair
A thoracic aortic aneurysm repair is done when the portion of your aorta that runs through your chest needs to be replaced. If you develop a weak spot or the aorta begins to bulge, you may need surgery to repair or remove the aneurysm.
Learn more about aortic surgery
Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR)
With TAVR, the aortic valve is replaced using a catheter, which is inserted through a small incision (cut). The artificial valve is expanded inside the existing valve by inflating a balloon.
Learn more about TAVR
Valve Surgery
Four valves direct blood flow through your heart. Heart valve repair or replacement surgery is needed when your valves are damaged or diseased and don’t work as they should. Your valves can become blocked (a condition called stenosis) or they may leak. This may cause shortness of breath, fatigue and chest pain. Valve surgery can repair or replace mitral, aortic and tricuspid valves, and can be both open and minimally invasive.
Learn more about valve surgery

content.articleContent:
Here to Help You Live a Healthy, Active Life
If you or a loved one have been diagnosed with hemophilia, you likely have lots of questions about your health and what lies ahead. Your ProMedica team is here to answer your questions, ease your fears and provide support and guidance every step of the way.
Hemophilia doesn’t have to slow you down. With the right treatment and expert care, you and your family can live a healthy, active lifestyle.
content.overview:
Understanding Hemophilia
If you have hemophilia, it means your body doesn’t clot blood normally because it doesn’t have enough clotting factor. This means injuries like cuts and scrapes can bleed more than usual. And in some severe cases, you may even bleed for no reason.
There are many different types of hemophilia and most of them are inherited, which means they’re passed down from parents to children.
Risk Factors
Many people inherit hemophilia from their parents. If you have a family member with hemophilia, be sure to tell your doctor. You may be asked to have a blood test to see if you have it, too.
Two-thirds of hemophilia patients have inherited hemophilia.
Hemophilia Symptoms
If you have hemophilia, you may have symptoms like:
Bleeding under a joint, such as the elbow or knee, after a minor injury. In some cases, you may notice bleeding under the joint for no reason.
Blood in your urine or stool.
Excessive (lots of) bleeding after cutting the inside of your mouth, or after losing a tooth.
Lots of bruises, or bruises that are larger than normal. You may also feel a hard lump below the bruise.
Nosebleeds that happen for no clear reason.
Unusual or excessive bleeding during surgery. In children, this may mean a lot of bleeding after circumcision.
Hemophilia Types
There are three different types of hemophilia. Doctors determine your type by looking at which clotting factor you’re missing in your blood.
Hemophilia A
Hemophilia A, also called “classical” hemophilia, is the most common type and happens when your blood has low levels of clotting factor VIII (8).
Hemophilia B
Hemophilia B, also called “Christmas disease,” is the second most common type. It happens when your blood has low levels of clotting factor IX (9).
Hemophilia C
Hemophilia C, also called Rosenthal syndrome, is a rare type of hemophilia. It happens when your blood has low levels of clotting factor XI (11).
Hemophilia Classifications
The average person’s blood is made up of 50% or more clotting factor. If you have hemophilia, the severity of your condition will be measured and classified into one of three categories.
Severe Hemophilia
If you have severe hemophilia, it means less than 1% of your blood is made up of clotting factor. This means you may have excessive bleeding after an injury, surgery or dental work, or you may even bleed for no known reason.
Moderate Hemophilia
If you have moderate hemophilia, 1-5% of your blood has clotting factor. While most people with moderate hemophilia have excessive bleeding after trauma, surgery or dental work too, they do not have as many episodes of unexplained bleeding.
Mild Hemophilia
If you have mild hemophilia, it means 5-50% of your blood is made up of clotting factor. Mild hemophilia can cause some extra bleeding during surgery, dental work or after an injury.
content.treatment:
Treatment
With specialized hemophilia treatment, you or your child can live a healthy and active lifestyle.
At ProMedica, the hemophilia experts at our Northwest Ohio Hemophilia Treatment Center combine medical therapies and lifestyle changes to treat your hemophilia. We’ll work closely with you and your family to create a personalized plan that fits your child’s specific needs.
Medical Treatment
Medical treatments for hemophilia help replace the missing clotting factors in the blood, which allows your blood to clot properly. This is usually done by injecting concentrated clotting factor into your vein.
Your doctor may also recommend that you take medicine that helps prevent excessive bleeding.
Lifestyle Changes
Living with hemophilia doesn’t mean you have to give up your daily activities. With careful management and medical treatment, you can live a healthy and normal life.
You can manage your hemophilia by:
Avoiding blood thinning medicines, including aspirin and ibuprofen.
Avoiding contact sports, such as football and hockey.
Getting regular exercise with low-impact activities.
Getting your hepatitis A and B vaccinations.
Maintaining good dental hygiene. See your dentist twice a year for cleanings and check-ups.
Wearing protective gear, such as kneepads, elbow pads and a helmet.
Learn about the Northwest Ohio Hemophilia Treatment Center.

content.articleContent:
Protect Your Health, Know Your Numbers
High blood pressure (HBP), or hypertension, is a common form of heart disease that affects nearly half of all adults in the United States. And, since the condition offers very few warning signs, it often goes undetected in roughly one-third of those who have it.
Just knowing you have hypertension is a step in the right direction. Working together, you and your doctor can put a plan in place to manage it so you can protect your heart.
More than 100 million American adults have high blood pressure. Could you be one of them?
content.understanding:
Understand High Blood Pressure
Knowing your numbers and learning more about the condition can help you take steps to protect yourself from heart disease.
What is high blood pressure?
Blood pressure refers to the pressure in your arteries as blood flows through them. When your blood pressure is high, your heart is working harder than it should to pump blood through your body. This damages your arteries and can lead to heart disease, kidney failure and stroke.
How is blood pressure measured?
A nurse or doctor places a blood pressure cuff around your upper arm to take your blood pressure. The cuff measures the pressure in your arteries during your heartbeat and when your heart is between beats.
These two pressures are assigned separate numbers. Written down, your blood pressure reading may look something like this: 130/95. Your doctor may tell you, “Your blood pressure is 130 over 95.”
What is a healthy blood pressure?
In a healthy blood pressure reading, the first number is less than 120 and the second number is less than 80. If either number is higher than it should be, it’s important to discuss your results with your doctor.
What causes high blood pressure?
Many things may contribute to high blood pressure, including:
Family history.
High levels of stress.
Obesity.
Poor diet with too much salt.
Smoking.
How often should blood pressure be checked?
You should have your blood pressure taken at least once a year. Your doctor can do it at your annual appointment. If your blood pressure is high, ask your doctor how often you should get it checked.
What can you do to prevent high blood pressure or help return your blood pressure to a healthy level?
To help prevent or control high blood pressure, work with your doctor and take these steps:
Avoid tobacco smoke.
Eat a healthy diet.
Increase your physical activity.
Lessen your stress.
Limit your alcohol intake.
Maintain a healthy weight.
Reduce your salt intake.
Take medication if prescribed by your doctor.

content.articleContent:
A Faster Road to Recovery
If you have a hernia, or if you think you might have one, the expert hernia surgeons at ProMedica can diagnose you quickly so you can get on the road to recovery.
Hernias usually cause a lump or bulge in the affected area, and sometimes this lump is pain-free. But you should never ignore hernia symptoms. Left untreated, a hernia can cut off an organ’s blood supply.
At ProMedica, we’ll see you within 24 hours after you contact us. We understand how important treating your hernia is — for your comfort and for your health.
Call 567-585-0067 to schedule your hernia consultation.
content.overview:
What is a Hernia?
Hernias happen when there’s a weakness or tear in a muscle or tissue that allows an internal organ to push through. This usually happens in the abdomen, and the organ that typically protrudes is the intestine.
This weakness in your muscle or tissue may be there at birth, or may come from repeated strain caused from too much lifting or coughing, from abdominal surgery, obesity or straining due to chronic constipation. The tendency to have a hernia can also be inherited.
There are many types of hernia, including:
Abdominal hernias.
Inguinal hernias.
Femoral hernias.
Umbilical hernias.
Incisional hernias.
content.symptoms:
Hernia Symptoms
The most common symptom of hernia is a lump or bulge in your abdomen or groin. Other symptoms can depend on the type of hernia you have, including:
A sense of fullness.
Pain or discomfort.
Swelling or an unusual shape to your abdomen.
Your surgeon can usually diagnose your hernia by your symptoms and by feeling the bulge is causes. In some cases, imaging tests may be used to diagnose this condition.
content.treatment:
Hernia Treatment
Hernias don’t usually go away on their own, and surgery is often the best way to treat them. At ProMedica, we help people who:
Are interested in an advanced, minimally invasive robotic hernia repair.
Are newly diagnosed with a hernia.
Have been living with a hernia and have decided it’s time for surgery.
Need a complex abdominal wall reconstruction.
Our Hernia Program team streamlines the process of hernia repair. We offer safe, comfortable procedures including robotic surgery, which means you can benefit from a shorter recovery time.
Your ProMedica hernia surgeon will choose the best type of surgery for your specific hernia. We provide these types of hernia surgery in Toledo and the surrounding area:
Open Hernia Repair
With this procedure, your surgeon cuts the skin at your groin and pushes the bulging intestine back into your belly. The opening in the muscle wall is then stitched closed. If your muscle wall is weak, your surgeon may use a steel mesh or wire to strengthen the area.
Laparoscopic Hernia Repair
Your surgeon will make several small incisions in your lower belly, then insert a thin, flexible tube into one of the incisions. The tube, which is called a catheter, has a camera that allows your surgeon to see the area. Other catheters have tiny instruments that your surgeon uses to repair the hernia and use steel mesh, if necessary.
Robotic Hernia Repair
This type of surgery is also performed with small incisions. The surgeon sits at a console a few feet from the operating table and uses a camera and tiny instruments to repair your hernia. Our Hernia Program is centered on minimally invasive robotic hernia repair, which can shorten your recovery time.

content.articleContent:
It Turns Out You Can Have Too Much of a Good Thing
Cholesterol plays a positive and important role in your health — helping your body make new cells and produce vitamins, hormones and bile acids. However, high levels in your blood can contribute to clogged arteries and raise your risk for heart disease and stroke.
Regular cholesterol checks help protect your heart health.
content.understanding:
Understand Cholesterol: The Good and the Bad
Your body makes all the cholesterol it needs. But foods that come from animal sources, such as meats, dairy products and oils that contain saturated fat, also raise cholesterol levels.
Other things that can contribute to unhealthy cholesterol levels include:
Age.
Excess weight.
Family history.
Lack of exercise.
Tobacco smoke.
Cholesterol moves through your bloodstream on proteins known as lipoproteins. There are several types:
High-density lipoprotein (HDL): Often called “good cholesterol,” HDL helps your body get rid of excess cholesterol, lowering your risk for heart disease.
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL): LDL is the bad cholesterol that causes the most buildup in your arteries. The higher your LDL levels, the greater your risk for cardiovascular disease.
Very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL): VLDL is like LDL, carrying a fat called triglycerides. Alcohol and sugar are two major contributors to high triglyceride levels.
content.prevention:
Prevention and Treatment
Getting Your Cholesterol Checked
Since you can have abnormal cholesterol levels without having symptoms, regular cholesterol checks are extremely important. A simple blood test after you fast can provide the information your doctor needs to determine if treatment is needed to ensure your heart health.
The American Heart Association recommends adults 20 years and older have their cholesterol checked every four to six years if they’re at low risk. Children should be screened once between the age of 9 and 11 and then again between the ages of 17 and 21.
In general, optimal cholesterol levels for a healthy adult are:
60 mg/dL or higher for HDL.
100 mg/dL or lower for LDL.
200 mg/dL or lower for total cholesterol.
Your doctor will consider many factors, such as your lifestyle and other health conditions — along with your various cholesterol levels — to weigh your risk for cardiovascular disease and decide if you need treatment.
Changing Your Lifestyle
While you can’t control factors like your age or family history, there are many lifestyle changes you can make to lower your risk for getting high cholesterol or manage the condition:
Drink alcohol in moderation, if you drink at all.
Eat a healthy diet. Include fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fish, skinless and lean poultry, nonfat dairy products, beans and nuts. Limit saturated fats, trans fats and salt.
Exercise regularly.
Quit smoking.
In some cases, your doctor may also recommend medication to help you reach healthier cholesterol levels. Talk with your doctor if you have concerns about your cholesterol or to learn more ways to lower your risk of heart disease.

Our Approach

Full Range of Support Services

Rehabilitation services.

content.articleContent:
We’re here for your healing heart.
A heart attack is a life-changing event. Whether it happens to you or a loved one, it’s natural to feel overwhelmed. That’s where we come in.
Our expert and compassionate team will guide your every step. From helping you understand why it happened to walking you and your family through what comes next, we’ll be by your side. Informing. Supporting. Caring.
content.toledo:
Heart Attack Care at ProMedica Toledo Hospital
ProMedica Toledo Hospital is the only hospital in the region with a cardiologist on site 24 hours a day, seven days a week. 24/7 Cardiology allows patients who come to Toledo Hospital, at any time day or night, with symptoms of a heart attack to see a cardiologist when needed.
Having a cardiologist on site can help a patient receive an accurate diagnosis and life-saving treatment immediately, which is pretty important because surviving a heart attack depends greatly on receiving treatment as soon as possible.
Board-certified cardiologists from ProMedica Physicians Cardiology are on site to provide the care patients need, which improves community access to quality heart care.
In addition to having a cardiologist on site 24/7, Toledo Hospital also has a full range of cardiac diagnostics, interventional cardiac labs, electrophysiology labs, a coronary intensive care unit and the region’s most experienced cardiothoracic surgeons.
We are the region's most experienced heart-care team.
content.overview:
Understanding Heart Attacks
What is a heart attack?
Think of a heart attack as a plumbing problem. When your arteries are clear, blood flows easily through your body. However, when something interrupts the flow of blood to your heart, it causes heart tissue to die (a heart attack). It can also affect how well your heart pumps in the future.
The most common cause of heart attack is coronary artery disease (CAD). With this condition, fatty deposits called plaque build up inside the arteries that supply oxygen-rich blood to your heart muscle.
If plaque restricts your blood flow, or part of it breaks off and forms a clot that blocks blood flow, your heart won’t get the oxygen it needs. This can result in chest pain called angina or in a heart attack.
What are the symptoms of heart attack?
Identifying heart attack symptoms can be tricky. The sudden, overwhelming symptoms portrayed in movies don’t always happen: They vary from person to person, and between men and women. Being aware of these signs can mean getting help for you or your loved one when every second counts, and can be life-saving:
Chest discomfort that can feel like pressure, squeezing, fullness or pain. This can last for several minutes, or go away and come back.
Cold sweat, nausea, vomiting or lightheadedness.
Shortness of breath, which can happen before or during your chest discomfort.
Upper body discomfort in one or both arms or in your back, neck, jaw or stomach.
For women, heart attack symptoms often don’t include crushing chest pain or discomfort. Rather, women tend to have discomfort in one or both arms, their back, neck, jaw or stomach.
Only 27% of people are aware of the major signs of a heart attack.
How do I lower my risk for a heart attack?
Take these healthy steps to strengthen your heart and lower your heart attack risk:
Be active: Any physical activity will benefit your heart. Exercise increases blood circulation, improves your energy and helps you manage stress. It also helps control your weight.
Control your blood pressure: A normal blood pressure lessens the strain on your heart and minimizes your risk.
Eat healthy foods: Load up on fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts, lean meats, fish and healthy oils — and bake, broil, poach or grill your foods. Limit red meat, salt, and packaged foods.
Know your family history: If you have a family history of CAD or heart attack, you may be at increased risk yourself. Discuss any family history of these conditions with your doctor.
Limit your alcohol intake: Consuming alcohol can raise your blood pressure, increase your weight and sometimes cause heart conditions such as irregular heart beat, cardiomyopathy and stroke.
Maintain a healthy weight: Excess weight is linked to the hardening of your arteries, which increases your risk for heart attack. Maintaining a healthy diet and weight can decrease your risk.
Reduce stress: Ongoing or severe bouts of stress can increase your heart rate, blood pressure and your body’s demand for oxygen — all of which can affect your heart.
Stop smoking: You’ll breathe easier. Your food will taste better. You’ll feel better mentally and physically — and you’ll reduce your heart attack risk significantly. Learn more about ProMedica’s Stop Smoking Programs.
Take your heart medication: Staying on schedule with any prescribed heart medications is important. Make sure you’re taking the right dose, at the right times. It’s also a good idea to carry an up-to-date list of all your medications with you, including your prescribed medicines as well as over-the-counter ones you take often.
Schedule routine check-ups: Seeing your primary care provider at least once a year will help you maintain an overall healthy lifestyle and will help identify any potential heart issues.
Our compassionate team is ready to support your journey to whole health, whether you are working to prevent a heart condition, lower your risk for heart attack, manage an existing heart condition or heal from a cardiac event. We have everything you need to accomplish your goals and stay healthy.
How can I help someone with heart attack symptoms?
Call 911 right away at the first sign of any heart attack symptoms.
Though waiting for an ambulance can be stressful, avoid the temptation to drive to the emergency department instead of calling 911. The ambulance will have emergency medical personnel who can provide life-saving treatment at the scene. They can also inform doctors in the emergency department about important details before arrival at the hospital, so they’ll be prepared with the best treatments.
While you wait for an ambulance, you can have the symptomatic person chew a regular-strength (325mg) aspirin if you have any available. Aspirin is an anticoagulant and can help prevent blood clots.
Call 911 at the first sign of any heart attack symptoms. Don't hesitate. Every second counts.
What is life like after a heart attack?
You can go on living a full, active life after a heart attack. And ProMedica will guide you step by step through your journey to find your new normal. You’ll make healthy changes. You’ll be aware of a few limitations. But mostly, you’ll feel great because you’ll be a healthier, happier you after making that commitment to your heart.
If you’ve had a heart attack, you may be referred to cardiac rehabilitation to help you recover. A team of experienced professionals will help you develop an individualized care plan.
Learn more about cardiac rehab.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Heart Failure
Heart failure is the condition in which your heart cannot pump sufficient blood to meet your body's needs. It is a multi-stage condition that means your heart is working less efficiently than a normal heart. You may have heard heart failure called 'congestive heart failure' or 'CHF.'
Heart Failure and Its Problems
What’s important to know is heart failure is often long-term, and is caused by many different heart problems such as:
Heart disease
Heart attack
Heart valve disease
Abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias)
Infections that weaken the heart
Common Signs of Heart Failure
Do you have shortness of breath when you're active or after you lie down?
Do you have trouble breathing when you're lying down?
Have you gained weight?
Are your legs and ankles swollen?
Do you feel weak or tired easily?
Does your heart race or beat in an uneven pattern?
Heart Failure Risk Factors
If you have had a previous heart attack
Family history of heart attack
If you are a man over 45 or woman over 55
Smoking
High blood pressure
High blood cholesterol
Being overweight
Limited or no exercise
Diabetes
If you think you may have heart failure, talk to your doctor about diagnosis and treatment options.

content.articleContent:
About the Infant Monitor Program
Assuring the safe transportation of infants is a requirement at the time of hospital discharge, and consequently, medically fragile and/or premature infants generally undergo a car seat challenge to ensure they are physiologically ready to travel in a rear-facing car seat. Most tested (or challenged) infants will travel home from the hospital in a properly fitted car seat; however, because some infants are unable to maintain a patent airway in the semi-reclined position of a car seat, they must instead travel home in a recumbent car bed. 
We meet the needs of high-risk infants at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children's Hospital with our diagnostic, therapeutic and educational Infant Monitor Program. We support infants and families whose conditions require the use of home monitoring services. Our pediatric pulmonologists are lung specialists who are board-certified in pediatrics and in pediatric pulmonary medicine with a specialty in intensive care and direct patient care. Our team of physicians, nurses and respiratory therapists follow your baby’s care.
Infants referred to the Infant Monitor Program may be:
Babies who experience an apparent life-threatening event (ALTE)
SIDS siblings
Premature infants with apnea / bradycardia
Infants with obstructive apnea
Babies with seizure / neurological-related apnea
Oxygen dependent infants
Infants with cardiac problems
Infants that initially fail the car seat challenge should undergo an additional car seat challenge prior to transitioning to a traditional, semi-reclined car seat. The Infant Monitor Program staff at Toledo and Russell J. Ebeid Children's Hospital's will administer follow-up test on infants that failed their initial Car Seat Challenge Testing prior to discharge. 
Follow-up out-patient testing is done in Harris McIntosh Tower by a Respiratory Therapist or an RN, when the pediatrician feels it is time to re-test.  A test will take a minimum of 90 minutes. 
We can be reached by telephone 24 hours a day to answer questions and solve problems related to infant alarms and/or equipment use
Contact the Infant Monitor Program at 419-291-2229 or 800-876-2763.

Quality Testing for Better Health
ProMedica Laboratories has committed to provide quality testing to improve your health and well-being. Using the latest in advanced testing, paired with expert consultation, we are able to provide continuum care across the entire ProMedica system.
When you have your medical testing performed by ProMedica Laboratories, you are receiving the highest level of quality. Certification and accreditation programs in which ProMedica Laboratories participates represent the on-going commitment to exacting quality standards.
Why Choose ProMedica

Customer Service Representatives available 24/7 by calling 419-291-4134 or 1-888-471-4134.
Quality - CAP ISO 15189 accreditation high level of excellence in medical laboratory quality management.
Laboratory consultations provided by board-certified pathologists.
Conveniently located draw sites in Ohio and Michigan.
Routine results within 24 hours.
Walk-in service and convenient hours to fit your schedule.

Financial Assistance: If you don’t have health insurance or can’t afford care, we can help. Learn more.

content.symptoms:
Signs and Symptoms
Your liver, pancreas, gallbladder and bile ducts all play vital roles in the body. They work together to digest food, produce bile, filter out toxins and deliver essential vitamins and enzymes to our bodies.
Cancer can begin in any of these areas. However, it’s more common for cancer to start in other parts of the body and spread (metastasize) to the hepatopancreaticobiliary system.
Because the liver, pancreas, gallbladder and bile ducts work so closely together, the signs and symptoms of cancer can look a lot alike. If you have any of the following symptoms, see your doctor right away for tests:

Liver Cancer Symptoms
Biliary Cancer Symptoms
Pancreatic Cancer Symptoms
Liver Cancer Symptoms
Early symptoms of liver cancer may include:
Chills.
Fatigue.
Fever.
Night sweats.
Late-stage symptoms may include:
Decreased appetite.
Weight loss.
Nausea or vomiting.
Jaundice.
Dark urine.
Upper abdominal pain and/or bloating.
White stools.
Biliary Cancer Symptoms
Symptoms of gallbladder or bile duct cancer may include:
Abdominal pain.
Change in stool patterns.
Decreased appetite.
Fatigue.
Jaundice.
Nausea or vomiting.
Weight loss.
Pancreatic Cancer Symptoms
Symptoms of pancreatic cancer may include:
Abdominal pain.
Change in stool patterns.
Decreased appetite.
Fatigue.
Increased blood sugar levels.
Jaundice.
Nausea or vomiting.
Weight loss.
Liver Cancer Symptoms

Providing education and support to you and your family.
Facilitating/coordinating care provided by an interdisciplinary team of physicians, including medical, surgical and radiation oncology consults.
Working on behalf of you and your family to remove possible obstacles to care, including insurance issues, medication assistance or lack of transportation.
Communicating with your physician and helping to communicate the physician’s plan of care.
Expertise and Technology to Help You Feel Confident in Your Care
When you come to ProMedica for care, you’ll have a whole team rooting and working for you. With expert medical, radiation and surgical oncologists, oncology nurses, pharmacists, genetic counselors, therapists and more, you’ll have all the support you need along the way.
Our goal is to provide you with today’s most promising diagnostics, treatments and services. We work hard to stay on the leading-edge of medicine because your healing is our top priority.
Trust the Care That’s Certified by Professional Medical Accreditors
When you need us most, you can count on the accredited and nationally recognized services provided through the ProMedica Cancer Institute, which houses the largest cancer registry in the region. These accreditations show that we consistently demonstrate the highest standards of care and connect patients to a vast network of diagnostic, treatment and support resources.
content.prevention:
Risk Factors, Prevention and Screening
Although lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States, the good news is that it’s largely preventable.
Also known as lung carcinoma, lung cancer is a malignant lung tumor caused by uncontrollable, abnormal cell growth in one or both of your lungs. These cells, as they keep growing and spreading, keep your lungs from working normally. This growth can also spread beyond your lungs, too, by a process called metastasis.
There are five different types of lung cancer. The two most common are non-small cell carcinoma and small cell carcinoma, which make up 96% of all lung cancers.
When you know your risk, you can take steps to help prevent the disease and stay on top of any recommended screenings. Early diagnosis is more treatable and could save your life, because treatment may begin before the cancer spreads. According to the American Cancer Society, the 5-year relative survival rate is 61% for non-small cell lung cancer patients and 27% for small cell lung cancer patients if the cancer is detected while it is still in the lungs and hasn’t metastasized beyond the lungs.
Know Your Risk
Smoking is the single greatest risk factor for lung cancer. Smoking damages the tissues in your lungs to the point where your body can’t repair itself anymore. Even secondhand smoke is dangerous.
Beyond the dangers of smoking, other risk factors can include:
A family history of lung cancer.
A history of cancer in another part of your body.
Being over the age of 50.
Exposure to radon, asbestos or other industrial chemicals.
Other diseases in the lungs.
Previous radiation therapy.
Take Preventive Measures
Quitting smoking is the best thing you can do to prevent lung cancer. Quitting at any age can greatly lower your risk for lung cancer.
Other ways to prevent lung cancer include:
Be aware of chemical exposure. Talk to your employer about worksite wellness and safety procedures.
Have your home tested for radon. Radon is a natural gas in rock, soil and water. It can collect in unsafe levels in any building.
Know your family history. If lung cancer runs in your family, talk to your doctor.
Learn more about Tobacco Cessation.
Stay on Top of Recommended Screenings
Because lung cancer shows very few signs early on, many people get diagnosed after it’s already progressed. This makes early detection key to survival.
A simple, low-dose CT scan to screen for lung cancer takes less than 15 minutes. Talk with your doctor about your lung cancer risk. Together, you can create a screening schedule that’s right for you.
Most major insurance plans (including Medicare) cover this screening for people at high risk for lung cancer. You’ll need a doctor's order.
Your doctor may recommend a low-dose CT scan if you are age 50-80 who:
Currently smokes OR has quit smoking within the last 15 years AND who have a 20 pack-year smoking history.
Smoked at least one pack of cigarettes a day for the past 30 years OR smoked at least two packs a day for 15 years.
If you would like to schedule a screening, obtain an order from your doctor and call our central scheduling at 419-291-3000 or 1-800-479-8805.

content.articleContent:
About Lymphedema
Lymphedema refers to excessive swelling of one or more extremities following damage to the lymphatic system. The lymphatic system is a complicated system in the body that helps to carry fluid, bacteria and harmful substance through a series of lymph nodes that “clean” the fluid.
When lymph nodes are damaged or surgically removed, the system can malfunction and lead to excessive and sometimes uncontrollable swelling in the body. This can often happen as a result of cancer and the treatment associated with it. Lymphedema can be a debilitating disease that has a significant impact on the ability to perform everyday tasks.
Treating Lymphedema with ProMedica Total Rehab
How can ProMedica Total Rehab help you?
If you are experiencing any of the symptoms discussed, then lymphedema therapy may be beneficial to you. ProMedica Total Rehab employs licensed and certified therapists that specialize in the treatment of this condition. Therapy will include:
Education on self-care
Techniques for reducing and controlling swelling,
Techniques that will help to improve day to day function.
Which ProMedica locations offer lymphedema therapy?
At ProMedica Total Rehab, our experts are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. We provide lymphedema therapy in a number of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.
Please consult with your physician to determine if lymphedema therapy is right for you.
A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.
Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

content.articleContent:
About Mammography
You know early breast cancer detection is essential. It’s important you feel confident in the screening you receive. Talk with your doctor about digital mammography’s enhanced quality and accuracy.
How does a digital mammogram work?
As far as your experience, all mammograms are very much alike. You’ll most likely begin regular mammograms between the ages of 35 and 40, younger if there’s a breast cancer history for yourself or your family. Your mammograms are used for both early detection as well as for diagnosis of lumps, breast pain or unusual breast symptoms.
During your mammogram, your breast is compressed between two flat surfaces and X-rayed. Digital mammograms display and record the high definition X-ray images on a computer monitor, while a standard film-based mammogram records these images on individual films.
What are the benefits of digital mammography?
A few solid benefits for you are:
Less exposure to radiation compared to a standard film-based mammogram.
Reduced need for mammogram re-takes means less time spent for you
Higher resolution images and image manipulation for accurate detection and diagnosis
Your images are stored in computer files for easy access and sharing amongst experts
Is a digital mammogram right for you?
This decision is between you and your doctor, but the common perspective is that digital mammography is better suited for you if you:
Are under 50 years old
Have dense breasts
Haven’t been through menopause or have gone through it within the past year
Are digital mammograms available at every ProMedica Radiology location?
We have many convenient locations with this state-of-the-art technique. Find one near you.
content.mammogram:
Ready for a mammogram?
Routine mammograms are essential for finding breast cancer early, which can reduce the severity of treatment and save lives.
Learn How to Schedule

content.articleContent:
Understanding High-Risk Pregnancy
Often, pregnancies have little or no complications. But if you or your baby are considered high-risk, you’ll get expert care from our multi-disciplinary team of maternal-fetal medicine specialists.
You might be considered high risk as the result of a medical condition you had before you become pregnant. Or your pregnancy can become high risk if a medical condition develops during your pregnancy for either you or your baby.
Complications that lead to high risk include:
Hypertension (high blood pressure)
Diabetes
Rh disease
Multiple gestation including twins of higher multiples
Platelet and blood disorder including thrombocytopenia, sickle cell anemia, and thalassemia
Recurrent pregnancy loss, including incompetent cervix
Fetal abnormalities, including growth disorders, inherited disease, and structural malformations
Abnormal bleeding
Cardiac problems
Trauma
The Risk of Preterm Labor
Some of these complications can lead to preterm labor. Learn the signs of preterm labor, and talk to your obstetrician if you have concerns.
Download this brochure to learn more about preterm labor
Care for High-Risk Pregnancies
Care begins with evaluation and consultation to identify risks and potential treatment options. Diagnostic and therapeutic procedures, such as amniocentesis, chorionic villus samples, and umbilical cord blood samples may be performed. When appropriate, these services are also available:
3D/4D ultrasound
Genetic diagnosis and ultrasound
Fetal therapy
Prevention and management of prematurity
Transportation of high-risk maternity patients and newborns via helicopter equipped with mobile ICUs
Pregnancy loss evaluation and treatment
Perinatal hospice program
Your Care Team
Your care is co-managed by our board-certified maternal-fetal medicine physicians along with your Ob/Gyn and our multidisciplinary team. This team includes:
Maternal-fetal medicine specialized nurses
Genetic counselors
Certified diabetic educators
Dietitians and nutritionists
You’ll also have access to:
Certified nurse midwives
A perinatal social worker
Neonatologists
Lactation consultants
Respiratory therapists
Parent instructors
Ask your obstetrician to refer you to Maternal-Fetal Medicine at ProMedica Toledo Hospital. Or call us at 419-291-3604 to learn more.
