content.articleContent:
Healthy Babies, Healthy Moms
Congratulations on your pregnancy! As you get ready for your new baby, it’s time to focus on you. On getting the best possible maternity care, and on taking extra special care of yourself.
The idea of giving birth can seem daunting. You want to know you’re in the care of a highly skilled delivery team. With ProMedica you don’t have to look far. Nearly half of the babies born in Toledo are born at ProMedica Toledo Hospital, which is also home to a Level III perinatal unit. And, we offer more high quality maternal care in our other hospitals throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
Our obstetricians and gynecologists (OB/GYNs) and pediatricians are ready to care for your maternity needs — and your baby’s — during pregnancy, childbirth and after delivery (postpartum).
Find your maternity specialist
content.services:
Our Services
When you find out you’re pregnant there’s a lot to think about: maternity care, childbirth and parenting classes, where you want to deliver your baby and what to expect when the big day arrives.
Some of the most advanced birthing facilities in the Toledo metro region are found in ProMedica hospitals. We’ll be with you every step of the way. That includes everything from your obstetric exams and ultrasounds to the first days of your baby’s life — and everything in between.
You’ll have access to:
Anesthesiologists.
Certified midwives.
Childbirth education.
Maternal-fetal medicine specialists for high-risk pregnancies.
Neonatal services.
Obstetric services.
Spacious labor, delivery and postpartum rooms.
Support groups.
About Ultrasounds
Ultrasounds are a safe way to see how your baby is developing and make sure it’s healthy as it grows in your uterus.
Also called sonography, an obstetric ultrasound uses high-frequency sound waves sent into your body from a scanning instrument placed on your skin. The sound waves reflect off bones and tissues and are analyzed by a computer. This results in an image.
Along with a standard ultrasound, your doctor may want you to have a Doppler ultrasound. It evaluates organ and fetal vessel blood flow. In some cases, you may need a vaginal ultrasound to provide more information.
A typical ultrasound takes between 30 and 60 minutes. You don’t need to make special preparations, but you may want to wear loose-fitting clothes that can be washed, since a gel-like material is used on your abdomen.
Some doctor’s offices limit the number of people who can come to your appointment. Usually one adult is welcome to watch your ultrasound with you. Sometimes when the ultrasound is almost over, your doctor will allow other adults to join you in the room.
A detailed report is always sent to your obstetric care provider after the ultrasound. It will help your doctor learn:
If there are any potential birth defects.
Whether your baby is growing at a suitable rate.
How much fluid is around your baby.
The measurement of your cervical length.
Your baby’s due date.
Your baby’s position in the womb.
About C-Sections
A C-section, also called cesarean delivery, is a type of surgery. Your baby is delivered through incisions (cuts) in your abdomen and uterus, instead of a vaginal birth.
You can schedule your C-section ahead of time if you begin to have pregnancy complications or you've had a past C-section and don’t plan to have vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC). But for first-time moms, the need for a C-section often isn’t clear until labor has started.
Stalled labor is one of the main reasons why your doctor might recommend a C-section. Other reasons include:
A problem with your placenta.
You or your baby have a health concern that makes vaginal delivery risky.
You’re carrying twins, triplets or other multiples.
Your baby is not in a normal position.
Your baby is not getting enough oxygen.
About High-Risk Pregnancies
Your pregnancy may be considered high-risk because of a health condition you had before pregnancy or a health condition that develops during pregnancy. If so, ProMedica’s maternal-fetal medicine specialists are ready with the care you and your baby need.
Learn more about high-risk pregnancy care.
content.before:
Before Delivery
Getting Ready for the Role of a Lifetime
Take Advantage of Education Opportunities
Set yourself and your baby up for a positive, healthy birth experience with ProMedica’s childbirth education program. They’re designed to provide vital information for expectant mothers and their families. By joining these classes, you may find they reduce stress and help make sure you’re ready when your baby comes.
If you can’t go to in-person classes because of bed rest, schedule conflicts, time constraints or other personal reasons, our online childbirth classes are an option. They give you a complete education in a personalized format on your own computer at home.
Register early in your pregnancy and plan to start classes by week 32. Confirmation, which will include the locations of your classes, will be mailed (or emailed) to you.
Our childbirth education program includes classes, tours and orientations covering:
Baby care.
Big brother and big sister.
Breastfeeding.
Breastfeeding for working mothers.
Childbirth.
Infant safety and CPR.
Lactation center services.
Maternity tours.
Prenatal water aerobics.
To register, call 419-291-5666 or email ChildBirthEducation@ProMedica.org.
Choose a Hospital Wisely
When you’re deciding where you want to bring your new baby into the world, keep these important things in mind:
Amenities: What are your personal needs? Do you prefer a certain room size? Will your partner be staying the night?
Location: You may prefer a location close to your home so you can get to the hospital faster when labor begins.
Tours: Visit several hospitals before you make a decision. Take your partner, mother or a trusted friend. This will help you think about which hospital best fits your needs and makes you as comfortable as possible when it’s time to deliver.
Know the Signs and Stages of Labor
After nine months of waiting, you’ll be ready for the big day. When you have these signs of labor, call your doctor and family members:
Contractions: Contractions are the shortening of your uterine muscles. They happen before and during childbirth. When they occur less than 10 minutes apart, that usually means labor has started. It’s not unusual to have periodic, irregular contractions as your labor nears.
Your water breaks: The amniotic sac surrounds and protects your unborn baby. When fluid leaks from your vagina, it means the membranes of the sac have ruptured. This can happen hours before labor starts or during labor. Most women go into labor within 24 hours after their water breaks.
It will also help to recognize the stages of labor:
Stage one: The first stage of labor includes latent, active and transition phases. To help your cervix dilate, your contractions will come more and more often until you’re completely dilated (10 centimeters).
Stage two: Stage two begins when the cervix is completely opened. At this point, your doctor will tell you to push. Pushing, along with your contractions, propels your baby through the birth canal. Your baby’s head will crown, and you’ll keep pushing to deliver your baby’s shoulders and body. Once your baby is fully delivered, the umbilical cord is clamped and cut.
Stage three: In the final stage of labor, you’ll deliver the placenta, the organ that nourishes your baby inside your womb.
Pack Your Bag for the Hospital
Pack a bag for your hospital stay ahead of time. Include any paperwork you may need, your birth plan, comfy clothes, personal hygiene items and any items that may help you pass the time as you wait.
You may also want to pack items for your baby. Include clothing for pictures and your ride home. And don’t forget the car seat.
Prepare for a C-Section, Just in Case
Whether you’re having a planned C-section or will only have one if it becomes necessary during labor, a little advance preparation will go a long way to ease your anxiety. Planning will also help make sure your C-section goes as smoothly as possible. This planning includes talking to your doctor about anesthesia choices ahead of time to decide on the best one for you if it’s needed. You may also be asked to take blood tests in case an emergency blood transfusion is needed during delivery.
Also, plan for your at-home recovery by asking for help from friends, family or a nanny.
Some of the ways that a C-section differs from vaginal birth include:
Abdominal incision: The doctor will make an incision through your abdominal wall, usually horizontally near your pubic hairline.
Anesthesia: Anesthesia is used to numb the lower part of your body, which allows you to stay awake during the C-section.
Bathing: For a scheduled C-section, you’ll be asked to shower or bathe the night before with antibacterial soap. This lowers the risk of infection. Your abdomen will be cleaned again at the hospital before your procedure. A tube will be inserted to collect your urine.
IV: An IV will be inserted in your hand or arm to deliver fluids and medicine.
Uterine incision: After your abdominal incision, the doctor will make an incision in your uterus. The uterine incision is usually horizontal across the lower part of your uterus.
Understand How to Manage Your Pain During Childbirth
You may learn special ways to breathe in childbirth classes or choose to have pain medicine for labor. Pain-relieving drugs for labor have two categories: analgesics and anesthetics. Talk to your doctor about the best pain treatment medicine for you.
content.after:
After Delivery
Postpartum Care and Recovery
Pregnancy and childbirth put your body through a lot. After you give birth (postpartum), it’s vital that you rest as much as you can to make sure you get back to good health.
Slowly ease back into your daily routine. Ask family and friends for help with meals and babysitting so you can rest.
Know About C-Section Recovery
C-section recovery takes longer than recovering from vaginal birth. C-sections also come with specific risks to you and your baby.
Risks to your baby include breathing problems such as transient tachypnea or surgical injuries such as nicks to your baby’s skin. These risks are rare.
A C-section can put you at risk for:
Blood clots.
Increased bleeding.
Increased risks during future pregnancies.
Inflammation and infection of the membrane lining your uterus.
Reactions to anesthesia.
Surgical injury.
Wound infection.
Maintain Your Health After Giving Birth
Just as it was important to take care of yourself during pregnancy, you should also protect your health as you recover. There are a few easy steps you can take to make sure you have the best, and fastest, recovery.
Avoid sex if you’ve had a C-section: It’s usually safe to have sex again about four to six weeks after surgery or after your doctor gives you the go-ahead.
Drink plenty of fluids: Drinking water and other fluids will help replace the fluid you lost during delivery and will lose when you’re breastfeeding. Fluids also help keep you from getting constipated.
Eat well: Eat foods with plenty of vitamins and minerals to restore your body and build strength.
Take it easy: Rest often and try to keep everything you or your baby will need within your reach. Avoid lifting from a squatting position or lifting anything heavier than your baby for the first few weeks.
Take your medication: Your doctor might recommend Tylenol or other medicines to relieve pain. Ask your doctor which pain relief medicines are safe for women who are breastfeeding.
Recognize Post-Delivery Complications
These signs point to a post-delivery problem. Call your doctor right away if you have:
Bleeding that soaks a sanitary napkin within an hour or contains large clots.
Breast pain along with redness or fever.
Bad-smelling vaginal discharge.
Leg pain or swelling.
Painful urination.
Signs of infection, such as a fever higher than 100.4° F, severe pain in your abdomen, or redness, swelling and discharge at your C-section incision site.
Watch Out for Postpartum Warning Signs
Postpartum depression is a common problem with pregnancy and delivery, and it can affect anyone. Ranging from moderate to severe, this form of depression can happen as soon as your baby is born or anytime up to one year after delivery.
Signs include:
Trouble bonding with your baby.
Lack of joy in life.
Loss of appetite.
Loss of interest in sex.
Overwhelming fatigue.
Severe mood swings.
Withdrawal from family and friends.
Often, these symptoms naturally lessen over time. However, if not recognized or managed well, postpartum depression can become quite serious. Call your doctor right away if you have any of the signs. We can help ease your symptoms and keep you safe.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Your Body Through Menopause
Menopause is a natural biological process, but it can sometimes cause unwanted symptoms. If you’re experiencing hot flashes, sleep problems, thinning hair or other issues, your OB/Gyn can help you manage your symptoms with lifestyle changes or treatments. ProMedica’s menopause clinic is also ready to help with specialized menopause management.
content.clinic:
A Clinic Dedicated to Menopause
Located in Sylvania, Ohio, ProMedica offers a menopause clinic led by Heather Wahl MD, FACOG, NCMP a certified menopause provider by the North American Menopause Society. The clinic helps women who have trouble managing their symptoms and could benefit from seeing a provider who is specialized in menopause management.
View Dr. Wahl's Profile

About Midwifery
ProMedica’s certified nurse midwives provide an array of women’s care services. While midwives are probably best known for their care of women during pregnancy and childbirth, they are also experts in women’s health throughout the lifespan - from adolescence through menopause.
Midwives offer specialized care, intended to foster a holistic approach to health and well-being, by providing choices of healthcare options that help their patients make informed decisions.
Midwifery services include:
Menopause management
Urinary incontinence
Prenatal care and birth
Family planning
Pelvic pain
Well-woman care
Breastfeeding support
Midwives offer specialized care, intended to foster a holistic approach to health and well-being.

content.articleContent:
You Don’t Have to Live With Pain
Migraine headache pain can take over your life — but it doesn’t have to. At ProMedica, we have the expertise and tools to help you find the relief you deserve.
Treating migraine headaches takes more than a one-size-fits-all approach. Based on your particular symptoms, our team uses different methods to diagnose the problem. Whether it’s a pounding head, flashes of light or tingling in your arms or legs, ProMedica’s doctors will find the treatment that works best for you.
content.diagnosis:
Diagnosing Migraines
A migraine headache is an intense throbbing or pulsing in one area of your head. Migraines sometimes include nausea, vomiting and extreme sensitivity to both light and sound. Often, migraines will have sensory warning symptoms, which include:
Blind spots.
Flashes of light.
Tingling in your arm or leg.
Get a Thorough Examination and Accurate Diagnosis
Just as there are a number of conditions that could be causing your headache pain, there are a number of diagnostic tools to help us get a clear picture of what’s happening. After gathering your complete medical history and performing a physical, your healthcare provider will help you decide which tests are needed to help diagnose your condition.
Common diagnostic procedures include:
Blood tests: These tests are often done to check for other underlying conditions.
Computed tomography scan (CT or CAT scan): A CT scan combines X-rays and computer technology to produce images of the body. These images can show detailed parts of the body, including bones, muscles, fat and organs. CT scans are more detailed than standard X-rays.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): An MRI combines large magnets, radiofrequencies and a computer to produce detailed images of organs and structures within the body.
Sinus X-rays: X-ray imaging can find congestion or other problems that may be corrected.
Spinal tap (lumbar puncture): With a spinal tap, a special needle is placed into the spinal canal within the lower back. It measures pressure in the spinal canal and brain. A small amount of cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) is removed and tested to learn if you have an infection or other problems.

providers.name: NICOLE SHEEHAN, DO
providers.location: ProMedica Physicians River Road Family Medicine

content.articleContent:
About Molecular Breast Imaging (MBI)
You want an accurate reading of your breast health. If you have dense breast tissue, molecular breast imaging (MBI) can supplement your mammogram.
ProMedica Breast Care is one of the only locations in the Midwest where you’ll find new MBI technology at work.

Understanding MRI
In order to diagnose a disease or confirm your treatment’s effectiveness, your doctor sometimes needs high-resolution images of your organs or other parts of your body. To get these images, your doctor may order an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scan.
How does MRI work?
MRI is a technique that uses radio waves and a magnetic field to gather these necessary images. During an MRI, you’ll lie inside an MRI machine (in most cases). It’s here that the magnetic field inside the machine will re-align itself with your body and, paired with radio waves, will give off faint signals.
Your radiology technician or nurse will record the signals and images and report them to your radiologist who, in turn, will interpret the findings. These findings help with diagnosis and treatment recommendations.
Where do you go for your MRI?
Choose from our many radiology centers offering MRI, as well as a variety of other radiology services.

About Multiple Sclerosis
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease in which your immune system attacks myelin, the covering that protects your nerves. This damage to the myelin disrupts information flow both within your brain and between your brain and the rest of your body. These nerves deteriorate, which is an irreversible condition. MS is a degenerative disease, meaning the symptoms will get progressively worse over time.
MS Symptoms
People with multiple sclerosis usually have their first symptoms between the ages of 20 and 40. Signs and symptoms vary depending on the extent of nerve damage and which nerves are affected. Some Multiple Sclerosis symptoms include:
Blurred vision
Loss of balance
Poor coordination
Slurred speech
Tremors
Numbness
Extreme fatigue
Problems with memory and concentration
Paralysis
Blindness
MS Flare-Ups
You can go days or years without major changes in your symptoms and then suddenly experience a “flare up,” or relapse. MS is active again when you develop new MS symptoms, a regular problem gets worse, or your symptoms last 24 hours or longer.
Causes of Multiple Sclerosis
The cause of MS is currently unknown, but childhood infections and genetics are believed to play a role.There’s no cure, but there are ways to control your symptoms. Since prolonged over-exertion and stress may be contributing factors to flare ups, exercise, regular stretching, and relaxation may help you manage MS symptoms. Talk to your primary physician or neurologist, who may recommend treatments such as physical therapy, muscle relaxants, or medications to reduce fatigue or other symptoms.

Responsive, Nurturing Care for Babies and Their Families
When your newborn needs swift, precise attention, the highly trained team at the Hillabrand Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital is here with around-the-clock care. You can count on us to be sensitive to your fragile newborn’s unique needs, and your concerns.
content.approach:
Our Approach
Our Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) is the region’s largest Level IIIb NICU. It offers 72 beds to care for newborns who need medical attention right away. The ProMedica Hillabrand NICU:
Features around-the-clock, complete care for critically ill newborns.
Includes services such as subspecialty care; mechanical ventilation with NAVA, conventional and high frequency oscillatory and jet ventilators; nitric oxide; whole body cooling; surgical management; transport; education; simulation training; research; and national outreach.
Is directed by in-house, board-certified neonatologists. These are doctors who are specially trained to care for infants.
Our NICU is committed to family-centered care.
Meet the NICU Team
The Hillabrand NICU team is a group of highly trained medical specialists. They’re on-site 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Our expert team has been recognized at national and international levels, and offers the highest-level of neonatal care right here in Toledo.
Your baby will get best-in-class care from a complete team of experienced professionals, including:
Breastfeeding specialists.
Clinical pharmacists.
Child life specialists.
Neonatal dietitians.
Neonatal nurse practitioners.
Neonatologists.
Nurses.
Physical, occupational and speech therapists.
Respiratory therapists.
Social workers.
Our Neonatologists
Neonatologists are pediatric doctors who are specially trained to care for sick and premature newborns. Our neonatologists are there for you and your family 24 hours a day. They provide routine and emergency care from pregnancy through delivery. Your neonatologist will help make sure your baby receives the care that’s needed to grow and thrive.
Neonatologists at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital include:
Howard Stein, MD, Director of Neonatology.
Kristie Hornick, DO.
Patrick Ethington, DO.
Holly Brine, MD.
Shawna Shafer, DO.
Bonisha Sthapit, MD.
Srinivasan Mani, MD.
Arnab Sengupta, MD.
Our Neonatal Nurse Practitioners
A neonatal nurse practitioner is a registered nurse who is specially trained to care for sick and premature newborns. Our neonatal nurse practitioners will support you and your family 24 hours a day with routine and emergency care for your baby.
The following neonatal nurse practitioners work under the direction of the neonatologist and help direct your baby's care at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital:
Mischel Balazs, MSN, NNP-BC, Lead NNP.
Jodie Frazier, NNP-BC
Vicky Gall, MSED, NNP-BC.
Colleen Kwiatkowski, MSN, NNP-BC.
Kellie Miller, MSN, NNP-BC, PNP-BC.
Stephanie Butler, MSN, NNP-BC.
Kristin O'Shea, NNP-BC, MSN.
Kasey Gerschutz, MSN, NNP-BC.
Shannon Canterbury, MSN, NNP-BC.
content.services:
NICU Services
Our expert team at the ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital Hillabrand NICU uses the latest technology and resources. They care for premature babies as early as 22 weeks’ gestation and as small as 400 grams (14 oz). Learn more about the services we provide to patients, as well as healthcare professionals and our community.
Education
Our NICU is a clinical training facility for:
Medical students and pediatric residents from The University of Toledo Health Science Campus.
Neonatal nurse practitioners.
Physician assistants.
Nurses.
Respiratory therapists.
Emergency medical technicians (EMTs).
Paramedic students.
They all work under the close supervision of the neonatologists, neonatal nurse practitioners, nurses and respiratory therapists. You may see many of these trainees helping with daily care for your baby.
Research
Our NICU takes an active part in multiple research initiatives to advance the field of neonatal medicine. Our goal is to provide the highest-quality care to your baby and to future babies. You may be asked by a research associate if you’d like to join a study. All studies have been approved by the ProMedica Pediatric Institutional Review Board. This regulatory body makes sure the patients in research studies are safe and protected.
If you agree to take part in a study, you’ll be asked to sign a consent form that details the study and all the benefits and risks that come with participating. Keep in mind that you don’t have to join a study. Your baby will still receive the best possible care even if you choose not to participate. Please talk with your doctor if you have any questions about taking part in a research study.
Simulation Training
Members of the NICU team receive simulation training on life-like premature and newborn mannequins. These high-fidelity mannequins simulate neonatal heart and lung functions and can be programmed to simulate infant emergencies. Simulation scenarios include high-risk, high stress situations and allow trainees to make mistakes and learn from them in a safe setting.
This practice environment helps our 'team of experts' become an 'expert team' and enhances overall patient safety.
Transportation
We are a regional referral center. Every year, approximately 350 babies are transported in and out of our NICU. We have a dedicated, highly skilled transport team comprised of nurses and respiratory therapists. We serve over 25 hospitals across 27 counties in northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan and utilize both air and ground transportation. The transport team provides specialized neonatal care from the moment they pick up a baby at the referring hospital until they arrive at our NICU.
Ventilation
Our team uses a range of ventilatory support. To meet the specific needs of critically ill newborns, the team relies on conventional ventilation, non-invasive ventilation, high frequency ventilation, nitric oxide and neurally adjusted ventilator assist (NAVA).
NAVA is a progressive mechanical ventilation method that’s controlled by a patient’s brain. This technology provides synchronized breathing support for your baby and may help reduce lifelong damage to the lungs.
As one of the first users of NAVA in newborns in the world, we’ve treated more than 1200 infants. That’s more than the rest of the world combined. Doctors at our hospital also helped to develop the worldwide management strategies and clinical guidelines for using NAVA in newborns.
content.donations:
Support the NICU
ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital Foundation raises funds to support the hospital’s NICU. Donations are used to improve technology and treatment areas and provide support programs for patients and families.
Give to the NICU Fund .

content.articleContent:
Neurologic Rehabilitation at ProMedica
You want rehabilitation professionals skilled in neurology.
Our neurological rehab addresses the physical, emotional, and psychological needs of each patient. We evaluate movement patterns, strength, flexibility, functional ability, balance, and muscle tone. Our team addresses various functional areas such as:
Thinking skills
Communication skills
Walking
Use of hands and arms
Daily living activities
We offer a range of physical, occupational, and speech therapies in a variety of settings, such as:
Acute care
Inpatient rehab
Outpatient rehab
Schools
Skilled nursing facilities
Begin your journey to health. Search for a neurological rehabilitation location near you, or download this list of neurological rehab locations.

Ease Your Mind
ProMedica's award-winning team of neurology experts includes board-certified neurologists and neurosurgeons. Whether your treatment starts at a ProMedica hospital, doctor’s office or outpatient facility, you’ll benefit from our coordinated, expert neurological care.
We’re here to help you live better when you’re facing a neurological condition. And we’re ready to guide you through the basics and beyond.
Learn more about our neurology and neurosurgery services.
View our 2021 annual report
content.approach:
Our Approach
Leading-Edge Program
Neurological conditions range from the common to the complex and rare. But all have a major impact on your health and lifestyle. That’s why we put patient-centered care at the heart of all we do.
At the ProMedica Neurosciences Institute, we combine academics, research, prevention, screening and treatment to give you access to leading-edge neurological care. It’s how we serve you with expertise and precision. And how we advance treatment and care for patients in northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
When you’re in our care, you’ll have access to:
A multidisciplinary team of experts.
Complete services including diagnostics, rehab therapies, support groups and research.
Highly specialized and caring neurologists, neurosurgeons and clinicians.
Ohio’s first BrightMatter neurosurgery technology.
The ProMedica Stroke Network, which spans northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
The region’s premier neurosciences center on the campus of ProMedica Toledo Hospital.
Toledo’s first Comprehensive Stroke Center.
A range of specialists, including neurologists, pediatric neurologists a neuro-ophthalmologist.
Nationally Recognized Team
ProMedica is nationally recognized for the consistent, high-level care we provide to our communities. Our neurology department, in particular, is awarded and recognized for its expert stroke and neurological care.
Named to 100 Hospitals and Health Systems with Great Neurosurgery and Spine Programs in 2018 by Becker's Hospital Review.
Awarded Acute Stroke Ready Certification by The Joint Commission and American Heart Association/American Stroke Association.
Certified as a Comprehensive Stroke Center by The Joint Commission and American Heart Association/American Stroke Association.
Awarded Get With The Guidelines® Gold Plus by the American Heart Association.
Received numerous Healthgrades awards and distinctions.
Awarded Primary Stroke Center Certification by HFAP (Healthcare Facilities Accreditation Program).
Certified as a Primary Stroke Center by The Joint Commission and American Heart Association/American Stroke Association.
content.services:
Comprehensive Neurological Care in Toledo
Your brain coordinates thought by combining memory, emotion, behavior, movement, speech and sensation. It’s the center of your nervous system and extremely important to your body’s functioning.
Neurosciences at ProMedica includes both neurology and neurosurgery. Neurology is the treatment of nervous system disorders, including those that affect the brain, spinal cord and nerves.
Neurological surgery provides operative and nonoperative care for disorders of the brain, meninges, skull and blood supply. Neurosurgeons also perform spine surgery for conditions such as spinal stenosis, herniated disks and disk degeneration.
Additional Services
At ProMedica, we support your whole neurological health journey, from your first consultation and diagnosis through your recovery. Our support services include:
Neurological rehab.
Occupational therapy.
Physical therapy.
Speech language pathology.
Neurophysiology testing, which includes EMGs, EEGs, vestibular testing, Botox services.
Conditions We Treat
Many health conditions can cause you to have neurological issues and side effects. At ProMedica, we care for patients living with or recovering from:
Alzheimer's and dementia.
Brain aneurysms.
Brain tumors.
Migraine headaches.
Multiple sclerosis.
Parkinson's disease.
Seizures and epilepsy.
Spine conditions.
Stroke.
Vestibular problems and dizziness.

content.articleContent:
Neurosurgery at ProMedica Toledo Hospital
Receive best-in-class neurosurgery care right here at ProMedica Toledo Hospital. Our experienced team of neurosurgeons brings a long-standing history of quality care and expertise in the diagnosis and surgical treatment of brain and spine conditions. As part of ProMedica Neurosciences Institute, Toledo Hospital connects you to the latest neurosurgery technologies, treatments, resources and experts.
BrightMatter™ Technology
Toledo Hospital is home to Ohio’s first BrightMatter™ technology, an innovative solution that combines advanced imaging, planning, navigation and robotics for complex brain and spine surgeries. BrightMatter provides our neurosurgeons with the latest advancements in visualization tools to perform minimally invasive, patient-specific brain and spine procedures. It uses an advanced MRI brain-imaging method called diffusion tensor imaging, or DTI, to create a highly detailed map of the brain’s white matter pathways. This functionality allows surgeons to see details that can't be seen with the naked eye and may allow access to brain locations previously deemed inoperable.
 
 
 
BrightMatter leads to less surgical time and improved patient outcomes.
Conditions and diseases treated:
Aneurysms
Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs)
Brain tumors
Congenital anomalies
Degenerative diseases
Infections
Injuries and trauma
Spine and spinal cord conditions
Types of procedures performed:
Craniectomy
Craniotomy
Discectomy
Laminectomy
Skull base surgery
Spinal fusion
Call 419-291-4590 today to schedule an appointment with a neurosurgeon.

Understanding Nuclear Medicine
Nuclear medicine is used to determine how an organ is functioning. For example, nuclear medicine can be used to study how a damaged heart is functioning or how blood flow is restricted in parts of the brain. Other organs that can be imaged using nuclear medicine include the liver, kidneys, thyroid, bones, and many others.
During a nuclear medicine study, chemicals 'tagged' with radionuclides that emit gamma rays are injected into the body. The chemicals collect in the area of the body that is to be studied. Images, which may be taken immediately or days after the injection, are obtained by using a gamma camera that detects the gamma rays and produces an image map called a scintigram.
Nuclear medicine studies provide information that can help your doctor diagnose and treat diseases in their early stages. Nuclear medicine, using radioactive substances, can also be used to treat certain diseases and conditions, such as overactive thyroid glands or thyroid tumors.
Preparing for a Nuclear Medicine Study
Generally, there are no special preparations that need to be made prior to having a nuclear medicine study. However, certain types of studies may require some preparation. For example, prior to having a thyroid uptake and scan, your doctor may ask that you avoid foods and medications with iodine for one week prior to the test. Your doctor or radiologist can advise you about any special instructions you may need to follow.

Reap the Lifetime Benefits of Better Nutrition
You want to eat a balanced, nutritious diet. But what does that mean? The answer is unique to you. One-on-one time with a registered dietitian will help you plan and reach your nutritional goals.
Call us at 419-291-6767 to schedule an appointment with a registered dietitian.
Nutrition Counseling FAQ
What is nutrition counseling?
Learn the value of a balanced, nutrition diet from our certified nutrition specialists.
Assessment of nutrition history and specific nutrient needs
Nutrient analysis of a specific three-day food record
Individual menu plan
Goal setting
Diet navigation
Recommended meal planning apps
How will nutrition counseling help you?
This program is tailored to your specific needs, potentially including:
Weight management
Nutrition after surgery or illness
Food allergy management
Health risk minimization and disease prevention
What does nutrition counseling cost?
Program costs may be reimbursed by health care flexible spending accounts. Contact us at 419-291-6767 for information.
How do you get an appointment?
Call us at 419-291-6767. Counseling can also be done via phone or video conference.
Can nutrition counseling help a specific condition?
Yes, nutrition often plays a big role in the treatment and recovery of certain conditions, which is why we build our nutrition counseling around your specific needs.
You can also find more information about the role of nutrition as it relates to:
Cancer: Proper nutrition can help you manage fatigue, nausea and other challenges.
Diabetes: A healthy diet can help you manage your glucose levels.
Heart and Vascular: The right diet can help you control cholesterol and plaque buildup.
Wound care: Help your body heal with the right supplements and foods.
High Risk Pregnancy: Proper nutrition is crucial for your baby’s best health in the womb.

Understanding Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition where one experiences unreasonable fearful thoughts and performs ritualistic activities in order to manage those thoughts.
The frequent disturbing thoughts or images are referred to as obsessions. The repetitive rituals performed to try and dispel the obsessions are called compulsions. For example: mealtimes, bath, bedtime, and exercise are all positive routine activities. However, OCD rituals are so frequent and intense that they can interfere with your daily life.
The following are examples of obsessions:
Aggressive impulses, thoughts and/or behaviors
Counting, thinking about numbers and sequences for long periods of time
Excessive fear of something terrible happening
Extreme attention to detail
Intense preoccupation with dirt and germs
Persistent thoughts of performing extremely distasteful sexual acts
Preoccupation with perfection, symmetry or order
Preoccupation with remembering trivial things
Repeated doubts (for example, did I lock the door?)
Thoughts about violence towards someone else or their self
Thoughts conflicting with religious beliefs
The following are examples of compulsions:
Asking the same question repeatedly
Constant checking and rechecking (for example, checking if a door is locked)
Excessive counting, recounting and/or grouping
Hoarding objects
Repeated obscene words or gestures
Repeated words, sounds, numbers, and/or music to self
Repeated hand-washing (often more than 100 times a day)
Repeated words spoken by self or others
Causes
The exact cause is unknown, but research suggests that it’s a neurological brain disorder caused by a deficiency of the chemical, serotonin, in the brain. OCD tends to run in families.
OCD in Children and Adolescents
If you believe your child has OCD, contact your pediatrician to set up an appointment for evaluation. If further assessment is needed, your pediatrician may recommend evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional. OCD can be effectively treated, usually with a combination of individual therapy and medication.

content.articleContent:
Occupational Therapy at ProMedica Total Rehab
ProMedica Total Rehab offers a wide variety of therapy specialties, including Occupational Therapy. Our licensed occupational therapists focus on maximizing each person’s skills and abilities through evaluation and treatment of various disorders. These disorders include musculoskeletal such as a tendon repair; neurological such as a stroke; cognitive and emotional impairments, and limitations in functional ability due to these disorders.
How can ProMedica help you with occupational therapy?
Following a physician referral to Occupational Therapy, our therapists will work closely with you and your physician to coordinate a plan of care that will achieve your best possible outcome in recovery. From your session, you can expect:
A treatment plan developed between you and the therapist during the initial evaluation.
Follow up sessions if necessary, scheduled to meet your financial and lifestyle requirements.
Written plan of care and progress reports shared with the referring physician.
Home program designed to address your individual needs.
Where and how can I receive occupational therapy?
At ProMedica Total Rehab, our experts are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. We provide occupational therapy in a number of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.
Please consult with your physician to determine if occupational therapy is right for you.
A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.
Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

3 Steps to See a Provider in Minutes
With ProMedica OnDemand, you can have a live video visit anytime with a board-certified provider through your mobile device or computer. It’s open to all ages and you don’t have to be a ProMedica patient to use it. Prescriptions are even sent to your desired pharmacy if needed.
All visits are $64 or less, depending on your insurance coverage.
content.mobile:
Step 1. Sign Up
It’s simple to sign up through our mobile app or website. Afterwards, you’ll be ready to start a visit anytime.
On Your Smartphone or Tablet
Download our free ProMedica OnDemand app.
 
On Your Desktop Computer
Visit our ProMedica OnDemand sign-in page.
Go to ProMedica OnDemand
Step 2. Choose Your Provider
Once you’re ready to have a visit, choose your provider from our directory of board-certified professionals.
Step 3. Visit with Your Provider in a Virtual Setting
See a provider in minutes through secure, high-quality video. All visits are $64 or less, depending on your insurance.

content.articleContent:
Relief From the Joint Pain That's Holding You Back
Joint pain can feel like a roadblock in your day. It can keep you from tackling essential tasks and doing the activities you enjoy. The orthopaedic surgery team at ProMedica may be able to help.
ProMedica is home to the only specialty hospital in the Toledo region that’s solely dedicated to orthopaedic care: Wildwood Orthopaedic and Spine Hospital. Plus, our experienced orthopaedic specialists perform more than 15,000 orthopaedic surgeries every year throughout our service area. So, no matter where you are in your joint pain journey, you’ll be in expert, caring hands.
content.procedures:
Orthopaedic Procedures at ProMedica
Arthroscopy
Arthroscopy is an outpatient procedure used to look at, diagnose and treat problems inside a joint. During the procedure, surgeons reconstruct ligaments or cartilage and remove loose bone or cartilage from the knee, shoulder, elbow, ankle, hip or wrist.
Hip Replacement Surgery
Hip replacement surgery allows your surgeon to replace damaged parts of your hip joint with new parts made of metal alloys, high-grade plastics and polymers. Hip replacement choices include:
Total hip replacement: removes part of the thigh bone, including the ball (the top), and replaces it with a new, smaller artificial ball.
Anterior approach hip replacement: a minimally invasive surgical method that’s done from the front of the hip. It may result in earlier and easier recovery, less pain and unrestricted movement after surgery.
Resurfacing: a procedure for younger patients in which the damaged joint is repaired with a cap placed over the ball of the thigh bone. A matching cup is mounted into the hip socket.
Knee Replacement Surgery
An artificial knee replacement allows your surgeon to replace damaged parts of your knee with artificial parts made of metal alloys, high-grade plastics and polymers.
Rotator Cuff Repairs
Rotator cuff repair surgery can help restore the function and flexibility of your shoulder and relieve pain that can’t be controlled by other treatments.
Spine surgery
Spine surgery is a delicate process. It can require extensive entry to repair a curved spine or a minimal incision to repair a herniated disc. Conditions of the spine that often require surgery include:
Herniated or bulging disc.
Broken vertebrae.
Spinal fusion.
Deformity surgery (like correcting spine curvatures caused by scoliosis).
content.before:
Preparing for Your Orthopaedic Procedure
What to Expect at Your First Appointment
At your initial orthopaedic consultation, your doctor will talk with you about the best ways to treat your bone, joint or muscle pain.
Be prepared to share your health history and any current health conditions. This is also the time to ask your doctor any questions you have, including:
Are tests or other medical evaluations needed first? How, when and where do I get them?
Are there any dietary restrictions before or after surgery?
Do I need to bring someone with me to the procedure?
What are the benefits and risks of this procedure?
What are the possible complications and how likely are they to happen?
What should I expect after treatment? How long will it take to recover?
Orthopaedic Diagnostic Tests
To diagnose your possible bone, joint or muscle condition, your orthopaedic provider will examine your range of motion and do a physical exam to check for:
Growths or cysts around joints.
Misalignment in your skeleton.
Muscles that are not equal on both sides of your body.
Swollen joints.
Along with the physical range of motion and flexibility exam, your doctor may order other tests which could include:
Blood tests to pinpoint conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, cancer and other health concerns.
Bone scans to measure how much bone tissue needs to be removed or replaced.
Computed tomography scans (CT or CAT scans) to produce detailed images of your body.
Gait analysis to spot abnormalities in your body structure, see how your limbs align and check your joint rotation.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to create pictures of what’s happening inside your body.
Reflex response to assess how quickly your joints and brain respond to stimulus.
X-rays to check for fractures or tumors.
Preparing for Recovery
Once your procedure is scheduled, our team will talk with you about how to proactively prepare for recovery. This will include health and wellness guidelines, as well as ways to make sure your home is set up for healing.
Preparing Your Body for Recovery
You can lower your risk of complications by being in the best possible health before your procedure.
Eat healthy, nutritious foods.
Exercise safely to improve fitness.
Stay at a healthy weight.
Manage sleep apnea.
Get help for depression.
Setting Your Home Up For Recovery
During recovery, you may not be able to move around as much as usual. Think through your daily routines and make sure you have the support and resources you need to recover safely and fully heal.
Arrange for help with household chores.
Be aware of medicines that make you sleepy, dizzy or lightheaded.
Follow the recommended exercises to have more strength and better balance.
Make a plan about what to do if you fall.
Make sure your bed is low enough.
Move a bed to the first floor to avoid climbing stairs.
Remove any loose objects or carpeting from the stairs.
Bathroom Safety Tips
Bathing is one of the trickiest tasks you’ll tackle after surgery. You can make showering after the procedure easier and safer by being ready ahead of time. Try these tips for your bathroom:
Get a bath chair or bench to use in the shower.
Install safety bars — one to help you get in and out of the tub and another to help you stand from a sitting position.
Place nonslip suction mats or rubber silicone decals inside and outside the bath.
content.after:
Healing at Home After Your Orthopaedic Procedure
Home Health Care
The ProMedica Home Health Care team provides extra support for patients at home. Services include medical care for your wounds, help around the house and physical therapy. We can also help you purchase the Lifeline Medical Alarm Service.
Pain Management
Pain relief after surgery helps you build the strength and confidence you need to heal. Our multidisciplinary approach to pain management begins with the most up-to-date anesthesia methods.
Post-surgery, your pain management plan may include in-office procedures, physical and aquatic therapy and medicine. For patients undergoing total joint replacement, we offer the ON-Q* Pain Relief System, which can provide better pain relief than narcotics alone.
Learn more about pain management.
Physical Therapy
At ProMedica Total Rehab you’ll have access to a wide variety of therapy specialties, including physical therapy. After a joint replacement, our licensed physical therapists evaluate and treat you so you can maximize your skills and abilities. Their goal is to coordinate a plan of care that will help you recover with the best possible outcome.
Once you’ve recovered from your surgery, you may need to have physical therapy in an outpatient setting. We offer therapy at more than 20 convenient locations in northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.
Find a ProMedica Total Rehab location near you.
Swing Bed Program
If you’re recovering from a major surgery such as total joint replacement, you may benefit from our swing bed program. It’s called a swing bed because your care “swings” from traditional hospital care to skilled nursing care. It allows you to stay at the hospital, rather than transferring to a nursing center. Your care team can help you decide if the swing bed program is right for you.
Wound Care
Your surgical team will give you detailed instructions to care for your incision (cut) site safely. Once you’re at home, call your doctor right away if you notice:
A temperature above 100°F for more than four hours.
An increase in the wound size.
Bleeding.
More drainage or the wound turns green or yellow or smells bad.
More pain, redness or swelling.
Learn more about wound care.

content.articleContent:
To Help You Get Moving Again
It’s hard to feel your best, or to live your best life, when you’re in pain. If your bones, ligaments, muscles or joints are hurting, we’re here to help.
With services across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan, you can rest easier knowing there’s high-quality orthopaedic care, close to home. Our board-certified specialists will support your every step until you’re back to the life and activities you love.
Learn more about orthopaedic services.
View our 2021 annual report
content.approach:
Our Approach
At the ProMedica Orthopaedic Institute, you get more than an appointment with a doctor or a therapist. You get experience, knowledge and attention from a large network of orthopaedic, sports medicine and spine experts.
Our specialists work together to make sure you get the best possible bone, joint and muscle care. You’ll receive services including prevention and awareness, diagnosis, surgery and rehabilitation.
At the center of the Institute is the ProMedica Wildwood Orthopaedic and Spine Hospital, a division of ProMedica Toledo Hospital. This specialty hospital was built with you in mind, from our use of advanced technology and special features that provide comfort and convenience.
You’ll also find a wide range of orthopaedic and rehab services at each ProMedica hospital. So, whether you start out at your local emergency room after a sports injury or visit your doctor with a joint problem, you’ll find all the help you need to get moving again.
Comprehensive, Whole-Person Care
When you have pain, you need relief. But you also need a clear path to healing to keep from getting injured again. That’s why we look at your whole health, not just at the condition or injury that brought you to us. The region’s leading orthopaedic and spine specialists have come together to bring you whole-person care, from diagnosis through treatment and beyond.
Multidisciplinary, Expert Team
Our team of orthopaedic experts include:
Orthopaedic surgeons: You can count on our experienced orthopaedic surgeons for the latest surgical procedures to give you the best possible results and the shortest recovery.
Pediatric orthopaedic surgeons: Our highly trained pediatric team offers expert, compassionate bone and joint care for children.
Rehabilitation therapists: Our therapists work with you to help you move, reduce pain, restore function and prevent disability.
Sports medicine specialists: Our skilled team will get you back in the game faster with on-field injury evaluation and diagnosis, surgery referrals, care during rehabilitation and performance training.
Access to Leading-Edge Clinical Trials
When you need orthopaedic care, you want the best, most advanced care. Clinical trials let you access treatments and methods that aren’t always available to the public. Talk to your doctor to see if you’re eligible to be part of an orthopaedic clinical trial.
To learn about current orthopaedic clinical trials, contact phsirb@promedica.org or research@promedica.org.
content.injuries:
Common Injuries
Whether you’re an athlete, weekend warrior or senior, your body is a complex system of moving parts that keep you in constant motion. Because of all that movement, your joints and muscles are prone to injury. Common orthopaedic injuries can include:
Whether you’re an athlete, weekend warrior or senior, your body is a complex system of moving parts that keep you in constant motion. Because of all that movement, your joints and muscles are prone to injury. Common orthopaedic injuries can include:
Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears: Sudden stops or twists can cause the ACL to tear or overstretch.
Carpal tunnel syndrome: Pain, weakness or numbness in your hand, wrist and arm caused by a pinched nerve in your wrist.
Boutonnière deformity: Torn tendons that keep your fingers from straightening.
Bursitis: The fluid-filled pads (bursae) between your joints become inflammed and make it painful and difficult to move.
Dislocation: Bones are moved out of their normal positions in a joint.
Fractures: Force or pressure is put on a bone and it breaks or cracks.
Fragility fractures: Small breaks in the bone caused by simple falls. Low bone density from osteoporosis can lead to fragility fractures.
Herniated (slipped) discs: Painful shifts, swelling or tears in the discs that cushion and separate the bones in your back.
Medial collateral ligament (MCL) injuries: Twisting and knee bending, or a blow to the outside of the knee, that tears or strains the ligaments.
Meniscal (cartilage) tears: The knee’s cushioning is torn by a sharp twist or pivot.
Osteoarthritis: Damage to joint cushioning and bones through overuse as you get older.
Plantar fasciitis: Intense pain when standing, that’s caused by strained ligaments in the foot.
Rheumatoid arthritis: A condition where the body mistakenly attacks cartilage and other organs in the body.
Rotator cuff injuries: Swelling or tearing of the tendons and bursae (fluid-filled cavity) in your shoulder where your arm meets your upper body. It’s caused by repeated, strenuous overhead activity.
Sciatica: Pain or numbness in the leg caused by a pinched or damaged nerve in the spine.
Spinal stenosis: A narrowing or loss of space in the spinal column that puts pressure on the spinal cord.
Sprains: Ligaments surrounding a joint are stretched too far or torn.
Tarsal tunnel syndrome: Pain, weakness and tingling in the foot caused by a pinched nerve.
Tendonitis: A swollen tendon that causes pain and discomfort.
content.services:
Our Services



Testing
Treatments
Pain management
Testing
We all have aches and pains from time to time. But what if you have symptoms such as aching, swelling and limited range of motion that disrupt daily life? It may be time to get help. Talk to your doctor about seeing an orthopaedic specialist who can check for:
Alignment issues
Growths or cysts around the joints
Muscle issues
Swollen joints
An orthopaedic specialist will also check your range of motion and flexibility. If there are problems, you may need diagnostic testing. These tests can include:
Arthroscopy: This surgical procedure is used to see inside a joint using small instruments and a tiny camera inserted through a small incision (cut).
Blood tests: A variety of blood tests may be used to diagnose rheumatoid arthritis, cancer and other conditions.
Bone scans: Your doctor may recommend a bone scan to measure your bone tissue.
Computed Tomography Scans (CT or CAT scan): These scans can create detailed images of your body.
Gait analysis: Your doctor may use a gait analysis to pinpoint issues with your structure, limbs and joint rotation.
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): MRI technology uses powerful magnets and radio waves to create pictures of what’s happening inside your body.
Reflex response: A test used to see how fast your joints and brain respond.
X-Ray: X-rays help us find injuries like fractures and cancer tumors.
Treatments
Our team of orthopaedic experts are here for one reason: to heal your pain and help you feel whole again. Our team offers a wide variety of services including:
Orthopaedic services.
Orthopaedic surgery services.
Pediatric orthopaedic services.
Short-term skilled nursing and rehabilitation.
Specialized sports medicine services.
Total Rehab services
Pain management
If you live with chronic pain in your bones, joints or muscles, you want relief. Every type of pain is unique, and so are you. That means you need expert advice to help control your pain so you can feel more like yourself.
Our experts are here to help. They may suggest different ways to ease your pain, including home remedies, medical massage, medicines, physical therapy or injections.
Your surgeon will also provide medicine to help with your pain after surgery. This may include medicine you can take by mouth, with a pain pump or through injections.
Learn more about pain management.

content.articleContent:
Rehab for Osteoarthritis
Many people with osteoarthritis believe that symptoms are inevitable and cannot be managed. Let our experts at ProMedica Total Rehab help you relieve your joint pain.
Have you noticed mild swelling around your joints?
Do you feel as though your joint pain is worse after activity or towards the end of the day?
Have you heard a clicking or cracking sound when a joint bends?
What is osteoarthritis?
Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis. It occurs when the cartilage in a joint breaks down due to “wear and tear” over time. This can result from overuse during a job or athletic activities. When the cartilage is damaged or gone completely, moving a joint can cause pain and friction between joints.
Can osteoarthritis be treated?
If you have osteoarthritis, talk to your doctor about treatment options. With a prescription from your physician, physical and occupational therapy can be an effective method of treatment. We believe that regular weight bearing exercise, strengthening and stretching can help to reduce or alleviate pain and improve your day to day function.
How can ProMedica Total Rehab help you?
At ProMedica Total Rehab, we are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. Most ProMedica Total Rehab locations provide osteoarthritis care.
Talk to your physician to determine if this treatment is right for you.
A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.
Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

content.articleContent:
About Osteoporosis and Other Bone Conditions
You know you need to take care of your bones. But your lifestyle choices, illness, and occupation can take a toll. Learn about common bone conditions.
Osteoporosis FAQ
What is osteoporosis?
Osteoporosis is the thinning of bone tissue and loss of bone density, most often experienced by women, over time. Osteoporosis affects close to 32 million American women over 50, and nearly 2 million men between 50 and 70 years old.
How does osteoporosis affect you?
As osteoporosis progresses, the bones become more and more brittle. Thinner bones lead to fractures and broken bones, and thin bones are harder to heal. In extreme cases, your bones can be so fragile that bumping into a piece of furniture can cause a fracture. Osteoporosis can also decrease your height and put stress on your back.
What causes osteoporosis?
Menopause is one of the primary causes of osteoporosis in women. The female hormone estrogen protects women’s bones. During menopause this hormone decreases sharply. Some women lose up to 20 percent of their bone mass during menopause.
But men with certain conditions are at risk too. Cystic fibrosis, asthma, low testosterone levels, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease can all lead to osteoporosis in men. Alcohol abuse and tobacco usage lead to significant damage to your bones, for both men and women.
Are you at risk?
If you answer yes to any of the following questions, talk to your doctor about a bone density test.
Are you over the age of 65?
Do you have a history of bone fractures as an adult or do you have a close relative with a history of bone fractures?
Do you have a family history of osteoporosis?
Did you have an early menopause or removal of your ovaries?
Do you smoke?
Do you have a small-boned, thin body frame?
Are you physically inactive?
Are calcium-rich foods, like dairy or leafy green vegetables, limited in your diet? Have you been told you're vitamin D deficient?
Do you consume alcohol on a regular basis?
Are you on certain medicines, such as steroids or anticonvulsants?
How can you prevent osteoporosis?
Regular exercise and a diet rich in calcium and Vitamin D strengthen your bones and prevent damage from osteoporosis. If you’re over the age of 50, you should get 1,500 milligrams of calcium and 1,000 milligrams of Vitamin D daily. Foods like eggs, cheese, low-fat milk, fish, and leafy vegetables are good sources of both calcium and Vitamin D. Spending 20 to 25 minutes in the sun is also a beneficial way to get Vitamin D.
Ask your doctor about an osteoporosis bone screening to detect osteoporosis early.
The most common test is the dual X-ray absorptiometry (DXA or DEXA) test. This measures your bone density using X-ray imagery.
What are some other bone conditions?
Acromegaly: Excess growth hormone production causes bones in the face, hand, and feet to grow too large.
Cancer: Common bone cancers include leukemia, osteosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma, malignant fibrous histiocytoma, and chondrosarcoma.
Fibrous Dysplasia: Swelling and abnormal growth of bones of the skull, face, ribs, upper arms, pelvis, thighs, and shins.
Heel spurs: Calcium deposits that form on the base of the heel bone.
Osteogenesis Imperfecta: A genetic disorder that interrupts the production of collagen, which weakens your bones.
Osteomalacia: Weak and abnormal bones caused by a defect in the way your body processes vitamin D.
Osteomyelitis: A bacterial infection of bone requiring antibiotics and sometimes surgery.
Paget's Disease: Thick and enlarged, but brittle, bones caused by a malfunction in the cells that repair your bones.
Perthes' Disease: The head of a child’s femur (thigh bone) deteriorates because of a lack of blood supply.
Rickets: Weak and easily fractured bones in children due to a lack of vitamin D.

content.articleContent:
A Partner in Your Child’s Care
Find a Provider
Childhood is a journey filled with growth and joy. When there are bumps in the road, like illnesses or injuries, ProMedica is here to guide the way.
Our pediatricians and specialists offer a full spectrum of services for children of all ages. We treat common and complex conditions with a focus on compassionate, family-centered care. From preventive care and check-ups to state-of-the-art emergency care, you can be sure you’ll always have a place to turn to.
content.primarycare:
Pediatric Primary Care Services
Our goal is to deliver whole-child care that helps your little ones stay safe and healthy. Our network of doctors and providers means your kids receive care from a single trusted source. You’ll have access to preventive care like immunizations and physicals. And, if more serious issues arise, we’ll connect you with pediatric specialists. At ProMedica, we treat your family like our family.
Well-Baby Care
Well-baby checkups let you and your pediatrician monitor and encourage your baby’s health and growth. Our well-baby services include:
Baby immunizations.
Breastfeeding support and education.
Baby’s sleeping habits.
Normal weight loss or gain.
Your infant’s energy levels.
Children’s Care
Having a primary care pediatrician you can trust is a vital resource. With our network of pediatricians and specialists all around the region, it’s easy for your family to get outstanding care close to home.
Our pediatric primary care services include:
Chronic disease management such as asthma or diabetes.
Developmental milestone guidance.
Regular checkups and physicals.
Sick visits.
Specialist referrals.
Vaccines and childhood immunizations.
Vaccinations
Vaccinations can help protect your child from serious diseases including measles, mumps, rubella, diphtheria, polio, tetanus and hepatitis. Many vaccines are given during your child’s first year, though some are given through childhood.
Your pediatrician can tell you about immunizations and vaccinations that are recommended for your child. You may have questions about vaccines, side effects or whether you can combine multiple vaccines into a single shot. Your child’s doctor is here to guide you through them.
Back-to-School and Sports Physicals
Regular physicals are an important part of preventive care and help your child safely participate in educational and athletic opportunities. During these physicals, our pediatric experts will review your child’s current and past medical history, family history, medications and any health concerns.
Sports physicals allow us to identify conditions that may need treatment or rehabilitation, like a muscle strain or broken bone, before your child participates. That’s why it’s ideal to have your child’s physical done 4-6 weeks prior to the start of their sport season.
content.specialties:
Specialty Care
ProMedica’s wide range of pediatric specialists provide advanced care for chronic and acute pediatric health conditions. Along with leading-edge treatments, our care teams offer support and guidance for families as they navigate treatment and recovery. Learn more about our featured pediatric specialties below or find a pediatric specialist near you.
Find a Pediatric Specialist
Asthma & Pulmonology
Our team of pediatric pulmonologists, pediatric sleep specialists, registered nurses, respiratory therapists and asthma educators are here to help manage your child’s asthma and sleep issues with a family-centered approach. We’re also the first program in Ohio certified by the Joint Commission for both inpatient and outpatient asthma care.
Find a Provider
Autism
We’re proud to offer a range of autism support, resources and services in one convenient location – the ProMedica Finnegan Family Autism Center. We partner with specialty organizations such as the Autism Early Learning Program, Great Lakes Collaborative for Autism, Harbor, iTaalk and Special Kids Therapy to give your child the support they deserve.
Find a Provider
Cystic Fibrosis
We are home to the Cystic Fibrosis center of Northwest Ohio, accredited by the National Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. From cystic fibrosis diagnosis to ongoing treatment and research, our care plans are tailored to your child to ease symptoms and improve quality of life.
Find a Provider
Gastroenterology
Our skilled pediatric gastroenterologists and clinical staff assess and treat children with digestive system diseases and conditions, including celiac disease, lactose intolerance and liver disease. ProMedica facilities provide a full range of inpatient and outpatient services, diagnostic procedures, and treatments.
Find a Provider
Hemophilia
The hemophilia experts at our Northwest Ohio Hemophilia Treatment Center combine medical therapies and lifestyle changes to treat your child’s hemophilia. We’ll work closely with you and your family to create a personalized plan that fits your child’s specific needs.
Find a Provider
Orthopaedics
Whether it’s a chronic condition or a sports injury, we treat a range of chronic and emergency orthopaedic diseases and disorders. Our fellowship-trained and board-certified orthopaedic surgeons belong to a network of pediatric support services. That means your child is connected to all the care they need – from diagnosis to treatment and beyond.
Find a Provider
content.emergency:
Hospital & Emergency Care
Our Children's Hospital
We offer specialized care just for children at the ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital. Your child will receive inpatient and outpatient services in a family-centered environment that’s designed for comfort. We want you and your child to be at ease while you receive the region’s best care.
Highlights of our award-winning children’s hospital include:
Emergency and trauma care.
Pediatric critical care and newborn ICU (NICU).
Surgical services.
ProMedica NICU
Our staff is sensitive to each family and the unique developmental needs of every infant, especially those who spend time in our Newborn Intensive Care Unit (NICU). We have a responsive and nurturing approach to providing developmentally appropriate care, and we team family members and healthcare professionals together to meet each infant’s needs.
Emergency and Urgent Care
You’ll find state-of-the-art pediatric emergency care at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital. Pediatric and emergency doctors are there 24/7, and the hospital is tailored to the unique needs of kids, with kid-sized equipment to diagnose and treat to keep your child comfortable.
When your child needs to be treated for minor illnesses or you need a last minute sports physical, ProMedica Urgent Care clinics can be found all around Toledo and the surrounding areas. We even have a ProMedica Urgent Care for Kids in Perrysburg, Ohio.

content.articleContent:
Find an Expert Who Advocates for Your Health
When it comes to your day-to-day health, your primary care provider is your main advocate. They are the ones who help you stay on track with prevention. They are also the first you go to when you have questions or concerns about your health. They are your trusted source for medical information and advice.
Find a Provider
content.toKnow:
Things to Know
For New Patients
We’re here to discuss your medical history, health screenings and any medications or supplements you’re taking. Not sure what to ask us? Download our guide.
Download Guide
Your Care Team
Your primary care team may include a physician or an advanced practice provider, such as a certified nurse practitioner or physician assistant.Family medicine providers are trained to diagnose and treat each member of the family, from infants to adults. Internal medicine providers typically focus on adult patients over the age of 18.
Flu Shots and Physicals
We’ve got these basics covered. Flu shots are typically available from October until early in the next year, while physicals are available year-round.You should see your primary care provider at least once a year for a general health check-up.
Primary Care or Specialist?
Start with your primary care provider. We’ll connect you and your health record to the specialized care you need in our network of more than 960 ProMedica Providers.
Managing Chronic Conditions
Take charge of your chronic condition with our help. From heart disease to diabetes, we’ll help with lifestyle changes and medications, and refer you to specialists when needed.
Social Risk Factors
Your ProMedica primary care provider is also committed to addressing any social risk factors that may impact your health and well-being. They may ask you questions about your living and working environment to better understand your holistic health.

content.articleContent:
Physical Therapy by ProMedica Total Rehab
ProMedica Total Rehab offers a wide variety of therapy specialties, including physical therapy. Our licensed physical therapists focus on maximizing each person’s skills and abilities through evaluation and treatment of various disorders including musculoskeletal such as total joint replacements, and neurological impairments such as stroke.
How can ProMedica Total Rehab help you?
Our physical therapist will identify and treat problems that interfere with your ability to move naturally and perform daily activities independently. Following a physician referral to physical therapy, our therapists will work closely with you and your physician to coordinate a plan of care that will achieve your best possible outcome in recovery.
From your session, you can expect:
A treatment plan developed between you and the therapist during the initial evaluation.
Follow up sessions if necessary, scheduled to meet your financial and lifestyle requirements.
Written plan of care and progress reports shared with the referring physician.
Home program designed to address your individual needs.
Where and how can I receive physical therapy?
At ProMedica Total Rehab, our experts are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. We provide physical therapy in a number of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.
Please consult with your physician to determine if physical therapy is right for you.
A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.
Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

Our Pain Management Programs
You want ease, not an easy way out. You’re ready to be active in your pain management treatment. Connect to relief by considering the many options available to you through our pain management programs.
Our individualized pain management programs help you control your pain so that you can start living your life again.

Understanding Parkinson's Disease
Parkinson's disease is a chronic and progressive disease of the central nervous system. While it traditionally was considered to affect the motor system, it is now recognized to have a range of clinical features. In addition to movement problems, there may also be neuropsychiatric and non-motor symptoms. The exact cause of Parkinson's disease is not always clear but many symptoms are thought to result from a lack of dopamine (chemical that is responsible for transmitting signals in between the nerve cells (neurons) of the brain).
The key motor features of Parkinson's disease are:
Tremor that typically occurs at rest and may have a 'pill rolling' appearance
Stiffness or rigidity of the limbs and trunk
Generalized slowness of movement (bradykinesia)
Inability to keep body in stable or balance position
Gait difficulty

About Pediatric Gastroenterology
For disorders of the digestive system, including the esophagus, stomach, intestines, liver, gallbladder, and pancreas, ProMedica facilities provide a full range of inpatient and outpatient services, diagnostic procedures, and treatments.
We provide treatment for these common childhood digestive system diseases and conditions:
Abdominal pain
Celiac disease
Constipation / encopresis
Diarrhea
Pediatric failure to thrive and feeding problems
Food allergies and sensitivities
Gastrointestinal bleeding
Gastroesophageal reflux
Inflammatory bowel disease
Lactose intolerance
Liver disease
Vomiting
Treatments and Procedures
Our skilled pediatric gastroenterologists and clinical staff assess and treat children with these conditions using the most effective inpatient and outpatient techniques including:
Colonoscopies
Endoscopy procedures, including video capsule endoscopy
24-hour pH / impedance probes
Banding of esophageal varices
Esophageal manometry
Liver biopsies
Nutritional services / feeding team
Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube placement
Rectal suction biopsies
Sclerotherapy of esophageal varices
Stricture dilatations
For more information or to schedule an appointment, call 419-291-7010.

content.articleContent:
Help Your Child Regain Control
When your child has a hard time breathing, it can be hard to catch your breath, too. That’s why our team of pediatric pulmonologists, pediatric sleep specialists, registered nurses and respiratory therapists are here to help.
content.ourProgram:
A Program Dedicated to Supporting Your Child’s Every Breath
ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Hospital’s asthma program is the first to be dual-certified for inpatient and outpatient care by The Joint Commission. This recognition puts us in the company of fewer than a dozen organizations in the United States to achieve this certification. We meet the highest national standards for quality and safety in asthma diagnosis, treatment and education.
Childhood asthma in Lucas County is widespread. It affects 5% of children under the age of five, 15% of children under the age of 11, and 21% of children in grades 6 through 12. Of children diagnosed with asthma, 32% are African American.
At ProMedica Ebeid Children’s Hospital, the goal of our asthma program is to help minimize the frequency and severity of a child’s symptoms. Working directly with affected children and their families, we help them understand and manage their condition. This reduces their risk for emergency room and hospital visits, and improves quality of life. Our patient care program offers a wide spectrum of services and support, including:
Controller medicines to decrease symptoms and prevent asthma attacks.
Education on personal asthma triggers, such as allergies, smoke, exercise and cold air.
How to understand the differences among medicines and how to take the right one at the right time.
Personalized Asthma Action Plans to help monitor and manage symptoms and document key healthcare contacts. The plans can be shared with schools, athletic coaches and day care providers.
Rescue medicines for sudden attacks.
content.ourExpertise:
Experts in Pediatric Pulmonary Conditions
The board-certified specialists in our pediatric pulmonary clinic are committed to excellent care for your child. We follow nationally recognized guidelines and advise on the most up-to-date medicines.
Most importantly, we make sure families understand how to help their children with the right treatments and symptom management for asthma and other respiratory disorders, including chronic cough, apnea of infancy, cystic fibrosis, sleep disturbances, and more.
content.resources:
Asthma Resources
We work with patients and their families to empower them to better understand asthma and how they can manage their condition. If your child has asthma, you can help by:
Understanding signs and symptoms. Download our booklet .
Becoming tobacco free. Download our flyer .
Attending a free asthma class. Learn more by calling 419-291-5474.
Download our free pediatric asthma activity book .
