content.articleContent:
Helping You Feel Healthier, Stronger and More Resilient
Living with chronic pain isn’t easy. It can affect every part of your day and take a toll on your mental and emotional health. That’s why it’s important to find a team who can diagnose and treat your pain with care and precision.
We don’t want chronic pelvic pain to define your life. That’s why we have a large network of specialists who can work together to pinpoint the cause of your pain. Once we find the source, we’ll create a treatment plan to fit your unique needs.
Whether you’ve been in pain for months or years, we’ll work hard to help you feel more like yourself again.
content.causes:
Understanding Chronic Pelvic Pain
Chronic pelvic pain is discomfort in the lower abdomen (below the belly button) that lasts for at least six months. There are many different conditions that can cause chronic pelvic pain. And symptoms can vary widely from person to person — from pain that comes and goes to severe and steady pain.
Just as each person is unique, so is each case. While some describe chronic pelvic pain as a dull ache or heaviness in the pelvis, others have cramping and sharper bouts of pain. Whatever your experience is, when your pain causes you to miss work and lose sleep or avoid activities you love, it’s time to get medical attention.
Working with a pelvic health specialist, you can pinpoint the source of your pain and come up with a care plan that offers relief.
1 in 3 women of childbearing age have chronic pelvic pain.
Causes of Chronic Pelvic Pain
Endometriosis
Endometriosis happens when tissue that normally grows inside your uterus, grows on the outside. While we still don’t know the exact cause, we know its risk factors. These include:
A family history of endometriosis (blood relative).
Any condition that prevents normal menstrual flow.
Going through menopause at an older age.
Higher levels of estrogen in the body.
Heavy periods that last longer than seven days.
Low body mass index.
Never giving birth.
Reproductive tract problems.
Short menstrual cycles (less than 27 days).
Starting your period at an early age.
We’ve also been able to pinpoint common symptoms; the most telling seem to be chronic pelvic pain, painful intercourse or difficult periods.
Endometriosis is usually diagnosed after your doctor does a pelvic exam. You may also need to have an ultrasound or MRI. In some cases, your doctor may use minimally invasive surgery (laparoscopy) to check for signs of endometriosis.
Treatment for endometriosis can include pain medicine, hormone therapy or surgery. The type of treatment you receive will depend on your symptoms and whether you want to have children. Your doctor will work with you to decide on the best treatment for your needs.
Pelvic Congestion Syndrome
Veins that are weak can cause blood to build up, and this pooling can lead to varicose veins. When varicose veins develop in your pelvis and cause chronic pelvic pain, we call it pelvic congestion syndrome.
This syndrome usually affects women of childbearing age, women who’ve had two or more pregnancies or women with a family history of vein problems.
The main symptom of pelvic congestion syndrome is chronic pelvic pain, but you also could have an urge to urinate more often, develop hemorrhoids or notice varicose veins on the outside of your genitals or on your inner thighs.
If your doctor thinks you have pelvic congestion syndrome, you’ll have a physical exam. Then you may need to have an ultrasound or CT scan to confirm the diagnosis.
Treatment usually involves taking hormone medicines, and sometimes minimally invasive surgery.
Learn more about pelvic congestion syndrome.
Pelvic Floor Disorders
The muscles, ligaments and nerves at the bottom of your pelvis make up what we call “your pelvic floor.” You may have a pelvic floor disorder if you notice changes in your normal habits. These changes include trouble urinating, urine or feces that leak out or sudden pelvic fullness or pain.
If your doctor suspects you have a pelvic floor disorder, a physical exam alone can often confirm your diagnosis. But, if your doctor needs a clearer picture of your pelvic health, more imaging tests may be requested.
Treatment for pelvic floor disorders can vary based on your unique condition, but it will often include behavioral therapy, physical therapy or medicines. Surgery may also be recommended in some cases.
Learn more about pelvic floor disorders.
Uterine Fibroids
Uterine fibroids are noncancerous growths that form in the muscles of the uterus. They can be as small as a pea or as large as an orange or cantaloupe.
Fibroids are more likely to affect women with a family history of the condition. However, obese women, African American women and women who started puberty early are also at higher risk.
While many women have no symptoms, others may experience:
Frequent urination.
Heavy bleeding between or during periods that includes blood clots.
Increased menstrual cramping.
Menstruation that lasts longer than usual.
Pain during intercourse.
Pain in the pelvis or lower back.
Pressure or fullness in the lower abdomen.
Swelling in the abdomen.
Uterine fibroids are usually diagnosed with a pelvic exam. Your doctor may also want you to have imaging tests, such as an ultrasound or MRI. These tests can offer a clearer picture of your pelvic health and confirm your diagnosis.
Treatment for uterine fibroids may include hormone therapy, changes to your diet and in some cases, minimally invasive surgery.
Other Conditions
If you’re living with chronic pelvic pain, the usual reasons for that are endometriosis, pelvic floor disorders and uterine fibroids. However, other conditions can cause chronic pelvic pain, including:
Abdominal myofascial pain happens when muscles in the abdominal wall, pelvic floor or lower back don’t work properly. Sometimes, these muscles are too sensitive or contract too much. Women who have this condition often have small areas in the pelvis (trigger points) that feel tender.
Cancers of the reproductive organs include cancer in the cervix, ovaries, uterus, vagina or vulva. If your doctor believes cancer is causing your pelvic pain, he or she will refer you to a gynecologist-oncologist.
Interstitial cystitis happens when the bladder becomes inflamed, often causing urinary incontinence. If your doctor believes you have this condition, he or she will refer you to a urogynecologist or a urologist.
Musculoskeletal problems affect your bones, joints and connective tissue, causing fibromyalgia, pelvic floor muscle tension, inflammation of the pubic joint and hernias.
Psychological factors, such as depression, chronic stress and a history of abuse, can sometimes cause pelvic pain.
Talk to an expert: Call 567-585-0240 to make an appointment.
content.treatment:
Diagnosing and Treating Your Pain
Get a Fast and Accurate Diagnosis
If you have chronic pelvic pain, your doctor will use different tests to find its source. These diagnostic tests may include:
Computed tomography (CT scan).
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
Minor surgery (laparoscopy) that allows your doctor to check for problems or signs of infection inside your pelvis.
Pelvic exam.
Pelvic ultrasound.
Physical exam and discussion about your medical history.
X-ray.
When you’re in our care, we want you to feel at ease. That’s why we work hard to get you in for testing quickly, make sure you’re comfortable during your testing appointment and share your results with you as quickly as we can.

Treating Chronic Pelvic Pain
ProMedica Gynecologist Heather Wahl, MD, FACOG, NCMP talks about the causes of chronic pelvic pain and the different ways it can be treated.
Find Effective and Compassionate Treatment
While your treatment choices are based on your specific condition, we can often help you find relief from your chronic pelvic pain with nonsurgical or minimally invasive therapies.
Because there are many different causes of pelvic pain, it’s important to work with an expert to find the right treatment for you. ProMedica’s board-certified doctors specialize in treating pelvic pain and have spent years helping women overcome chronic pelvic pain.
Your personal treatment plan may include:
Pelvic floor physical therapy can help you develop a coping strategy for your pain. This can include stretching, massage and other ways to relax.
Medicines, including pain relievers, hormone treatments, antibiotics, anti-depressants and anti-seizure drugs, may be used to help manage your chronic pain.
Psychotherapy can help with the depression and anxiety that usually accompany chronic pain.
Trigger point injections may be helpful if you have specific spots in your pelvis where you feel pain. Your doctor can inject a medicine right into the painful spots. The medicine is usually a strong anesthetic.
Laparoscopic surgery allows your doctor to see the inside of your pelvis. In some cases, your doctor may also remove tissue during your laparoscopic procedure.
Surgery may be considered in some cases. Based on your diagnosis, you may be able to have minimally invasive surgery or robotic surgery. These surgeries cause less pain and blood loss and allow you to return to normal activities sooner.
Hysterectomy to remove your uterus. This treatment is used in rare, complicated cases of chronic pelvic pain.

content.articleContent:
Compassionate Care with Exceptional Results
The way you look and the way you feel go hand in hand. We want to help you achieve your aesthetic goals so you can enjoy the self-confidence you deserve.
Our board-certified plastic and reconstructive surgeons will work with you to decide on the best treatment and services for your needs. Whether you’re looking for simple, nonsurgical enhancements or a major change, we’re here to offer the compassionate care and exceptional results you’ve come to expect from ProMedica.
content.bodyAndBreast:
Body and Breast Procedures
Breast Procedures
When you want to change how your breasts look, you want a procedure designed with your unique needs and goals in mind. Whether you want a breast augmentation or you’re considering reconstructive surgery after breast cancer treatment, we offer a range of procedures that will help you feel like your very best self.
Breast Augmentation
If you’re not satisfied with the size or shape of your breasts, an augmentation procedure may be able to help you reach your aesthetic goals. We use silicone or saline gel implants to help you get the look you’ve always wanted.
Breast Lift
Life takes its toll on your body. Over time, you may find that your breasts have become lower or lost shape. Pregnancy, breastfeeding and weight loss can all add to these changes. A breast lift, or mastopexy procedure, can help. During this procedure, we remove the excess skin around the breasts and tighten the tissue that supports the breasts. This helps to support and lift your breasts. Based on your goals, breast lifts may also use implants.
Breast Reconstruction
After breast cancer surgery, you have one goal – feeling like yourself again. Our board-certified reconstructive surgeons are here to discuss your goals and give you choices for restoring the size, shape and feel of your breasts.
We encourage you to discuss reconstructive surgery with your breast surgeon before you have a mastectomy or lumpectomy. Sometimes, reconstructive surgery can be performed at the same time as your breast cancer surgery. This means you might spend less time in the hospital and more time healing at home.
Breast Reduction
Some women feel their breasts don’t fit their body size. Not only that, large breasts may cause back, neck and shoulder pain. A breast reduction can help ease discomfort while still shaping your breasts to fit your body. Our highly experienced surgeons will remove excess breast tissue before remodeling the breast and nipple.
Breast reduction surgery isn’t just for women. Men also have breast tissue that may not be in proportion to their bodies. Male breast reduction surgery, or gynecomastia, can remove excess tissue. We perform this procedure using liposuction or surgery.
Breast Reduction Surgery

Dr. Thomas Flanigan explains how breast reduction surgery is performed and how it can help both men and women.
Body Contouring
Tummy Tuck
A tummy tuck, also called abdominoplasty, removes excess fat and skin from the abdomen. This procedure can also help renew weakened or separated muscles in the abdomen, which is a common issue after pregnancy. A tummy tuck creates a smoother and firmer abdominal profile.
content.facialProcedures:
Facial Procedures
Your face expresses who you are. If you feel wrinkles or sagging skin keep you from showing yourself to the world, we can help. The board-certified plastic surgeons at ProMedica offer a range of surgical and nonsurgical facial procedures to help you achieve the look you feel is truly you.
Dermal Fillers and Volumizing Injections
Both dermal fillers and volumizing injections can add fullness to the skin of the face. These nonsurgical treatments lessen the appearance of wrinkles around the nose and corners of the mouth. Although they have similar effects, the two treatments are slightly different. Fillers address wrinkles and depressions in the face. Volumizers actually stimulate collagen production for a more filled-out look.
Our surgeons and medical aestheticians have broad experience with dermal fillers and volumizing injections. They can guide you to the best approach to give you a natural, youthful appearance.
We offer the following dermal fillers and volumizing injections:
Belotero Balance®
Juvederm® and Juvederm Voluma.
Perlane.
Restylane.
Sculptra Aesthetic.
Endoscopic Lift
An endoscopic lift is an innovative, minimally invasive approach to brow and forehead lifts. An endoscopic lift tightens loosened skin and removes wrinkles that are simply part of the aging process. This approach can offer a variety of benefits, including:
Regenexx AD™ (Adipose Derived)
Regenexx AD™ (Adipose Derived) treatment combines our traditional Regenexx SD™ procedure with stem cells taken from fatty tissue (adipose stem cells).
This can be used to solve structural problems within the joint.
Faster recovery.
Less pain.
Lower risk of complications.
Eyelid Rejuvenation
As we age, the skin around our eyes loses its elasticity. The result? A tired appearance that can make us look older than we feel. Eyelid rejuvenation, or blepharoplasty, helps you appear more alert and refreshed.
Facial Rejuvenation
Facial rejuvenation, or facelift, can help you appear younger and more refreshed. Facial rejuvenation can be achieved surgically or nonsurgically with laser resurfacing treatments.
Fat Grafting
Fat grafting, or fat injection, transfers fat from one area of your body to another area where you want more volume. This procedure is considered a permanent filler, especially when used for face and lip injections.
Neck Lift
A neck lift, or rhytidectomy, can help you achieve a smoother neckline and improve visible signs of aging. During the procedure, your surgeon will remove excess skin and fat from around the neck and sculpt a natural silhouette.
Rhinoplasty
Rhinoplasty, or cosmetic nose surgery, can enhance the way the nose looks in proportion to the rest of the facial features. It can also help improve a range of noncosmetic issues such as breathing problems caused by a deviated septum or a birth defect.
Wrinkle-Relaxing Injections
Wrinkle-relaxing injections, also called neuromodulators, are a temporary way to improve the look of moderate to severe frown lines between the brows and around the eyes. We use Botox® Cosmetic and Xeomin to help men and women achieve a smoother, more youthful appearance.

content.articleContent:
Live Your Life Without Foot Pain
Feet have a lot of stress put on them. While it’s normal to sometimes have aches and pains, if you have constant foot or ankle pain, it’s time to find relief.
Regular visits to a podiatrist can keep your feet and ankles healthy. ProMedica’s team of foot and ankle doctors can evaluate and treat foot conditions before they turn serious. Our goal is to help you keep doing the activities you love, without pain.
content.approach:
Our Approach
People all over Toledo and the surrounding areas choose our foot and ankle experts because:
Our foot and ankle experts provide complete care by working together with orthopaedists, diabetes specialists, sports medicine doctors and other providers.
ProMedica Physicians Podiatry has been serving the Toledo area for more than 30 years.
We specialize in podiatric care for both common and complex foot conditions, from corns and bunions to complex sports injuries.
content.conditions:
Foot and Ankle Conditions
ProMedica's podiatry team can handle everything from routine checkups and conservative treatments to reconstructive surgery for a variety of conditions, including those listed below.
Achilles Tendon
The Achilles is the longest and largest tendon in the body. The tendon runs from the back of the calf muscle to the heel. One of the common conditions that affect the Achilles tendon is Achilles tendonitis, which is inflammation and swelling of the tendon. Another problem is Achilles tendonosis, which is degeneration or weakening of the tendon. Both conditions raise the risk of a ruptured tendon.
Ankle Instability
Ankle instability means there’s weakness or a recurring 'giving way' of the outside of the ankle. The condition can be inherited but is usually because of an earlier ankle injury that hasn’t been properly treated or hasn’t been completely rehabilitated. Repeated sprains can cause more ligament and joint damage and lead to arthritis.
Ankle Sprain
Sprains involve injury to one or more ankle ligaments, usually on the outside of the ankle. Ligaments are bands of tissue, like thick rubber bands, that connect one bone to another at the joints. The ligaments control and limit the joint’s motion. The sprain’s severity depends on whether the ligament(s) are stretched, partially torn or completely torn. At a minimum, a complete exam and X-rays are needed to accurately diagnose and treat the injury.
Athlete’s Foot
This skin disease is caused by a fungal infection that often occurs between the toes. The infection can spread across the entire bottom of the foot and cause dryness, cracking, itching and blisters. Feet are prone to fungal infections because shoes create a warm, dark and humid environment. This encourages fungus growth. Other conditions that can mimic athlete's foot infections are eczema, psoriasis and allergic reactions to shoe dye or glue.
Bunions
A bunion is a visible bump of bone that reflects changes to the bony framework at the ball of the foot. Bunions tend to get worse over time. Bunions are usually caused by wearing high-heeled or pointed shoes that crowd the toes.
Charcot Foot
Charcot foot occurs when the bones and joints in the foot break down because of nerve damage (neuropathy). Charcot foot is a very serious condition that can lead to severe deformity, infection, disability and even amputation.
Diabetic Foot
The most common complications of diabetes that affect the foot are nerve damage (neuropathy), decreased or blocked blood circulation (PAD) and decreased response to infection (immune compromise). These problems put people with diabetes at a higher risk for serious infections or foot wounds.
People with diabetes should check their feet closely. It’s also very important to have regular foot exams with a podiatrist. Any sudden swelling or redness in the feet could mean there’s a serious problem.
Fractures
Bone fractures can be divided into two categories: traumatic fractures and stress fractures. Traumatic fractures are caused by an incident, a direct blow or an injury that results in bruising, swelling and pain. Stress fractures are caused by repeated stress over time that leads to more pain and swelling. Stress fractures can cause pain during activity that may go away after rest. They can be caused by more intense exercise or new activity.
Fungal Nails
Fungal nails are caused by fungus or yeast infections of the nail or nail bed. Often associated with athlete's foot, this condition can become chronic and may resist treatment. Toenail fungus can usually be treated with conservative treatments.
Ganglion Cyst
A ganglion cyst is a benign growth under the skin that contains a jelly-like fluid. They can vary in size, and get smaller or larger over time. They’re common on the foot and the wrist and are often located near a tendon or joint. Early treatment can help avoid surgery for larger lesions.
Gout
Gout is a painful disorder usually associated with the big toe. It happens when uric acid collects in a joint or in the tissues. Symptoms of gout include sudden intense pain, redness, swelling and extreme skin sensitivity in the affected area. Blood tests and joint fluid analysis are used to diagnose gout.
Hallux Rigidus
This is an arthritic condition of the joint that’s located at the base of the big toe. Hallux rigidus is a form of degenerative arthritis, which means the joint cartilage has worn away. It can cause bone spurs to form and joints to enlarge. It’s a progressive condition that causes pain, stiffness, swelling and inflammation of the big toe joint.
Hammertoe
A hammertoe is a bend in one or both joints of a toe. Hammertoes usually get worse over time. Left untreated, the toe can become permanently contracted. People may develop corns or ulcers on the toes because of the toe deformities. Surgery may be needed to straighten the hammertoe.
Heel Pain
Heel pain is most often caused by plantar fasciitis, an inflammation of the tendon-like band of tissue that runs from the heel to the ball of the foot. Heel pain may also be caused by a stress fracture, bone spur, tendonitis, arthritis or nerve irritation. Because there are many causes, it’s important to have heel pain properly diagnosed by a podiatrist.
Ingrown Toenail
An ingrown toenail happens when the nail curves down or inward and grows into the skin at the nail border. Symptoms include skin irritation, pain, redness and swelling in the toe. The affected toe is often irritated by shoe or sock pressure. If an ingrown nail causes a break in the skin, bacteria may enter and cause an infection.
Metatarsalgia
Metatarsalgia is a generalized term used to describe pain in the ball of the foot. There is often swelling in this area.
Morton’s Neuroma
Morton's neuroma is the most common neuroma in the foot. A neuroma is when nerve tissue between the base of the third and fourth toes in the foot becomes enlarged and scarred. It’s caused by compression, trauma or irritation of the nerve. Patients describe a sharp pain or numbness in the associated toes, cramping in the foot or the sense that their sock is curled up under the ball of the foot. If a neuroma isn’t treated, it could lead to permanent nerve damage.
Osteoarthritis
Osteoarthritis is a condition characterized by the breakdown and eventual loss of cartilage from the surface of the joint. When 'wear and tear' causes the cartilage to become weak, painful symptoms develop that can keep someone from easily doing daily activities. In the foot, the disease often occurs in the big toe joint, but it’s also found in the midfoot and ankle joints.
Plantar Fasciitis
Plantar fasciitis is an inflammation, weakness or tearing of the tissue called the plantar fascia, anywhere along the bottom of the foot. Symptoms are usually worse when first standing in the morning or after sitting for periods of time. Wearing poorly constructed shoes or shoes without support, going barefoot or even wearing flip-flops can cause this problem.
Posterior Tibial Tendon Dysfunction (PTTD)
PTTD is an inflammation, weakness, overstretching or tearing of the posterior tibial tendon inside the foot and ankle. In PTTD, the tendon's ability to help support the arch is impaired and results in the food becoming flat. PTTD is often called 'adult acquired flat foot.' Orthotics or braces may help keep the foot from collapsing. Surgical repair may be needed.
Tailor’s Bunion
A tailor's bunion is when the bone at the base of the little toe becomes enlarged. It’s also called a bunionette. Bunionettes are aggravated by shoe pressure. Wearing shoes that are too tight can make the deformity worse over time.
Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome
Tarsal tunnel syndrome happens when the post tibial nerve is compressed. The post tibial nerve runs along the inside of the ankle into the foot. Tarsal tunnel syndrome is similar to carpal tunnel syndrome of the wrist. The nerve compression may at first cause numbness or pain at the great toe, pain in the heel or cramping in the arch. As the condition goes on, it can lead to muscle wasting, chronic foot pain and permanent nerve damage.
Warts
Warts are caused by a viral infection in the skin. Warts come in different shapes and sizes and include flat warts, mosaic warts and plantar warts. Different types of warts respond best to different treatments. Most can be treated with topical medicine, though some need laser treatment, freezing (cryotherapy) or surgical removal.
content.treatment:
Foot and Ankle Treatments
Most foot or ankle conditions can be treated by combining conservative treatments. We can perform many treatments, including minor procedures, right in our office. Our treatments include:
Custom foot orthotics: Orthotics are special shoe inserts that support your feet and restore normal foot function. They’re custom-made for your foot using a digital image, foam impression or plaster casting.
Diagnostic ultrasound: An ultrasound uses sound waves to create an image of the foot or ankle. It helps us diagnose soft tissue issues such as tendonitis, tendon tears, plantar fasciitis and cysts.
Minor office surgeries: Our office is equipped to perform many minor surgeries. Under local anesthesia, your foot doctor can safely correct ingrown or fungal nails, remove warts or bone spurs and relax tight tendons and joints.
PADnet testing: PADnet testing checks the blood circulation in your legs and feet. It can help detect blockages caused by peripheral artery disease (PAD). A person with PAD has a higher risk of stroke, heart attack and serious foot problems.
Sural nerve conduction study: This study can help us diagnose diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN). Neuropathy, or nerve damage, in the legs and feet can cause numbness, tingling and pain. It’s often one of the first symptoms of diabetes. This test gives results in less than one minute and can find signs of neuropathy even when symptoms are minor.
X-rays: Our office uses high-speed, low-dose X-rays to help find and diagnose fractures, bone spurs, arthritis and other bone problems in the feet and ankles. We take and process X-rays during your visit to quickly and efficiently diagnose your condition.

content.articleContent:
About Positron Emission Tomography (PET Scan)
Your doctor has discussed the need for a PET. Understand what it is, what to expect, and how it might benefit your health.
What is a PET?
Commonly called a PET scan, PET stands for positron emission tomography. It’s commonly requested in order to provide more information about how the following organs and tissues are working:
Brain
Heart
Lung
Breast
How does a PET scan work?
During your PET, you’ll be injected with a small amount of radioactive material, called a tracer. This tracer travels throughout your body and collects in your organs and tissues, giving your radiologist a highlighted view of the area under examination.
In order for your radiologist to assess your body’s function, you’ll lie still on a table and pass through a tunnel-like machine. This machine will detect the tracer and transform the signals into the image your radiologist will assess.
Why is a PET scan important to your health?
Generally, a PET gives your doctor a much more complete picture as to the origin or causes of symptoms you might have. Clear information means concise treatment; and focused treatment gives you the best opportunity to improve your health. Also, a PET can have results that indicate that your body is functioning just as it should, therefore ruling out serious conditions.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a condition that occurs after one experiences an emotionally or physically frightening event. The person is so affected by the ordeal that they develop frequent memories or flashbacks of it. When exposed to situations that resemble the traumatic event, they undergo severe emotional, mental and physical distress.
PTSD symptoms can start soon following the event and improve shortly after or they may persist long-term.
Common PTSD Symptoms
Signs vary, but you may notice any, or all, of the following:
Avoiding certain situations or places
Depression
Difficulty concentrating
Experiencing physical discomfort (headaches, stomachaches)
Fearing death at an early age
Having frequent flashbacks or intrusive memories
Irritability
Loss of interest in activities you used to enjoy
Lost touch with reality
Having nightmares
Trouble at work or in school
Events That Trigger PTSD
Specific examples of events which typically cause PTSD:
Abuse – physical or emotional
Animal bites
Automobile accidents
Experiencing a natural disaster (such as a flood or hurricane)
Invasive medical procedures
Man-made tragedies (bombings and shootings)
Neglect
Sexual assault or molestation
Violent attacks (mugging, torture, kidnapping, being held captive)
If you believe you may have PTSD, schedule an appointment with a provider who works in behavioral health. Counselors, therapists, psychologists, and psychiatrists are all examples of providers who may be able to help diagnose and treat your PTSD.
PTSD in Children and Adolescents
Children and adolescents can suffer from PTSD. A child with PTSD will exhibit many of the same symptoms that an adult might. In addition to the standard symptoms, children may also begin acting younger than their age (thumb-sucking, wetting the bed). Many times, PTSD started during childhood develops into a chronic disorder. However, PTSD can be treated with therapy.
Can PTSD be prevented? As a parent, you may be able to reduce the risk of traumatic experiences in your child.
Preventing PTSD in Children and Adolescents
Teach your child to say NO to someone who tries to touch them inappropriately or make them uncomfortable.
Offer support and counseling to children who have undergone a traumatic experience.
Support prevention programs within your community and at your child’s school.
If you suspect your child may have PTSD, contact your pediatrician for a proper evaluation. If further assessment is needed, your pediatrician may recommend a comprehensive evaluation by a licensed behavioral health professional.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Pulmonary Embolism
Pulmonary embolism (PE) is a blood clot in the lungs that develops in a blood vessel, often in the leg. It then breaks off and travels to an artery in your lung, where it suddenly blocks blood flow.
Blood clots in the lungs can be life threatening. It's important to call 9-1-1 right away if you have any unusual signs or symptoms.
Frequently Asked Questions
Pulmonary embolism: what is it?

What are the symptoms of a pulmonary embolism?
If a clot breaks off from the wall of your deep vein and is released into your bloodstream, it's called an embolus. This embolus travels through your bloodstream up to an artery in your lung. There, it suddenly blocks blood flow and can be life threatening if not treated immediately.
Blood clots in the lungs can cause:
Chest pain anywhere under the rib cage (may worsen with deep breathing)
Coughing up blood
Fast heart rate
Lightheadedness or fainting
Low blood pressure
Rapid breathing
Unexplained and sudden shortness of breath
What are the risk factors?

Risk factors include:
History of a blood clots in the legs or lungs
Conditions that make blood more likely to clot
Medical conditions/treatments such as cancer that is treated with chemotherapy
Birth control
Hormone therapy
Pregnancy and the first six weeks after giving birth
Recent surgery or trauma
Immobility
Obesity
Smoking
Long periods of travel
Smoking
Long periods of travel

Your Partner in Health
From cancer screenings and diagnosis to state-of-the-art treatment and support services, ProMedica does it all.
You can count on us to help guide your cancer journey with the expertise you need, treatments you want and compassionate care you deserve. ProMedica Cancer Institute offers the widest range of cancer care services in northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. We give you access to the top specialists, all in one trusted network.
When you’re ready, we’re here for you to be your trusted healthcare partner.
content.approach:
Why ProMedica?
If you’ve been diagnosed with prostate cancer, you likely have a lot of questions. We give you the answers you need and help you navigate every stage of cancer treatment.
Supportive Services for Every Step of Your Cancer Journey
We provide the support you need to face cancer treatment with hope and optimism. There will be challenges along the way, but ProMedica is here to help. Our support services include:
Genetic counseling.
Healing Care.
Medicine management counseling.
Nurse navigators.
Rehabilitation services.
Support groups.
Survivorship program.
Learn more about our cancer support services.
Care Coordination and Nurse Navigators
We know cancer treatment can feel overwhelming. We want you to focus on getting better, not trying to keep tests, treatment and doctors straight. A member of your care team or a personal nurse navigator will guide you through every step of treatment, including:
Working side-by-side with you to ensure compassionate, supportive and individualized care.
Scheduling/coordinating appointments, and helping to reduce the amount of time from diagnosis to treatment.
Providing education and support to you and your family.
Facilitating/coordinating care provided by an interdisciplinary team of physicians, including medical, surgical and radiation oncology consults.
Working on behalf of you and your family to remove possible obstacles to care, including insurance issues, medication assistance or lack of transportation.
Communicating with your physician and helping to communicate the physician’s plan of care.
Expertise You Can Count On
At ProMedica, we’re committed to excellence. By providing the highest quality care, we’re helping people live longer, healthier lives. And while our services have earned national recognition, our greatest reward is watching our patients return home, free of cancer.
Exceptional care starts with exceptional doctors. We’ve put together a highly experienced team of prostate cancer specialists, including:
Medical oncologists.
Radiation oncologists.
Radiologists.
Surgeons.
Urologists.
content.aboutProstateCancer:
Understand Prostate Cancer
Understanding prostate cancer and how it affects your body is an important part of fighting cancer. It can help you make more informed decisions about your care.
Prostate cancer, second only to skin cancer, is the most common cancer in American men. The American Cancer Society estimates that there will be more than 174,000 new cases of prostate cancer diagnosed yearly.
The prostate is a gland located below the bladder and in front of the rectum. It produces a fluid that together with other fluids produces sperm. The prostate is about the size of a walnut, but can be much larger in older men. Almost all prostate cancers are adenocarcinomas, which are cancers that start in gland cells.
Prostate cancer grows slowly. If confined to the prostate, it may not cause any serious damage. Prostate is less likely than other cancers to spread (metastasize) to other parts of the body.
Know Your Risk
One in nine men will be diagnosed with prostate cancer during his lifetime. But the good news is that, as with most cancers, the earlier you catch it, the easier it is to treat.
Since you may not show signs or symptoms, especially if your prostate cancer is in its early stages, knowing you’re at higher risk can help you stay on top of taking preventive measures and having regular screenings.
Men may have a higher risk for prostate cancer if they:
Are African American.
Are over age 65.
Have a family history of prostate cancer.
Live in North America, northwest Europe, Australia or Caribbean Islands.
Recognize the Symptoms
Since symptoms aren’t easy to notice, especially in the early stages, prostate cancer can sneak up on you. But knowing what to look for can help. Talk with your doctor if you have:
Blood in your urine or semen.
Bone pain.
Loss of bladder or bowel control.
Problems urinating.
Trouble getting an erection.
Weakness or numbness in your legs or feet.
Screening and Diagnosis
Prostate cancer screenings can usually detect this disease in its early stages. If you’re 50 or older, or you’re at a higher risk for prostate cancer, talk to your doctor to create a screening schedule that’s right for you.
Prostate cancer screening will usually begin with yearly or twice-yearly exams that include a:
Physical exam.
Digital rectal exam (DRE).
Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test.
Based on the results of your DRE and PSA screenings, your doctor may want you to have more tests.
Prostate Ultrasound
An ultrasound probe is inserted gently into your rectum. This allows your doctor to scan your entire prostate and check for abnormalities inside and around your prostate. This is often performed along with a prostate biopsy.
Prostate Biopsy
Tiny pieces of prostate tissue are removed using small needles. They are checked for cancer cells. Biopsies are the only way to know if you have prostate cancer.
Call 419-291-3000 or 1-800-479-8805 to schedule your prostate cancer screening.
content.treatment:
Find Expert and Effective Treatments
Your ProMedica care team will design a prostate cancer treatment plan that meets your unique needs. In some cases, one form of treatment could be effective. But in many cases your doctor might suggest combining multiple treatment methods to help you achieve the best possible outcome.
Your personal treatment plan may include:
Chemotherapy
Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment given intravenously (through a vein) to stop cancer cells from growing. Chemotherapy drugs work by killing the cells or keeping cells from dividing. It may be given before or after surgery.
Radiation Therapy
Radiation therapy uses high-energy X-rays to shrink and kill cancer cells. It’s usually given after surgery or chemotherapy to lower the risk of the cancer returning.
Immunotherapy
Immunotherapy, also called biotherapy, uses substances made from living organisms to help the body fight cancer and other diseases. These substances may be synthetic or they may occur naturally.
Hormone Therapy
Hormone therapy for prostate cancer reduces the levels of male hormones called androgen. Lowering androgen levels can shrink prostate cancers and make them grow more slowly.
Cryotherapy
Cryotherapy uses very cold temperatures to freeze and destroy cancerous cells.
Surgery
The most common prostate cancer surgery is a prostatectomy or removing the prostate. ProMedica offers this procedure using innovative robotic technology. This minimally invasive procedure has several potential benefits, including:
Effective cancer control.
Faster return of urinary continence and sexual function.
Less pain.
Fewer potential side effects.
Quicker recovery.
Learn more about robotic surgery.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Pelvic Congestion Syndrome
Chronic pelvic pain, defined as pain lasting six months or more, affects 15% of women in America. Many issues can cause this pain. But, did you know that a vascular problem could be one of them?
Pelvic congestion syndrome (PCS) is a condition that causes chronic pelvic pain due to problems with your veins in your lower abdomen. Veins carry blood from all areas of your body back to the heart. However, in some women, the veins in the lower abdomen have weakened, making their veins inefficient at moving the blood back up to their heart. This allows blood to build up or pool, causing pressure and bulging veins resulting in varicose veins in the pelvis.
Some sub-types of pelvic congestion syndrome include ovarian vein reflux, nutcracker syndrome, and May-Thurner syndrome.
New Procedure Offers Speedier Recovery for Patients with Nutcracker Syndrome

Who is at risk for pelvic congestion syndrome?
PCS mostly effects women of childbearing age. It is also common in women who have had two or more pregnancies and those who have a family history of venous disease.
What are the symptoms of pelvic congestion syndrome?
The main symptom of pelvic congestion syndrome is pelvic pain that lasts at least six months. Often, the pain starts during or after a pregnancy. Many women describe the pain as a severe, dull ache that worsens around the time of their menstrual period. Others describe the pain as heavy or sharp.
Other symptoms include:
Pain before or during a heavy menstrual flow
Frequent urge to urinate
Varicose veins on the external genitals, thighs and/or hemorrhoids
Activities that can worsen the pain include:
Changing your posture
Having sexual intercourse (pain can occur both during and after)
Standing or sitting for long periods of time
Traveling on long automobile trips or flights
Walking
How is pelvic congestion syndrome diagnosed?
Pelvic pain is not easy to diagnose. Your primary care provider (PCP) or gynecologist will need to consider the many possible causes of pelvic pain, including problems with your reproductive, urinary or gastrointestinal systems. To diagnose, your doctor will typically obtain a complete medical history, perform an abdominal and pelvic exam, Pap smear, and order blood work.
After ruling out other pelvic problems, a vascular expert like the ones at Jobst Vascular Institute may be consulted. This specialist may recommend additional testing such as:
Ultrasound – A Doppler ultrasound to check the blood flow in the pelvic blood vessels.
Computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) – Imaging that provides more detailed pictures of your pelvic veins.
What are the next steps?
Once you have been diagnosed with PCS, know that today more treatments than ever are available. Your gynecologist may prescribe hormone medications to relieve pain. Your gynecologist may also recommend that you talk with a Jobst vascular surgeon for additional treatment options. Most of these treatments are minimally invasive and can be performed in an outpatient setting.
To learn more about treatment options, call Jobst Vascular Institute Vein Care at 877-551-VEIN (419-291-2090).

Get Back to Your Life
Talking with a doctor about your pelvic floor disorder symptoms — such as painful intercourse, leakage or constipation — can feel embarrassing. We understand. But when symptoms are disrupting your life, finding compassionate health care can help ease your pain and get you back to feeling like yourself again.
When you’re ready to talk, we’re here to listen.
Whether you’re having minor incontinence or have more serious concerns, our fellowship-trained doctors, urogynecologists and pelvic floor physical therapists will help you find a solution. Together, we’ll create a treatment plan that makes you feel healthier and more confident in your daily life.
One in every five women will have a pelvic floor disorder in their lifetime.
content.approach:
Our Approach
Personalized, High-Quality Care
At ProMedica, our compassionate team will work closely with you to find the treatment that best fits your unique needs. From your first consultation to your last follow-up appointment, we’ll be at your side during every step of the journey.
Most Experienced Team in the Region
Your care team will include all the experts and specialists you need to get the full range of care for your pelvic disorder. Our fellowship-trained surgeons, urogynecologists and pelvic floor physical therapists are among the most experienced and highly-respected in the region. They’ll make sure you receive the highest level of care in a compassionate and confidential way.
content.disorders:
Understanding Pelvic Floor Disorders
Pelvic floor disorders are conditions that affect your pelvic floor, which includes the muscles, ligaments and nerves at the bottom of your pelvis. In men and women, the pelvic floor supports the bladder, rectum and bowel. It also supports a woman’s reproductive organs.
It’s common for a woman’s pelvic floor to weaken after pregnancy and childbirth. But men can also have pelvic floor weakness. This can be caused by surgery, constipation, heavy lifting or other bladder and bowel problems.
Know Your Risk Factors
When the surrounding muscles are weak, your pelvic organs can’t work correctly. You can protect your pelvic health by understanding the characteristics and activities that put you at risk for a pelvic floor disorder. This will also help you avoid disruptive and painful symptoms.
Your pelvic floor muscles can weaken from:
Aging.
Being overweight.
Birth defects.
Emotional stress.
Enlarged prostate gland or treatment for another prostate problem.
Heavy lifting.
Menopause.
Nerve damage from spinal cord injuries, diabetes, Parkinson’s disease and multiple sclerosis.
Overactive bladder.
Pregnancy and childbirth.
Smoking.
Stool build-up in the bowels.
Urinary tract infections.
Recognize the Symptoms
While most people have the same symptoms, the severity can vary widely. We can help, whether your symptoms are very minor or are so severe they’re affecting your quality of life. Talk with a doctor if you have:
Constipation.
Trouble urinating.
Frequent or urgent urination.
Leaking urine or feces.
Pain in the lower back.
Pain with intercourse.
Pelvic pain or discomfort.
Pressure or fullness in the pelvis.
Types of Pelvic Floor Disorders
Fecal Incontinence
When you have fecal incontinence, it means you can’t hold your stool. Although it’s not a normal part of getting older, you are more likely to have fecal incontinence as you age. It can also be caused by:
Congenital problems.
Diabetes.
Diarrhea or constipation.
Injuries from having a baby or being pregnant.
Injuries or diseases of the spinal cord.
Large hemorrhoids.
Severe dementia.
Severe inflammation.
Surgery involving the anal sphincter.
Tumors.
Pelvic Organ Prolapse
Pelvic organ prolapse happens when your pelvic floor becomes so weak a pelvic organ drops into your pelvis. Sometimes, these organs can even fall into or outside the vagina or anus.
There are different types of prolapse, including:
Cystocele (bladder).
Enterocele (small bowel).
Rectocele (rectum).
Urethrocele (urethra).
Uterine (uterus).
Vaginal vault (vagina).
Many people with pelvic organ prolapse don’t have any symptoms at all. However, if symptoms are present, they may include:
Bulging in the vagina.
Feeling of heaviness, fullness, aching or pressure in the pelvis or lower belly.
Frequent or urgent need to urinate.
Frequent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
Inability to completely empty the bladder.
Inability to pass stool without laxatives.
Lower back pain.
Needing to push organs back up into the vagina to urinate or have a bowel movement.
Pelvic pressure that gets worse when standing, lifting or coughing, or as the day goes on.
Problems putting in tampons or vaginal applicators.
Sexual dysfunction or pain during sex.
Uncontrolled urine leakage.
Urinary Incontinence
Urinary incontinence — the loss of bladder control — is a problem many of us could face as we get older. Cases can range from mild (a bit of leaking when you cough or sneeze) to more severe (a sudden and urgent need to urinate without being able to hold it).
Learn more about urinary incontinence.

Pelvic Organ Prolapse
Hear from ProMedica urogynecologist Dr. Dani Zoorob about the symptoms and treatments for pelvic organ prolapse.
content.treatment:
Diagnosis and Treatment
Getting a Diagnosis
If you believe you may have a pelvic floor disorder, it’s important to see a doctor. Not only is this the first step in getting back to your everyday life, this simple visit can help you prevent more serious problems later on.
During your consultation, the doctor will likely recommend that you have:
A physical exam.
A discussion about your personal and family health history.
A discussion about your symptoms.
Imaging tests to check the muscle and nerves in your pelvis may also be recommended. (These tests will sometimes be scheduled at another time or location.) In some cases, women may be referred to a doctor who specializes in treating pelvic floor disorders in women (urogynecologist).
Regardless of your unique situation, your care team will be with you every step of the way to coordinate your examinations and test results. We’ll be sure you understand your condition, so you’re empowered to make the best possible health decisions.
Talk to an expert: Call 567-585-0240 to make an appointment.
Access a Full Range of Treatment Options
At ProMedica, you’ll have access to a full range of treatment options, from minimally invasive therapies to traditional surgery. Once you have a diagnosis, your care team will help you carefully consider the right treatments for you.
Many pelvic floor disorders can be treated without surgery. In fact, it’s likely your doctor will recommend behavioral therapies, nonsurgical treatments or physical therapy before having you consider surgery. In some cases, you may have a combination of all these treatments first.
Behavioral Therapies
Behavioral therapy for pelvic floor disorders may include:
Bladder training: You’ll be taught ways to help you increase the amount of time between urinating and resisting the urge to urinate.
Lifestyle changes: Many lifestyle changes can help you manage your symptoms. These include things like changing your diet, adjusting how much fluid you drink and limiting your caffeine and alcohol intake.
Scheduled toileting: By scheduling your toilet breaks to prevent leaking, you can train your bladder to empty every two to four hours.
Nonsurgical Treatments
Nonsurgical treatments for pelvic floor disorders can include:
Medicines: Your doctor may prescribe incontinence medicines or estrogen therapy.
Pessaries: Made out of plastic or silicone and inserted into your vagina, these small, removable devices can keep your pelvic organs in place. Your doctor may recommend a pessary to help with stress incontinence or pelvic organ prolapse.
There are different types of pessaries. If you need one, your device will be fitted to your body to make sure it’s comfortable for you.
Physical Therapy
In some cases, physical therapy can help with pelvic floor disorders. This can include pelvic floor exercises such as kegels, and biofeedback.
Our pelvic floor physical therapists specialize in treatments that strengthen your pelvic floor. If you think you may benefit from pelvic floor physical therapy, talk to your doctor. You’ll need a referral to begin pelvic floor physical therapy.
Learn more about pelvic floor physical therapy.
Surgery
In some cases, surgery may be the only way to treat your pelvic floor disorder. If that's the case, our fellowship-trained surgeons will work with you to determine the best surgical option for you. to find the right treatments.
Many disorders can be treated with minimally invasive surgery, including robot-assisted procedures. The benefits of minimally invasive surgery include:
Faster return to normal activities.
Less blood loss.
Less injury to tissue.
Less pain.
Shorter hospital stays.

content.articleContent:
Helping Your Child Get Back to a Healthy and Active Life
When your child has a bone or joint problem, finding a treatment is about more than easing the pain. It’s about finding a way to help them grow properly and thrive.
At ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital, we understand the unique needs of children who have bone and joint conditions. Our pediatric experts are specially trained to diagnose and treat injuries and deformities.
Our goal is to help your child live a normal, active kid life and grow into a healthy young adult.
content.overview:
Understanding Pediatric Orthopaedics
Pediatric orthopaedic specialists (also called orthopaedists) treat bone or joint problems in children. At ProMedica, we see children of all ages — from infants to teens to young adults.
It’s important to see an orthopaedic doctor who specializes in treating kids. This is because children are still growing. Our specialists know how to spot problems that may go away with growth and time. They also know how to find treatments that won’t cause growth problems.
Many active kids break or fracture a bone at some point in their lives. Besides treating these common injuries, our specialists also help kids who are born with bone or joint problems. Our specialists treat a range of injuries and deformities, including:
Broken bones and fractures.
Clubfoot.
Hip dysplasia.
In-toeing (also called “pigeon toed”).
Limb length problems.
Osgood-Schlatter disease.
Scoliosis.
Sports injuries.
Traumatic injuries.
Talk to an expert: Call 419-291-2345 to learn more.

Orthopaedics: Common Pediatric Issues
ProMedica Orthopaedic Surgeon Aaron Buerk, MD, talks about some of the most common bone and joint problems children face.
content.diagnosis:
Pinpoint Problems Fast
Diagnosing an orthopaedic condition starts with a physical exam. A doctor who suspects a bone or joint problem may also ask for an imaging test. These tests can include X-rays, ultrasounds, MRIs or CT scans.
Many children are diagnosed with a bone or joint problem shortly after they’re born. If there’s a problem after your baby is born, your doctor will ask one of our specialists to visit the nursery. After looking at your baby, the specialist may ask for imaging tests to figure out a diagnosis.

content.articleContent:
Treating Chronic Pelvic Pain with Physical Therapy
Pelvic floor physical therapy is an evidence-based, non-surgical approach to treating chronic pelvic pain and pelvic floor disorders. Treatment starts with an assessment by a specially-trained physical therapist (PT), who has received specialized training in evaluating and treating pelvic floor disorders. The initial evaluation typically includes:
Checking the motor control, strength, and endurance of core support muscles
Assessing your pelvic floor muscle coordination for different activities and positions
Other testing, as needed.
Based on the findings of this exam, the physical therapist creates a unique treatment plan to help you improve your pelvic floor function. The treatment plan may include working with you on behavioral approaches such as bladder re-training techniques. Plus, an individualized physical therapy regimen to help rehab your pelvic floor muscles. The physical therapist may use a variety of techniques. Specific treatments help to improve urinary and/or fecal continence.
Pelvic floor physical therapy is NOT…
Just for women. Men, women and children suffer from pelvic floor disorders and could benefit from therapy.
Just massage and kegels. A variety of techniques are used to treat patients.
Evaluation or treatment involving speculums or stirrups—neither is used in pelvic floor physical therapy
A “one size fits all” program. Treatment is uniquely designed to your specific needs.
How can pelvic floor physical therapy help me?
The treatments used by our pelvic floor physical therapists are designed to address issues with the structures of the pelvic floor (i.e. nerves, lymphatics, muscles, connective tissue, skin, and bones). Pelvic floor physical therapy exercises and treatments aim to improve:
The leakage of urine or loss of bladder control
Painful sex and vaginal pain
Sexual dysfunction (male and female)
Pelvic pain and discomfort in the vaginal area with or without sexual interactions
Pelvic organ prolapse (the dropping of the bladder, rectum or uterus)
Constipation or incomplete bowel or bladder emptying
Back, hip or sacroiliac joint (SI) pain that has not improved with time or traditional treatment
Talk to a specialist; call 419-824-1968 to schedule an appointment today.
What should I expect when I visit the pelvic floor physical therapist?
Our certified and well-trained therapists welcome you in a comfortable and friendly environment. We also believe in a team approach to care so that you are in control of your treatment.
At your first visit, we’ll do an initial evaluation that lasts about 60 minutes. This evaluation typically includes:
A detailed discussion including an explanation of your medical history and your condition
Checking the motor control, strength, and endurance of core support muscles
Assessing your pelvic floor muscle coordination for different activities and positions
An external and external and internal assessment of your pelvic floor function including strength, coordination, tone, and sensation
Based on the findings of this exam, we’ll create a unique treatment plan to help you improve your pelvic floor function. The treatment plan may include working with you on behavioral approaches such as bladder re-training techniques. Plus, an individualized physical therapy regimen to help rehab your pelvic floor muscles. The physical therapist may use a variety of techniques specific to your needs.
Kegels and More for Your Pelvic Health
Pelvic floor physical therapist may utilize a number of different therapies to treat chronic pelvic pain and pelvic floor disorders, including:
Stretching exercises, massage and other relaxation techniques
Kegel exercises: Regular, daily exercise of pelvic muscles can make the pelvic floor muscles stronger and improve, and even prevent, urinary incontinence.
Biofeedback: Uses different types of devices to give information on how well pelvic muscles are contracting. The message or “feedback” can help improve awareness and control of pelvic floor muscles. This is often used along with Kegel exercises to help patients gain awareness and control of the pelvic muscles.
Vaginal weight training: Small weights are held within the vagina by tightening the vaginal muscles.
Pelvic floor electrical stimulation: Mild electrical pulses stimulate muscle contractions. This may be done along with Kegel exercises.

content.articleContent:
Help Your Child Build Confidence for Life
When it comes to specialized rehab services, you want to be sure your child is in caring, capable hands. At ProMedica, our pediatric rehabilitation teams include occupational therapists, physical therapists and speech therapists. They work under the direction of a pediatric physiatrist to provide expert care in a setting where children can find support and strength.
Together, our pediatric rehab team helps children from birth to age 21 who are having trouble with:
Cognition and motor planning.
Fine motor activities.
Gross motor activities.
Motor coordination.
Oral motor skills.
Sensory processing.
Speech.
Swallowing and feeding.
content.expect:
Know What to Expect When Starting Pediatric Rehab
Successful rehabilitation starts with families and doctors working closely together. Upon referral to ProMedica for pediatric rehab, you’ll be asked to complete an initial evaluation of your child’s skill set. This will help make sure we know all aspects of your child’s health.
The evaluation will also help guide what we discuss at your child’s first appointment. This way, we can work together to design a custom plan of care and help strengthen your child’s abilities.
content.services:
Our Pediatric Rehab Services
Family-Friendly Inpatient Pediatric Rehab
The goal of the pediatric inpatient rehabilitation team at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital is to help children restore their day-to-day abilities. Our child-friendly setting includes select inpatient rooms and a therapy gym where you and your child can take part in rehabilitation therapy together.
When your child is discharged from the hospital, you’ll receive a supportive home rehabilitation plan. It’s customized to your child’s needs and designed to help improve quality of life.
Child-Focused Outpatient Pediatric Rehab
ProMedica Total Rehab offers pediatric services in the Toledo metropolitan area. They’re all at one convenient location that’s specially designed for children’s needs. The site provides occupational, speech and physical therapy services for infants, children and adolescents.
Our 10,000-plus square feet of space features 20 private therapy rooms, and several have observation windows. There are also four separate gyms, including:
A developmental gym for very young patients who have general developmental delays.
A gross motor gym designed for children who have sensory, physical, cognitive and communicative disabilities. It features an adaptive climbing wall.
A sensory gym designed for children who have sensory processing difficulties.
Learn More
Specialty Services
We believe that personalized care is key to successful rehabilitation. That’s why we offer custom rehab plans that support children and are made possible through specialty services that meet children’s unique needs. These plans include ongoing home therapy programs to supplement services received during outpatient rehabilitation or at school or daycare.
At ProMedica, your child will have access to services and treatments such as:
Adaptive equipment modifications.
Aquatics.
Augmentative communication.
Central auditory processing therapy.
Cognitive therapy.
Computer and environmental accessibility.
Feeding and swallowing therapy.
Fine and gross motor training.
Infant massage.
Mobility training.
Neurodevelopmental therapy.
Sensory integration.
Speech and language therapy.
Splinting and casting.
content.ourTeam:
Count on a Multidisciplinary Team That Delivers Complete Care
Our goal is to help your child regain previous levels of independence. We’ll also partner with your family for your child’s transition to home, outpatient services and school re-entry.
Your child’s rehab team includes:
A pediatric physiatrist, board-certified in both pediatrics and physical medicine and rehabilitation.
Child life and education specialists.
Nurses.
Physical, occupational and speech therapists.
Social services.
To learn more about pediatric rehabilitation at ProMedica, call 567-585-0180.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Your Pelvic Health
The pelvic region is home to quite a few muscles and organs, including your bladder, rectum and reproductive organs. When these important parts aren’t working properly, it can cause problems, including pain and incontinence.
You're not alone in this either. One in three women of child-bearing age experiences chronic pelvic pain and one in five women experiences pelvic floor disorder.
Pelvic health issues are common, but not normal. They aren’t just part of aging or having children. Unfortunately, many people put up with it or suffer in silence because they aren’t comfortable talking about it, even with their doctor. If you think you may have a pelvic health issue, we’re here to help.
One in five women experiences a pelvic floor disorder.
Is it a pelvic health issue?
Pelvic health issues can cause a variety of symptoms in women and men. Here are some of the symptoms associated with pelvic conditions:
Severe steady or intermittent pain in the pelvic area
Pain during or after intercourse
Pain while having a bowel movement or urinating
Frequent or urgent urination
Leakage or passage of urine or feces
Constipation
Learn more about the symptoms of chronic pelvic pain and pelvic floor disorders or call 567-585-0240 to schedule an appointment
How can we help?
Our professionally trained and experienced specialists provide quality care in the diagnosis, treatment and rehabilitation of chronic pelvic pain and pelvic floor disorders. We offer a wide range of surgical and nonsurgical treatment options, including pelvic floor physical therapy. We believe in an individualized and team approach to best fit your needs and lifestyle.
If you’re experiencing pelvic health symptoms, even if they are mild or bearable, we encourage you to learn more and start a conversation with your healthcare provider. Your primary care physician, OB/GYN or certified nurse midwife can refer you to one of our knowledgeable pelvic health experts.

Understanding Peripheral Artery Disease
Peripheral artery disease (PAD), also known as peripheral arterial disease, occurs when narrowed arteries reduce the amount of blood flow to your legs, most commonly, but sometimes to your arms. This narrowing is caused by fatty build up, called plaque, that clings to your artery walls. This lack of blood flow causes symptoms, though you may not notice symptoms in the early stages.
 
 
Learn more about PAD with our infographic.
PAD Signs and Symptoms
 
What are the symptoms of PAD?
Painful cramping or aching calf, hip, or thigh muscles when walking. The cramping goes away when you rest.
Your leg or foot may feel better when it’s dangling off the edge of or elevated in your bed, sofa, or chair.
Sores on your toes, ankles, or feet that don’t heal.
Color changes of the skin on your legs or feet.
Cold leg or foot, especially when compared to your other side.
Shiny skin or loss of hair / slow hair growth on your leg.
Erectile dysfunction in men.
Weak or no pulse in your legs or feet.
Diagnosing PAD
 
How is PAD diagnosed?
Along with a complete medical history and physician exam, other tests include:
Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a comparison of the blood pressure in the ankle with the blood pressure in the arm.
Angiogram is an X-ray of the arteries and veins to detect blockage or narrowing. Your doctor will use a thin tube and insert it into an artery in the leg and inject a contrast dye. This makes your arteries and veins visible on the X-ray.
Doppler ultrasound is used to create images of blood vessels. Your doctor will use the ultrasound to measure and assess the flow of blood.
Risk Factors
More common in men than women
Diabetes
Smoking
High blood pressure
High cholesterol
Family history
Heart disease
If you think you’re at risk for PAD,
make these healthy lifestyle changes.
Eat a healthier diet.
Increase your physical activity.
Maintain a healthy blood pressure by reducing stress and taking medications as prescribed.
Limit your alcohol.
Avoid tobacco smoke.
Maintain a healthy weight.
Discuss further diagnosis and treatment options, like surgery and medication, and healthy lifestyle changes with your doctor.
Call us today at 1-800-39-JOBST (56278) to schedule an appointment.

content.articleContent:
About Pediatric Pulmonology
When your child has breathing problems, our team of pediatric pulmonologists, pediatric sleep specialists, registered nurses and respiratory therapists are here to provide an accurate diagnosis and treatment for your child.
The certified pediatric pulmonary specialists at ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital are specialized in treating disorders of the respiratory system, such as:
Pediatric asthma.
Chronic cough.
Pneumonia and recurrent pneumonia.
Chronic lung disease of prematurity.
Apnea of infancy.
Childhood sleep apnea and sleep disturbances.
Cystic fibrosis.
Stridor.
Restrictive lung disease.
Services and Procedures
Our experts provide additional support for children with pulmonary conditions through inpatient and outpatient services and procedures, including:
Tracheostomy and ventilator care.
Bronchoscopies.
Newborn screenings for cystic fibrosis.
Pulmonary function testing.
Infant monitoring.
Experts in Pediatric Pulmonary Conditions
The board-certified pediatric pulmonary specialists in our practice are committed to excellent care for your child. We follow nationally recognized guidelines and advise on the most up-to-date medicines.
Most importantly, we make sure families understand how to help their children with the right treatments and symptom management for their pulmonology conditions.

content.articleContent:
Help Your Child Get a Restful Night’s Sleep
If your child doesn’t sleep well at night, it can be hard on the entire family. At ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital, our pediatric sleep medicine specialists work with you and your child to identify and treat sleep conditions so that everyone can have a restful night’s sleep.
content.overview:
About Pediatric Sleep
Pediatric sleep disorders are very common and can often have a negative impact on a child’s health. The American Academy of Pediatrics estimates that sleep problems affect 25 to 50% of children and 40% of adolescents.
Our board-certified specialists at our pediatric sleep medicine clinic understand that when a child does not get enough quality sleep through the night, it can lead to daytime consequences.
content.ourExpertise:
Experts in Pediatric Pulmonary Conditions
The board-certified specialists in our pediatric pulmonary clinic are committed to excellent care for your child. We follow nationally recognized guidelines and advise on the most up-to-date medicines.
Most importantly, we make sure families understand how to help their children with the right treatments and symptom management for sleep disorders and other respiratory disorders, including asthma, chronic cough, apnea of infancy, cystic fibrosis, and more.
content.conditions:
Experts in Pediatric Sleep Conditions
It’s crucial for children who experience sleep issues to receive a thorough investigation to achieve an accurate diagnosis. Our specialists identify and treat a range of sleep problems, including:
Sleep Apnea
Sleep apnea is when a child has snoring and nighttime awakenings as their breathing briefly stops while they sleep. This is a common condition in children and frequently requires treatment that is dependent on the severity and the child’s age.
Nightmares and Night Terrors
These are both very common in children and usually do not require significant treatment. However, it is important to differentiate these from disorders that require treatment.
Insomnia (difficulty sleeping)
When a child has trouble falling asleep, staying asleep or both. There are many possible causes for insomnia, such as behavior, delayed sleep phase, medications or an underlying medical diagnosis.
Hypersomnia (sleepiness)
Hypersomnia is when a child is sleepy during the day, even after a full night of sleep. A sleep study may be necessary to help determine the quality of your child’s sleep.
Restless Leg Syndrome (RLS)
When a child experiences uncomfortable feelings in their legs while they are laying down at night. They may have the irresistible urge to move their legs, preventing them from falling asleep.
Sleep walking, sleep talking, confusional arousal and teeth grinding
Sleep walking, sleep talking, confusional arousal and teeth grinding are undesirable events that can occur during a child’s sleep that may be associated with poor quality sleep.
content.treatment:
Evaluation and Treatment
During a visit to our clinic, patients can expect to undergo a comprehensive evaluation by our care team. Patients will be screened for sleep and behavioral problems and given a medical and airway evaluation. A sleep study may be ordered for a more thorough investigation of the patient’s sleep pattern.
During the sleep study, you will spend the night with your child in a private room while they are monitored while they sleep. You and your child will go home in the morning and the results of the study will be evaluated by a sleep specialist. Results of the study are usually available within two weeks of completion. Based on results of the sleep study, a treatment plan or referral will be done.

content.articleContent:
Using Radiation Therapy to Treat Cancer
Radiation therapy is the use of high-energy X-rays to treat cancer. These are therapeutic X-rays, which are different from diagnostic X-rays. Radiation can be an effective cancer treatment and is designed to prevent cancer cells from growing and multiplying. The goal is to slow or stop tumor growth and, in many cases, completely destroy the tumor.
Your radiation therapy treatment is administered in stages. You’re supported by experienced professionals and caregivers along the way.
What are the steps to radiation therapy treatment?
Your first visit. This is a consultation to discuss your cancer and treatment options with your radiation oncologist. This is a time to ask questions. If possible, bring a family member.
Simulation. Your radiation oncologist uses X-ray equipment called a “simulator” to aid in your treatment plan. Sometimes, a non-toxic dye is injected in order to outline certain organs. Prior to the simulation, your radiation therapist places you into a special positioning device that will hold your body still during treatment.
Planning marks. During your simulation, you’re given either small black permanent marks, about the size of a freckle, or similarly sized semi-permanent marks. These marks create a focal point for the radiation treatment machine so treatment can be given to precisely the same spot each time.
Receiving treatments. A machine called a “linear accelerator” provides your therapeutic radiation dosages. You’ll lie on a table, sometimes shielded by protective blocks, and will be raised under the linear accelerator. The treatment machine will move to a predetermined position and apply the radiation treatment. You won’t feel or see the radiation. Expect weekly assessments while you’re given treatment to see how your body responds.
Follow-up care. It’s extremely important to schedule regular exams after you’ve finished your radiation treatment. This may include blood work and X-rays. Continue to maintain a healthy lifestyle after your treatment is complete.
What are the side effects of radiation therapy? Side effects differ, depending on the treatment area. The most common are fatigue and skin irritation. Your doctor or nurse will discuss ways to prevent or minimize these effects with you, including nutrition for managing fatigue.
