content.articleContent:
About Radiology
Radiology is the medical imaging practice of taking pictures of your internal organs in order to diagnose disease or better understand a medical condition. Your doctor may order a radiology scan in order to get a better idea of what is going on inside your body.
Our Radiology Experts
Expert diagnostic imaging is performed by fellowship-trained radiologists, who coordinate with specialized technologists and nurses. Need imaging results STAT? No problem. Wherever you are, whenever you need us, your reports are available 24/7.
You know the right test might make all the difference. When you need diagnostic imaging, what means the most to you? Board-certified radiologists. State-of-the-art technology. Thirty convenient, full-service locations. (Yes, there’s one near you.)

Imagine a Life Without Pain – Without Surgery
Nonsurgical pain relief is within your reach. ProMedica offers a range of the most innovative regenerative medicine treatments available. Our board-certified experts bring state-of-the-art care to those in and around northwest Ohio.
content.faq:
Frequently Asked Questions
At ProMedica, we want you to feel confident in your treatment decisions. Our specialists will take the time to discuss your options for regenerative medicine and answer any questions you may have.
What is regenerative medicine?
Regenerative medicine is a same-day, nonsurgical adult regenerative procedure that treats common injuries and degenerative joint conditions. Regenerative cells are growth cells found naturally in the body. They adapt to become almost any type of cell and rejuvenate hard-to-repair tissues like cartilage.
Am I a candidate for regenerative medicine?
When you meet with one of our regenerative medicine specialists, we’ll review your test results and medical history to determine your eligibility. We’ll consider a number of factors, including your:
Activity level.
Age.
Body mass index.
Condition of the joint.
Medicines.
Overall health.
Past medical and surgical history.
What can I expect during the procedure?
During the procedure, we withdraw a small amount of whole marrow from the back of your hip bones. Cells are processed from the bone marrow and injected into the injured part of the body. A procedure typically takes one to three injections.
You will go home the same day and be able to resume light activity within a week. You may start to see positive results between 6-8 weeks post procedure, and may continue to see results thoughout the year.
Can you have more than one treatment at a time?
It’s possible to treat multiple areas at once, but your doctor will help you decide if this is a good choice for you.
How much does it cost?
Blood-derived injections start at $1,200. A bone marrow procedure, which consists of three injections done within a seven to ten day time frame, costs anywhere from $6,000 to $11,000. This is based on which part of the body is being treated, the number of injection sites and any protocol recommended by the doctor. We are not able to offer payment plans for our services.
Is regenerative medicine covered by insurance?
Regenexx® procedures aren’t covered by most insurance providers. The procedures are still too new and are considered experimental. But we’re happy to give you a copy of your statement and medical records if you decide to submit on your own behalf after the procedure is completed.
content.conditions:
Benefits of Regenerative Medicine
Regenerative medicine doesn’t just treat symptoms. It heals your body at the source of the injury by using your own body’s healing growth factors. This may help heal damaged tissues, tendons, ligaments, cartilage, spinal discs and bones.
We offer the Regenexx® family of regenerative medicine procedures. Now you can get same-day treatment for many joint conditions to ease your pain, and help you move and heal faster.
Conditions We Treat
We treat a variety of orthopaedic conditions with regenerative medicine. This includes sports injuries and degenerative conditions, such as arthritis. Our doctors will assess your condition and decide on the best course of treatment for your unique needs. Our goal is to reduce your pain and increase your mobility so you can get back to doing the things you love.

Elbow
If you have elbow pain, regenerative medicine could be an excellent treatment option. Our outpatient procedures may help restore elbow function and decrease pain without the need for surgery. With image guidance, we inject the right amount of your body's natural healing mechanism into the exact areas of damage. This may tighten and stabilize your elbow joint for better function and mobility.
Some elbow conditions we treat include:
Tennis and Golf Elbow: People with tennis or golfer’s elbow often struggle to open a door or shake someone's hand. Regenerative medicine may improve function and mobility.
Ulnar collateral ligament UCL) injuries: This ligament holds the elbow together. Injuries are especially common among baseball pitchers due to the physical strain to the arm.
Foot and Ankle
Common foot and ankle conditions may improve with regenerative medicine. This includes degenerative conditions such as osteoarthritis, as well as tendon and ligament tears.
Ankle ligament tears: Ankle sprains often cause stretched or torn ligaments. This can change how you walk and put painful stress on foot joints, increasing your risk for another ankle sprain. This incomplete healing leads to a cycle of chronic pain and instability. Regenerative medicine may promote healing in damaged ligaments and improve function and mobility.
Ankle osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis of the ankle leads to tenderness, pain, swelling, stiffness and even an inability to bear weight. This can change how you walk, increase stress on the foot and may lead to injury. Regenerative medicine may tighten and stabilize your ankle for better function and mobility.
Ankle tendon tears: Damage to the Achilles tendon is the most common form of tendon damage. It often results from acute injury or overuse often as a result of athletics. Regenerative medicine may promote repair of strains and tears to the Achilles tendon.
Toe osteoarthritis: This condition can cause toes to bend sideways and create painful bone spurs. If left untreated, the big toe in particular can become rigid, putting more stress on the rest of the foot and ankle. Regenerative medicine may promote repair, leading to better function and mobility.
Hand and Wrist
Wear and tear on the wrists and hands is common in a world filled with hand-held devices and keyboards. As we place more and more strain on our hands and wrists, they can wear down over time. Regenexx may treat injuries and degenerative problems related to the hand or wrist.
TFCC tear: The triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) contributes to use of our opposable thumbs. Wear or injury can lead to wrist pain and swelling. Regenerative medicine may reduce pain and discomfort and help restore function.
Carpal tunnel syndrome: Roughly 5% of people in the workplace have carpal tunnel syndrome. This condition causes pain, numbness, or tingling in the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and inside of the ring finger. Regenerative medicine may loosen the pinching and restore function.
Thumb Osteoarthritis: Hand and thumb osteoarthritis is the second most common type of arthritis. Movements from writing, using a phone, and other daily activities cause the cartilage to wear down. Regenerative medicine may help stabilize the thumb joint for better function and mobility. Patients in the Regennexx registry reported almost 50% improvement in function and reduction in pain on average.
Hip
Hips have many tendons, ligaments and muscles around the joint that can sustain injury. Conditions such as hip labrum tears, hip tendon tears and hip osteoarthritis and degeneration may improve with regenerative medicine.
We use image guidance technology to inject your own bone marrow concentrate — which contains stems cells — directly where it’s needed to repair damaged tissue in the hip joint structure. The cells in your bone marrow concentrate work at the site of your injury to promote the growth of new, healthy tissue. This aids in the stabilization of your hip joint for better function and mobility. It may also help reduce pain.
Knee
The knee has many parts that keep it protected, stable and mobile. To relieve knee pain, you must first figure out what’s causing the pain. Knee pain can be caused by an acute injury or by chronic wear and tear of the knee, such as osteoarthritis or degenerative joint disease. Common knee conditions include:
Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears: There are numerous types of ACL tears. Some may require surgical repair, but many may be treated with regenerative medicine.
Knee osteoarthritis: Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is one of the most common orthopaedic conditions. If can negatively impact your quality of life and enjoyment of daily activities. Your doctor can help determine if you are a candidate for regenerative medicine.
Meniscus tears: The meniscus is a cushion of cartilage between the bony ends of your thigh bone and shin bone. This cartilage acts as a shock absorber during movement. Tears of the meniscus can be the result of wear and tear on the joint or can occur when there’s an injury.
Some knee conditions need rest and/or special exercises prescribed by a physical therapist. If pain or function does not improve, it may require advanced medical attention. Our experts are highly trained in diagnosing and treating knee issues. Regenexx procedures may help improve knee function, but in some cases, surgery may be the best solution.
Shoulder
The shoulder joint is the most mobile joint in your body. When there's an injury or degenerative disease, your body struggles to keep the joint stable. Tendons and ligaments may stretch or tear due to trauma, or simply wear out due to age. This allows too much motion in the joint. The added motion may lead to bone spurs or arthritis.
Common conditions affecting the shoulder include:
Rotator cuff tears: The rotator cuff is a series of muscles and their tendons that surround the shoulder. It helps move the shoulder while supporting this ball in the socket joint. The tendons can become torn with trauma or wear and tear. This can cause pain and weakness in the shoulder. An MRI or ultrasound image is used to make the diagnosis.
Labrum tears / SLAP tears: The labrum is a cup-shape rim of cartilage that lines and reinforces the ball-and-socket joint of the shoulder. A direct injury to the shoulder or prolonged wear and tear may lead to a shoulder labrum tear. Regenerative medicine procedures may help treat these tears.
Shoulder osteoarthritis and degeneration: The cartilage in your shoulder cushions the bone and reduces friction. Arthritis occurs when this cartilage starts to wear down or is injured. This leads to chronic shoulder pain, stiffness, limited shoulder function, and decreased mobility. Shoulder arthritis impacts nearly 25% of adults. Regenerative medicine procedures may be an alternative for people looking to avoid surgery.
Spine
If you’re living with back pain, regenerative medicine may help restore spinal function and decrease pain without surgery. During this outpatient procedure, our expert physicians use image guidance to inject custom concentrations of your body’s natural healing tools into and around the areas of damage. This may help stabilize your spine and improve overall function and mobility.
Regenerative medicine may be an effective treatment for the following spine conditions:
Bulging disc.
Continued pain after lower back surgery.
Herniated discs.
Torn disc.
Neck pain.
Sacroiliac joint pain.
Spondylolysis.
Spinal stenosis.
Request a consultation with one of our regenerative medicine specialists
content.procedures:
Procedures We Offer
Our advanced regenerative medicine procedures offer nonsurgical treatments for people who are living with joint or bone pain, torn or strained tendons and ligaments, degenerative conditions or other common injuries. Regenexx® procedures offer viable options for people with chronic pain who may be thinking of having surgery.
Regenexx SD™ (Same Day)
Regenexx SD™ (Same Day) is a Regenerative Medicine procedure that uses bone marrow from your hip. The regenerative cells are concentrated in a bedside machine, then enriched and injected into the damaged joint.
Regenexx PL-Disc™
Regenexx PL-Disc™ helps you avoid back surgery for herniated discs and the side effects of steroid treatments commonly used for spinal issues. The goal of the procedure is to use your own healing growth factors to reduce inflammation and heal or manage disc-related injuries. The outpatient procedure allows you to return to normal activity (as tolerated) right away, does not damage vital back muscles, and has few complications.
Regenexx AD™ (Adipose Derived)
Regenexx AD™ (Adipose Derived) treatment combines our traditional Regenexx SD™ procedure with regenerative cells taken from fatty tissue (adipose). This can be used to solve structural problems within the joint.
Regenexx SCP™ (Super Concentrated Plasma)
Regenexx SCP™ (Super Concentrated Plasma) treatment gathers cells from your blood and uses them to repair damaged tissues
Regenexx PL (Platelet Lysate)
Regenexx PL (Platelet Lysate) treatment allows your doctor to concentrate all of the growth benefits to one area of your body. Our doctors create Regenexx PL by cracking open the platelets to allow all of the growth factors to be available in a specific area of your body right away. This is especially useful for areas of the body where using Platelet Rich Plasma (PRP) may cause too much inflammation.
Platelet Rich Plasma (PRP) Therapy
Platelet rich plasma (PRP) therapy combines platelets that are separated from your blood. These materials are then injected into the injury site to stimulate repair without causing blood clots.
Call 419-578-7515 to schedule a consultation.
Are Regenerative Medicine Treatments Right for You?

Roger Kruse, MD, ProMedica Regenerative Medicine, talks to Chrys Peterson, ProMedica Health Correspondent, about what Regenerative Medicine treatments do, and who's a good candidate.

content.articleContent:
Getting You Back to the Life You Love
Surround yourself with the very best when you need to get back to the activities you love. ProMedica offers state-of-the-art rehabilitation services throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
Whether you’re recovering from an injury, illness or surgery, you want expert care that’s tailored to your unique needs. Our facilities are staffed by certified occupational, speech and physical therapists who offer treatment plans for your situation. The best outcomes happen when everyone — patient, physician and therapist — work together to achieve exceptional results.
content.overview:
Conditions We Treat
When you’re recovering from a health problem, you want to get moving and regain your independence as soon as you can. The rehabilitation and therapy professionals at ProMedica Total Rehab understand. That’s why we provide complete physical, occupational, speech and aquatic therapy services for a wide range of health conditions.
Balance Disorders
A balance disorder is a condition that makes you feel unsteady or dizzy. If you’re lying down, sitting or being still, it may feel as though you or the area around you is moving. If you’re walking, you may feel as though you’ll tip over.
A licensed physical therapist at ProMedica can perform a thorough evaluation of your balance disorder by observing your posture and how you move. Your therapist will then determine the strengths and weaknesses of your balance system and work with you to form a treatment plan and exercises for you to do at home.
In some cases, a balance disorder is because of an underlying condition such as a brain injury or infection. Your therapist will always work closely with your doctor to make sure you’re getting complete care.
Cancer
After going through cancer treatment, you want to feel like yourself again. Our cancer rehab program helps survivors minimize treatment-related side effects and work toward the best possible quality of life. Some of the issues we help treat include fatigue, weakness, insomnia and memory loss.
Learn more about services for cancer survivors.
Orthopaedic Conditions
Whether you’re dealing with a degenerative (weakened) condition like osteoarthritis, you’re recovering from surgery, or you have a sports injury, we can create a custom treatment plan to help make the most of your mobility.
Orthopaedic conditions we treat include:
Ankle sprains.
Back or neck pain.
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.
Fractures.
Knee injuries.
Osteoarthritis.
Rotator cuff tears.
Sprains and strains.
Tendonitis.
Pediatric Conditions
Your child has unique needs and, no matter what, comfort and gentle care are key to healing. That’s why we offer therapy services in a comforting, family-centered environment. Our pediatric therapy team consists of occupational, physical and speech therapists who work under the medical direction of a pediatric physiatrist. This team specializes in treating children with congenital or acquired neurological, developmental or orthopaedic conditions.
Pediatric conditions we treat include:
Cognitive disorders.
Developmental disorders.
Movement disorders.
Speech disorders.
Swallowing and feeding disorders.
Learn more about pediatric rehabilitation.
Stroke and Neurological Conditions
Most people who are recovering from a stroke will need physical, occupational or speech therapy services to help retrain their bodies to take on day-to-day activities.
During your first therapy appointment, a complete evaluation will be performed by the therapist to learn about your individual therapy needs. A plan of care will be designed to help you or a loved one achieve the best possible outcome in recovery.
For patients with a stroke and spinal cord injury, our wearable robotic exoskeleton, called EksoNR™, allows them to begin to take steps sooner and initiate gait faster. ProMedica is the first in northern Ohio to add this advanced technology to its comprehensive rehabilitation program.
Learn more about the robotic exoskeleton.
Women’s Health and Incontinence
Have you had minor or occasional leaks of urine? Urinary incontinence affects about 25 million Americans. Our experts at ProMedica Total Rehab will work with you to help you regain control of your bladder.
A physical therapist who specializes in women’s health will use some of the following methods to help with incontinence:
Biofeedback.
Bladder and muscle re-education.
Electrical stimulation.
Relaxation techniques.
Strengthening the pelvic floor and core muscles.
Learn more about pelvic floor physical therapy.
content.services:
Services
Cardiac Rehabilitation
ProMedica offers in-person cardiac rehabilitation at all of our hospitals as well as virtual at-home sessions through our partner, Recora. All sessions, both in-person and virtual, are overseen by nurses and cardiac therapists who work as a team to provide you with a personal care plan customized to your needs. Visit our page to see if our virtual program is right for you.
Physical Therapy
Our licensed physical therapists evaluate and treat a range of disorders with a focus on making the most of your skills and abilities. The therapists identify and treat problems that keep you from moving naturally and performing daily activities.
Once your doctor refers you to physical therapy, our therapists will work closely with you and your doctor to design a plan of care that will achieve your best possible outcome in recovery. Our goal is to help you move, reduce pain, restore function and prevent disability.
Occupational Therapy
Occupational therapists use everyday activities as therapy for people who are ill, injured or disabled. They help their patients develop, recover and improve the skills needed for daily living and working.
You may see an occupational therapist if you’ve had a joint replacement, have a neurological disease or have had a stroke. This type of therapy is based on your health and your goals, but it can include everything from learning how to use utensils again to going back to the workforce.
Speech Therapy
Our licensed speech-language pathologists assess and treat problems with speech, language, communication and swallowing. Speech and language disorders may be something a person is born with or they may be caused by a stroke or neurological condition. Children with speech disorders often have impaired hearing or developmental delays. At ProMedica, we treat children and adults with expert, compassionate care.
Aquatic Therapy
If you’re recovering from an injury, surgery or illness and dealing with pain or weakness that makes it hard to exercise, aquatic therapy may be right for you. Aquatic therapy is especially helpful for people with arthritis, joint swelling or other conditions that keep them from doing high-impact, weight-bearing activities.
Lymphedema Therapy
Certain illnesses or therapies, such as cancer treatment, can lead to excessive swelling in the extremities. This condition, caused by a damaged lymphatic system, is called lymphedema. Lymphedema therapy can help reduce swelling, pain and the risk of infection. It can also help you keep up with your normal activities. Lymphedema therapy can take many forms, including massage, specialized skin care and compression wrapping.
The experienced therapists at ProMedica can:
Educate you about self-care.
Provide techniques to reduce swelling.
Help improve daily functions.
Sports Medicine
ProMedica sports medicine therapists will design a personal treatment plan to fit your fitness, mobility and strength goals. Our multidisciplinary team of rehabilitation experts knows how to restore your function as quickly as possible.
Pediatric Rehabilitation
Our pediatric therapy team is made up of occupational, physical and speech therapists who specialize in pediatric care. We help children with congenital or acquired neurological, developmental or orthopedic problems. Therapists go alongside your child to help improve motor, sensory and communication skills. They also assist with adaptive equipment needs.
We believe rehabilitation can be a family-centered journey. A personal care plan is designed by the therapist along with the child’s doctor and family. Because family participation is critical, Total Rehab also provides ongoing home therapy programs. Based on your child’s needs, these programs are added to the rehab services your child already receives at one of our outpatient rehab centers or at school or daycare.
Learn more about pediatric rehabilitation.
content.faq:
Frequently Asked Questions
You should always feel confident about your healthcare decisions. That’s why we’re here to answer all your questions about rehabilitation and therapy. For more information, please call 1-877-425-5734.
Do I need a doctor’s prescription for therapy?
Yes. You should always discuss the option of rehabilitation with your doctor. They can decide if it’s safe for you to have therapy for your health condition
Do I need a referral for therapy?
Some insurance providers require a referral form (this is separate from a physician prescription). Please contact your insurance company for more details.
Will my insurance pay for therapy?
The best way to understand your insurance coverage is to contact your insurance company. There are many different health plans that provide various kinds of coverage.
What do I need to bring with me?
Please bring your insurance card and photo ID, along with paperwork from your doctor or forms that you may have filled out ahead of time. Be sure to wear or bring clothes that are comfortable enough for exercise and allow for access to the area of your body that’s being treated.
What can I expect from my therapy session?
You can expect:
A treatment plan that you and your therapist discuss during the first evaluation.
Follow-up sessions if needed, that are scheduled to meet your financial and lifestyle requirements.
A written plan of care and progress reports that are shared with the referring provider.
A home program designed to meet your specific needs.
How long will my appointment take?
Your first appointment will take about an hour. But you’ll need to give yourself extra time to arrive early and complete paperwork before the therapist will see you. Follow-up appointments will take from 30 to 60 minutes.
How many visits will I need?
The number of visits each patient needs varies and is based on many different reasons. Your therapist will be able to give you an estimate after reviewing your physician’s orders, completing your initial assessment and talking with you about your treatment plan.
Will therapy hurt?
You may have discomfort because you’ll be exercising areas that are recovering from an injury or procedure. But your therapist will work closely with you to check on your discomfort and adapt your program to make sure you have the most improvement with the least discomfort. Therapies such as manual therapy, massage, ice and heat are often used for pain control.
Will I receive exercises to do at home?
Yes. One of the most important aspects of your recovery will be doing the at-home exercises your therapist recommends. Your therapist will write down instructions, tell you what to do, give you pictures or provide all three.
Will the therapist talk to my doctor?
Your therapist will send your plan of care and progress notes to your referring physician to explain your therapy treatments. Your therapist and doctor may also speak directly with each other during your care if there are any questions or concerns.
Are ProMedica therapists licensed?
All of our physical, occupational and speech therapists are licensed. Physical and occupational therapist assistants are also licensed and may take part in your treatments to help you reach your treatment plan goals.

content.articleContent:
Breathe Easier with these Respiratory and Pulmonary Services
Do you tire easily? Have a hard time catching your breath? Sometimes find it hard to sleep? Breathe easier knowing expert clinicians are here to help you with any breathing or respiratory difficulties.
What is respiratory/pulmonary care?
Respiratory/pulmonary care applies the newest technology and strategies to help you breathe easier. Whether you need help for a chronic condition such as asthma, or you need emergency services to help your lungs function, you’ll receive expert care from our respiratory care practitioners.
What conditions does respiratory/pulmonary care treat?
Our doctors, nurses, and registered respiratory therapists specialize in treating a range of chronic and acute conditions, including:
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Asthma
Pneumonia
Cystic fibrosis
Sleep disorders
Emphysema
Tobacco cessation
What types of testing help with diagnosis and treatment?
Pulmonary function test measures how well your lungs take in and release air, as well as how they’re able to transport gases such as oxygen from the atmosphere into your circulation.
Electrocardiographic test checks for problems with your heart’s electrical activity. It finds the source symptoms of heart disease like chest pain and shortness of breath.
Arterial blood gas test measures your acidity (pH) as well as the oxygen and carbon dioxide levels in your blood. It checks how well your lung can transport oxygen into your blood and remove carbon dioxide from your blood.

Rehab for Stroke and Spinal Cord Injury
The EksoNR™ is available for inpatient care at ProMedica Flower Hospital and outpatient care at ProMedica Neurosciences Center.
About Robotic Exoskeleton Therapy and Rehab
For a majority of stroke and spinal cord injury patients, regaining the ability to stand and walk is a physical and emotional challenge. A new, advanced robotic technology is now available to help get patients up and walking again.
The EksoNR™ is the first ever FDA approved, wearable robotic exoskeleton for stroke and spinal cord rehabilitation. With early and repetitive use, patients are getting up sooner after their injury, beginning to take steps sooner, and initiating gate faster.
ProMedica is the first in Northern Ohio to add this advanced technology to its comprehensive rehabilitation program. It adds another tool to what therapists can use to get their patient mobilized early.
How It Works
The EksoNR™ is designed with custom software that allows clinicians to amplify a patients’ natural ability to activate muscles and produce movement. Real-time software adjustments can be made for customized patient rehabilitation sessions. Torso support with the EksoNR™ helps to correct posture and hip width can be adjusted during sessions. Ankles are supported and kept stable. Patients report feeling secure as they re-learn correct step patterns, weight shifting and work on their posture.
Learn more through our outpatient services at 877-425-5734.
What It Means to Patients
With use of the EksoNR™, patients gain not only mobility quicker, but confidence and independence as well. The device improves:  
Functional Balance
Walking Distance
Gait Speed
How a Patient Gets Referred
Patients referred to therapy receive a comprehensive assessment during their evaluation. The therapist will select the exoskeleton device as a treatment intervention for pre-gait and gain activities when indicated. This intervention becomes part of the patient’s treatment plan.
Call ProMedica Total Rehab at 877-425-5734 to schedule a consultation.

Care That Gives You Peace of Mind
Along your journey to better health, surgery may become your best option for healing. But even when it’s necessary, we know the decision to have surgery can still be stressful for many reasons. That’s why our surgical team will be with you every step of the way, from ensuring that a surgical procedure is the right decision for you to supporting your recovery until you feel like yourself again.
content.approach:
Our Approach
Experienced and Compassionate Surgical Team
You can count on the ProMedica surgical team for the highest level of care. Our surgeons are highly trained in their fields and use the most advanced technologies and methods available to shorten your recovery time and make your experience as comfortable as possible. From initial consultation through your surgery and recovery, you’ll have all the support and understanding you need to feel whole again.
Fast and Convenient Access to Care
At ProMedica, we’re dedicated to offering innovative and advanced surgical care, close to home. That’s why we offer surgical services at locations across ProMedica’s 27-county service area in northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
And because we know you may be in pain or just anxious to move forward right away, we make same-day consultations available whenever possible. When same-day appointments are not available, we can typically arrange your visit with your surgeon within five days.
Leading-Edge Surgical Techniques and Technologies
When you partner with us for your surgical care, you’ll have access to today’s most advanced surgical technologies and methods, such as state-of-the-art robotic tools like da Vinci® Surgical System.
Trusted and Nationally Recognized Care
Before deciding to have surgery, you need to feel confident you’re getting the best surgical care for you or your loved one. Though our highest honor is serving your needs, we’re proud to share our general surgery awards and accreditations.

content.roboticSurgery:
Robotic Surgery
Robot-assisted surgery can create a safer, more accurate surgical experience with a faster recovery and less scarring. The surgeons at ProMedica use the da Vinci® Surgical System, a revolutionary tool that helps our surgeons perform several common surgeries through an incision that’s less than an inch long.
Benefits of Robotic Surgery
Because of the small incision and greater accuracy, the benefits of robotic surgery include:
Faster recovery.
Fewer complications after your surgery.
Less blood loss.
Less pain.
Minimal scarring.
Quick and safe return to your daily activities.
Robotically Assisted Procedures
Our surgeons use the da Vinci® Surgical System for a wide range of surgeries, including:
General robotic surgery.
Gynecologic robotic surgery.
Thoracic (lung) robotic surgery.
Urologic robotic surgery.
How It Works
Even though it’s called a robot, the da Vinci® Surgical System can’t perform surgery or make decisions. Your surgeon controls the robotic arms with joystick-like controls from a console a few feet from the operating table.
During surgery, a powerful scope is inserted through an incision just one or two centimeters (about .5 – .75 inches) long. A camera is attached to the outside of the scope. This gives your surgeon a highly detailed view of the surgical site. Through three-dimensional, binocular-like lenses that magnify up to ten times, your surgeon is able to see details within hundredths of an inch.
Our Robotic Surgery Team
Our robotic surgery team offer compassionate care using the da Vinci® Surgical System with a human touch. They’re all backed by well-trained robotic surgical support teams of nurses and technicians who work together to make sure you have minimal scarring, a faster recovery and less pain after your surgery.
content.specialtySurgery:
Specialty Surgery
Working closely with your doctor, we’ll ensure the best possible diagnosis, treatment and recovery plan with the highest level of care.
When you need surgery, we offer more than 15 surgical specialties. Our surgeons are the most experienced in the Toledo area and offer specialty surgeries at all of our hospitals across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
Some of our specialized procedures include:
Bariatric weight loss surgery: By changing the anatomy of your stomach and digestive system, we can help improve health conditions such as type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, sleep apnea and more.
Breast surgery: In many cases, breast surgery can improve the effects of cancer, back pain associated with large breasts or self-confidence issues related to your breast size or shape.
Cardiothoracic surgery: Heart surgery, lung surgery and any other surgery affecting the thorax (chest) is considered cardiothoracic surgery. Minimally invasive options for heart surgery include coronary artery bypass graft and valve surgery.
Colon and rectal surgery: Through colon and rectal surgery, we can treat conditions and disorders like diverticulitis, colon and rectal cancer, Crohn's Disease and ulcerative colitis.
Ear, nose and throat surgery: Used to treat diseases related to the ear, nose and throat — like allergies, sleep apnea, hearing loss and thyroid issues —surgery can help improve the structure of your head and neck.
Gynecologic surgery: Gynecological surgery focuses on cancerous and noncancerous conditions of the female reproductive system.
Hepatobiliary and pancreatic surgery: Used to treat diseases that affect the liver, gallbladder, bile ducts and pancreas — including cysts and tumors — our surgeons may offer hepatobiliary or pancreatic procedures to get you back to feeling your best.
Neurosurgery: Neurosurgery is often an effective option for treating issues related to your nervous system, including your brain, spine and nerves.
Ophthalmic surgery: We offer surgical procedures, including laser vision-correction, to treat eyelids, eye sockets, tumors and tear ducts.
Orthopaedic surgery: Through a wide range of procedures, our orthopaedic surgeons can treat your bones, joints and muscles to relieve pain associated with arthritis, tendinitis and osteoporosis or to help heal an injury.
Plastic and reconstructive surgery: Whether you want an elective cosmetic procedure to improve your look or need reconstructive surgery after an accident or health condition, we offer a variety of operations to restore, reconstruct or alter different parts of the body.
Podiatric surgery: Treating diseases and conditions of the feet, from conservative treatments to reconstructive surgery, our specially trained podiatrists are here to help with surgical options, when needed.
Robotic surgery: Robotic surgery options allow our surgeons to perform several common and specialty surgeries. Through smaller incisions, we can help you benefit from a faster recovery, less complications, minimal scarring and decreased pain.
Surgical oncology: Focusing on removing cancerous tumors and other growths from areas of the breast, esophagus, gallbladder, liver, pancreas, skin and tissues, our surgical oncology team is here when you need us most.
Thoracic (lung) robotic surgery: Our surgeons can use robotically assisted thoratic surgery to treat non-small cell lung cancer or other lung diseases.
Trauma surgery: Whether it’s minor (like hitting your finger with a hammer) or major (like being hit by a car traveling at a high rate of speed), our trauma surgery team will be ready to perform surgical procedures to treat injuries to internal organs, bones, the brain and soft tissues of the body.
Urology surgery: Our skilled urology surgeons can treat diseases of the male and female urinary tract system and the male reproductive organs through specialized surgical procedures.
Vascular surgery: Treating diseases and conditions of your arteries, veins and lymphatic system, our surgical team can clear blockages, create bypasses and treat lymphedema.

content.articleContent:
What are seizures?
Your brain controls how your body moves by sending out small electrical signals from your nerves to your muscles. A seizure, or convulsion, is a sudden charge of electrical activity in your brain. It occurs when irregular signals from your brain change the way your body functions. Seizures are classified into epileptic, non-epileptic or provoked seizures.
content.types:
Seizure Symptoms and Types
Seizure Symptoms
Seizure symptoms vary from person to person. Some people may have minor hand shaking while remaining conscious, while others may lose consciousness as their entire bodies convulse.
Signs of a seizure may include:
A blackout, followed by confusion.
Uncontrollable muscle spasms.
Drooling or frothing at the mouth.
Falling.
Experiencing a strange taste in your mouth.
Clenching teeth.
Sudden, rapid eye movements.
Making unusual noises, such as grunting.
Losing bladder or bowel control.
Sudden mood changes.
Types of Seizures
Epileptic Seizures
Epilepsy is a nervous system disorder that can cause seizures. However, just because you have one seizure does not mean you have epilepsy. A minimum of two unprovoked seizures are usually the conditions for an epilepsy diagnosis.
Non-Epileptic Seizures
Non-epileptic seizures may be caused by psychological issues or stress and are not accompanied by abnormal electrical activity in the brain.
Provoked Seizures
Provoked seizures are single seizures that may occur as the result of trauma, low blood pressure, low blood sodium, high fever, or alcohol or drug abuse. Unlike provoked seizures, unprovoked seizures do not have an obvious physical cause. Unprovoked seizures are the main symptom of epilepsy.
content.treatment:
Diagnosis and Treatment
Diagnosing Epilepsy and Seizures
If you think you're at risk for seizures or have experienced one, talk to your doctor. You may want to schedule an appointment with a neurologist. A neurological exam is the first step in diagnosing seizure disorders and epilepsy. Your neurologist may order additional testing, such as:
Treating Epilepsy and Seizures
While there is no cure for epilepsy, ProMedica provides effective treatment options for controlling and eliminating seizures. Epilepsy is typically a long-term condition. But when it is managed properly, its impact on your daily life can be minimized.
Medications
After evaluating your condition, your provider may prescribe an individualized medical management regimen. Medication options for epilepsy include anticonvulsants, nerve pain medications, or sedatives.
Seizure Prevention
Even after you start your medication regimen, you may still experience seizures. You can prevent or reduce your seizure risk by avoiding common triggers, such as:
Lack of sleep.
Flashing lights.
Video games.
Use of heroin or cocaine.
Abrupt withdrawal from medications or alcohol.
Surgery
In certain cases, your physician may evaluate the benefits to surgery. Surgery for epilepsy is sometimes recommended for patients who have severe and frequent seizures which cannot be treated by medication.
Learn more about neurosurgery at ProMedica.

content.articleContent:
Sickle Cell Care for Every Age
The pain and complications caused by sickle cell disease can stop you or your child from doing the things you love. However, with the right support and treatment plan, it’s possible to live a full, active life. At ProMedica, we know how vital it is that those with sickle cell disease have the lifelong care they need. Our comprehensive sickle cell clinics offer preventive therapy and pain management for children and adults.
Let our family take care of yours with quality care close to home.
content.clinic:
Sickle Cell Clinics
ProMedica offers both adult and pediatric sickle cell clinics. Both clinics are designed to help coordinate and manage the care of sickle cell patients by using a multi-disciplinary approach.
ProMedica Comprehensive Pediatric Sickle Cell Clinic
At the ProMedica Comprehensive Pediatric Sickle Cell Clinic, children receive comprehensive care, preventive therapy such as prophylactic antibiotics and immunizations, and important screening for stroke risk and other known complications. They also have access to treatment, such as hydroxyurea and other new treatment options for sickle cell disease.
ProMedica Comprehensive Adult Sickle Cell Clinic
The ProMedica Comprehensive Adult Sickle Cell Clinic is one of the few adult-only sickle cell clinics in the country.
More than 95% of children survive to adulthood in the United States, but because of a host of factors including poor transition, disease complications and lack of comprehensive care, adolescent and young adult patients living with sickle cell disease have some of the highest mortality rates of any group with sickle cell disease.
ProMedica is working to change that statistic by providing comprehensive treatment including transfusions, pain management and exemplary care for adults at the Adult Sickle Cell Clinic.
Care Options for Sickle Cell Patients

Zyann has battled sickle cell since she was born. Learn how ProMedica doctors are making sure that Zyann, and all sickle cell patients, have the care they need.
content.management:
Managing Sickle Cell Disease
There is currently no cure for sickle cell disease and it usually requires life-long treatment. These treatments may include transfusions, medications and pain management. Children with the disease may need preventive therapy such as prophylactic antibiotics, immunizations and screening for stroke risk and other known complications.
While you may not be able to control how sickle cell disease affects you entirely, these things may help with managing symptoms:
Drink plenty of water.
Keep the house warm in the winter and cool in the summer.
Eat a healthy diet.
Get enough sleep.
Get your flu shot and all other recommended immunizations.
Take all your medication as prescribed.
Additionally, see a physician who specializes in treating sickle cell disease. ProMedica offers quality sickle cell disease care options close to home, for patients of every age.
content.understanding:
Understanding Sickle Cell Disease
Sickle cell disease is the most common genetic blood disorder in the world, affecting over 100,000 people in the United States and millions worldwide. The disease affects people of all races, but most commonly people who are Black, Hispanic, or of Middle Eastern, Mediterranean and Indian backgrounds.
Sickle cell disease causes red blood cells to change from being round and flexible to stiff, sticky and sickle-shaped. These cells can’t travel through blood vessels well and break down quickly.
The most common problems associated with sickle cell disease include anemia and blockage of the flow of blood in the tissues. It can cause swelling, pain and other complications. Over time, because of sickling of the red blood cells, patients can also develop chronic organ damage to almost any organ. Bone, kidney, lung and spleen are the most common sites of chronic damage.

content.articleContent:
About Skin Cancer
You want to reduce your risk for skin cancer, or maybe you need to know what to look for. Be informed. Know the signs. Understand how to prevent this disease.
What is skin cancer?
Skin cancer is a specific form of cancer that develops most often on skin exposed to the sun. The three main skin cancer types are:
Basal cell carcinoma. The most common cancer form. Found in the deepest part of your skin’s outermost layer.
Squamous cell carcinoma. Develops in the flat, outer skin cells.
Melanoma. A malignant tumor that forms in the melanin-forming cells. Often appears as dark brown or black “moles” on your skin.
What skin cancer signs should you look for?
It’s important to check yourself and have a dermatologist check your skin regularly. Examine not only skin that’s regularly exposed to the sun on your face, arms, lips, and scalp, but also places rarely exposed like the bottoms of your feet, stomach, and palms of your hands. Common signs for each skin cancer type vary.
Basal cell carcinoma often appears as:
A fleshy colored, flat lesion.
A small, white, shiny bump.
Squamous cell carcinoma often appears as:
A flat, crusty lesion.
A raised, hard, red bump.
Melanoma often appears as:
A mole that changes shape, color, texture, or starts to bleed.
A large, brownish, speckled spot.
A small irregular spot that appears blue, black, red, or white around the edges.
Dark lesions in your mouth, lining of your vagina or anus, or on the palms of your hands, bottoms of your feet, fingertips, or toes.
What can you do to prevent it?
Skin cancer prevention is within your control. Follow these simple steps to reduce your risk:
Wear sunscreen all year long.
Avoid the sun at high points of the day.
Don’t use tanning beds.
Wear protective clothing.
Men and women, especially over age 18, should always request a skin exam during regular health check-ups.
See your dermatologist regularly for thorough skins checks, early detection, and treatment.
What type of doctor treats skin cancer?
Most skin cancers can be removed in-office by your dermatologist. However, if your skin cancer is more advanced, you may require a cancer treatment team that could include surgical oncologists, medical oncologists, or radiation oncologists.

content.articleContent:
A Vibrant Outlook for Your Complexion
Look forward to great skin with treatments that are backed by medical expertise. Our aesthetic services can help make a healthy, clear complexion a reality. From facials to peels to injections, all of our services are performed under the supervision of board-certified plastic surgeons.
content.services:
Skin Care Services
Our licensed medical aestheticians offer a range of nonsurgical skin care treatments. They’re formulated to help you look and feel your best.
Dermaplane
Remove dead skin and vellus hair (peach fuzz) to reveal a refined and glowing complexion. Dermaplaning is a natural exfoliation procedure that removes dead skin cells from the surface of your skin. It has no downtime.
Facials
Relieve stress and get your skin in shape with a relaxing facial. Our 60-minute treatment is designed to help you on the inside as much as it helps on the outside. Our facials include:
Cleansing.
Exfoliating.
Extractions.
Treatment mask.
Lash and Brow Tinting
Simplify your beauty routine. Tinting enhances your natural beauty to darken your lashes and brows without makeup.
Peels
Our wide variety of peels can be customized for every skin type. The peels address skin conditions such as discoloration, texture, aging, acne, sensitivity and pore size. Peels exfoliate and help with antiaging, and also rejuvenate and stimulate skin.
Total Eye Package
Enhance the overall appearance of your eyes. Our total eye enhancement package can help address fine lines and dark circles. It also includes a free eyelash and eyebrow tinting service when you purchase Latisse and an eye cream.
Waxing
Over time, waxing can help hair grow back lighter, thinner and finer. We offer waxing services for all areas of the face, including the brows, upper lip, chin, cheeks and hairline.
content.specials:

content.articleContent:
Your Sleep Problems, Decoded
You’re at your best when you’ve had a full night’s sleep. But sometimes sleeping problems keep you from getting the rest you need.
Lack of sleep is often linked to other medical problems such as:
Obesity
Heart disease
Diabetes
Headaches
Depression
The good news is our sleep experts can help you get the rest your body needs.
Tired of sleep problems? Take our sleep assessment.

Common Sleep Conditions
Sleep apnea: breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep.
Narcolepsy: excessive sleepiness and frequent daytime sleep attacks.
Hypersomnia:excessive sleepiness, when you have trouble staying awake during the day.
Periodic limb movement disorder: when your limbs make rhythmic movements during sleep. Usually happens in your legs, but can also happen in your arms and shoulders.
Insomnia:trouble falling asleep or staying asleep through the night.
Common Symptoms
Feeling sleepy during the day, or falling asleep at random or irregular times.
Taking more than 30 minutes each night to fall asleep.
Awakening more than a few times or for long periods of time every night.
Taking frequent naps.
Sleep Tests
Depending on your symptoms, your doctor may order one or more of the following tests:
Polysomnography: also called a “sleep study.” It records your brain waves, the oxygen level in your blood, your heart rate, your breathing effort, and leg movements during sleep. For the most accurate results these studies are typically performed in a sleep lab. 
CPAP/Bi-Level trials: in-lab sleep studies used to measure continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and bi-level positive airway pressure (BiPAP). These use small machines that administer positive air pressure through a tube connected to a facial mask.
Multiple sleep latency testing: study for excessive daytime sleepiness by measuring how quickly you fall asleep in a quiet environment during the day.
PAP-Nap: study to help those individuals who may be reluctant to use a PAP machine; i.e.: claustrophobia, anxiety
Treatments
Depending on your test results treatment options include:
PAP therapy – the most effective non-invasive cure for sleep apnea
Over-the-counter or prescription sleep aid medications
Mouthpieces
Relaxation exercises
Surgery
Treatments for Children
We are able to diagnosis and treat children age two and up at many of our sleep centers. Talk to your pediatrician if your child demonstrates any of these signs:
Snoring
Difficulty falling or staying asleep
Breathing pauses during sleep
Sleepwalking or persistent nightmares
Changes in mood/behavior
Changes in school/grades

content.articleContent:
About Speech Therapy
ProMedica Total Rehab offers a wide variety of therapy specialties, including Speech and Language Pathology (speech therapy).
Our licensed Speech and Language Pathologists focus on maximizing each person’s skills and abilities through evaluation and treatment of various disorders. These disorders include musculoskeletal such as swallowing difficulties; neurological such as a stroke; cognitive and emotional impairments, and limitations in functional ability due to these disorders.
Following a physician referral to Speech and Language Pathology, our therapist works closely with the patient and physician to coordinate a plan of care that will achieve the best possible outcome in recovery. From your session, you can expect:
Treatment plan developed between you and the therapist during the initial evaluation.
Follow up sessions if necessary, scheduled to meet your financial and lifestyle requirements.
Written plan of care and progress reports shared with the referring physician.
Home program designed to address your individual needs.
Where and how can I receive speech language pathology services?
At ProMedica Total Rehab, our experts are committed to helping you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing what you love. We provide speech language pathology services in a number of our convenient locations throughout northwest Ohio and southwest Michigan.
Please consult with your physician to determine if speech language pathology is right for you.
A physician referral is required to begin rehab services.
Get the care you need where you need it. Our outpatient rehabilitation services are conveniently offered at locations right in your neighborhood. Call 877-4ALL-REHAB (877-425-5734) for information about locations and services.

Personalized Neck and Back Care to Ease Your Pain
Everyone deals with aches and pains at times. But when chronic pain in your back or neck starts to affect the quality of your life, you want prompt relief and treatment from a team of experts you know and trust.
ProMedica Spine Care is here to help. You’ll have easy access to the spine care you need, when you need it most.
Spine pain can develop slowly over time, result from an injury or develop from an underlying health issue. No matter how your pain started, our spine care experts are here to stop it with a personalized treatment plan for your unique needs.
content.spine:
Spine Clinic
When you don’t know where to turn for your spine pain, getting the right help can feel overwhelming. Our Spine Clinic is available to help test, diagnose and recommend treatment to help ease pain.
With clinics in Toledo at the ProMedica Neuroscience Center and in Perrysburg at Levis Commons, you can find spine care close to home. Our clinics are open to anyone who is having back or neck pain, and:
No referrals are needed and no prior work-up or testing is needed.
Patients with old or new injuries in any pain level are welcome.
We accept patients who are already being treated or want a second opinion.
At the ProMedica Spine Clinic, you’ll receive prompt access to a convenient, comprehensive evaluation of your back, neck pain or spine pain, with a quality diagnosis. Our team of specialty-trained nurse practitioners may order and interpret appropriate diagnostic studies (e.g., X-rays, MRI, CT, EMGs) to begin your customized care plan. Then, we’ll recommend a comprehensive, focused spine treatment plan, choosing from a variety of conservative and surgical options depending on your needs. We’ll refer you to experts to get you started on your course of treatment.
content.conditions:
Understanding Your Condition
Your spine and spinal cord work together as a complex network to help control your nervous system. This includes bones, called vertebrae, which protect your spinal cord. And between those bones are discs which help absorb shock and make your spine flexible.
Your spinal cord sends information to your brain and your body. So when something happens to your spine, the pain is sharp and more severe because of all the nerves and impulses in that part of your body.
Conditions that may cause pain in your spine can include:
Arthritis.
Bulging, herniated or ruptured disks.
Curvature of the spine, including scoliosis.
Overuse injuries.
Sciatica.
Spinal stenosis (narrowing).
Sprains, strains or fractures.
Trauma.
content.diagnosis:
Diagnosis & Treatment
Diagnosing Back Pain
If you’re in pain, your doctor may recommend testing by spine care specialists. Our team, which includes neurosurgeons, orthopaedic surgeons and pain management specialists, is here for you. We’ll help diagnose your condition and offer treatments that will help you get back to a pain-free life.
Your testing may include:
CT (computed tomography) scan.
Discogram.
EMG (electromyography.
MRI (magnetic resonance imaging).
Myelogram.
X-ray.
Treating Back Pain
When you need treatment to relieve your pain, you have options. Our highly-trained spine specialists can perform a variety of cutting-edge (take cutting edge out) surgical and non-surgical procedures, including:
Disc replacement.
Discectomy.
Epidural injections.
Laminectomy.
Medication (anti-inflammatory, muscle relaxers and pain relief).
Minimally invasive procedures.
Non-surgical treatments include:
Occupational therapy.
Physical therapy.
Regenerative medicine (replacing cells or tissues).
Spinal fusion.
Spine decompression.
Steroids.
We’re here to support you before, during and after your spine treatments. Our spine specialists will work closely with you to tailor your care plan and help you recover quickly. The goal is to get you back to your active life as soon as possible.
Follow-up Care
Whether you’re treated with surgical or non-surgical care with us, our spine specialists will create a personalized follow-up spine treatment plan to keep a close watch on your recovery process to make sure you heal correctly. This can include referrals for occupational therapy, physical therapy and exercises that will help continue your successful spine treatment journey.
Prompt, quality spine care. Two convenient locations.

content.articleContent:
Get Moving Again Without Pain
Part of having an athletic spirit is striving to be better. To run faster. To get stronger. To play harder. But when pain keeps you from being your best, you need expert treatment to be active again.
Our sports medicine team understands your commitment and passion. From sports-related injuries and tendonitis to joint pain and arthritis, our sports medicine experts can help keep you in the game. No matter your age or activity, we can help you rehabilitate and return to your sport safely.
content.injuries:
Common Injuries
Common injuries include:
Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears.
Ankle sprains.
Back pain.
Carpal tunnel syndrome.
Joint pain.
Meniscus tear.
Plantar fasciitis.
Rotator cuff tear.
Stress fractures.
Tendinitis.
Tennis elbow.
Wrist fracture.
Shoulder Injuries

Learn about shoulder pain, what you can do at home and when you should talk to your doctor.
Concussions

Concussions can be serious if not treated properly. Learn about the signs and symptoms of concussion and what to do to recover.
Runner’s Knee

'Runner's knee' can happen to anyone. Learn more about what is it and how to cope with this painful condition.
Watch more videos about sports medicine
content.services:
Our Services
Minimally-Invasive Treatments
We’ll work with you to create a treatment plan that’s based on your personal fitness, mobility and strength goals. We want you to feel comfortable with your treatment, so you’ll spend time with a sports medicine physician and our staff to make sure all of your questions are answered.
We offer a variety of treatment options to help you get back in the game.
Surgery
Surgery is a big decision. That’s why we will try every non-surgical technique first, like physical therapy and injections, to treat your injury before a surgical procedure is recommended.
If surgery is your best option, you can trust the specialized surgical care at ProMedica Wildwood Orthopaedic and Spine Hospital to get you on the road to recovery.
Rehabilitation
Our goal is the same as yours: To get you back out there safely and as quickly as possible. Our sports-oriented therapy programs were created by rehabilitation experts to do just that. We’ll work with you to restore your function and get you moving again without pain.
Learn more about therapy and rehabilitation.
content.prevention:
Prevention is Key
Whether you’re a competitive athlete or an active weekend warrior, constant movement can put strain on your bones, muscles and joints. Here are some basic tips to help you prevent a possible injury:
Always use the right safety gear, such as helmets, pads and braces.
Avoid activity or exercise when you’re tired or feeling pain.
Learn proper form.
Warm up before your activity.
Wear the right shoes for your activity.
Work up slowly to your activity.

content.articleContent:
Prevention and Treatment to Keep You Active and Healthy
If you or a loved one experiences a stroke, your old life feels like it’s been put on hold. The stroke experts at ProMedica are here for you with state-of-the-art stroke care to help you get back to the life you love.
From prevention to treatment, our compassionate stroke care team is available when you need us. You’ll find us at hospitals and outpatient clinics throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan. Because of our commitment to exceptional outcomes, our stroke program has earned several awards from the Get With The Guidelines® stroke initiative.
80% of strokes are preventable.
content.signs:
Signs of a stroke
Stroke, also known as a brain attack, is the fifth leading cause of death and the leading cause of disability in the U.S. They can happen to anyone at any time. It happens when blood can no longer reach the brain, which can cause brain cells to die.
When it comes to stroke care, every second counts. The faster you can get medical attention, the better your chances of lowering the long-term effects or preventing death. That’s why it’s important to understand the signs of a stroke. The easiest way to remember is watch for the signs to BE FAST:
B – Balance trouble and dizziness.
E – Eyes (blurry or double vision).
F – Face drooping or numbing (a person’s smile may look uneven).
A – Arm weakness (a person can’t hold their arms up).
S – Speech difficulty or trouble repeating a simple sentence.
T – Time to call 911.
Call 911 right away if you spot any of the BE FAST symptoms. Also, try to remember what time the symptoms started. It’s critical to seek medical attention right away.
Other warning signs may include clumsiness, sudden confusion and sudden severe headache.
content.care:
Stroke Care
ProMedica provides a wide range of stroke care options at hospitals and outpatient clinics throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
If you’re worried about having a stroke, we’ll work with you to help control cerebrovascular disease and stroke risk factors. We also offer counseling for prevention and awareness.
If you or a loved one are having a stroke event, our stroke team can quickly diagnose a wide variety of cerebrovascular diseases.
You or someone you love may be recovering from a stroke. We’re here for you then, too. You’ll receive physical, occupational and speech therapy that helps you get stronger and return to daily activities. Our certified therapists evaluate your needs and create a therapy plan that works for you. We’re committed to seeing you regain the skills and strength you need to get back to doing life — and doing what you love.
ProMedica Toledo Hospital was one of 46 hospitals in the country with better than average rates of 30 days mortality after stroke for Medicare patients.
Better Stroke Outcomes
At ProMedica, we focus on patient outcomes and life changing care. Our stroke program has earned several awards from the Get With The Guidelines® stroke initiative. ProMedica Toledo Hospital was one of 46 hospitals out of 4,313 hospitals in the country with better than average rates of 30 days mortality after stroke for Medicare patients.
View our 2021-2022 core measures
View our yearly thrombolytic data from 2016-2022
Learn more about our outcomes in our 2018-2019 Stroke Outcomes Report
Screening and Prevention
Screenings can point out your risk factors for conditions such as cancer, cardiovascular disease and osteoporosis, which tend to happen later in life. Once you know your risks, you can work with your doctor to determine the best combination of diet, lifestyle changes and medications to help you avoid these conditions. If you are diagnosed with a condition, your doctor will recommend an effective treatment plan.
Learn more about our outcomes in our 2018-2019 Stroke Outcomes Report
Advanced Imaging for Stroke Diagnosis
ProMedica’s RAPID imaging platform allows stroke teams to make faster, more accurate diagnostic and treatment decisions for stroke patients. That means better stroke care outcomes.
In fact, outcomes from clinical trials using the RAPID platform have led to new American Heart Association and American Stroke Association treatment guidelines and have dramatically altered the management of acute stroke around the world.
State-of-the-art Suites at ProMedica Toledo Hospital
Our dedicated space at Toledo Hospital makes it easier to treat stroke patients. Our 48-bed stroke and 16-bed neuro intensive care units featuring a new neuro-interventional lab, 24-hour MRI service, and portable CT scanner. Our stroke patients and families have access to private updated rooms with nursing staff specifically trained in caring for people with complex neurologic conditions.
The hospitals new, expanded interventional suites mean that our highly trained neurointerventionalists can now complete technically difficult procedures in a state-of-the art angiography suite. This suite is specifically designed to reduce radiation exposure, with have the added advantage of a 3D navigation system to provide more precise imaging.
Second Opinions
Strokes are complex and often hard to understand. That’s why it’s always good to get a second opinion. Our team offers second opinions when you need added expertise to decide on your next steps.
A Network of Care
Strokes need specialized attention right away. That’s why we created our stroke network to diagnose, treat and rehabilitate you right here in northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
You’ll receive safe, family-centered, compassionate care by working with a team of nationally recognized experts in our area. They specialize in the latest technologies, surgical procedures and research to help you get the best care possible.
The ProMedica Stroke Network supports:
Twelve regional ProMedica sites and 21 area hospitals in total across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
Collaborative care teams across the system that include:
Advanced practice providers.
Critical care physicians.
First responders.
Hospital emergency room staff.
Neurointerventionalists.
Neurological surgeons.
Neurologists.
Nurses.
ProMedica Access.
ProMedica Transportation Network.
Vascular surgeons.
Community outreach efforts which build awareness around stroke risk factors and warning signs
Highly specialized neurointerventionalists.
Monthly support groups for stroke survivors, caregivers and supporters.
Neurosciences center at ProMedica Toledo Hospital that offers outpatient care for a wide range of neurological conditions.
ProMedica Toledo Hospital, the area's first Comprehensive Stroke Center. It’s certified by The Joint Commission and the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association.
An evidence-based protocol called Rapid Arterial oCclusion Evaluation (RACE) used by first responders to recognize stroke emergencies. When a RACE alert is identified, the patient is taken immediately to an accredited stroke center with neurointerventional capability.
Stroke and Brain Aneurysm Clinic at ProMedica Toledo Hospital.
Stroke research programs.
Telemedicine: Tele-stroke network with specialized tele-stroke nurses.
Vascular neurology at ProMedica Toledo Hospital.
This means brain-saving care to more areas of northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan than ever before.
Clinical Trials
ProMedica patients may qualify for clinical trials related to stroke care. Clinical trials evaluate the safety and effectiveness of certain drugs, treatments or medical devices by monitoring the effects on a diverse group of people.
While it cannot be guaranteed that participants will benefit personally from participating in clinical trials, individuals may benefit from:
Breakthrough treatments: Participants may have access to promising new treatments that are not yet available outside of the clinical trial setting.
Increased monitoring: The Research team may provide them with close monitoring, advice, care and support and are very knowledgeable of the disease or condition.
Helping society: People who take part in clinical trials are vital to the process of improving medical care. If participants do not directly benefit from the clinical trial they are participating in, the information gathered by their participation will contribute to helping others.
Self advocacy: Participants have the chance to play an active role in their own health care and gain a greater understanding of their disease or condition.
Learn More About Clinical Trials
If you are interested in participating in a clinical trial or are interested in more information, please contact the ProMedica Research Department 419-291-8027 or email Research@ProMedica.org.

content.types:
Types of Stroke
Strokes can have many different effects on the brain. They can also have many different causes. There are three types of strokes.
Hemorrhagic stroke (bleeding)
If you have a hemorrhagic stroke, it means a vessel supplying blood to your brain ruptures and causes bleeding. When an artery bleeds into your brain, oxygen and necessary nutrients can’t reach your brain cells. Brain damage can happen because of the pressure in tissues that surround the brain. About 13% of all strokes are hemorrhagic strokes.
There are two types of hemorrhagic strokes:
Intracerebral hemorrhages
This type of hemorrhagic stroke happens when there is bleeding from the blood vessels within your brain. Besides the common risk factors for a stroke, unique risk factors for an intracerebral hemorrhage include:
Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs): Groups of blood vessels in your body that form in the wrong way. This causes arteries and veins to get tangled.
Cerebral cavernous malformations (CCM): Blood vessels that do not form correctly in the brain. For instance, capillaries are tiny blood vessels that group together to form a lesion. A lesion bleeds more easily, and if it bursts and bleeds into the brain, it can cause a stroke.
Dural arteriovenous fistulas (DAVF): Abnormal connections that take place between arteries and veins in the outer membrane of the brain and cause clots. These most often form during a surgery or injury.
Hypertension: Also known as high blood pressure, this is the most common cause of stroke.
Subarachnoid hemorrhages (SAH)
This type of hemorrhagic stroke happens when there is bleeding in-between the brain and the membranes that cover the brain. Besides the common risk factors for a stroke, unique risk factors for a subarachnoid hemorrhage include:
Cerebral aneurysm: Also known as a brain aneurysm, this is a bulging weakened area in the wall of the blood vessels of the brain. Aneurysms can keep growing in size and weaken the artery wall. If it bursts, uncontrolled bleeding may happen.
Warning signs of hemorrhagic stroke include a sudden, severe headache (often described as the worst headache of your life), confusion and being unresponsive.
Ischemic stroke (clots)
An ischemic stroke happens when a blood vessel that supplies blood to your brain becomes blocked or clogged. When blood flow is lowered, oxygen and needed nutrients can’t get to your brain. Brain cells and tissues begin to die within minutes. About 87% of all strokes are hemorrhagic ischemic strokes.
There are two main types of ischemic strokes.
Thrombotic strokes
Thrombotic strokes are caused by a blood clot (thrombus) formed in the arteries that supply blood to your brain. When a thrombotic stroke occurs in the tiny, deep blood vessels in the brain, it’s called a lacunar stroke. These are most common in people who have diabetes or hypertension.
Besides the common risk factors for a stroke, unique risk factors for a thrombotic stroke include:
Age: Typically in older adults.
Atherosclerosis: A buildup of fat and lipids inside blood vessel walls.
Family history and stroke.
High cholesterol.
Warning signs of a thrombotic stroke are unique. They can happen while you’re sleeping or slowly over several hours or days. You could also have one or more mini strokes.
Embolic Strokes
Embolic strokes start when plaque builds up or a blood clot forms in a vessel outside of your head. An embolic stroke happens when this clot travels through your bloodstream and reaches the blood vessels in your brain.
Besides the common risk factors for a stroke, unique risk factors for an embolic stroke include:
Having AFib.
Having heart disease.
Undergoing heart surgery.
Having carotid stenosis.
Having heart failure.
Having cardiomyopathy.
Signs of an embolic stroke can happen fast or without any warning signs at all.
Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) are sometimes referred to as warning strokes or mini strokes. Unlike a stroke, TIAs don’t cause permanent brain damage. TIA symptoms last less than 24 hours, and often less than one hour. About a third of people who have a TIA will likely suffer a stroke in the next 12 months.
With a TIA, an artery is briefly blocked and blood can’t reach a part of your brain. TIA symptoms vary based on the part of the brain that’s affected.
Besides the common risk factors for a stroke, unique risk factors for an embolic stroke include carotid artery stenosis. The carotid arteries are the main blood vessels that carry blood and oxygen to your brain. These arteries can become narrowed by fat and lipid buildup, which lowers the oxygen flow to your brain. Blood can’t reach your brain if your carotid arteries are too narrow.
TIA symptoms appear to be the same as a stroke, so it’s often hard to tell which type of attack you’re having.

content.articleContent:
Set Your Mind on a Healthy Heart
Whether you were born with a structural heart disease or developed a problem later in life, you can count on ProMedica’s skilled and compassionate team for the best possible care. We’ll work with you, your family and other specialists when needed, to ensure you get high quality, coordinated and personalized treatment.
content.overview:
Understanding Structural Heart Disease
Structural heart disease is a general term used to describe conditions that involve damage to, or flaws in, the anatomy of the heart. It’s different from coronary heart disease, which is caused by plaque in the arteries. Common structural heart disease conditions include, but aren’t limited to:
Aortic coarctation.
Aortic dilatation or aneurysm.
Aortic valve stenosis.
Atrial septal defect (ASD).
Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.
Left atrial occlusion.
Mitral regurgitation (both degenerative and functional mitral regurgitation).
Mitral stenosis.
Paravalvular leaks.
Patent foramen ovale (PFO).
Know the Risk Factors
Most types of structural heart disease can’t be prevented since it’s something you’re likely born with. However, you could be at increased risk for developing structural heart disease due to:
Age: As you get older, you become more prone to heart conditions.
Family history: Structural heart disease can run in families, and genetic factors can raise your risk.
Previous heart issues: High blood pressure, rheumatic fever, atherosclerosis, ischemic heart disease, an earlier heart attack or congestive heart failure can damage the heart.
If your structural heart disease is the result of other cardiac problems, managing your existing health conditions can help prevent more damage to your heart.
Find Fast, Accurate Diagnosis
Structural heart disease can be difficult to detect in adults, especially since most adult patients don’t seem to experience symptoms. If you do have symptoms, they would likely feel like:
Chest tightness.
Dizziness.
Fatigue.
Heart palpitations or flutters, skipping beats or racing heart beats.
Trouble with exercise or day-to-day activities.
Diagnostic Tests
If you’re experiencing any of the symptoms of structural heart disease, your doctor may recommend a series of tests, including:
A physical exam.
An echocardiogram or ultrasound.
A cardiac catheter of the heart.
CT scan.
MRI.
Get Effective Treatment
At ProMedica, we offer a full range of minimally invasive techniques to treat your structural heart condition. These procedures include:
Mitral Valve Clip
A minimally invasive procedure in which a clip is placed on your heart’s mitral valve to treat mitral regurgitation (a backflow of blood caused when the mitral valve doesn’t close tightly). For patients who aren’t able to have open-heart surgery, this treatment can be performed instead.
Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR)
A minimally invasive procedure that uses a catheter to replace a diseased aortic valve.
WATCHMAN™
A device implanted into the heart to lower the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (AFib). The procedure is minimally invasive and performed with a catheter, so it doesn’t involve open-heart surgery. The WATCHMANTM can be used instead of taking blood thinners. It permanently blocks off the specific area of the heart where AFib causes most blood clots to form.
content.approach:
Our Approach
The ProMedica Structural Heart Clinic is staffed by a team of expert cardiologists, cardiothoracic surgeons, cardiac anesthesiologists and cardiac imaging specialists — all dedicated to diagnosing and treating patients with structural heart disease.
Our multidisciplinary approach focuses on collaboration. This has made us the largest and most experienced structural heart team in the Toledo region. Together, we offer a wide range of structural heart therapies and provide patient care that’s tailored to you.
Your goal is our goal: We want to help you improve your heart health.

content.articleContent:
Care That Gives You Peace of Mind
Along your journey to better health, surgery may become your best option for healing. But even when it’s necessary, we know the decision to have surgery can still be stressful for many reasons. That’s why our surgical team will be with you every step of the way, from ensuring that a surgical procedure is the right decision for you to supporting your recovery until you feel like yourself again.
content.approach:
Our Approach
Experienced and Compassionate Surgical Team
You can count on the ProMedica surgical team for the highest level of care. Our surgeons are highly trained in their fields and use the most advanced technologies and methods available to shorten your recovery time and make your experience as comfortable as possible. From initial consultation through your surgery and recovery, you’ll have all the support and understanding you need to feel whole again.
Fast and Convenient Access to Care
At ProMedica, we’re dedicated to offering innovative and advanced surgical care, close to home. That’s why we offer surgical services at locations across ProMedica’s 27-county service area in northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
And because we know you may be in pain or just anxious to move forward right away, we make same-day consultations available whenever possible. When same-day appointments are not available, we can typically arrange your visit with your surgeon within five days.
Leading-Edge Surgical Techniques and Technologies
When you partner with us for your surgical care, you’ll have access to today’s most advanced surgical technologies and methods, such as state-of-the-art robotic tools like da Vinci® Surgical System.
Trusted and Nationally Recognized Care
Before deciding to have surgery, you need to feel confident you’re getting the best surgical care for you or your loved one. Though our highest honor is serving your needs, we’re proud to share our general surgery awards and accreditations.
ProMedica Toledo Hospital
