content.roboticSurgery:
Robotic Surgery
Robot-assisted surgery can create a safer, more accurate surgical experience with a faster recovery and less scarring. The surgeons at ProMedica use the da Vinci® Surgical System, a revolutionary tool that helps our surgeons perform several common surgeries through an incision that’s less than an inch long.
Benefits of Robotic Surgery
Because of the small incision and greater accuracy, the benefits of robotic surgery include:
Faster recovery.
Fewer complications after your surgery.
Less blood loss.
Less pain.
Minimal scarring.
Quick and safe return to your daily activities.
Robotically Assisted Procedures
Our surgeons use the da Vinci® Surgical System for a wide range of surgeries, including:
General robotic surgery.
Gynecologic robotic surgery.
Thoracic (lung) robotic surgery.
Urologic robotic surgery.
How It Works
Even though it’s called a robot, the da Vinci® Surgical System can’t perform surgery or make decisions. Your surgeon controls the robotic arms with joystick-like controls from a console a few feet from the operating table.
During surgery, a powerful scope is inserted through an incision just one or two centimeters (about .5 – .75 inches) long. A camera is attached to the outside of the scope. This gives your surgeon a highly detailed view of the surgical site. Through three-dimensional, binocular-like lenses that magnify up to ten times, your surgeon is able to see details within hundredths of an inch.
Our Robotic Surgery Team
Our robotic surgery team offer compassionate care using the da Vinci® Surgical System with a human touch. They’re all backed by well-trained robotic surgical support teams of nurses and technicians who work together to make sure you have minimal scarring, a faster recovery and less pain after your surgery.
content.specialtySurgery:
Specialty Surgery
Working closely with your doctor, we’ll ensure the best possible diagnosis, treatment and recovery plan with the highest level of care.
When you need surgery, we offer more than 15 surgical specialties. Our surgeons are the most experienced in the Toledo area and offer specialty surgeries at all of our hospitals across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
Some of our specialized procedures include:
Bariatric weight loss surgery: By changing the anatomy of your stomach and digestive system, we can help improve health conditions such as type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, sleep apnea and more.
Breast surgery: In many cases, breast surgery can improve the effects of cancer, back pain associated with large breasts or self-confidence issues related to your breast size or shape.
Cardiothoracic surgery: Heart surgery, lung surgery and any other surgery affecting the thorax (chest) is considered cardiothoracic surgery. Minimally invasive options for heart surgery include coronary artery bypass graft and valve surgery.
Colon and rectal surgery: Through colon and rectal surgery, we can treat conditions and disorders like diverticulitis, colon and rectal cancer, Crohn's Disease and ulcerative colitis.
Ear, nose and throat surgery: Used to treat diseases related to the ear, nose and throat — like allergies, sleep apnea, hearing loss and thyroid issues —surgery can help improve the structure of your head and neck.
Gynecologic surgery: Gynecological surgery focuses on cancerous and noncancerous conditions of the female reproductive system.
Hepatobiliary and pancreatic surgery: Used to treat diseases that affect the liver, gallbladder, bile ducts and pancreas — including cysts and tumors — our surgeons may offer hepatobiliary or pancreatic procedures to get you back to feeling your best.
Neurosurgery: Neurosurgery is often an effective option for treating issues related to your nervous system, including your brain, spine and nerves.
Ophthalmic surgery: We offer surgical procedures, including laser vision-correction, to treat eyelids, eye sockets, tumors and tear ducts.
Orthopaedic surgery: Through a wide range of procedures, our orthopaedic surgeons can treat your bones, joints and muscles to relieve pain associated with arthritis, tendinitis and osteoporosis or to help heal an injury.
Plastic and reconstructive surgery: Whether you want an elective cosmetic procedure to improve your look or need reconstructive surgery after an accident or health condition, we offer a variety of operations to restore, reconstruct or alter different parts of the body.
Podiatric surgery: Treating diseases and conditions of the feet, from conservative treatments to reconstructive surgery, our specially trained podiatrists are here to help with surgical options, when needed.
Robotic surgery: Robotic surgery options allow our surgeons to perform several common and specialty surgeries. Through smaller incisions, we can help you benefit from a faster recovery, less complications, minimal scarring and decreased pain.
Surgical oncology: Focusing on removing cancerous tumors and other growths from areas of the breast, esophagus, gallbladder, liver, pancreas, skin and tissues, our surgical oncology team is here when you need us most.
Thoracic (lung) robotic surgery: Our surgeons can use robotically assisted thoratic surgery to treat non-small cell lung cancer or other lung diseases.
Trauma surgery: Whether it’s minor (like hitting your finger with a hammer) or major (like being hit by a car traveling at a high rate of speed), our trauma surgery team will be ready to perform surgical procedures to treat injuries to internal organs, bones, the brain and soft tissues of the body.
Urology surgery: Our skilled urology surgeons can treat diseases of the male and female urinary tract system and the male reproductive organs through specialized surgical procedures.
Vascular surgery: Treating diseases and conditions of your arteries, veins and lymphatic system, our surgical team can clear blockages, create bypasses and treat lymphedema.

content.articleContent:
Advanced Surgery for the Organs of Your Chest
Finding out you need thoracic surgery can feel overwhelming, especially since it involves delicate organs like your lungs, chest wall, trachea and esophagus. But at ProMedica, you can have peace of mind knowing you’re in good hands. With specialized expertise, our thoracic surgeons will care for you with skill, today’s most promising treatments and compassion.
content.approach:
Our Approach
From diagnosis to recovery, the caring ProMedica team is here for you. Using the most advanced methods, our cardiothoracic surgeons specialize in minimally invasive thoracic procedures to treat the lungs, chest wall, trachea and esophagus.
content.typesOfSurgery:
Thoracic Surgery Types
You may need thoracic surgery for many different reasons, including treating lung cancer or lung injuries, performing biopsies and removing diseased or damaged lung tissue.
At ProMedica, we offer a full range of thoracic surgery services to help with your unique needs.
Our surgeons will work with you to decide on the right procedure for your condition and your overall health. Our surgery options include:
Bilobectomy: Removes two of the lobes in the right lung.
Decortication: Removes the outer surface (or membrane) of the lung. This allows the lung to expand completely.
Empyema: Treats an infection in the lung.
Lobectomy: Removes one of the lobes of the lungs.
Lung biopsy: Removes a tissue sample from the lungs to be tested for lung disease, cancer or another condition.
Pericardial window: Drains fluid from the pericardial sac that surrounds the heart.
Pneumonectomy: Surgery to remove the lung.
Pneumothorax: Treats a collapsed lung.
Robotic thoracic surgery: Offers all the benefits of robot-assisted surgery. Because it makes tiny incisions (cuts) in your chest, most robotic lung-surgery patients experience better outcomes, shorter hospital stays and quicker recoveries.
Thoracotomy: Reaches the lungs through an incision in the side of the chest, usually between the ribs.
Tracheostomy: Creates a hole in the front of your neck to insert a breathing tube.
Video-assisted thoracic surgery (VATS) : Removes all or part of a lung using a type of minimally invasive surgery. The surge on uses a special camera called a thoracoscope for a detailed view of the lung. Learn more.
Wedge resection (segmental resection): Removes part of the lung.
Thoracic Robotic Surgery
Until recently, if your doctor suggested lung surgery to remove part your lung, you needed to have a thoracotomy, which means the surgeon made an incision in your chest and seperated your rib cage to expose your lungs.
Today, if you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer or other lung disease and need surgery, our highly trained ProMedica cardiothoracic surgeons offer you the alternative of robot-assisted lung surgery.
Thoracic robotic surgery is performed through several tiny incisions in your chest and offers all of the benefits of robot-assisted surgery. Most robotic lung-surgery patients experience:
Better outcomes
Shorter hospital stays
Quicker recoveries
If your physician recommends lung surgery, ask if robotic surgery is right for you.

content.articleContent:
Get Ready to Quit for Good
You have so much to gain by quitting tobacco. That’s because smoking is more than just a bad habit. It’s the leading cause of preventable death in the United States.
When you’re ready to quit smoking, the first thing you need is a plan. And because there’s no one-size-fits-all approach, you’ll likely need a range of tools and programs to help you stop using tobacco products.
At ProMedica, our highly skilled and experienced staff of respiratory therapists and registered nurses will tailor your plan for quitting. It will address your dependence on nicotine and build habits and behaviors to help you stay tobacco free.
content.services:
Our Services
With specialized smoking cessation programs for teens and adults, we focus on helping you get support, get information and get healthy. Our treatment programs give you choices for every step of your journey to a tobacco-free life, including:
Confidential group and individual nicotine addiction counseling.
Medicine education.
Preventative education for children and teens.
Stop smoking plan development.
Support groups.
We serve the northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan area and can schedule tobacco prevention programs at schools and worksites. You’ll also find specialized programming at these ProMedica facilities:
Charles and Virginia Hickman Hospital: 517-577-0098
ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital: 419-436-6688
ProMedica Monroe Regional Hospital: 734-240-5301
ProMedica Toledo Hospital: 419-291-8034
Natural Therapy Services
Some natural therapies, such as auricular therapy, may help you in your efforts to quit tobacco. At the ProMedica Natural Wellness Shop, our licensed and certified natural wellness practitioner uses an internationally recognized method called The National Acupuncture Detoxification Association (NADA) protocol to aid with smoking cessation. This may help with your overall well-being and support your body’s function while quitting.
Learn more about services at ProMedica Natural Wellness Shop.
content.prepareToQuit:
Prepare to Quit
You probably have a few reasons of your own, but there may be reasons to quit smoking that you aren’t aware of. Here are some important ones:
You’ll feel better: Tobacco use delays healing. By quitting tobacco, you’ll recover more quickly from cuts, incisions, wounds and broken bones. You’ll soon find you have more energy and are able to breathe easier, too. The time will come when you’ll no longer have urges to smoke, which leaves you free to focus on what’s important in your life.
You’ll protect yourself from disease: The health risks of tobacco use include various cancers, asthma, emphysema, heart disease, stroke and diabetes. Pregnant women who smoke have a higher risk of premature delivery, low birth-weight babies, stillbirth and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).
Steps to Becoming Tobacco Free
Quitting smoking is a big undertaking. That’s why we advise taking it step-by-step.
Your personal smoking cessation plan will help you cope with the physical and emotional issues that may come with your decision to stop smoking. These issues include nicotine withdrawal and strong urges to smoke. We’re here to help you prepare for those challenges and stay the course on your journey to becoming tobacco free.
The first step is to think through what that journey will look like for you.
Mentally prepare to quit: Think about your past attempts to quit. Consider what worked and what didn’t, and open your mind to new ideas.
Form healthier habits: Go for a brisk walk or join a gym.
Reward yourself: You’ll save money if you stop smoking. As you’re on your way to becoming tobacco free, reward yourself with small things or experiences that reinforce your progress.
Create a support system: Get help from family and friends; get group, individual or telephone counseling; or join a support group.
Stay away from temptation: Set a no-smoking policy in your home and car, be careful around other tobacco users and avoid alcohol until you’re more comfortable with not smoking.
Do your homework and get help from experts: Ask your doctor about medicines to help you quit. Also consider counseling, which doubles your chances of quitting for good.
Set a quit date: Remember that your plan and medicines take time to work. Set a date two to four weeks in the future to help you plan and prepare.
Make a plan, work your plan: Decide what kind of counseling you want. Talk to your doctor about medicines that can help you quit. Create an emergency plan to help keep you on track. Tweak and adjust your plan as needed.
Don’t give up: Remember that every attempt to quit brings you closer to quitting for good. Never quit trying to quit.
Find Community Support for Quitting Smoking
You can get more information and resources for quitting tobacco from the following community and public organizations:
Ohio Quit Line (call 1-800-QUIT-NOW)
American Cancer Society
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
American Heart Association
Staying Tobacco and Nicotine Free for Life
How to Stay Tobacco and Nicotine Free for Life

A slip is a normal part of learning how to remain nicotine free for life. Learn how staying positive prevents a slip from becoming a full-blown relapse.
content.aboutTobacco:
Are Any Tobacco Products Safe?
The answer is no. Tobacco products of any kind aren’t safe, and there are many more tobacco products than just cigarettes. Not only are these products harmful to you when you use them, many of them also cause issues for nonsmokers who have to breathe secondhand smoke.
Confidential group and individual nicotine addiction counseling.
Medicine education.
Preventative education for children and teens.
Stop smoking plan development.
Support groups.
We serve the northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan area and can schedule tobacco prevention programs at schools and worksites. You’ll also find specialized programming at these ProMedica facilities:

Smokeless Tobacco
Cigars and Pipes
Hookahs
Smokeless Tobacco
Smokeless tobacco is a term for the many forms of tobacco that aren’t used for smoking. Chewing tobacco, snuff and dip are all forms of smokeless tobacco. They contain chemicals that lead to:
Death.
Facial disfigurement.
Gum recession, tooth loss, yellow teeth, bad breath and precancerous sores inside your mouth.
Heart disease and high blood pressure.
Oral cancers including cancer of your mouth, gums, lips, tongue and throat.
Tobacco dependence.
Cigars and Pipes
Cigars, cigarillos, little cigars and pipes contain nicotine and cancer-causing chemicals. They can cause:
Cancer of your lips, lungs, mouth and throat.
Higher risk of chronic bronchitis, emphysema and heart disease.
Hookahs
Commonly referred to as water pipes, hookahs produce smoke that contains high levels of carbon monoxide, heavy metals, carcinogens and nicotine. These chemicals can cause:
Cancer of your lips, lungs, mouth and throat.
Gum disease.
Tobacco dependence, since it delivers about the same amount of nicotine as cigarettes.
For your best health, don’t use any tobacco-related products.
Smokeless Tobacco
Smokeless Tobacco
Smokeless tobacco is a term for the many forms of tobacco that aren’t used for smoking. Chewing tobacco, snuff and dip are all forms of smokeless tobacco. They contain chemicals that lead to:
Death.
Facial disfigurement.
Gum recession, tooth loss, yellow teeth, bad breath and precancerous sores inside your mouth.
Heart disease and high blood pressure.
Oral cancers including cancer of your mouth, gums, lips, tongue and throat.
Tobacco dependence.

Cancer of your lips, lungs, mouth and throat.

Cancer of your lips, lungs, mouth and throat.

Tobacco dependence, since it delivers about the same amount of nicotine as cigarettes.
For your best health, don’t use any tobacco-related products.

content.articleContent:
Understanding Ultrasound
Ultrasound is a technique that uses sound waves and a computer to create pictures of the inside of your body. Ultrasound gives your doctor a clearer picture of your tissue and organs so you get a concise diagnosis and the most effective treatment. Your doctor may order an ultrasound for your:
Heart
Kidneys
Liver
Blood Vessels
Fetus if you’re pregnant
Other organs or body parts
What can you expect from your ultrasound?
It’s a simple and painless procedure that can be done right in your doctor’s office or at one of our radiology centers.
You’ll lie on a table while your doctor or ultrasound technician guides a smooth instrument over your skin in the targeted area. Though you won’t hear them, sound waves are sent through your body where they’ll bounce off your body’s tissues. The instrument also receives the sound waves that bounce back. The ultrasound machine will interpret these into a picture that your doctor can review and then make an assessment.

Immediate Care When You Need It Most
When the unexpected happens, you need care that’s convenient and fast. ProMedica Urgent Care is here to treat injuries and illnesses that don’t require a trip to the emergency room. Walk-ins are welcome. No appointment is necessary.
We treat children of all ages at ALL of our ProMedica Urgent Care locations; however, ProMedica Urgent Care for Kids in Perrysburg is only for kids under the age of 18.
If you or a loved one have a life-threatening health emergency like a heart attack, stroke, limb-threatening injuries, unconsciousness or a severe allergic reaction, please call 911 right away.
We’re open 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., 365 days a year. You don’t need to make an appointment.
content.care:
Connected Care
Sometimes it can be difficult to know if an urgent care is the right place to go for the care you need. We’re here to help you choose the right care. Learn more about the various levels of care you’re connected to with ProMedica.
ProMedica Emergency Centers
If an illness or injury is more serious, you should call 911 or go to your nearest emergency room right away. Sometimes it can be difficult to know if an emergency center is necessary. Serious, life-threatening conditions that require an ER visit include:
Amputation.
Bleeding that won’t stop.
Broken bones.
Chest pain.
Head injuries.
Poisoning.
Pregnancy complications.
Seizures.
Serious mental health conditions.
Severe burns, electrical shocks or cuts.
Severe shortness of breath.
ProMedica Emergency Centers are open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.
Find Locations
ProMedica Physicians
If you’re looking for a healthcare provider, we offer expert, compassionate care for a variety of conditions, including:
Allergy management.
Asthma.
Chronic condition management.
Diabetes management.
Immunizations.
Non-emergency pediatric, internal medicine or geriatric (senior) care.
Physicals and yearly exams.
Pregnancy testing.
Prescription and drug management.
Specialty referrals.
Wellness services.
Find a ProMedica Doctor near you: Call 1-800-PPG-DOCS or search for a provider online.
ProMedica OnDemand
When you want unscheduled care from a healthcare provider, our on demand service can immediately connect you with a board-certified provider. These online doctor visits are available 24/7 through your mobile device or your computer.
Learn More
content.services:
Our Services
We’re committed to treating you with high quality care. ProMedica Urgent Care is accredited by the Urgent Care Association (UCA), and was the first urgent care in northwest Ohio to earn accreditation.
Asthma attacks.
Bladder infections.
Cuts that may need stitches.
High fever.
Minor burns.
Minor injuries like sprains, strains or simple fractures.
Seasonal allergies.
Severe headaches.
Stomach pain.
Strong pain.
Cold, cough, congestion and flu.
Ear infections.
Urgent Care for Kids
When your child is suddenly sick or injured, our pediatric urgent care team is here with treatment and relief for them, and peace of mind for you.
All of our ProMedica Urgent Care locations treat children, but our Urgent Care for Kids location in Perrysburg is just for kids. In fact, we’re the only urgent care in the area dedicated to kids.
Learn More
content.faq:
Frequently Asked Questions
What types of payment does ProMedica Urgent Care accept?
We accept most major insurances and credit cards.
Am I eligible to go to ProMedica Urgent Care?
We're open to patients of all ages at all of our urgent care locations.
What is ProMedica Urgent Care for Kids?
ProMedica Urgent Care for Kids is the only pediatric urgent care in the region dedicated to treating children.
We treat patients of all ages at every one of our urgent cares in the area. However, ProMedica Urgent Care for Kids in Perrysburg is a pediatric urgent care that specializes in treating only children under 18.
Who will care for me at ProMedica Urgent Care?
ProMedica Urgent Care is staffed by highly trained, certified nurse practitioners who can diagnose your condition, perform physical assessments and prescribe medicines. All certified nurse practitioners work under ProMedica Physicians, which is a network of expert providers and high-quality services across the region.
When is ProMedica Urgent Care open?
ProMedica Urgent Care is open 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., 365 days a year. Walk-ins are always welcome.
Can I go to ProMedica Urgent Care if I already have a doctor?
Yes. If your doctor is a ProMedica Physician, we will follow up to make sure your doctor is aware of your visit to the urgent care.
If you aren't a ProMedica patient, we’ll send a note to your primary care physician.
Need a doctor? Call 1-800-PPG-DOCS or search for a ProMedica doctor online.
What is antibiotic stewardship?
Antibiotic prescriptions are important medicines that help our bodies fight bacterial infections. Misusing these medicines can lead to antibiotic resistance, which means they are no longer effective. To protect patients and our community, we are committed to the responsible use of antibiotics (also known as antibiotic stewardship).
At ProMedica Urgent Care, we are committed to leading our industry forward in improving the use of antibiotics. That means reducing unnecessary antibiotic prescriptions. It also means educating patients on how to use them. We’re committed to developing organization and collaborative solutions, which include:
Supporting the tracking and reporting of antibiotic use.
Providing ongoing education for urgent care providers and patients about antibiotic stewardship.
Implementing procedures that support providers in practicing evidence-based antibiotic prescribing.
Supporting scientific evidence that enhances our knowledge, leads to stewardship interventions and builds effective resources for providers and patients.
We understand the pressing need for action to preserve the use of these life-saving drugs. We're working to immediately reduce unnecessary antibiotic use while ensuring patients receive the best care and treatment possible. Many challenges lie ahead in the fight against antibiotic resistance. Together we will maximize our chance for success.

content.articleContent:
Expert, Compassionate Care for Lasting Relief
When losing control of your bladder disrupts your life, it’s important to get treatment. The urinary specialists at ProMedica are here to help diagnose and treat a wide range of bladder-related issues. From occasional incontinence to a urinary tract infection, we can help you heal and get back to the life you love.
You aren’t alone. Over 26 million people in the United States have urinary issues.
content.conditions:
Understanding Your Condition
Urinary incontinence, or the loss of bladder control, is a common problem. Sometimes it starts with leaking urine when you cough or sneeze. Then it may progress to sudden, sharp urges to urinate that are so strong you can’t get to the bathroom in time.
There are several different types of incontinence, including:
Functional incontinence: You have urine control but can’t get to a restroom in time, usually due to a mental or physical condition. For example, if you have arthritis, it’s hard to unbutton your pants quickly.
Mixed incontinence: You experience more than one type of incontinence.
Overflow incontinence: You leak small amounts of urine when your bladder is overfilled and you feel like you can’t empty your bladder.
Stress incontinence: You lose urine while coughing, sneezing, laughing, walking, running or lifting heavy objects. You may also be moving in other ways that put pressure on your bladder.
Urge incontinence: You have frequent, uncontrollable urges to urinate and often can’t get to a restroom in time. Also known as overactive bladder, urge incontinence is common in people who have conditions such as diabetes, stroke, dementia, Parkinson’s disease and multiple sclerosis.
Most people assume bladder control issues come with aging. But bladders don’t shrink over time, and problems can happen at any age. Some common causes of urinary incontinence are:
Childbirth.
Enlarged prostate. In men, stress incontinence or urge incontinence can be associated with untreated prostate cancer. But more often, incontinence is a side effect of prostate cancer treatments.
Menopause.
Obesity.
Poor nutrition.
Pregnancies.
Weakening muscles that control the bladder valve.
content.treatment:
Personalized Treatment for Your Urinary Issue
Urinary issues should never affect your daily activities. When they do, it’s time to get treatment. Our experts will help you create a treatment plan that’s just right for you. Treatment choices range from minimally invasive therapies to traditional surgery.
Lifestyle Changes
Your ProMedica care team is specially trained to help you manage your urinary incontinence in a way that fits your life best. If you aren’t ready to consider surgery, there are many steps you can take to manage your symptoms on a daily basis. We’re here to help, which includes everything from creating an exercise program to strengthen your pelvic floor, to finding ways to balance your diet for optimal health.
Medication
Many incontinence problems can be improved with special pelvic floor therapy or medicine. Medical options include exercises, stimulation and biofeedback, injections and custom-fit devices you can use in the comfort of your own home.
Non-Invasive Medical Therapies
There are many ways our expert team can treat your urinary conditions, including biofeedback, stimulation and more.
Surgery
Sometimes surgery is the best choice. If you need surgery to get back to living your best life, our urologists and urogynecologists will use the most advanced and least invasive surgical methods so you can recover faster and have better results.

It can be embarrassing for women to talk about, but incontinence issues can really affect your quality of life.

content.articleContent:
Understanding UTIs
Urinary tract infections or UTIs are infections in any part of the urinary tract. They are a common health problem that affects millions of people each year. Women are especially prone to UTIs.
Treating Urinary Tract Infections
Our providers will figure out the best treatment for your UTI based on:
How old you are
Your overall health and past health
How sick you are
How well you can handle specific medicines, procedures, or therapies
How long the condition is expected to last
Your opinion or preference
Treatment for UTIs may include:
Antibiotics
Other medicines to ease pain
Heat (such as heating pad) to ease pain
Our providers provide safe, effective UTI treatment to thousands of patients each year.

content.articleContent:
Compassionate Care for Sensitive Issues
Talking with a doctor about a urology condition like incontinence or urinary tract infection (UTI) can be hard. It feels personal. But you can rest easy knowing that thousands of patients visit us each year for compassionate urologic care.
With expertise in both male and female conditions, including kidney stones, cancer, vasectomies and bladder issues, we’re here to help you feel comfortable — and whole again.
We’re northwest Ohio’s only full-service urology center.
content.approach:
Our Approach
Providing urologic care throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan, our urology specialists are highly skilled, having completed training at some of the leading urologic institutions in the country.
With a full range of services to diagnose, manage and treat your urologic condition, you can count on our team to help improve your quality of life with personalized care and leading-edge innovation.
But even more importantly, at ProMedica we know that truly caring for you or your loved one extends beyond treating a physical condition. That’s why when you’re in our care, we’ll treat you like family.
content.maleUrology:
Male Urology Health
Our board-certified urology experts treat men of all ages who are having urologic problems. Using the latest technology and treatments, we deliver complete, high-quality care. You can have peace of mind knowing that ProMedica is northwest Ohio’s leader in advanced care for male urologic disorders.
Birth Control
Approximately 500,000 men request vasectomies each year, and no other urology group in northwest Ohio performs more. Learn more about vasectomies.
Bladder Control
Aging isn’t always the cause of bladder control problems, urinary incontinence or a shrinking bladder. We can help you understand the cause of your condition, so you can find effective treatment.
Incontinence
Incontinence can be troubling. It can also be a side effect of prostate cancer treatment. You’ll find a variety of treatments ranging from noninvasive to surgical that we can offer. We can help you improve your condition and stop worrying.
Infertility
About 15% of couples can’t get pregnant during their first year of trying. In about half of those cases, the reason is male infertility. Nearly 2 million men are diagnosed with infertility every year in the U.S. That’s one in 136 men. Our Male Infertility Clinic is led by experts in male infertility who can help you find a solution.
Prostate Health
Most prostate diseases aren’t cancerous or life threatening. Still, they’re uncomfortable and inconvenient. The two main benign prostate diseases are prostatitis and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), or an enlarged prostate. Both can be treated to improve your quality of life. Treatment options include oral medicines, minimally invasive procedures and new surgical methods.
Sexual and Erectile Dysfunction
You may feel embarrassed to talk about erectile dysfunction or urinary problems. And we understand. But since these problems are easily treatable, we hope that you’ll trust us with your concerns. Today’s technology and treatment choices are very effective for curing urinary incontinence, sexual dysfunction and an enlarged prostate. Don’t suffer in silence or be forced to live your life differently. Let us help.
content.urologicCancer:
Urological Cancer
Our doctors combine skill and innovation to treat urologic cancers and support you and your family during your treatment journey. In fact, we can diagnose and treat most forms of cancer right here at our main office.
You’ll receive the most advanced urinary cancer care in the area. You can have an in-office diagnosis along with the added convenience of onsite prostate screening and biopsy. We have our own board-certified urologic pathologist to evaluate biopsy specimens.
Bladder Cancer
Treatment for bladder cancer varies by how far along it has advanced in the bladder, and also depends on your age and overall health. Treatment can include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation and immunotherapy. And, in some cases, we’ll combine treatments for the best results.
Kidney Cancer
Kidney or upper tract cancer can develop into other types of cancer. Surgery is usually needed to treat kidney cancer. We offer a wide range of methods to successfully remove the cancerous areas.
Prostate Cancer
Prostate cancer is among the most common cancers in men, but it can be treated effectively if it’s caught early. That’s why regular screening for men over 50 is so important. While diagnosed cases have risen rapidly, mortality rates are dropping, in part because more men are aware of their need for screening.
We can treat prostate cancer with brachytherapy (radiation), cryotherapy (extreme cold) or robotic surgery.
Testicular Cancer
Testicular cancer is treated successfully in more than 95% of all cases. Treatment depends on the stage and tumor type and may need radiation, chemotherapy or surgical lymph node removal. Onsite imaging with ultrasound and CT scanning can help us find the right treatment for you. Surgery can be performed quickly (if needed) at our ambulatory surgery center.

locations.imageAlt: ProMedica Defiance Regional Hospital - Surgery Center
locations.name: PROMEDICA DEFIANCE REGIONAL HOSPITAL - SURGERY CENTER

content.articleContent:
Advanced Valve Surgery Techniques to Restore Your Heart Health
Valve surgery is one of the most common treatments for valve disease. But when you’re faced with having a valve replaced or repaired it can feel far from ordinary. At ProMedica, we apply our research-driven approach to advanced heart surgery methods. These include traditional open-heart surgery and minimally invasive procedures to help restore your heart health.
content.beforeAfter:
What to Expect Before and After Heart Valve Surgery
Knowing What to Expect Helps You Prepare for Optimal Results
Your first step towards healing is to schedule your pre-surgery consultation. During this appointment, you’ll meet with your surgeon to learn what pre-admission testing you need to have. This could include blood work, a chest X-ray, an EKG, dental work and an exam of the arteries in your neck.
If you need surgery, you’ll receive detailed instructions that could include starting a new medicine or stopping current ones.
During this conversation, you’ll also have a chance to ask questions. It’s important to learn about the procedure and how you’ll manage your health when it’s over. If you have questions, ask them — doing so will help you take better care of yourself.
You can start by asking your doctor:
How quickly will I recover?
What are the pros and cons of each type of valve surgery?
What kind of lifestyle changes will I have to make after surgery?
Will I need care or rehab after my surgery?
Post-Surgical Care That Puts You on the Path to Recovery
Heart valve surgery is an in-depth procedure and requires several days of recovery at the hospital. Most patients are able to go home on the third or fourth day after surgery. Here’s what to expect:
You’ll have several tubes inserted and will be connected to monitoring equipment during and after surgery.
Your care team will provide updates to your family during your surgery and as you move into recovery.
After surgery, you’ll be taken to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) to recover.
You’ll consume meals while sitting up in a chair (starting with a clear liquid diet and slowly adding solid food as tolerated).
You may be moved to the step-down floor on the first postoperative day.
You’ll begin taking short walks in the hallway and start some cardiac rehab therapy exercises.

content.articleContent:
Give Your Body the Blood Flow It Needs
Vascular disease prevents your body from getting the blood flow it needs to work properly. With symptoms that can be hard to recognize, it’s important to know your risks and get a screening for vascular disease if needed. Early and effective treatment is the best way to lower your chance of serious complications.
content.approach:
Our Approach
With coordinated services that include vascular disease prevention, management, emergency care and vascular surgery — and with locations across the Toledo region — our team works hard to deliver world-class care, close to home.
You can count on the board-certified specialists at Jobst Vascular Institute for the most advanced technologies in vascular health. Bringing you today’s most promising treatments, so you can get back to the life you love, is our pleasure.
Improving Your Circulatory System
Our vascular medicine specialists help care for your circulatory system outside of your heart. This includes your arteries, veins and lymphatic system:
Arteries: The blood vessels that carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to the body.
Veins: Blood vessels that carry blood from the body back into the heart.
Lymphatic system: A network of vessels throughout the body that drains lymph fluid from tissues to maintain fluid balance and to clear byproducts of inflammation.
content.conditions:
Understanding Vascular Disease
Vascular disease describes a range of different diseases of your circulatory system, including conditions that affect your arteries, veins and lymph vessels and blood disorders that affect circulation.
Many forms of vascular disease are caused by atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries), which happens when fat and cholesterol plaque build up and cause blockages in your arteries.
Some of the most common vascular diseases include:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm.
Carotid artery disease.
Deep vein thrombosis.
Peripheral artery disease.
Varicose and spider veins.
The Effects of Vascular Disease
There are many different causes of the various types of vascular conditions and diseases. However, coronary artery disease (heart attack and chest pain), cerebrovascular disease (stroke), and peripheral arterial disease (loss of limb or use of limb) are some of the leading causes of illness and death in the United States.
Know Your Risk Factors
Certain health conditions and lifestyle choices can raise your risk for vascular disease. Talk to your doctor about your chance of developing vascular disease if:
You have diabetes.
You have high blood pressure.
You have high cholesterol.
You smoke.
You’re overweight.
You’re inactive.
You have a family history of vascular disease.
You have high stress levels.
Lower Your Risk
With vascular disease, knowledge is power. If you understand your risks, you can improve your vascular health and lower your chances of having vascular problems.
Here are simple steps you can take to support your goal of better vascular health:
Eat smart: Choose foods rich in good fats and nutrients.
Know your history: Get familiar with your family’s health history and share it with your doctor.
Limit your stress: Make time to do things that are calming and spend time with people who support you.
Stop smoking: Sign up for a smoking cessation program if you need extra support.
content.treatment:
Diagnosing and Treating Vascular Disease
Get a Fast and Accurate Diagnosis
Your vascular specialist at Jobst Vascular Institute will use state-of-the-art diagnostic tests to pinpoint your condition quickly and accurately, so you can decide on the most effective treatment. These tests include:
Cardiac CT (computerized tomography scan).
Cardiac functioning tests.
Cardiac MRI (magnetic resonance imaging).
Coronary angiography.
CT angiography.
Echocardiogram.
Electrocardiogram.
MRA.
Segmental pressure and pulse volume recording.
Stress echocardiography.
Vascular ultrasound.
Find Effective Treatment
Our vascular providers specialize in vascular disease, medicines, treatment and surgery. Their team will work with you to decide on your best personal treatment plan, which may include procedures and support services such as:
Angioplasty, stents or atherectomy.
Anticoagulation treatments.
Artery repair.
Bypass grafts.
Dialysis.
Endarterectomy.
Medical management.
Open and minimally invasive repair of aneurysms in the body.
TAVR (transcathetar aortic valve replacement).
Varicose and spider vein treatments.
Wound care.

content.articleContent:
About the Vascular Lab
After a provider takes a detailed medical history and completes a physical exam, testing in a vascular laboratory is often the next step in diagnosing your vascular disease. Jobst Vascular Institute’s accredited vascular laboratory performs more than 30,000 studies each year, including many vascular ultrasounds.
These studies help your doctor understand what’s going on with your circulatory system. That body system includes the blood vessels outside of your heart, which carry blood to parts of your body like your brain, abdomen and extremities.
Who performs vascular lab tests?
Our highly dedicated, well-trained and credentialed vascular technologists will do all that they can to make you feel comfortable during your visit to our vascular lab. We are very proud of our vascular testing accreditation through the Intersocietal Accreditation Commission. It’s one more way to show you how we ensure excellent, quality testing for you.
Also good to know: The tests, including vascular ultrasounds, in our labs are non-invasive. That means there’s no need to insert an instrument or device through your skin or into your body. There is also no exposure to radiation because we use sound waves. 
Once completed, all of our studies are reviewed by one of our board-certified vascular physicians.
Jobst Vascular Laboratory is also an education site for local vascular ultrasound training programs including: Owens Community College and Jackson College.
Call us today at 1-800-39-JOBST (56278) to schedule an appointment.
What kinds of vascular studies are offered?
Jobst Vascular Laboratory is a full-service laboratory that provides many different types of state-of-the-art diagnostic tests. But vascular ultrasound is the most important tool in our lab and the one we use the most.
A duplex vascular ultrasound uses sound waves to take pictures of your vessels and a Doppler to listen to blood flow through your arteries and veins. The exam is painless and easy for you. But it provides invaluable information for your physician.
Studies performed in our vascular lab include:
Cerebrovascular studies of the blood flow to the brain: Carotid artery duplex, transcranial artery Doppler (TCD)
Venous: DVT (deep venous thrombosis), CVI (chronic venous insufficiency)
Arterial studies to determine the amount of blood flow in your arms and legs: ankle-brachial Index (ABI), pulse volume recording (PVR), segmental pressures, duplex scan graft surveillance
Abdominal studies to check the blood flow in the arteries and veins in the abdominal cavity: ultrasound of the inferior vena cava, aorta, kidney and visceral arteries
Where are your labs located?
We have several vascular labs in convenient ProMedica locations across northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.Each of these locations provides vascular ultraound services.

title: Varicose Veins and Spider Veins | ProMedica

content.articleContent:
Say Hello to Healthy Legs
Uncomfortable and sometimes unsightly, varicose and spider veins can make you feel like you need to hide your legs. But the good news is that both are treatable. The first step is knowing how to tell the difference between these common, but often confused, conditions.
ProMedica Jobst Vascular Institute Vein Care brings together an experienced and specialized team. These providers diagnose and treat varicose veins and spider veins, as well as vascular birthmarks.
As Northwest Ohio's largest group of board-certified vascular surgeons, vascular medicine specialists and advanced practice providers, we’re trained in all aspects of vascular disease. In our vein clinic, we use the latest technologies so we can identify not only the surface problem, but its underlying causes.
Schedule evaluation with one of our vein specialists.
Contact Us
content.conditions:
Understanding Your Veins
Varicose Veins
Varicose veins are enlarged, twisted and weakened blood veins. They can happen anywhere on the body but are most common in the legs. Although they're deeper under the skin than spider veins, they appear as bulging veins raised above the skin.
While not life threatening, varicose veins can make you feel self-conscious. They can also lead to more serious vein diseases and cause vein pain, such as:
A venous stasis ulcer, which forms when there isn’t proper drainage in the enlarged vein.
Phlebitis, an inflammation of the vein.
Thrombosis, a blood clot that forms in an enlarged vein.
Knowing Your Risk Factors
While some risk factors are out of your control, there are some steps you can take to prevent the development of varicose veins. Knowing which risk factors apply to you can go a long way in helping you prevent or manage the condition. Risk factors for varicose veins include:
Age.
Being overweight.
Being a woman.
Not being physically active.
Genes.
Pregnancy.
Smoking.
Taking oral contraceptives or hormone replacement.
How to Prevent Varicose Veins
Maintaining a healthy weight and exercising regularly can help stop varicose veins from forming. Other ways to prevent them include:
Putting up your feet while sitting.
Uncrossing your legs while sitting.
Wearing compression stockings.
Spider Veins
Spider veins are a milder condition caused by the dilation (expansion) of a small group of blood vessels near the surface of your skin. They often look like a sunburst or “spider web,” are red or blue in color and are often found on the face and legs.
At this time, no one knows what causes spider veins. However, contributing factors include age, heredity, hormonal changes and pregnancy.
content.treatment:
Diagnosis and Treatment
Diagnosis of Varicose and Spider Veins
Before your vascular specialist selects the best treatment option for you, they will perform a complete medical history and physical exam. Also, you may have one of the following diagnostic tests:
Duplex Ultrasound
An ultrasound that checks the blood flow and structure of your veins.
Color-flow Imaging
Also called a triplex ultrasound, this procedure is similar to a duplex ultrasound in that is uses color to show the direction of blood flow.
Magnetic Resonance Venography (MRV)
MRV uses a combination of large magnets and a computer to view your veins. During this test, a dye is injected into your veins for a better view.
Find Vein Treatment That's Right for You
We offer both cosmetic and therapeutic treatments for varicose veins, spider veins and other venous-related conditions. Your vascular specialist will work with you to decide which treatments best fit your condition and your lifestyle.
Non-Surgical Treatments
Compression stockings: elastic stockings that squeeze your veins and prevent blood from pooling. They’re proven to work when worn daily.
Minimally Invasive Options
Sclerotherapy: the most common treatment for spider and varicose veins. A concentrated saline solution is injected into the veins and then hardens. This causes the veins to close and collapse. Over time, healthy blood vessels will absorb the blood flow.
Endovenous laser ablation: removes veins using high-intensity laser beams or intense pulsating light that’s guided by an ultrasound.
Phlebectomy: removes your veins using tiny punctures or incisions (cuts) along the path of the vein. Your surgeon then uses a phlebectomy hook (similar to a tiny crochet hook) to remove your veins through these small incisions.
Radiofrequency closure ablations: a treatment that can be used instead of vein stripping. A thin catheter is inserted into the vein through a small opening using a single needle stick. The catheter delivers radio frequency energy to the vein, which causes it to heat, collapse and seal shut. Over time, other healthy veins will take over.
VenaSeal™ closure system: a new, minimally invasive procedure that uses an advanced medical adhesive to close the diseased vein. VenaSeal™ is designed to minimize patient discomfort and recovery time. It offers many benefits to the patient including no need for anesthesia or compression stockings after the procedure.
Clarivein®: a cathether based treatment that uses a rotating tip to disperse medicine and close damaged veins.
Varithena®: a cathether based treatment that injects foam into the diseased vein causing it to close or collapse.
Surgical Options
Vein stripping: an incision is made in your skin to remove or tie off the blood vessel.

content.articleContent:
Your vascular team offers expert care that’s close to home.
When you or a loved one needs treatment for a vascular problem, you want to spend your time getting healthy. You don’t want to travel here and there visiting specialists. With Jobst Vascular Institute, you’ll have expert care right where you live.
Jobst Vascular Institute offers you access to world-class vascular care that’s close to home. You may live in northwest Ohio or southeast Michigan — no matter which region it is, your skilled specialists will be by your side.
Rest easy when you visit a ProMedica specialist. Our network will help coordinate every part of your treatment. Whether you need testing, medical treatment or surgery, you can expect well-connected care.
Learn more about our vascular services.
View our 2021 annual report
content.approach:
Our Approach
When you come to ProMedica for vascular services, you can expect doctors to care for you with compassion. They’re also dedicated to high-quality patient care. Our team includes specialists who are board-certified in vascular medicine and vascular surgery.
ProMedica doctors and specialists are also working to improve the field of vascular medicine. Many of our team members contribute to vascular care through research studies and scientific and professional publications.
Vascular medicine specialists who provide nonsurgical treatments for vascular conditions.
Vascular surgeons who are trained in minimally invasive and reconstructive procedures.
Wound care specialists who treat hard-to-heal wounds.
Jobst Vascular Institute
The Jobst Vascular Institute is a group of medical experts who focus on making sure patients receive high-quality, personal vascular care.
Our vascular specialists and researchers use today’s most advanced technology. This allows our patients to receive world-class vascular care close to home.
Learn more about Jobst Vascular Institute
content.services:
Our Services
The vascular system, also called the circulatory system, is the body’s network of blood vessels. It includes veins and arteries that carry blood and other fluid all through the body.
Vascular disease is a condition that blocks or weakens blood vessels. When blood vessels are narrow or blocked, blood can’t flow easily through the body. This can damage organs or other parts of the body.
Vascular Conditions
At Jobst Vascular Institute, you’ll find experts who can help diagnose and treat many vascular diseases, including:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An abdominal aortic aneurysm happens when a part of the aorta weakens and then expands. The aorta is the main artery in the body that carries blood away from your heart to the rest of your body.
Carotid artery disease. This is a condition where blood vessels in the neck narrow. The narrowing is usually caused by a buildup of cholesterol in the blood vessels.
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Deep vein thrombosis happens when a blood clot forms in a vein deep inside your body. The clot usually forms in the leg.
Peripheral artery disease (PAD). This condition happens when your arteries narrow and reduce blood flow to your arms and legs.
Varicose and spider veins. Varicose veins are large, swollen veins that you can see through the skin. They usually form in the legs. Spider veins are small red, purple or blue veins that you can also see through the skin.
Diagnostic Services
If your doctor thinks you may have a vascular problem, you’ll need vascular testing. At Jobst Vascular Labs, our specialists use advanced testing. This provides accurate results, so your care team can design the best treatment plan for you.
Vascular testing usually includes a vascular ultrasound. This painless test uses high-frequency sound waves to create pictures of arteries and veins. A vascular ultrasound may be done on the neck, abdomen, legs, arms, feet or hands.
Find a vascular lab near you.
Treatment Services
ProMedica vascular experts are building a healthier tomorrow for you and your family. Our network of specialists provides high-quality care at all of our hospitals, physician offices and outpatient facilities. You’ll find them throughout northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
Anticoagulation Services
The clinical pharmacists at Jobst Medication Therapy Management teach you how to manage your medicine. They’ll answer any of your questions, too.
Learn More
Diabetes Services
Learn how to optimize your diabetes medicines with the Jobst Medication Therapy Management pharmacists and your doctor.
Learn More
Physician Offices
Wherever you need vascular care, ProMedica is there for you. You’ll find vascular physician offices in convenient locations all over northwest Ohio and southeast Michigan.
Find a ProMedica vascular physician office near you.
Vascular Medicine
Some vascular conditions can be treated with nonsurgical therapies. These may include medicine and lifestyle changes. At ProMedica, we have a team of board-certified vascular medicine specialists. Their goal is to provide expert care to help you manage your disease.
Find a vascular medicine physician.
Vascular Surgery
If your vascular condition needs surgery, ProMedica’s board-certified vascular surgeons specialize in a wide range of procedures. Perhaps you need minimally invasive treatment or reconstructive surgery. Whatever your need, you’ll find expert surgical care close to home.
Learn More
Vein Care
Are you suffering from the discomfort of varicose veins or feeling self-conscious about spider veins? We’ll find an effective treatment that fits your needs.
Learn More
Wound Care
Some vascular conditions may cause wounds, blisters and cuts. These may heal slowly or not at all. With ProMedica’s network of vascular specialists, you can find expert wound care close to home.
Learn More

content.articleContent:
About Vascular Surgery
With the largest group of board-certified and fellowship-trained vascular surgeons in the area, the team at Jobst Vascular Institute stands ready to provide the high quality vascular surgery care at ProMedica Toledo Hospital and other ProMedica locations.
What is vascular surgery?
Vascular surgery focuses on the surgical treatment of disease in your circulatory system outside of your heart and brain. This includes your arteries, veins and lymphatic system:
Arteries: Blood vessels that carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to the body.
Veins: Blood vessels that carry blood from the body back into the heart.
Lymphatic system: A network of vessels throughout the body that drains lymph fluid from tissues to maintain fluid balance and to clear byproducts of inflammation.
What vascular diseases do you treat?
Our vascular surgeons treat and manage acute and chronic vascular diseases including:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm
Atherosclerosis
Blood clotting disorders
Carotid artery stenosis
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism
Dialysis access for patients with kidney disease
Lymphedema
Peripheral artery disease (PAD)
Spider and varicose veins
Swollen legs
Venous and lymphatic diseases
Venous ulcers
Wound care
Call us today at 1-800-39-JOBST (56278) to schedule an appointment.
What vascular surgery services are available?
Vascular surgery for vascular disease may be required and includes both open and endovascular repair:
Angioplasty and stenting for peripheral artery disease (PAD)
Arteriovenous Fistula formation
Atherectomy for peripheral artery disease (PAD)
Carotid angioplasty and stenting
Carotid endarterectomy
Dialysis access
Endovascular repair of aortic aneurysm
Endovenectomy
Open bypass for peripheral artery disease (PAD)
Open repair of aortic aneurysm
Thrombolysis for extensive deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
Wound debridement
When is vascular surgery recommended?
If the doctor suspects that a person may have decreased blood flow somewhere in the peripheral (arms, legs, and/or neck) circulation, vascular studies may be performed. Using these studies and other information, the surgeon will decide on the best course of treatment for the patient.

Vascular Neurology at ProMedica Toledo Hospital
At ProMedica Toledo Hospital, expect only the best in vascular neurological services. Our highly-trained, specialized physicians provide care in a state-of-the-art, 20-bed stroke unit with a neuro-interventional lab. The facility features private rooms, a portable CT scanner, 24-hour MRI service, and nursing staff specifically trained in caring for people with complex neurological conditions.
Our vascular neurological services are offered throughout Toledo Hospital and coordinated by your physician specialist.
Conditions and diseases treated:
Aneurysms
Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs): including spinal AVMs
Dural arteriovenous fistulas (DAVF)
Hemorrhagic strokes: including subarachnoid hemorrhages and intracerebral hemorrhages
Ischemic strokes: including thrombotic strokes, embolic strokes
Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)
Procedures and treatments performed:
Aneurysm treatment: coil embolization, pipeline flow diversion device, surgical clipping
Angioplasty
Carotid artery stenting
Carotid endarterectomy
Clot busters: tPA; including intra-arterial tPA
Clot Evacuation
Hemicraniectomy
Mechanical thrombectomy
Nasal embolization
Tumor embolization
Ventriculostomy or External Ventricular Drain (EVD)
Testing available:
Carotid ultrasound
Cerebral angiography
CT
CTA
CT Perfusion
Echocardiogram: transthoracic, transesophageal
MRI
MRA
MRV
Transcranial doppler
WADA testing

What Is a Vasectomy?
A vasectomy is a permanent and effective form of birth control for men. During the procedure, your vas deferens, the tube that carries sperm from your testes, is cut and sealed. This blocks sperm from reaching semen so that, when ejaculated, it cannot get a woman pregnant.
The procedure typically takes 20-30 minutes and is safe with few side effects. Usually within a couple of days, you’re feeling better and back to your normal routine.
Call 1-844-855-TEAM for a consultation.
Types of Vasectomies
Two most common types include:
Conventional vasectomy. During this more traditional method, small cuts are made on each side of the scrotum to reach the vas deferens, which are cut, tied or fastened with a metal clip.
No scalpel vasectomy. This newer, more modern method is done through one tiny hole in the skin. A tool is used to gently stretch the skin opening so that the vas deferens can be reached. Because no cuts are made, there is little bleeding. It heals quickly with little or no scarring.
Debunking the Myths about Vasectomy
It’s normal to have questions and concerns about a vasectomy, but sometimes myths about the procedure can lead to unfounded concerns. Here’s the truth about vasectomies. A vasectomy:
Won’t affect your sexual performance. A vasectomy won’t affect your sex drive or your masculinity in any way other than preventing you from fathering a child. Men have even reported higher sexual satisfaction after a vasectomy.
Is safe for your sexual organs. There's very little risk that your testicles, penis or other parts of your reproductive system will be injured during surgery.
Doesn't increase your risk of certain cancersAlthough there have been some concerns about a possible link between having a vasectomy and getting testicular or prostate cancer in the past, there's no proven link.
Doesn’t increase your risk of heart disease. As with cancer fears, there doesn't appear to be any link between vasectomy and heart problems.
Causes minor, not severe, pain. You might feel minor pain and pulling or tugging during surgery, but severe pain is rare. Likewise, after surgery you might have some pain, but for most men the pain is minor and goes away after a few days.
ProMedica Vasectomy FAQs
Is a vasectomy right for me?
Choosing a vasectomy as a form of birth control is a major decision. You should be 100% sure that it is the right decision for you before undergoing this procedure. You and your partner should talk about the decision to not have any more children. Having a vasectomy may be a good choice if:
You are an adult male and you are either done having children or don’t want to have children.
You are in a stable relationship and both partners agree to permanent birth control.
Pregnancy would be a health risk for your partner.
You or your partner has a genetic disorder that you don’t want to pass on to a child.
To learn more about a vasectomy and ask questions to determine if it is right for you, schedule a consultation with one of our board-certified urologists.
How do I prepare for a vasectomy?
It is important that you share your medical history with the doctor; include information about drugs (both prescription and over-the-counter), as well as supplements, you are taking. Be sure to tell your doctor about any drug allergies or bleeding conditions you have.
Your physician will tell you about any specific things you need to do (and know) to get ready for your procedure. Follow directions and recommendations as explained during the consultation. Wear comfortable, close-fitting underwear. It is recommended that you bring someone to drive you home after the procedure.
What happens during a vasectomy?
This procedure is most often done in our outpatient surgery center. Your vasectomy will most often be done under local anesthesia, but sedation is available for those who need it. The area will be numbed, but typically you will be awake. It takes about 20 - 30 minutes to complete the procedure.
Generally, here’s what happens during a vasectomy:
You will be asked to remove any jewelry or other objects that might get in the way during the procedure.
You will remove your clothing and put on a hospital gown.
You will be asked to empty your bladder.
You will lie on your back on an exam table.
Your scrotum may be shaved and cleaned with an antiseptic solution or special soap.
The surgeon will inject a numbing medicine into your scrotum.
The doctor will make either a small cut or opening on one side of your scrotum to find the vas deferens, which will be cut, tied or fastened with a metal clip. The site is closed and a bandage applied. The procedure is repeated on the other side of the scrotum to block the second vas deferens.
In many cases, both vas deferens can be reached through the same hole.
In some cases, small stitches or skin glue may be used to close the cuts.
What happens after a vasectomy?
You will likely be able to go home soon after surgery. The staff will watch you closely and the doctor may give you pain medication. You may be told to use an ice pack for the first day to reduce pain and swelling. Here is what you may expect during recovery:
Rest at home the day after surgery. Don't do any strenuous activity. Avoid standing or walking too long.
Depending on the type of work you do, you may be able to go back in 1 to 3 days.
You should be able to return to most activities in a week, but avoid heavy lifting and hard exercise for up to 1 to 3 weeks.
You may need to wear a jock strap for a few days.
You should not bathe or swim until 1 to 2 days after your vasectomy.
You may be able to return to sexual activity in about a week, but you should continue to use another form of birth control until the doctor tests the semen to be sure there are no sperm left. This test is often performed about two months after surgery. It is important to know that vasectomies will occasionally fail and checking semen samples afterwards to confirm sterility is strongly recommended.
Vasectomy is very safe, but all surgeries carry some risks. Tell your doctor if you have any of the following:
A lump in your scrotum
Any drainage, bleeding, redness, or swelling
Fever
Chills
Increasing pain or pain that is not eased by medicine
Trouble passing urine
Bleeding disorders
Can I have my vasectomy reversed?
Possibly. Some vasectomies may be reversed, but the process can be more difficult than the actual vasectomy, isn’t always successful and can be expensive. Many insurance providers do not cover reversals.

title: Varicose Veins and Spider Veins | ProMedica

content.articleContent:
Say Hello to Healthy Legs
Uncomfortable and sometimes unsightly, varicose and spider veins can make you feel like you need to hide your legs. But the good news is that both are treatable. The first step is knowing how to tell the difference between these common, but often confused, conditions.
ProMedica Jobst Vascular Institute Vein Care brings together an experienced and specialized team. These providers diagnose and treat varicose veins and spider veins, as well as vascular birthmarks.
As Northwest Ohio's largest group of board-certified vascular surgeons, vascular medicine specialists and advanced practice providers, we’re trained in all aspects of vascular disease. In our vein clinic, we use the latest technologies so we can identify not only the surface problem, but its underlying causes.
Schedule evaluation with one of our vein specialists.
Contact Us
content.conditions:
Understanding Your Veins
Varicose Veins
Varicose veins are enlarged, twisted and weakened blood veins. They can happen anywhere on the body but are most common in the legs. Although they're deeper under the skin than spider veins, they appear as bulging veins raised above the skin.
While not life threatening, varicose veins can make you feel self-conscious. They can also lead to more serious vein diseases and cause vein pain, such as:
A venous stasis ulcer, which forms when there isn’t proper drainage in the enlarged vein.
Phlebitis, an inflammation of the vein.
Thrombosis, a blood clot that forms in an enlarged vein.
Knowing Your Risk Factors
While some risk factors are out of your control, there are some steps you can take to prevent the development of varicose veins. Knowing which risk factors apply to you can go a long way in helping you prevent or manage the condition. Risk factors for varicose veins include:
Age.
Being overweight.
Being a woman.
Not being physically active.
Genes.
Pregnancy.
Smoking.
Taking oral contraceptives or hormone replacement.
How to Prevent Varicose Veins
Maintaining a healthy weight and exercising regularly can help stop varicose veins from forming. Other ways to prevent them include:
Putting up your feet while sitting.
Uncrossing your legs while sitting.
Wearing compression stockings.
Spider Veins
Spider veins are a milder condition caused by the dilation (expansion) of a small group of blood vessels near the surface of your skin. They often look like a sunburst or “spider web,” are red or blue in color and are often found on the face and legs.
At this time, no one knows what causes spider veins. However, contributing factors include age, heredity, hormonal changes and pregnancy.
content.treatment:
Diagnosis and Treatment
Diagnosis of Varicose and Spider Veins
Before your vascular specialist selects the best treatment option for you, they will perform a complete medical history and physical exam. Also, you may have one of the following diagnostic tests:
Duplex Ultrasound
An ultrasound that checks the blood flow and structure of your veins.
Color-flow Imaging
Also called a triplex ultrasound, this procedure is similar to a duplex ultrasound in that is uses color to show the direction of blood flow.
Magnetic Resonance Venography (MRV)
MRV uses a combination of large magnets and a computer to view your veins. During this test, a dye is injected into your veins for a better view.
Find Vein Treatment That's Right for You
We offer both cosmetic and therapeutic treatments for varicose veins, spider veins and other venous-related conditions. Your vascular specialist will work with you to decide which treatments best fit your condition and your lifestyle.
Non-Surgical Treatments
Compression stockings: elastic stockings that squeeze your veins and prevent blood from pooling. They’re proven to work when worn daily.
Minimally Invasive Options
Sclerotherapy: the most common treatment for spider and varicose veins. A concentrated saline solution is injected into the veins and then hardens. This causes the veins to close and collapse. Over time, healthy blood vessels will absorb the blood flow.
Endovenous laser ablation: removes veins using high-intensity laser beams or intense pulsating light that’s guided by an ultrasound.
Phlebectomy: removes your veins using tiny punctures or incisions (cuts) along the path of the vein. Your surgeon then uses a phlebectomy hook (similar to a tiny crochet hook) to remove your veins through these small incisions.
Radiofrequency closure ablations: a treatment that can be used instead of vein stripping. A thin catheter is inserted into the vein through a small opening using a single needle stick. The catheter delivers radio frequency energy to the vein, which causes it to heat, collapse and seal shut. Over time, other healthy veins will take over.
VenaSeal™ closure system: a new, minimally invasive procedure that uses an advanced medical adhesive to close the diseased vein. VenaSeal™ is designed to minimize patient discomfort and recovery time. It offers many benefits to the patient including no need for anesthesia or compression stockings after the procedure.
Clarivein®: a cathether based treatment that uses a rotating tip to disperse medicine and close damaged veins.
Varithena®: a cathether based treatment that injects foam into the diseased vein causing it to close or collapse.
Surgical Options
Vein stripping: an incision is made in your skin to remove or tie off the blood vessel.

Ready to lose weight? We’ll take the journey with you.
Losing weight can seem like an uphill climb, especially if you’ve been on that hill before. At ProMedica, we can give you the structure and support you need to reach your goal. Learn more about our options and find the right fit for you.
content.scaleDown:
ProMedica Scale Down® Weight Management Program
ProMedica Scale Down® helps you lose weight by combining structured diets, physical activity and lifestyle changes. And you’ll also have a long-term maintenance plan to keep the weight off.
Our plan is not a quick fix. Instead, it’s based on a nationally recognized program called HMR® Weight Management. We offer low-calorie meal replacements along with weekly support from health care professionals.
With the most comprehensive medical weight-loss system in the area, you and your physician can choose one of three diets to make sure you have the program that fits your needs. We’ll be with you every step of the way as you watch the numbers on the scale go down.

content.articleContent:
Care for Life
You have so much to do in this life. And great health care helps your body keep up with you. Our women’s health programs are designed to support you with personalized preventive, ongoing and — when you need it — acute, or short-term, care. You’ll be ready to meet life’s challenges and go for your goals.
Learn more about women's services.
View our 2021 annual report
content.services:
Complete Care for Women at Every Stage of Life
Starting at birth through puberty, motherhood, menopause and beyond, women need health care that addresses their bodies’ nuances and their lives. Here, you’ll find healthcare providers who listen to your needs and concerns to provide expert care that supports your health and your life goals.
Breast Cancer Treatment
It can feel overwhelming when you find something suspicious in your breast. You’ll gain confidence to face cancer with help from ProMedica’s multidisciplinary cancer care teams. Known as the region’s leading experts in breast cancer care, they have access to the most current research and technology in the field.
Learn More
Digital Mammography
Early detection is vital to the fight against breast cancer. Digital mammography creates higher-resolution images. It also allows for images to be manipulated to give you more accurate results. This also reduces the need for retakes, which means a quicker mammogram for you.
Learn More
Gynecologic Care
Women’s lives are diverse and complex. That’s why our gynecologists focus on your specific needs. Starting at puberty, you’ll receive reproductive health care that’s personalized to your age, your health and your life choices. We’re here to help you stay healthy all through your life.
We’re also here for your daughter. We offer advice on how to talk with her about safe sex and also provide immunizations to protect her from sexually transmitted diseases — so you can both stay healthy.
Learn More
Maternity Care
When you’re pregnant, you’re caring for two. Our highly skilled obstetricians, gynecologists and pediatricians are here to support all of your maternity needs. We’ll make sure you and your baby have access to the best possible care during pregnancy, childbirth and postpartum.
Learn More
Midwife Support
Have you ever wished for a go-to expert on all things women’s health? Midwives are best known for their roles during pregnancy and childbirth, but a midwife offers specialized care throughout a woman’s life. You’ll have help with taking a holistic approach to health and well-being.
Learn More
High-Risk Pregnancy Care
When you or your baby are considered high-risk during pregnancy, you need compassionate and consistent care. Our multidisciplinary team of maternal-fetal medicine specialists provides expert care during a high-risk pregnancy. You’ll have our full attention as we help make sure you and your baby have the best possible outcome.
Learn More
Menopause Care
Every woman will go through menopause. While the side effects can be unpleasant, you can manage them. Our women’s health specialists can help you decide how best to manage your specific symptoms. These treatments may include lifestyle changes, supplements and hormone therapy.
Learn More
Pelvic Pain Treatment
Chronic pelvic pain can feel like it’s taking over every day. But you don’t have to let it define your life. Our network of specialists will work with each other and you to diagnose and treat your condition with precision, so you can return to life without pain.
Learn More
