content.articleContent:
Helping You Heal When You’re Hurting
Cuts and scrapes are part of our daily life. When a band-aid or over-the-counter cream won’t do the trick, you may have something more serious.
If you have a wound, you need to know how to take care of it. That’s why the expert team at ProMedica Wound Care is here for you with education and treatment to help you heal.
You’re an important part of your wound healing process.
content.services:
Services and Tools
Understanding Chronic Wounds

Wound Care for Seniors
Aging comes with more than its fair share of challenges, and taking care of stubborn wounds is one of them. You or the senior you care for may need help. That’s why we have wound care locations specifically for seniors with trained wound care specialists who understand seniors’ unique needs.
Wound Care for Diabetes
Whether you’ve been diagnosed or you’re caring for a loved one with diabetes, it’s important to understand how the disease can affect wound care.
Diabetes can lead to wounds and infections, including potentially dangerous foot ulcers. Watch the video below to learn more about diabetes-related wound care.

Wound Care Nutrition
For wounds to heal, your body needs good nutrition. A well-balanced diet that’s high in protein, vitamins and minerals is very important for healthy skin and growing new tissue.
If you can’t eat a normal diet or have dietary restrictions, please be sure to talk to your wound care team about it. Your nurse will discuss more details with you about your diet.
Watch the video below to learn more about wound care nutrition.

Fluids
Extra fluids are important for normal cell function and healing. Try to drink at least six to eight glasses of water, milk, juice or other fluids every day and limit alcohol and caffeinated beverages. Oral medications can be taken with a full glass of water.
Proteins
Protein is the building block for new cells and wound repair. It prevents muscle loss. Without enough protein, your body will pull protein from muscle tissue, making you weaker. Eat at least one serving of high protein food, like meat and dairy products, for every meal and snack. Adding protein powder or liquid to food or beverages is another great way to get enough protein.
Vitamins and Minerals
Your skin needs vitamins and minerals to heal. A diet rich in vitamin C, vitamin E and magnesium is important for the healing process. Your doctor may prescribe a daily vitamin and mineral supplement.
content.faq:
Frequently Asked Questions
What causes a wound?
Wounds can be caused by everyday accidents and injuries. These types of wounds are fairly routine and easy to care for. However, wounds caused by diabetes, poor circulation, pressure sores and other medical problems need expert treatment and care.
How can I get help?
Call ProMedica Wound Care at 1-800-39-JOBST (56278) to schedule an appointment. We’ll examine your wound and talk to you about your overall health. Wound healing can include removing damaged tissues, infection control, changes to your diet, and pressure relief. Our nurses will teach you to take care of your wounds at home, including how to bandage, clean and protect your wound so it can heal.
What do I need to do?
Follow your wound care instructions and let us know your questions and concerns. We need to know if things change between your visits with us. It’s important for you understand how to take care of your wounds and to be actively involved in the healing process.
Can my wound be treated in other ways?
Hyperbaric medicine is another clinically proven option for helping wounds heal more quickly with pure oxygen. Talk with your wound care provider to see if it’s a good choice for you.
content.yourVisit:
Before Your Wound Care Visit
Come prepared for your visit with lots of questions. We’re here to help you heal. Also be sure to bring:
Insurance information.
List of medications you’re taking, including over-the-counter medicines and herbal supplements.
List of your allergies.
Medical history.
Bring Your Passport To Success
Just like an actual passport you would bring on a long trip, you will receive a Passport to Success at your first with us. Please bring it with you to every wound care appointment. The doctor or nurse adds notes and may take a photo of your wound to measure your progress.
Watch the video below to learn more.

providers.name: FELIX BOECKER, MD, FACS
providers.location: ProMedica Physicians Jobst Vascular Wound Care

content.articleContent:
Understanding X-ray
General radiology most often refers to diagnostic x-rays used to help identify disease or injury inside the body. X-ray— using radiation passing through the body to produce an image on a special film —was discovered in 1885, and is considered a milestone in the development of modern medicine. For the first time, physicians were able to see inside the body to detect injury and disease, often in its early stages when the illness or injury is most treatable.
What to Expect During an X-ray
During an x-ray, a machine is used to send x-rays through your body. Radiation is absorbed by the more dense parts of your body, which produces a lighter image on the x-ray picture called a radiograph. The less dense areas of the body (soft tissue) absorb less radiation and appear darker on the x-ray.
Common x-ray studies used to detect disease and injury include:
Chest Exam - used to diagnose diseases of the heart and lungs
Bone Studies - used to determine the relationship between bones and visualize fractures
Digestive System Studies - used to detect diseases such as ulcers and tumors.
Searching for Foreign Bodies - used to locate objects in the body that should not be there
Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - Used to study the kidneys and ureters to the bladder.
